name: Abelsonite
description_short: Chemically a nickel porphyrine derivative, classified as deoxophylloerythroetioporphyrin. Unique combination of elements; the only organonickel mineral known. Formed at depth (Milton et al., 1978), likely from a chlorophyll (but likely not the chloroph...
tlform: Aggregates of platy crystals; as patches, sometimes over 2 mm in diameter.
occurrence: Mahogany Zone oil shale; found in six stratigraphical zones ( M9, M7, M2, L6, L0, and K1); its genesis is connected with unique geochemical conditions of Lake Uinta; likely formed due to chlorophyll diagenesis; abelsonite's relatively insoluble precursor was likely transported by an aqueous solution towards sediments of favorable lithology.
otheroccurrence:
Small aggregates, to 1 cm, of thin laths or
plates. Of secondary origin on fracture surfaces in oil shale.
colour: Pink-purple, dark greyish purple, pale purplish red, reddish brown
aboutname: For American physicist Philip Hauge Abelson (27 April 1913, Tacoma, Washington, USA - 1 August 2004, Bethesda, Maryland, USA). He was co-discoverer of element 93 (neptunium), editor of the periodical Science (1962-1984), and director of the Carnegie Institution of Washington's Geophysical Laboratory (1953-1971).
other: UV-Vis bands [nm]: 392, 510, 550 in benzene or 390, 512, and 552 in acetone (suggestible for deoxophylloerythroetioporphyrin with an isocyclic ring); also 618 band present, suggesting presence of some free-base porphyrin
type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, number 1979,135.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, numbers 143566, 145712.

name: Adamite
description_short:
Olivenite Group. Adamite-Olivenite Series. 
The orthorhombic dimorph of Paradamite. The Zn analogue of Olivenite.

In terms of chemistry, but not structure, adamite is an arsenic equivalent (stoichiometrically similar to) of tarbuttite. The two mine...
otheroccurrence: A secondary mineral in the oxidised zone of zinc- and arsenic-bearing hydrothermal mineral deposits.
colour: Ideally white, colourless, frequently pale yellow, honey-yellow, brownish yellow, rose red; blue, pale green to green, may be zoned; bright green (Cu-bearing); bright pink, purple (Co-bearing)
opticalextinction: X = a; Y = c; Z = b.
aboutname: Named by Charles Friedel in 1866 for Gilbert Joseph Adam (7 April 1795 Seine-et-Marne, Fontainbleau, France - 8 June 1881 Paris, France), Inspector (Auditor) of Finance for the French Government, who supplied the first specimens of his mineral. Adam was a wealthy mineral collector and his mineral collection was described in Annales des Mines in 1869 and later in a published catalog (1869). Adam was also the discoverer of aerugite, chenevixite, corkite, cuprotungstite, scacchite, and xanthiosite. Adam's mineral collection was acquired by the École des Mines, Paris, France. Adam was a member of Société géologique de France and received the honor of Commandeur de la Légion d'Honneur.
other: Readily soluble in dilute acids.
morphology: Crystals of variable morphology. Often elongated [010], also elongated [001], rarely elongated [100]. Tabular at times {101} or equant. Commonly forms radial aggregates, fanlike rosettes or crystalline crusts.
opticaldispersion: strong r > v or r < v
opticalpleochorismdesc: In pale colours if cuprian or cobaltian.
uv: May fluoresce or phosphoresce lemon-yellow under SW and LW UV.
type_specimen_store:
Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France, number 16976.
Muséum Nationale d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France, number 66.34.
thermalbehaviour: Heated in a closed tube, it decrepitates feebly, and gives a little water, becoming white and porcelanous. On  charcoal, it fuses, producing a coating of zinc oxide, and a faint odor of arsenic. In a closed tube with soda and charcoal, it gives a ring of arsenic.
commentcolor: Colourless or faintly tinted in transmitted light.

name: Aeschynite-(Y)
mindat_formula_note: Previously given as <f>(Y,Ln,Ca,Th)(Ti,Nb)^2(O,OH)^6</f>. Redefined in 2025.
description_short:
The yttrium analogue of Aeschynite-(Ce).
The most common Aeschynite Group mineral. 

Some black varieties may be confused with chemically similar members of the Euxenite Group.


Compare the chemically very similar Euxenite-(Y) which has differen...
occurrence: Granite pegmatite
otheroccurrence: In granite and granite pegmatites, in ankerite-dolomitic carbonatites, as a detrital mineral in placers.
colour: Pale yellow, yellow-orange, pale greenish yellow, black, brownish black
aboutname: For its relationship to Aeschynite-(Ce), with yttrium as the dominant rare-earth element. First named in 1906 as blomstrandine by Waldemar Christofer Brøgger, in honor of Christian Wilhelm Blomstrand [October 20, 1826 Växjö, Sweden – November 5, 1897 Lund, Sweden], professor of chemistry at the University of Lund, who did the chemical analysis. Brøgger had earlier published a crystallographic description of this material in 1879 from Urstad Feldspar Mine, Hidra, Vest-Agder, Norway but then without a chemical analysis. He first thought it to be identical with aeschynite (From Miask, which later was named aeschynite-(Ce)). Later, in his description in 1906 he states that the blomstrandine from Hitterö was a "Yttrium-Aeschynit". The mineral was later renamed Aeschynite-(Y) by the IMA in 1987 following Levinson (1966).
other: magnetic
morphology: Crystals to 10 cm, commonly tabular, less commonly prismatic, forms {001}, {010}, {021}, {110}, {210} and {111}, also granular and massive
commentluster: Submetallic to pearly on crystal faces, resinous to waxy on fracture surfaces.
ima_history: Renamed by IMA in 1987 (special procedure) as aeschynite-(Y).

name: Aheylite
description_short: Light blue crystals in dense clusters.
tlform: Isolated and aggregate clumps of hemispherical or spherical, radiating to interlocked masses of crystals that average 3 µm in maximum dimension.
occurrence: A late stage hydrothermal mineral in a base-metal-tin deposit.
colour: Very pale blue, pale green, to blue-green
aboutname: Named in 1998 by Eugene E. Foord and Joseph E. Taggert in honor of Allen V. Heyl (1918-2008), economic geologist of the U. S. Geological Survey.
morphology: Dense clusters of crystals ideally displaying typical turquoise group morphology: short prismatic with large {001}, {010}, {1-10}, and {-1-11}.
opticalcomments:
Mean RI 1.63.
Individual indices could not be determined due to small grain size.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.

name: Aksaite
tlform: Elongated crystals up to 7 mm.
occurrence: In fine-grained halite in a salt dome.
aboutname: Named after its discovery locality in Kazakhstan.
other: Insoluble in water, readily soluble in HCl.
morphology: Crystals are elongated along <mi>[001]</mi> and flattened <mi>{100}</mi> , with <mi>{100}</mi> , <mi>{010}</mi> , <mi>{021}</mi> and rarely <mi>{001}</mi> , to 1.5 cm; prism faces are striated parallel to <mi>[100]</mi> .
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 160056.

name: Aldermanite
mindat_formula_note: formerly given as Mg<sub>5</sub>Al<sub>12</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>8</sub>(OH)<sub>22</sub>·32H<sub>2</sub>O (redefined in 2021)
description_short:
Structurally to some extent related to walentaite group and zirconolite-3O. The relation is due to similar, intersecting, kagomé nets. 

The OH analogue of penriceite.

In aldermanite the pyrochlore-like 6-membered rings of corner-sharing octahedra...
tlform: Minute talc-like flakes, thinly coating cracks and cavities. The crystals are generally less than 0.1 mm across and only about 0.1-0.2 um thick.
occurrence: As a secondary mineral in cavities in a brecciated metamorphosed sedimentary phosphate deposit, formed by the alteration of fluellite .
aboutname: Named by Ian R. Harrowfield, Edgar Ralph Segnit, and John. A. Watts in 1981 in honor of Arthur Richard Alderman (1901–1980), Professor of Geology and Mineralogy, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia.
other: Soluble in mineral acids.
morphology: Frequently in talc-like flakes and aggregates, to 0.1 mm.; also in clusters of transparent platy crystals.
type_specimen_store: C.S.I.R.O. Division of Mineral Chemistry, Melbourne, M636; Museum Victoria, Melbourne, Australia, M34778.
ima_history: Redefined due to acceptance of the proposal 20-I (Newsletter #60)

name: Allanite-(La)
description_short:
Allanite Group of the Epidote Supergroup. The La-analogue of Allanite-(Ce).

The large well formed crystals of "allanite-(La)" from the Nueva Vizcaya Mine, Spain published by Del Tanago et al. (2002)  as “macroscopic La-dominant allanite and REE-rich...
tlform: prismatic crystals up to 2–3 mm in length
occurrence: baryte veins cutting a dolomitic metamorphosed limestone
aboutname: Named in 2006 by Paolo Orlandi and Marco Pasero for its relationship to other allanite group minerals, with lanthanum as the dominant rare earth element. The root name is for Thomas Allan (1777, Edinburgh, Scotland - 1833, Morpeth, Northumberland, England), Scottish banker and mineralogist who first described what is now allanite-(Ce). Samples fitting the description of allanite-(La) were described earlier and the name was recommended by Levinson (1966) but a proper species description was not given until 2006.
morphology:
prismatic crystals, elongated along [010]
observed forms: {001}, {100}, {101}, {10_1}, {210} and {011}
opticalpleochorismdesc: greenish to greenish brown

name: Althausite
description_short: This rare magnesium phosphate was first described from serpentine-magnesite deposits in Modum, Buskerud, Norway. Later the mineral has also been found as a secondary product in granitic pegmatites, in Brazil. In pegmatites the colour of the mineral may...
tlform: Cleavable masses and crude tabular crystals to 3 cm
occurrence: A serpentine-magnesite deposit
colour: Pale gray, reddish brown; dark blue, green, black
aboutname: Named in 1975 by Gunnar Raade and Magne Tysseland in honor of Prof. Egon Althaus (February 15, 1933-June 16, 2022), mineralogist at University of Karlsruhe, Germany.
morphology: Rare crude crystals are elongated along [001], flattened on {010}, showing {010}, {110}, {131}, to 3 cm; generally as cleavable masses.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical-Geological Museum, Oslo University, Oslo, Norway, 21978, 22044, 22045.
commentcolor: turning brown on alteration to apatite

name: Amakinite
tlform: rhombohedra to 1.5 cm; typically in irregular grains
occurrence: in a drill core, in thin veins and pockets in kimberlite
colour: Pale green to yellow-green; rapidly turns brown when exposed to air, due to formation of Fe(OH)3
aboutname: For the Amakin Expedition, which prospected the Yakutian diamond deposits.
morphology: Rhombohedra <mi>{10_11}</mi>, modified by <mi>{10_12}</mi>, <mi>{10_14}</mi>, <mi>{11_23}</mi>, <mi>{20_25}</mi> and {0001} to 2 cm; typically in irregular grains.
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 69547.
commentcrystal: Point Group: <mi>_3 2/m, 3m, or 32.; Space Group: R_3m, R3m, or R32.</mi>

name: Ammoniojarosite
description_short: Maybe confused with hydroniumjarosite.
tlform: Small lumps and hard irregular flattened nodules up to 4 cm across by 5 mm thick embedded in blackish-brown lignitic material.  With magnification, it is seen to form minute, transparent, pale-yellow, tabular grains including a few showing hexagonal outlines.
occurrence: Formed in black lignitic shales containing pyrite.
colour: Light yellow; light yellow to nearly colourless in transmitted light.
aboutname: In allusion to its composition containing dominant AMMONIum, and its relationship to JAROSITE.
other: Soluble in hot HCl.
morphology: Small lumps and irregular flattened nodules comprised of microscopic tabular grains with hexagonal outlines at times.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 95654.

name: Andrémeyerite
tlform: As crystals, < 0.2 mm
occurrence: In vesicles of melilite-leucite-nephelinite; may represent crystallization of an associated green glass.
aboutname: To honor André Marie Meyer (Turku, Finland, October 13 1920 - Libreville, Gabon, January 10 1965), Belgian geologist with the Geological Survey of the Belgian Congo, who first collected the mineral. His publications were essentially devoted to igneous rocks from Kivu, in particular to lava flows of the Nyiragongo and Nyamuragira volcanoes, as well to the rocks forming the syenite-carbonatite complex of the Lueshe (Der Meersche et al. 2010).
morphology: As crystals, < 0.2 mm, with {100} and {010} dominant, also {011} and {120}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = pale bluish green; Y = Z = colorless with faint brownish tint.
type_specimen_store:
University of Helsinki, Helsinki, Finland.
Canillo (1988) examined the crystal structure using matarial provided by Thure Sahama: this could explain the absence of any holotype material in the present-day collection in Helsinki.

name: Anorthite
description_short:
Feldspar Group.

Ca-rich end member of the plagioclase (Albite-Anorthite Series).

High- and low-temperature structural modifications exist.

Chemically and stoichiometrically very similar to lawsonite (which contains OH groups and H2O molecules,...
otheroccurrence: Mafic plutonic rocks
cleavage: Perfect on {001}, less so on {010}, imperfect on {110}
aboutname: Named in 1823 by Gustav Rose from the Greek αν and oρθός, "not right angle" or "oblique", in allusion to the oblique triclinic form of the crystals.
morphology: Commonly short, prismatic, lamellar, coarse-granular, massive
twinning: Commonly polysynthetic on albite law, pericline, Carlsbad, Manebach and Baveno twinning.
type_specimen_store: Museum für Naturkunde, Humboldt Universität, Berlin, Germany, numbers 1999-0087, 1999-0088 (type?).
commentcrystal: Low modification; non-standard unit cell (reduced cell: 8.18, 12.87, 12.90 A, 85.8, 81.1, 88.7°)

name: Apachite
description_short: Note: specimens of acicular dioptase haven been erroneously sold as apachite.
tlform: Spherules of radial fibers. Crystals are usually minute twisted or curved blades .
occurrence: A retrograde metamorphic or mesogene mineral, formed at the expense of a prograde calc-silicate and sulfide assemblage in tactites.
opticalextinction: γ nearly parallel to length, α nearly normal to the smallest dimension.
aboutname: Named for the Apache tribe that live in the area of the Christmas Mine.
other: Easily soluble in cold, dilute HNO3 or HCl.
morphology: As minute, twisted or curved beaded spherules of radial fibers, composed of crystals; in seams, exhibiting a silky, fibrous structure on broken surfaces.
type_specimen_store: University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona, USA; The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1980,532.
commentcrystal: Point Group: n.d; Space Group: n.d.

name: Arsenolite
tlform: oxidation product of arsenic-bearing sulphides in hydrothermal veins
colour: White, bluish; reddish to yellowish if impure with realgar or orpiment; colourless in transmitted light
aboutname: For arsenic in the composition.
other: Slightly soluble in hot water.
morphology: Commonly as tiny octahedra, sometimes modified by the dodecahedron; also in aggregates or crusts, botryoidal, stalactitic, earthy to powdery.
thermalbehaviour: Sublimates when heated in a closed tube, condensing in the upper (cooler) part of the tube in minute octahedrons.

name: Arsenolamprite
description_short: Compare also pararsenolamprite.
otheroccurrence: Carbonate rocks, calcite veins
aboutname: Named for its composition and for the Greek λαμπρός ("lampros") for "brilliant", in allusion to its luster.
morphology: Needles to 8 mm, foliated, radial aggregates of plates, massive.
commentcrystal: On synthetic material. Non-standard space group Bmab.
commentcolor: Alters to a dull black coating

name: Argutite
description_short: Rutile Group. The Ge analogue of stishovite.
tlform: Subhedral crystals to 20 µm, included in sphalerite.
occurrence: In a zinc deposit formed in metamorphosed lower Paleozoic sediments.
aboutname: Named after the type locality.
other: Insoluble in water, NaOH and acids.
morphology: Crystals are showing {111}, {100} and {101}
opticalcomments: The optical properties are very close to those of cassiterite.
opticalcolour: Light grey; dark gray in oil.
opticalinternal: Frequent white to brownish internal reflections (the brown color likely due to enclosing sphalerite).
type_specimen_store: Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France, number 54619.
thermalbehaviour: Melting point of 1086 °C.

name: Arsendescloizite
description_short: Adelite-Descloizite Group. Arsenate analogue of Descloizite.
occurrence: Oxidized zone of a polymetallic ore arsenic-bearing sulfide deposit
colour: Pale yellow to deep green, greyish brown
aboutname: Named by Paul Keller and Pete J. Dunn in 1982 for being the arsenate analog of descloizite.
morphology: Platy to wedge-shaped crystals. Platy {100} to 1 mm; also with {101}. {110}, {100}, {111}.
type_specimen_store:
Institut für Mineralogie und Kristallchemie, Stuttgart, Germany, number NM 08.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C.,  USA, number 148303.
Archiv der Universität Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany, number TM-79.30-B76.

name: Arthurite
description_short:
Arthurite Group.

May be confused with acicular conichalcite.
tlform: Apple-green crusts
occurrence: Formed by alteration of arsenopyrite or enargite.
aboutname: Named in 1964 by Richard J. Davis and Max Hutchinson Hey in honor of Sir Arthur Edward Ian Montagu Russell [November 30, 1878 Folkestone, Kent, England, UK - February 23, 1964 UK],  and Mr Arthur William Gerald Kingsbury [June 27, 1906 East Meon, Hampshire, England, UK - August 3, 1968 UK], both <vid></vid>English mineralogists and collectors. Sir Arthur Edward Ian Montagu Russell (1878-1964) 6th Baronet, of Swallowfield Park, Reading, Berkshire, was perhaps the greatest British mineral collector of the 20th century. Sir Arthur Russell’s will directed that his collection should be given to the British Museum (Natural History) – now the Natural History Museum. The Russell Society, an organisation for amateur and professional mineralogists, dedicated to British topographical mineralogy, was named in his honor. Arthur Kingsbury, Russell's friend, was an indefatigable field collector and prolific author of mineralogical articles.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = colorless to pale green; Y = gray-green; Z = olive-green.
type_specimen_store: The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1964,74–75 and 1964,80.

name: Asisite
description_short:
The Si analogue of janchevite.

Note: Asisite from the Kombat mine has been sold as either "lorettoite" or "chubutite".
tlform: Yellow to greenish-yellow, 0.5 mm, platy crystals.
occurrence: Manganese silicate lens.
aboutname: Named after the Asis farm where the Kombat mine is located.
morphology: Tabular on {001}.
opticalinternal: Abundant uncolored reflections in plane-polarized light, brilliant pale greenish yellow between crossed polars
opticalanisotropism: Not noticeable in air, only weakly so in oil, rotation tints of gray
opticalbireflectance: Not perceptible, except at grain boundaries
type_specimen_store:
Geological Survey of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, number GSC no. 64565.
British Museum of Natural History, London, UK, number 1986,304.
commentcrystal: Only subcell (but strongly dominant); real cell has tetragonal cell parameters ~14 and ~23 A (Welch, 2004)

name: Attakolite
tlform: Indistinctly crystalline, massive.
aboutname: From the Greek άττακος ("attakos") for "salmon", in allusion to its common colour.
other: Partially decomposed by acids.

twinning: Possible twin lamellae are observed in thin section.
opticaldispersion: r < v to r >> v; strong
type_specimen_store: No designated type specimen.

name: Avogadrite
tlform: minute octagonal crystals and dense crusts
occurrence: Sublimation products around volcanic fumaroles
otheroccurrence: Volcanic fumaroles
colour: Colourless to white, yellowish to reddish when impure, colourless in transmitted light
aboutname: For Amadeo Avogadro (Turin August 9 1776 - Turin, July 9 1856), Professor of Physics at the University of Turin, Turin, Italy. Remembered for Avogadro's gas law and Avogadro's number.
other: Slightly soluble in water.
morphology: Octagonal crystals, tabular to platy on {001}, may be elongated along [010] or [100].
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, Paris, France (No. 126.148)
thermalbehaviour: The mineral becomes cubic above 273°C.

name: Barytocalcite
description_short: Compare 'UM1974-03-CO:BaCaMg'.
occurrence: Veins in limestone.
colour: Colourless, white, greyish, greenish, light yellow
aboutname: In allusion to the composition, containing BARium and CALCium
other:
Soluble in dilute HCl.

Baryte and Quartz pseudomorphs after Barytocalcite observed.
morphology: Crystals normally short to long prismatic [101], also short prismatic [001] or equant. {100} striated [001]; and <mi>{1_11}, {2_52}, {1_31}</mi> striated [101]. Massive.
epitaxidescription: Witherite xls in parallel growth on Barytocalcite from Blagill. Baryte on barytocalcite, with baryte {001}[010] parallel to barytocalcite {001}[010]. Calcite on barytocalcite, with calcite <mi>(101_1), (1_101), and (01_11)</mi> approximately parallel to barytocalcite (101), <mi>(1_11), and (1_1_1)</mi>.
commentcrystal: Cell from Dickens & Bowen (1971). Older cell: 8.13, 5.22, 6.54 Å, 106°.

name: Balipholite
tlform: Crystals needle-like and fibrous.
occurrence: In a miarolitic cavity.
aboutname: Named in allusion to its composition, containing BArium and LIthium, and the Chinese for fibrous, in allusion to its structure.
type_specimen_store: National Museum for Geology, Beijing, China, number M07544.

name: Bararite
description_short: A hexagonal polymorph (space group P63mc) is also known from synthetic material (Fábry et al. 2001).
tlform: Arborescent, mammillary; commonly included within cryptohalite.
occurrence: Above a burning coal seam.
otheroccurrence: Above burning coal seams; sublimation product at fumaroles and in burning anthracite piles.
aboutname: For the locality at the Bararee colliery, Barari, Jharia coal field, India.  The name was given by Palache et al. (1951) based on the description by Christie (1926).  Earlier work recognized it as a constituent of mixtures with cryptohalite but it was not given an individual name.
other:
Easily soluble in water.
Sublimates without residue.
Tastes saline.
morphology: Minute crystals, flattened on {0001}, may be elongated perpendicular to [0001]; also arborescent and mammillary. Commonly included within cryptohalite.
twinning: Dartlike or paddlewheel twins, with twin plane inclined to {0001}
type_specimen_store: No defined type material.

name: Barringerite
description_short: "The Ollague meteorite, as a whole, was artificially annealed at a temperature above 1000°C and that heating gave rise to secondary high-temperature alteration of chemical and phase compositions of this meteorite, including the formation of barringerit...
tlform: As bands, 10-15 µm wide and several hundred µm long, consisting of individual grains less than 1 µm in diameter.
occurrence: Along the contact between schreibersite and troilite in a Fe-Ni meteorite.
otheroccurrence: As a single grain in a brecciated lunar meteorite of mixed mare and highland origin; in the oxidation zone of a platinum-bearing Cu-Ni sulphide deposit
aboutname: Daniel Moreau Barringer (May 25, 1860, Raleigh, North Carolina, USA – November 30, 1929, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA), early proponent of the meteor impact origin of Meteor Crater, Canyon Diablo, Arizona, USA.
other: Devoid of ferromagnetic properties (Curie point 7 deg C).
opticalcolour: White. Similar to kamacite, bluish compared to schreibersite.
type_specimen_store: Nininger collection, Center for Meteorite Studies, Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA.

name: Bastnäsite-(Ce)
description_short:
Cerium analogue of Bastnäsite-(La) and Bastnäsite-(Y).
Fluorine analogue of Hydroxylbastnäsite-(Ce). 
Bastnäsite-(Ce)-Hydroxylbastnäsite-(Ce) Series.

The most common member of the bastnäsite group.
May be intergrown with synchysite-(Ce) (syntacti...
occurrence: Narrow bands in a contact metamorphic amphibole skarn.
otheroccurrence: Most abundant REE mineral. Hydrothermal and primary igneous. Granitic and alkali syenites and pegmatites, carbonatites, contact metamorphic deposits, rarely in detrital deposits.
parting: On {0001} distinct to perfect of secondary origin).
colour: Yellow, reddish-brown; colourless to light yellow in transmitted light
aboutname: For the type locality at the Bastnäs mines, Riddarhyttan, Skinnskatteberg, Västmanland, Sweden, plus the "-(Ce)" suffix due to the dominance of cerium in the composition.
other:
Soluble in strong, hot acids.

May be found as pseudomorphs after Fluocerite or Tscheffkinite.
morphology: Crystals tabular {0001}, usually with <mi>{10_10}</mi> alone. Crystals normally deeply grooved horizontally due to oscillatory combination of <mi>{10_11}</mi> and <mi>{10_10}</mi>. Large anhedral masses; granular.
epitaxidescription: Bastnäsite forms oriented overgrowths and alteration pseudomorphs after fluocerite. Crystal axes of both species oriented in parallel position.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Faintly pleochroic with absorption E is greater than O.
type_specimen_store: Swedish Museum of Natural History 23:0476

name: Bayleyite
description_short: After collecting, bayleyite, when stored in a drier atmosphere, becomes dull and disintegrates to a yellow powder.
tlform: As crust on gypsum and mica schist
occurrence: Post-mining efforescent coatings on mine walls.
aboutname: Named after William Shirley Bayley (1861-1943), American mineralogist and geologist. It was first observed and collected by the American geologist Charles Alfred Anderson from the oxidation zone of the Hillside Mine, Arizona, USA and first described as a new mineral by Axelrod et al. (1951).
other: Soluble in water. Radiactive.
morphology: Crystals minute, short-prismatic; also acicular; in divergent groups (artificial material).

X = Pinkish
Y = Light yellow
Z = Light yellow

name: Béhierite
description_short:
The tantalum analogue of schiavinatoite. The second mineral with essential tantalum and boron after holtite.

Possibly crystallochemically related to xenotime-(Y) (Ondrejka et al., 2022).
tlform: 4 grayish-pink pseudo-octahedral crystals, 0.5 to 7.0 mm in size.
occurrence: A complex LCT granite pegmatite hosted in a marble
colour: Greyish pink; pale lilac; colorless to white
aboutname:
Named after Jean Jacques Francis Béhier (2 March 1903, Paris, France - 11 May 1965, Tsaratanana district, Betsiboka, Madagascar), French mineralogist at the Service Géologique (Geological Survey) of Madagascar, who found the mineral in 1959 when he was examining material collected in 1953.

Béhier was a self-taught mineralogist who brought together a collection of more than 5,000 pieces divided into three parts: French minerals, European minerals and Malagasy minerals. This collection was established thanks to his numerous field surveys and numerous exchanges carried out from 1925 to 1965.

Jean Béhier was a member of the Société française de minéralogie (French Mineralogical Society) from 1931, he became a prospector and teacher for the Commissariat à l'énergie atomique (CEA, Atomic Energy Commission) after the Second World War, shortly after its creation on October 18, 1945.

In 1946, he was assigned to the Malagasy CEA and then to the Geological Service in Madagascar in 1953. He was of great help in the development of Madagascar's mining industry. He described numerous mineral species there and published numerous articles and works from 1949 to 1962. Then, he reorganized and expanded the collection of the Geological Service of Madagascar. In 1951, he made a long stay in mainland France, where he resumed his field research work. He returned to Madagascar in 1952 where he resumed his initial work. In August and September 1956 he was assigned to the reorganization of the mineralogy museum of Maputo (Lourenço Marques at the time) in Mozambique. Béhier, in collaboration with the analytical laboratories of Madagascar, France and Washington, described approximately 70 new mineral species from Madagascar, including hibonite. Until his death in 1965, he also worked on the organization and improvement of the National Museum of Geology and the Mineralogy Laboratory of the Geological Survey. He was responsible for establishing the list of mineral species prohibited for export, listed in the Mining Law. This list was officially established to protect Madagascar's rare minerals, but in reality Béhier probably did this so that he would be the only person legally authorized to export minerals to museums and mineral collectors outside of Madagascar.

His work was crowned by the discovery of two new mineral species, hibonite and béhierite. Béhierite, a new mineral species that he discovered and described in Madagascar, was named in his honour in 1961. A large part of his collection was acquired in 2001 by various collectors.

On May 11, 1965, as he was preparing to return to France, he was killed in a plane crash in the northeast of Madagascar.

name: Bunsenite

Periclase Group.

aboutname: Named by James Dwight Dana in 1868 in honor of Robert Wilhelm Eberhard Bunsen (30 March 1811, Göttingen, Germany - 16 August 1899, Heidelberg, Germany), Professor of Chemistry, Heidelberg. He was an important analytical chemist and had observed artificial crystals of nickel oxide. Along with Gustav Kirchhoff, Bunsen investigated emission spectra of heated elements leading to the discovery of two elements: cesium and rubidium. The well known Bunsen burner was devised to obtain clean burning flames in order to collect pure spectra of elements so they might be identified by their emmission spectra. and the burner is named after him. Bunsen persued geological problems including the temperature of water in active geysers. Bunsen also invented several improvements to chemical batteries, including the Bunsen battery, which is also named for him. Bunsen was an important teacher and two of his famous students include: Dmitri Mendeleev and Julius Lothar Meyer, both of whom established aspects of the periodic law of the elements and both of whom are credited with devising what has come to be known as the Periodic Table of the Elements.

Much of Canfield's professional mining work was in New Jersey and Bolivia. Canfield was also a third generation mineral collector having acquired his great uncles' mineral collection as well as his own father's collection.

Carobbi (1936 and 1940) twice described the new mineral potassium fluoride, but he did not name it. Carobbi found KF in some yellowish stalactites collected on February 7, 1934 at the bottom of Vesuvius crater in a lava cave of the Dec. 1933 intracrater effusion, located in the NE quarter. The mineral was described as tiny colorless cubic crystals in association with erythrosiderite, hieratite, and mercallite.

name: Chalcopyrite
description_short:
Chalcopyrite Group. Chalcopyrite-Eskebornite Series.

A major ore of copper. Common in sulfide veins and disseminated in igneous rocks.
Weathering may lead to the formation of malachite, azurite, brochantite, langite and numerous other secondary cop...
otheroccurrence: Chalcopyrite is a prevalent sulfide mineral in ore deposits and hosts various trace elements such as Ag, Co, As, Se, Sb, Te, Bi, etc. The variations in trace element contents, as well as Fe, S, and Cu isotopic compositions of chalcopyrite are controlled by a series of factors including metallogenic temperature and pressure, fluid compositions, metal sources, and sulfide equilibrium. Chalcopyrite is found in porphyry Cu deposits (PCDs), sedimentary rock-hosted stratiform Cu deposits (SSCs), iron oxide Cu-Au deposits (IOCGs), sedimentary exhalative deposits (SEDEXs), magmatic Cu-Ni sulfide deposits (MSDs), and volcanogenic massive sulfide deposits (VMSs), etc.  Different types of ore deposits show significantly distinct chalcopyrite geochemical characteristics. For example, in PCDs, chalcopyrite is notably enriched in Zn and Pb, with negative δ34S values (−2.1 ± 3.64 ‰, n = 32) due to sediment contributions. Positive δ65Cu values (1.5 ± 2.00 ‰, n = 140) indicate a mantle-crustal mixed source, while negative δ57Fe values (−4.3 ± 5.10 ‰, n = 32) likely result from Fe isotope fractionation during magnetite precipitation or continental crust contamination. In MSDs, Cr is the most enriched element, with positive δ34S values (1.0 ± 2.14 ‰, n = 185) and slightly negative δ⁶5Cu values (−0.46 ± 0.50 ‰, n = 52). Chalcopyrite in SSCs is enriched in Zn and As, characterized by negative δ34S (−3.6 ± 0.12 ‰, n = 190) and δ65Cu values (−0.59 ± 0.98 ‰, n = 118). [[1]]
industrial: It is the principal ore of copper.
colour: Brass yellow, often with an iridescent tarnish.
aboutname: Named in 1725 by Johann Friedrich Henckel from the Greek "chalkos", copper, and "pyrites", strike fire.
morphology: Typically found as equant to wedge-shaped pseudo-tetrahedral disphenoidal crystals, often modified by tetragonal scalenohedral faces. Mostly found massive or in disseminated grains and major deposits of such material are known.
twinning: Twinned on {112} and {012}, penetration or cyclic.
epitaxidescription: Pyrite on chalcopyrite from Ege-Khay, Yakutia, Russia (Novgorodova 1977).
opticalcolour: Yellow against a white/gray phase, greenish-yellow when next to gold.
opticalanisotropism: Weak, but distinct blue-gray to yellow-green
commentcrystal: Subcell: I-centred tetragonal, a = 3.74, c = 5.21 Å.

other: Soluble in water.
morphology: Crystalline incrustations.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Museum, University of Bari, Bari, Italy.
commentdense: Measured values on artificial crystals.

name: Chernykhite
description_short: Mica Group.
tlform: small veinlets and leaflets, to 5 mm.
aboutname: Named in 1973 by S. G. Ankinovich, Ye. A. Ankinovich, I. V. Rozdestvenskaya, and V. A. Frank-Kamenetsky in honor of Viktor Vasil'evich Chernykh (Виктор Васильевич Черных) (1889-1941), mineralogist and head of the Mineralogy Department at the Leningrad Mining Institute.
type_specimen_store: Alma-Ata, Kazakhstan; Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, 1056/1; Vernadsky State Geological Museum, Moscow, 49845; A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 72369, vis5548.
commentcrystal: Point Group: 2/m or m; Space Group: C2/c or Cc:

name: Chladniite
description_short:
The Mg analogue of fillowite and johnsomervilleite.

Chemically close minerals (also anhydrous) include czochralskiite, brianite, and merrillite - all known from meteorites.

Originally found as a single grain (975 x 175 micrometers) with chlorapat...
tlform: A single grain, which measures 175 x 975 µm.
occurrence: In type IIICD iron meteorite and primitive achondrite meteorite.
otheroccurrence: Iron and primitive achondrite meteorites
aboutname: Named in honour of Ernst Florens Friedrich Chladni (30 November 1756, Wittenberg, Electorate of Saxony - 3 April 1827, Breslau, Prussia), physicist at the University of Riga, Latvia. He has been referred to as the "father" of meteoritics, for theorizing the origin of meteorites.  He is also called the father of acoustics.
morphology: Rims around other phosphates and silicates.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian Institution), Washington, D.C., USA, number 2707.

name: Choloalite
mindat_formula_note: The ideal formula is likely CuPbTe4+2O6 as suggested by Powell et al. (1994).
tlform: Green octahedral crystals to 2 mm in size.
occurrence: Tellurium deposit in intensely sericitized rhyolite vitrophyre.
aboutname: The name choloalite derives from the Nahua (indigenous people of Mexico and El Salvador) word choloa, meaning evasive, in allusion to the fact that the mineral escaped detection for many years.
other: Soluble in cold dilute nitric or hydrochloric acid.
morphology: Octahedral crystals.
opticalcomments: Some crystals show sectoring and anomalous birefringence up to 0.011.
type_specimen_store:
Natural History Museum, London, United Kingdom.
Muséum Nationale d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France (type).
thermalbehaviour: Fuses with ease (F = 2) to a runny brown glass.
commentcolor: Deep green in thin section.

name: Chudobaite
description_short: The Mg analogue of geigerite.
tlform: Crystals equant, to 5 mm
aboutname: Named for Karl Franz Johann Chudoba (10 August 1898, Wratzow, Moravia - 14 March 1976, Göttingen, Germany) was a mineralogist and petrologist and rector of the Rheinische Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität in Bonn, Germany. Pronounced koo-dō-baite.
type_specimen_store:
National School of Mines, Paris, France.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 162628.

name: Clinoclase

aboutname: Named in 1830 by August Breithaupt from  the Greek κλίυειυ = "to incline" and κλαυ = "to break," in allusion to its oblique basal cleavage.

Crystals elongated [010] and tabular {001}; also rhombohedral in aspect, or elongated [001] with {100} prominent; grouped into rosettes, as crusts and coatings. Densely aggregated with a fibrous structure at times.

Forms include: <mi>{001}, {100}, {110}, {_302}, (_201}, {_111}, {_552}, {_401}, {_972}</mi>.

X = Pale blue-green
Y = b = Light blue green

name: Clinobisvanite
description_short:
The monoclinic polymorph of Pucherite and Dreyerite.

A rare bismuth vanadate, often forming pseudo-tetragonal crystals. 

Possibly a chemical (V) analogue of kyawthuite, but space groups are not identical (though similar).

aboutname: In allusion to the crystallographic symmetry (monoCLINic) and composition, containing BISmuth and VANadium.

type_specimen_store:
Western Australian Museum, Perth, Australia, number MDC5144 (holotype).

name: Clinotobermorite
description_short:
Structurally closely related to Tobermorite.
A Ca-poor analogue may exist.
Two natural polytypes are known: Clinotobermorite-2M and Clinotobermorite-1A.
occurrence: gehlenite-spurrite-bearing skarns
aboutname: Redefined in by IMA in 2014, according to new nomenclature for the <m>Tobermorite Group</m>.

name: Cobaltaustinite
description_short:
Adelite-Descloizite Group. Cobaltaustinite-Conichalcite Series. 
The Co-analogue of Austinite and Nickelaustinite.
tlform: Dull green coatings of crystallites up to 25 µm in diameter.
occurrence: Oxidised zone in the Dome Rock copper deposit, as alteration product of arsenides.
aboutname: Named by Ernest H. Nickel and William D. Birch in 1988 after Austin Flint Rogers (1877-1957), American mineralogist at Stanford University, and in allusion to the dominance of Co in the composition.

type_specimen_store:
Western Australian Museum, Perth, Australia;

name: Colquiriite
tlform:
Anhedral grains to 1 cm.

Ralstonite appears to replace colquiriite and gearksutite is present as veinlets so that colquiriite appears to be the oldest.
occurrence: Tin mine.
aboutname: Named by K. Walenta, B. Lehmann, and M. Zwiener in 1980 for the type locality of Colquiri tin mine, Bolivia.
type_specimen_store: Institute for Mineralogy and Crystallography, University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany.
thermalbehaviour: Structure breaks down between 800-900 C.
commentcrystal: Point Group: <mi>_3 2/m or 3m.; Space Group: P_31c or P31c </mi>(synthetic).

name: Coombsite
mindat_formula_note: Type material has Si:Al = 16.41:1.54.
description_short:
Mn-analogue of zussmanite.

Compare the chemically and stoichiometrically very similar franklinphilite.
Compare also the chemically similar ganophyllite and parsettensite.
tlform: Aggregates of fibro-lamellar crystals up to 20 micron in length, and often shows semispherulitic texture.
occurrence: A 50 cm thick rhodonite-quartz lens.
aboutname: Named in 1991 by Teruhiko Sameshima and Yosuke Kawachi in honor of Douglas S. Coombs (23 November 1924 – 23 December 2016), professor of geology at the University of Otago, New Zealand. Coombs first described progressive mineralogical changes, especially relating to zeolites, due to low grade burial metamorphism. Coombs named wairakite, ferroceladonite, and ferroaluminoceladonite.
opticalcomments: First-order red to purple interference colours in standard thin sections.
type_specimen_store: The type material (OU34460) is deposited in the Museum of the Geology Department, University of Otago, and Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., U.S.A.

name: Cornubite
description_short:
The triclinic dimorph of Cornwallite.
May be confused with malachite, conichalcite and other green secondary copper minerals forming globular aggregates.

There are weak hydrogen bonds in the structure. Raman polarizability is dependent on the orien...
tlform: Apple-green patches of fibrous botryoids.
occurrence: Copper-Tin-Silver bearing hydrothermal veins.
otheroccurrence: Oxidation zone of copper deposits.
colour: Apple green, light to dark green
aboutname: Named in 1959 by Gordon Frank Claringbull, Max H. Hey and Arthur Russell for Cornubia, the medieval Latin name for Cornwall.
morphology: Rarely in crystals in tabular aggregates, usually botyroidal, also globular porcelaneous masses, fibrous.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, London 1964R, 8650.
commentdense: Measured density on fibrous material.

name: Cousinite
description_short:
Possibly a "Mg-Umohoite". Reinvestigation by modern methods needed.

Davison (1954) describes also an uran molybdate of Mg as monoclinic / pseudo-orthorombic with a = 6.37, b = 33.46, c = 15.0 A and beta = 90°. This mineral is listed in the recent co...
tlform: thin blades
aboutname: Named in 1958 by J.F. Vaes after Jules Cousin (Comblain-au-Pont, Liège province, Belgium, January 12 1884 - Brussels, November 12 1965). He worked for the Union Minière du Haut-Katanga, in Africa and in Belgium.
type_specimen_store: Royal Belgium Institute of Natural History, Brussels, Belgium, RC4759 and RC4760.

name: Criddleite
description_short: May stand for the Tl analogue of UM1993-08-S:AgAuSb.
tlform: 20 to 50 µm-sized lath-like, tabular or anhedral grains usually surrounding or penetrating aurostibite.
occurrence: Primary hydrothermal mineral.

Criddle (1944, South Wales, UK - 2 May 2002), mineralogist at the British Museum (Natural History) for his 'substantial contributions to the quantitative reflectance of ore minerals and for his research on opaque minerals. He helped to describe more than 65 new minerals and was author of the Quantitative Data File (QDF) for Ore Minerals (2nd and 3rd editions).
morphology: Lath like grains to 70 microns.

opticalanisotropism: Distinct - from buff to slate gray

British Museum (Natural History), London, UK, as polished section E.1230, BM 1987,351.
National Mineral Collection, Geological Survey of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, NMC 65186.

name: Cubanite
description_short:
Unlike the other chemically similar, but much more common Cu-Fe-sulphide, chalcopyrite, cubanite is weakly magnetic (note that the Handbook of Mineralogy says "strongly magnetic").

Very sensitive to temperature, pressure and compositional variations...
otheroccurrence: High-temperature hydrothermal deposits
aboutname: Named for the country of Cuba, which includes the type locality.
other: In a closed tube it produces a sulphur sublimate.  Before the blowpipe on charcoal, gives sulphur fumes and fuses to a magnetic globule.  The roasted ore reacts for copper and iron with the fluxes; with soda on charcoal it gives a globule of metallic iron with copper.
morphology: Elongated, thick tabular
twinning: Common on {110}. Pairs, fourlings and sixlings.
type_specimen_store: Technische Universität, Bergakademie Freiberg, Freiberg, Germany, number 5467.

otheroccurrence: Secondary mineral in uranium deposits
colour: Yellowish green to grass green or greenish yellow

X= nearly colorless
Y=Z= yellowish green

name: Cyanotrichite
description_short:
Cyanotrichite Group.
A secondary copper mineral found sparsely in the oxidation zones of copper-bearing ore bodies.
Cyanotrichite is closely related to Carbonatecyanotrichite, from which it is impossible to distinguish without XRD measurements (tests...
aboutname: From the Greek κυανός for "blue" and θρίξ for "hair" in allusion to its colour and habit.
other: Soluble in acids.
morphology: Occurs as velvet-, wool- or cotton-like aggregates and coatings comprised of minute acicular crystals; also radial-fibrous or tufted.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = nearly colourless; Y = light blue; Z = bright blue.

commentdense: A range from 2.737 (Morenci material) to 2.95 (Cap Garonne ?) exists in the literature.
commentcrystal: Originally assumed to be orthorhombic, with the unit-cell parameters 10.16, 12.61, 2.90.

name: Dalyite
description_short: Dalyite from Terceira ignimbrites contains some Na and minor Hf and Ti, but does not readily incorporate Fe, Mg and Ba.
tlform: Colorless, prismatic crystals to 0.5 mm.
occurrence: Ejected blocks of alkalic granite in trachytic and basaltic tuffs.
aboutname: Named by René van Tassel in 1952 for Reginald Aldworth Daly (March 18, 1871, Nepanee, Ontario, Canada – September 19, 1957, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA). Daly was professor at Harvard University and was one of the most brilliant igneous petrologists and established many geological principles. There are Daly Craters on both the Moon and Mars named in his honor. He also contributed greatly to the geological structure and petrology of Ascension Island, the type locality.
other: Strongly cathodoluminescent in bright azure-blue.
morphology: Short prismatic. Dominated by {101} and pinacoids parallel to [001].
twinning: Not uncommon, with {100} as the composition plane.
type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 64685.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 113106.

name: Daubréelite
description_short:
Linnaeite Group; Thiospinel Group.

NOTE: Not to be confused with daubréeite.
otheroccurrence: Meteorites
aboutname: Named by J.L. Smith in 1876 in honor of Gabriel Auguste Daubrée (25 June 1814, Metz, France – 29 May 1896, Paris, France), mineralogist and geologist who worked extensively with meteorites. He was also professor at Strasbourg and the Museum d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris. He was awarded the Wollaston Medal in 1880. The mineral daubréeite is also named in his honor.
morphology: Massive, scaly to platy in troilite and kamacite.
type_specimen_store:
Muséum Nationale d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France, numbers 76.196 , 96.1113 and 94.248.
Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France, numbers 15311, 24466.

name: Delafossite
description_short:
A not too uncommon member of the Delafossite Group.
Often associated with cuprite, copper and limonite.

Various synthetic analogues are known (Köhler & Jansen, 1986).
occurrence:
secondary mineral near the base of the oxidized zone of copper
deposits
aboutname: Named in 1873 by Charles Friedel in honor of Gabriel Delafosse [February 24, 1796 St. Quentin, France - October 13, 1878] Paris, France, French mineralogist noted for making advances in understanding crystal chemistry and establishing a distinction between empirical and molecular formulas.
morphology: Crystals tabular {0001} to equant, with {0001} and <mi>{101_1}</mi> as dominant forms. Rarely prismatic to acicular. Botryoidal crusts and rounded aggregates of subparallel tabular crystals.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
O = light golden-brown
E = darker rose-brown
type_specimen_store: National School of Mines, Paris, France.

name: Derbylite
mindat_formula_note: also given as Fe<sup>2+</sup><sub>x</sub>Fe<sup>3+</sup><sub>4-2x</sub>Ti<sup>4+</sup><sub>3+x</sub>Sb<sup>3+</sup>O<sub>13</sub>(OH)
description_short:
Homeotypic with graeserite, its As analogue. Both crystallize in the same point group, but different space group.

Also the Fe-Sb analogue of tomichite.

Compare batisivite.
tlform: Small grains and complex prismatic crystals.
occurrence: Cinnabar-bearing placer gravels.
opticalextinction: X = a; Y = b; Z = c.
aboutname: After American geologist Orville Adelbert Derby [July 23, 1851 Kellogsville, New York - November 27, 1915 Rio de Janeiro, Brazil), former Director, Brazilian Geological Survey.
other: Not soluble in acids. Decomposed by fusion in KHSO4.
morphology: Crystals prismatic, elongated [001], exhibiting numerous forms, mostly {hk0}; small grains.
twinning: On {011} or <mi>{_153}</mi>. Commonly as cruciform twins crossing at 57°38½', and rarely as trillings.
type_specimen_store: The Natural History Museum, London, England, UK: #80143.

name: Diamond
description_short: Diamond is the hardest natural substance known. It is formed deep in the mantle and is only brought to the surface via kimberlite pipes, lamprophyres, eclogites and other rocks that originate deep within the mantle. It is also found in alluvial deposit...
otheroccurrence:
Deep mantle-derived rocks such as kimberlites, lamprophyres, and others. With decreasing pressure, the diamonds dissolve back into the rock. To occur and survive in a metastable state at the surface they must arrive from depth quickly and very often crystals show dissolution features because the transport to the surface is not quick enough. 
Since diamond is extremely hard, it survives in alluvia.
industrial: Cutting and grinding due to extreme hardness. Used for the windows on the Venera spacecraft to photograph Venus' surface.
colour: Colourless, yellowish to yellow, brown, black, blue, green or red, pink, champagne-tan, cognac-brown, lilac (very rare)
luminescence: Some stones fluoresce pale blue, green, yellow, and, rarely, red.
aboutname: From Greek "adamas", 'invincible'. First known use by Manlius (A.D. 16) and Pliny (A.D. 100).
morphology: Octahedral crystals, also dodecahedrons, cubes, tetrahedral. Often has curved faces.
opticalbirefringence: Strain birefringence common (Raman and Rendall, 1944; Lang 1967; Howell, 2012).
thermalbehaviour: Greatest thermal conductivity known. A sizeable stone held in the hand feels cold, hence the slang name "ice".
commentcolor:
Eaton-Magaña, S., Ardon, T., Smit, K. V., Breeding, C. M., & Shigley, J. E. (2018). Natural-color Pink, Purple, Red, and Brown Diamonds: Band of Many Colors. Gems & Gemology, 54(4).

The spectroscopic data show that the yellow color of this diamond is due to N3 and N2 defects, although other kind of defects were detected, i.e., N3VH0 defects and platelets. The incorporation of H and defects resulting from the nitrogen aggregation are related to high-temperature formation, supporting the hypothesis that growth started at depths compatible with mantle conditions. [[1]]

name: Dimorphite
occurrence: Fumarolic vent
otheroccurrence: Secondary zone of ore deposits.
aboutname: From the Greek for two and form, for the two forms that the mineral supposedly occurs in.

type_specimen_store:
Natural History Museum, Paris, France, 50.588, 99.492.
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1937,1432.

name: Dollaseite-(Ce)
description_short:
Dollaseite Subgroup of the Epidote Group.

Chemically related to dissakisite-(Ce), gatelite-(Ce), manaevite-(Ce), västmanlandite-(Ce), and somewhat to khristovite-(Ce).
tlform: Brown, massive to subhedral 0.3-mm diameter crystals.
aboutname: In honour of Professor Wayne A. Dollase (1938-), University of California, Los Angeles, California, USA, for his research on the crystal chemistry of minerals of the epidote group, and the cerium content of the mineral.
morphology: Massive. Subhedral crystals, often in contact with carbonate. Also radiating, aggregates of lath-like crystals that are simple twinned crystals.  The laths may be extremely thin, even at high magnification, such that the aggregate is a fibrous felt.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, number R06505 (holotype/neotype).
commentcolor: In thin sections, very light brown with a pinkish tinge.
ima_history: The mineral now known as dollaseite-(Ce) was first described by Geijer in 1927 as “magnesium ortit”, based upon the high Mg content he found in some of the allanites (orthite) from the <l id='14533'></l>. He considered this mineral as the Mg-analogue of allanite-(Ce). Peacor and Dunn (1988) re-investigates material corresponding to Geijer’s "magnesium ortit" using modern methods. They found an elevated content of Mg in their material compared to what would be expected in the the Mg analogue of allanite-(Ce), finding nor only a Fe2+ <-> Mg2+ substitution one would expect from the Mg analogue of allanite, but also a Mg2+F- <->Al3+O2- substitution, giving a new mineral, dollaseite-(Ce)

name: Douglasite

name: Dufrénoysite

Dufrenoysite-Veenite Series. Closely related to buynite.

The structure contains isolated and interconnected AsS3 pyramids, as, e.g., in case of baumhauerite, gratonite, sartorite, and seligmannite.

morphology: Tabular {010} and somewhat elongated [100]; also elongated [010] and striated [100] to 3 cm.

name: Eckermannite
mindat_formula_note:
The eckermannite group minerals are sodium amphiboles defined with <sup>A</sup>(Na+K+2Ca)> 0.5 apfu and 0.5 apfu < <sup>C</sup>(Al+Fe<sup>3+</sup>+2Ti) < 1.5 apfu with Al as the dominant element

Eckermannite is defined with 

A position: Na dominant
C<sup>2+</sup> position: Mg dominant
C<sup>3+</sup> position: Al dominant
W position: (OH) dominant
description_short:
Name first introduced for an amphibole from Norra Kärr, Sweden by Adamson (1942).[[1]]
Redefined IMA in 2014 (IMA2013-136), according to the new IMA-approved nomenclature of amphiboles published in 2012 (Hawthorne et al., 2012).[[2]]

NOTE: In the c...
aboutname: For (Claes Walter) Harry von Eckermann (5 November 1886, Stockholm, Sweden - 20 May 1969, Rönö, Sweden), industrialist, mineralogist and petrologist.
