otheroccurrence: In lithium-rich pegmatites, often as graphic intergrowths with albite derived from alteration of spodumene.
colour: Colorless, white, pale tan, pale gray
aboutname: Named in 1880 by Brush and Dana from the Greek for "well concealed", in allusion to its occurrence embedded in albite. Also known as α-eucryptite or alpha-eucryptite.
other: Gelatinizes with HCl.
morphology: Usually massive, rarely in equant euhedral crystals with <mi>{10_10}, {0001}, and {11_20}</mi>. (Bikita: Hurlbut, 1962). More complex crystals found at Kings Mountain, North Carolina, USA.
twinning: Some eucryptite samples are polysynthetically twinned, with alternating thin and broad twin lamellae. Sometimes possible to recognize the twinning with the naked eye.  The angle between the optic axes of two adjacent crystals is about 74° and the angle between the composition plane of the crystals and the optic axis 37°.
uv: Magenta-red or orange under SW UV. Generally fluorescent (both natural and synthetic), however, Haapaluoma eucryptite is not fluorescent. The fluorescence of Tanco eucryptite fades rapidly after the larger grains have been crushed and disappears completely in powdered material (Cerny 1972).
type_specimen_store: No designated type specimen.
commentbreak: Pure masses from Bikita show conchoidal fracture.

name: Ewaldite
aboutname:
Named in honor of Paul Peter Ewald (23 January 1888, Berlin, Germany – 22 August 1985, Ithaca, New York, USA), physicist, crystallographer, and Professor at the Polytechnic Institute of New York, Brooklyn, New York,
USA. He was a pioneer in the field of X-ray diffraction and founded the journal Acta Crystallographica.
opticalpleochorismdesc: O = dark bluish green; E = pale yellowish green
type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1971,137.
National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian), Washington, D.C., USA, 121 683.
commentdense: measured on impure material

name: Falcondoite
description_short:
A nickel silicate forming friable masses of minute fibers, less than 10 microns in length.
The Ni analogue of sepiolite.
tlform: Slightly schistose, friable masses of minute fibrous particles, less than 10 μm in length.
occurrence: In garnierite veins cutting a laterite, associated with a serpentinized harzbergite massif.
aboutname: Named after the mining company Falconbridge Dominicana C por A. (Falcondo), which mines at the type locality.
type_specimen_store: Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M34324.
commentcrystal: Point Group: n.d.; : Space Group: n.d.

name: Fedorite
description_short:
A white micaceous mineral. 

Structurally related to Reyerite Group.
occurrence: Fenitized sandstone
colour: White, colorless, bright red, raspberry red
opticalextinction: X = c, Y = b, Z = a
aboutname: Named in 1968 by A. A. Kukharenko, M. P. Orlova, and A. G. Bulakh in honor of mathematician, crystallographer, and mineralogist Evgraf Stepanovich Fedorov [December 22, 1853 Orenberg, Russia - May 21, 1919 St. Petersburg, Russia]. Fedorov was very interested in group theory and proved important concepts involved in polytypism and wallpaper theory later used in solving crystal structures.
morphology: Platy micaceous aggregates

name: Fergusonite-(Y)
description_short: Compare also the chemically similar euxenite-(Y) and nioboaeschynite-(Y).
tlform: Crystals, embedded in quartz.
otheroccurrence: Rare earth bearing pegmatites, placer deposits.
aboutname: Named fergusonite after Robert Ferguson (8 September 1769 – 3 December 1840, London, England), Scottish landowner, politician and mineral collector.  The suffix was added in 1987 to conform to the Levinson rule for minerals with essential REE, in this case yttrium.
morphology: Prismatic to acicular dipyramidal crystals to 20cm.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.
thermalbehaviour: Before the blowpipe, infusible, but it loses its colour and becomes pale greenish-yellow.
commentcolor: Brownish black when altered, brown in transmitted light.

name: Ferrinatrite
tlform: Stellate groups of crystals forming nearly spherical nodules. Generally similar to pale wavellite in appearance.
otheroccurrence: Oxidation zone of iron sulfides in an arid region. Rarely in fumaroles.
colour: Colourless, grayish white, pale green, bluish green, amethystine; colourless in transmitted light.
aboutname: From the chemistry of the mineral. FERRIc iron and sodium (NATRium).
other: Alters to sideronatrite in moist air.  Soluble in water.
morphology: Crystals short prismatic [0001]. Isolated individuals or stellate groups; fibrous aggregates or cleavable masses; cryptocrystalline.
type_specimen_store: n.d.

name: Ferro-gedrite
mindat_formula_note:
The gedrite group are orthorhombic amphiboles in the magnesium-iron-manganese amphibole subgroup defined with <sup>A</sup>(Na+K+2Ca)<0.5 apfu and <sup>C</sup>(Al+Fe<sup>3+</sup>+2Ti)>1 apfu 

Ferro-gedrite is defined with Fe<sub>2+</sub> as the dominant element both in the B and C<sup>2+</sup> positions and Al in the C<sup>3+</sup> position.
description_short: Forms a series with gedrite.
aboutname: Named for its relationship to gedrite.  The species was originally named ferrogedrite.  The hyphen was added in 2012 by the IMA.
type_specimen_store: No designated type specimen.

name: Ferrosilite
mindat_formula_note: Simplified: <f>FeSiO^3</f>.
description_short:
Enstatite-Ferrosilite Series

Note: The name has been used in the past to describe the monoclinic dimorph clinoferrosilite, with the orthorhombic dimorph having the name orthoferrosilite so be careful when reading older texts.
aboutname: Originally a hypothetical mineral named by Henry Stevens Washington [1867-1934] in 1903. First used to name natural material in 1935 by Norman L. Bowen.
morphology: Usually in elongated grains; rare crystals are bladed to prismatic.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X pinkish brown, Z greenish brown
commentcolor: Bright-green ferrosilite has not been chemically verified, althought it has been verified by XRD as an orthopyroxene.

name: Fersmite
mindat_formula_note: Previously given as <f>(Ca,Ce,Na)(Nb,Ta,Ti)^2(O,OH,F)^6</f>.
description_short:
Fersmite (similar to Fergusonite) is one of the most low-titanoan niobates.
Compare Vigezzite.
otheroccurrence: accessory mineral in nepheline syenites and carbonatites.
colour: Black, dark brown, lemon-yellow to yellow-brown
aboutname: Named in 1946 by Elsa Maximilianovna Bohnstedt-Kupletskaya and T. A. Burova in honour of academic Aleksandr Evgenievich Fersman (November 8, 1883 St. Petersburg, Russia - May 20, 1945 Sochi, Georgia), mineralogist, founder of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum in Moscow, Russia.  The mineral <m>fersmanite</m> is also named after him.
morphology: prismatic crystals
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = Y = pale greenish yellow to colorless; Z = dark greenish yellow to olive-yellow
uv: Fluoresces yellow-green to bluish green under SW and LW UV; light blue cathodoluminescence
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 44383, 44384

name: Fingerite
description_short: black grains up to 150 micrometers
tlform: crystals, to 150 µm
occurrence: Outer sulfate zone of fumarole "Y" indicating a sublimation temperature between 100 and 200 degrees C.
aboutname: For Dr. Larry W. Finger (1940-), Geophysical Laboratory, Carnegie Institution of Washington
morphology: Plate like and equant crystals
opticalcomments: reflectance of randomly oriented grains in blue-filtered white light in air is 21+-2%
type_specimen_store: Carnegie Institution, Washington, D.C.; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 160387.

name: Florencite-(La)
tlform: Euhedral, colorless to pale yellow crystals normally not exceeding 30 µm in diameter.
occurrence: Siltstones belonging to an intertidal facies and overlain by lagoonal dolomites. In specimen used as type, florencite-(La) made up 3% by volume of the siltstone.
colour: Colorless to pale yellow; white in aggregates.
aboutname: Named for its relationship to florencite (now <M>florencite-(Ce)</M>). The root name florencite is in honour of Dr. Guilherme (William) Florence (19 June 1864 - 5 October 1942), Brazilian mineralogist with the São Paulo Geographic and Geological Commission. He made a preliminary chemical examination of the mineral. The "-(La)" suffix was added in 1987 (Nickel and Mandarino), in allusion to lanthanum being the dominant REE in the composition.
morphology: As pseudocubic rhombohedra, to 30 µm; as colloform crusts.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.

name: Fluorbritholite-(Ce)
description_short: A mineral in the Britholite Group of the Apatite Supergroup. The fluorine-dominant analogue of britholite-(Ce).
occurrence: In vugs in nepheline syenite, marble xenoliths, sodalite syenite xenoliths and pegmatite dykes
aboutname: First described as a new mineral from Mont Saint-Hilaire, Quebec, Canada (Gu et al. 1994). Named for its relationship to britholite-(Ce) with the fluorine content.

name: Foshagite
tlform: White veins of very compact fibrous structure with the fibers perfectly parallel and several inches long
occurrence: Thermally altered limestone
aboutname: Named in 1925 by Arthur S. Eakle in honor of William Frederick Foshag [March 17, 1894 Sag Harbor, New York, USA - May 21, 1956 Westmoreland Hills, Maryland, USA], chemist and mineralogist, curator of minerals at the Smithsonian Institution.
other: When the mineral is ignited to expel water it becomes a pale blue. Heated with the blowpipe it becomes incandescent and converted into a vitrified mass which is infusible. Easily soluble in HCl with abundant gelatinization.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 95229
commentdense: Measured with a pycnometer
commentcrystal: Monoclinic. Point Group: 2/m; 2; or m: Space Group: A-centered.

name: Frankdicksonite
description_short: The solubility is much higher than that of fluorite (CaF2).
tlform: Small discrete euhedral crystals ranging from 0.1 mm to 4 mm in diameter.
occurrence: Quartz vein.
aboutname: For mineralogist Frank W. Dickson (1922-), Professor of Geochemistry, Stanford University.
other: Electron bombardment of the mineral results in a strong medium-blue cathodoluminescence.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, number 133958.

name: Fresnoite
description_short:
The Ba analogue of alfredcasparite.
Fresnoite is ferroelectric.
tlform: Sparse grains, generally less than 1 mm long.
occurrence: Gneissic metamorphic rocks composed mainly of sanbornite and quartz.
aboutname: Named by John T. Alfors, Melvin C. Stinson, Robert A. Matthews and Adolf Pabst in 1965 for Fresno County that includes the type locality.
other: Insoluble or only slightly soluble in most cold dilute acids and bases. Decomposed by hot 1:1 HCl and cold acetic acid leaving a colorless residue.
opticalpleochorismdesc: In transmitted polarized light, from yellow to colorless. The mineral characteristically shows anomalous blueinterference colors.
uv:
Pale yellow under SW UV @ 265.2 nm.
No fluorescence under LW UV @ 365.0 nm.
type_specimen_store: California Division of Mines and Geology, San Francisco, California, USA.
thermalbehaviour: Fuses at about 4. Partially melted when heated in an electric furnace to 1200 °C and completely melted at 1300 °C to a yellow glass.
commentdense: Determined using a sample totaling 10.77 mg.

name: Fukalite
description_short: OD structure; six MDO polytypes are possible (Bonaccorsi et al., 2009).
tlform: Flaky crystals to 0.2 mm.
occurrence: Alteration product of spurrite.
aboutname: Named by Chiyoko Henmi, Isao Kusachi, Akira Kawahara, and Kitinosuke Henmi in 1977 after the type locality of Fuka Mine, Japan.
other: Decomposed by acids with effervescence.
type_specimen_store: Department of Earth Sciences, Okayama University.
commentcrystal: Cell conforms to one of six possible MDO types. Originally described with orthrhombic cell (5.48, 3.78, 23.42 A).

name: Gahnite
description_short: Gahnite-Hercynite Series, and the Gahnite-Spinel Series.
aboutname: Named in 1807 by Baron Karl Marie Ehrenbert von Moll in honor  of Swedish chemist and mineralogist, Johan Gottlieb Gahn [August 19, 1745 Voxna Bruk, Hälsingland, Sweden - December 8, 1818 Falun, Sweden]. The new name replaced automalite named by Anders Gustav Ekeberg.
morphology: Crystals usually octahedral.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.

name: Gamagarite
description_short: The Fe3+ analogue of tokyoite.
tlform: Aggregates of needles, approximately one centimeter in length, and also as somewhat flattened prisms.
occurrence: Banded manganese ore.
aboutname: After the Gamagara Ridge, South Africa, the type locality.
other: Moderately magnetic.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = red-brown; Y = very deep red-brown; Z = light salmon-buff.
type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, number 1958,553.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, number 105142.

name: Gaspéite
description_short:
Calcite Group. 
Gaspéite-Magnesite Series.
tlform: Light green rhombohedral crystals.
occurrence: Dolomite vein containing nickel.
aboutname: Named after the Gaspé Peninsula, Québec, Canada, that includes the type locality.
uv: White fluorescence under short- and long-wave ultraviolet light (from Dubostica).
type_specimen_store:
University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada, S-75-4222.
National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian), Washington, D.C., USA, 119544.
commentdense: Density increases with nickel content.

name: Gehlenite
description_short:
Gehlenite-Åkermanite Series.

Chemically very similar to bicchulite and kamaishilite (both hydrous, however).
aboutname: Named in 1815 by Johann Nepomuk von Fuchs in honor of Adolf Ferdinand Gehlen [5 September 1775 Bütow, Outer Pomerania, Prussia (Bytów, Poland) - 16 July 1815]. Gehlen was editor and publisher of publisher of Neues Allgemeines Journal der Chemie (1803–06), Journal für Chemie und Physik (1806-10) and the Repetitorium für die Pharmacie. He was initially a chemistry professor at the University of Halle (Martin-Luther-Universität Halle-Wittenberg) and later chemist at the Bavarian Academy of Sciences. He died early due to arsenic poisoning.

name: Gerasimovskite
tlform: Platy masses up to 1.5x1x0.3 cm.
occurrence: In ussingite-bearing pegmatites. Thought to have formed by the hydrothermal alteration of minerals of the murmanite-lomonosovite series.
colour: brown to gray or light gray
aboutname: Named in 1957 by Evgeny Ivanovich Semenov in honor of Vasilii Ivanovich Gerasimovsky (Василий Иванович Герасимовский) (20 June 1907, village of Artemyevskaya, Vologda province - 11 August 1979, Transbaikalia) in 1934, discovered (together with O.A. Vorobyova) industrial deposits of loparite ore on the Kola Peninsula.

name: Gianellaite
description_short:
Although somewhat chemically similar to kleinite and mosesite, gianellaite has a unique combination of dominant elements.

In the structure there are: (1) nitrogen-centered (NHg4)5+ tetrahedra, that have all corners common; (2) interstitial sulfate t...
tlform: Rosettes of flattened subhedral crystals, rarely as euhedral crystals 0.2-1.0 mm. in diameter of distorted octahedra.
occurrence: Oxidation zone of hydrothermal mercury deposit
aboutname: Professor Emeritus Vincent Paul Gianella (February 9, 1886 in Marysville, California -  Auburn, California on July 9, 1983), Mackay School of Mines, University of Nevada
other: Not attacked at 20-100° by H2SO4 (1:1), conc. HNO3, or HF. Decomposed by concentrated HCl at room temperature.
type_specimen_store:
Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA, 124993.
National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian), Washington, D.C., USA, 142886, 142887.
thermalbehaviour: Darkens when heated above 130°C, turns white at 400°C, volatilizes.

name: Girvasite
tlform: Creamy white spherulites, rarely single prismatic crystals.
occurrence: Dolomitic carbonatite
aboutname: Named by S.N. Britvin, Y.A. Pakhomovskiy, A.N. Bogdanova, and Y.V. Sokolova in 1990 for Lake Girvas, northwest of the Kovdor massif, Kola Peninsula, Russia.
other: Readily soluble in cold 10% HCl.
morphology: Crystals elongate [100] and up to 1 mm long and 0.07 mm across.
type_specimen_store:
Geology Museum, Kola Branch, Academy of Sciences, Apatity, Russia, 5948.
Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, Russia, 2025/1.
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 87981.
thermalbehaviour: There is a strong endothermic peak at 370 °C and a weak one at 580°C, the first corresponding to loss of H20, which is also lost at 700-750°C. C02 is gradually lost between 400 and 1000°C.
commentluster: Silky for spherulites, vitreous for single crystals
commentdense: Measured in heavy liquids
commentcolor: Spherulites creamy white; single crystals colorless

name: Glaukosphaerite
mindat_formula_note: Ni is confined to one out of two cation sites, so ideal endmember is NiCu(CO3)(OH)2
description_short: Rosasite Group.
tlform: Thin veinlets. Tiny spherules. Radiating aggregates of separate green fibers up to 3 mm.
occurrence: In the oxidized zone of serpentinized-dunite rocks containing nickel.
aboutname: The name is for the color (glaukos, Greek for blue-green, blue-grey) and spherulitic formation.
morphology: Fibrous, as spherules which may be concentrically zoned.
type_specimen_store:
Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France, number 50783 (cotype).
Natural History Museum, London, United Kingdom, number BM 1975,419 (holotype)
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, number 131889 (type).
Western Australian Museum, Perth, Australia, number MDC 5309 (holotype).

name: Goldichite
tlform: Radiating clusters of pale-green crystals or fine-grained crystalline encrustations.
occurrence: Cementing material of a talus slope below a small, pyrite-rich uranium deposit.
otheroccurrence: Oxidation of pyrite, rarely fumaroles.
aboutname: Named in 1955 by Abraham Rosenzweig and Eugene B. Gross in honor of Dr. Samuel Stephen Goldich ["January", 1909 USA - December 20, 2000 Applewood, Colorado, USA], American mineralogist, University of Minnesota and founding chief of the USGS Branch of Isotope Geology. The Goldich Stability Series was devised by him.
other: Slightly soluble in cold water. Soluble in hot water with hydrolysis.
morphology:
Flattened on {100} and elongated along [001] with forms {100}, {110}, and
{011}.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X= colorless
Y= colorless to pale yellow
Z= very pale yellow
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian), Washington, D.C., USA, 106903.
commentcolor: Lavender tint in artificial light.

name: Goudeyite
mindat_formula_note: Al may be replaced by minor Y and other REE.
description_short:
Mixite Group. 
Visually indistinguishable from other members of the mixite group.
tlform: hair-like crystals, encrusting fractures and as cross-fiber veinlets
aboutname: Named in honor of Hatfield Goudey (13 December 1906, Red Bank, New Jersey, USA – 11 April 1985, Mateo, California, USA), economic geologist, mineral collector and dealer in microscopic specimens, San Mateo, California, USA, who contributed to the knowledge of the type locality. He was elected to the Micromounter's Hall of Fame in 2003.
other: Dissolves slowly in dilute HCl
opticalpleochorismdesc: O = pale yellow-green; E = green.
type_specimen_store:
University of California, Santa Barbara, USA (specimen #8091).
Cotype material in the National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., USA.
commentdense: Berman balance on fragments of 8 mg in toluene at 22 C.
commentcrystal: Point Group: 6/m or 6 (probable); Space Group: [P63/m or P63] (by analogy to mixite)

name: Grayite
description_short:
Originally powdery or cryptocrystalline. Rarely in subhedral resinous crystals.
Possibly identical to brockite? See also the dubious smirnovskite.

Compare 'UM1979-08-PO:CCaFeHREESiTh'; 'UM1980-04-PO:CaHREETh', 'UM1979-07-PO:CaFeHREESiTh'.
occurrence: Originally in a lithia-rich granite pegmatite.
otheroccurrence: Has been found in granite pegmatite (Maine).
colour: Dark reddish brown, rarely tannish yellow
aboutname: Named in honor of Anton Gray, chief geologist, Kennecott Copper Corporation and advisor to the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority.
uv: Specimens from Havey #2 Quarry, Topsham, Maine fluoresce yellow in SW UV.
thermalbehaviour: Grayite may give a monazite-like powder pattern after heating to 850 degrees C.

name: Grischunite
description_short: Wicksite Group. Chemically similar to manganohatertite.
tlform: Anhedral grains and lathlike crystals
occurrence: Alpine metamorphism of manganese ores, with abundant arsenic in surrounding rock.
aboutname: For the Grischun (Grisons; Graubünden) region in which the type locality is situated.
morphology: Lathlike crystals, elongated along b.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = yellow green (X||b), Y = yellow brown (Y||a), and Z = dark red brown (Z||c)
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, Basel, Switzerland, MB19.295

name: Guarinoite
mindat_formula_note: Minor Co and Ni may replace Zn.
description_short: The Zn analogue of Unnamed (Co-analogue of Guarinoite). Chemically the Zn analogue of isselite.
tlform: Aggregates of hexagonal crystals.
occurrence: Secondary alteration mineral.
colour: Very pale pink, bright to deep pink.
aboutname: Named in honor of André Guarino (1945– ), mineral collector from Toulon, France, who collected the first specimens.
other: Soluble in HCl
morphology: Tabular {001}
opticalpleochorismdesc: O = pink, E = light pink
type_specimen_store: Mineralogy Department, Natural History Museum, Geneva, Switzerland, 435/85.
commentcrystal: Space group P63, P63/m or P6322.

name: Guyanaite
description_short:
The β phase of CrO(OH). As with other Cr mineral species from the Merume River locality, such as bracewellite, grimaldiite, and mcconnellite, this species is NOT universally present in every specimen and verification of each specimen is required.

A ...
tlform: microcrystalline aggregates, alluvial grains; very rarely as prismatic crystals, up to 0.1 mm
occurrence: In an alluvial placer deposit, in fine-grained intergrowth with other chromium oxide-hydroxide minerals
colour: Reddish brown, golden brown, greenish brown, green,
aboutname: Named in 1967 by Charles Milton, Daniel E. Appleman, Edward Ching-Te Chao, Frank Cuttita, Joseph I. Dinnin, Edward J. Dwornik, Margaret Hall, Blanche L. Ingram, and Harry J. Rose, Jr. for the country where the mineral was first found: Guyana / Guiana.
opticalpleochorismdesc: brown colours
type_specimen_store: The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1979,136.
commentcrystal: Space group is P2<sub>1</sub>nm or Pnnm (LP phase); HP phase: Pnnm
commentcolor: probably variable with particle size and degree of oxidation;

name: Hainite-(Y)
description_short:
Chemically close to fogoite-(Y).

Long regarded as a doubtful species, said to be related to rosenbuschite, but an independent species after all (Christiansen et al., 2003). The crystal structure of the type material has been determined by Giester et...
tlform: Crystals, less than 1 mm, needles and plates, [001] elongation; {010}, {100}, and <mi>{_110}</mi> faces present (TL material)
occurrence: Cavities and groundmass of phonolites (TL material); carbonatites
colour: Wine-yellow, honey-yellow; milk white, brownish, pale pink
aboutname: For the type locality, (Hohe) Hain Mountain, plus the "-(Y)" suffix due to the dominance of yttrium in the composition. It was first described by Josef Blumrich in 1893 under the name hainite [hainit]. The name was changed by IMA in 2016 to hainite-(Y) (IMA 16-A).
other: Fluoresces under electron beam.
opticalpleochorismdesc: colorless (X), colorless to pale yellow (Y), wine-yellow (Z)
commentcolor: Light wine-yellow in thin section. Altered hainite-(Y9 shows a brown colour
ima_history: 2016: Redefined. Name changed from hainite to hainite-(Y) (IMA 16-A).

name: Hanawaltite
occurrence: Alteration product of cinnabar, in a mercury deposit in silicate-carbonate rock hydrothermally altered from serpentinite.
aboutname: Named by Andrew C. Roberts, Joel D. Grice, Robert A. Gault, Alan J. Criddle, Richard C. Erd in 1996 in honor of Joseph Donald Hanawalt (6 July 1902, Royersford, Pennsylvania, USA – 26 June 1987), for his early work in X-ray powder diffraction.  He was a metallurgist and an authority on magnesium.  He was affiliated with 3M and the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA.  He developed what would be known as the Hanawalt X-ray Diffraction Method, and was awarded 30 patents and numerous awards.
other: Decrepitates on exposure to sunlight, photoreducing to mercury.
morphology: Subhedral to anhedral crystals, platy to bladed, striated k || [001].
opticalpleochorismdesc: Bright bluish white to grayish white
type_specimen_store: Canadian Geological Survey, Ottawa, Canada, 67396.

name: Hashemite
description_short: Ba-analogue of tarapacáite. Stoichiometrically related to crocoite and chromatite.
tlform: Euhedral brown crystals, less than 1 mm long, on ettringite. Color ranges from dark to light colored; some grains are zoned and have dark cores and light rims.
occurrence: Phosphate carbonate rock.
colour: Brown, dark greenish brown, yellow-brown, yellow
aboutname: Named by Phoebe L. Hauff, Eugene E. Foord, Sam Rosenblum, and Walid Hakki for the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan (the official name of Jordan), where the type locality is located.
morphology: Stubby, doubly terminated to tabular crystals.  Forms include {100}, {010}, {001}, and {110}.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian), Washington, D.C., USA, 146183.
commentcolor: Commonly zoned from cores of dark greenish brown to pale yellow brown.

name: Hawthorneite
description_short:
Unique combination of elements, although somewhat chemically similar to mathiasite and haggertyite.

The supposed Ti analogue (actually its Ti5Mg2Cr analogue) is IMA-coded as UM1994-07-O:BaCrFeMgTi.
tlform: Grains, up to 100 µm, surrounded by lindsleyite and oriented in spinel.
occurrence: Formed during upper-mantle (75–100 km, 900–1100 °C, 20–30 kbar) metasomatism of chromian spinel in peridotite xenoliths in a kimberlite pipe.
aboutname: Named by I.E. Grey, I.C. Madsen, and S.E. Haggerty in 1987 in honor of John Barry Hawthorne (1934–2018), former Chief Geologist (Diamonds), DeBeers Consolidated Mines, South Africa, in honor of his contributions to studies of the upper mantle.
morphology: grains to 100 µm
opticalanisotropism: Weak to moderate, brown to gray
type_specimen_store: The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1988,71.
commentcolor: light gray in reflected light.

name: Heideite
occurrence: Enstatite achondrite meteorite
aboutname: Named in honor of Hermann Wilhelm Friedrich "Fritz" Heide (19 December 1891 - 17 December 1973), German meteoricist, Jena, in 1965. One area of his work was the question of why the largest meteorite impact craters did not produce meteorites, and whether very large meteorites could vaporize on impact.
morphology: Anhedral grains to 100 microns
opticalpleochorismdesc: Purple-gray to cream-gray
commentdense: Synthetic

name: Hematophanite
tlform: Isolated thin plates up to 5 mm in diameter or aggregated into lamellar aggregates.
aboutname: Presumably in allusion to the blood-red color in transmitted light.
other: Easily soluble in acids.
morphology: Crystals are thin tablets {001} as lamellar aggregates in part.
type_specimen_store: Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm, Sweden.

name: Henritermierite
description_short: Garnet Group. The Mn(III) analogue of Holtstamite.
tlform: Aggregates of small grains up to 0.5 mm; mostly about 0.2 mm in diameter, filling interstices between crystals of marokite, hausmannite, and rare gaudefroyite.
otheroccurrence: Manganese deposits
colour: Clove-brown to apricot-brown; lemon-yellow to pale yellow in thin section.
aboutname: Named in 1969 by C. Gaudefroy, M. Orliac, F. Permingeat, and A. Parfenoff, in honor of Henri François Émile Termier (13 December 1897, Lyon, France - 12 August 1989, Gif sur Yvette, France), geologist known for his studies of the stratigraphy and paleontology of North Africa and France. He was, for a time, head of the Morocco Geological Service and later, professor at the University of Algiers and the Sorbonne.
morphology: As pseudo-octahedral crystals, to 3mm, and as aggregates of small grains.

O = very pale yellow
E = lemon-yellow

Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France, numbers 51098, 51099 (holotype).

name: Hewettite
description_short:
A secondary mineral resulting from the alteration of patronite (TL), or from the alteration of less-oxidized vanadium minerals.

May reversibly dehydrate to metahewettite.
tlform: Lumpy aggregates, composed of needles usually less than 0.01 x 0.2 mm.
occurrence: Very rich vanadium deposit in sedimentary rocks.
otheroccurrence: Colorado Plateau-type U-V deposits
colour: Deep red; chocolate brown (upon exposure); red to orange in transmitted light
aboutname: Named in honor of Donnel Foster Hewett (June 24, 1881, Irwin, Pennsylvania - February 5, 1971), U.S. Geological Survey, who studied the mineralogy of Mina Ragra, Cerro de Pasco, Peru.  He was primarily responsible for the discovery of that, the largest vanadium deposit in the world.
other: Reversibly dehydrates to metahewettite. Slightly soluble in water.
morphology: Crystals acicular and as fibers, elongated and intertwined parallel [010]; nodular aggregates, fracture fillings, and coatings.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = Y = Light yellow-orange; Z = Dark red.
type_specimen_store: U.S. National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA: #87459.
thermalbehaviour: When heated, it passes through various color changes and melts readily.

name: Hillebrandite
description_short: White fibrous crystals typical. Compare 'UM1977-14-SiO:CaH'.
tlform: White fibers in dense aggregates
occurrence: High temperature contact metamorphic mineral in marbles
colour: White, colorless, very pale greenish white.
aboutname: Named by Fred Eugene Wright in 1908 in honor of William Francis Hillebrand (12 December 1853, Honolulu, Hawaii, USA - 7 February 1925, Washington, D.C., USA). Hillebrand was regarded as one of the best wet analytical method chemists in the USA and was with the U.S. Geological Survey.  He described 5 new minerals himself, and 11 others jointly.
morphology: Rod-like to fibrous
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 86531.
commentcrystal: Non-standard setting Cmc21; also momoclinic with beta = 90 degrees

name: Hodrušite
description_short: Structurally closely related to cuprobismutite and kupčíkite.

occurrence: 150 and 250 meter mining levels on Rosalia vein.

name: Holtite
mindat_formula_note: Originally assumed to be Al6(Al,Ta)(SiO4,SbO4,AsO4)3(BO3)O3.
description_short:
Note: Groat et al. (2008) give the formula (Ta,[],Al)Al6(BO3)(Si,Sb,As)3O12(O,OH,[])3. 

Closely related to dumortierite.
tlform: Intergrown prisms and acicular coatings on stibiotantalite and as parallel acicular to asbestiform replacements of tantalite. Also as hard resinous pebbles composed of parallel needles often with S-shaped contortions. Crystals to 1 mm in length.
occurrence: Alluvial pebbles.
otheroccurrence: Pegmatites
colour: Light buff to cream-buff, deep olive-buff, brown, russet
aboutname: Named in honor of Harold Edward Holt (5 August 1908, Stanmore, New South Wales, Australia - 17 December 1967, Cheviot Beach, Victoria, Australia), Prime Minister of Australia (1966-1967).
morphology: Blocky crystals, pseudohexagonal needles
opticalpleochorismdesc: Various shades of yellow to colorless
uv: Dull orange (SW UV) and bright yellow (LW UV).

The Australian Museum, Sydney, Australia, number D43778 (type).
Western Australian Museum, Perth, Australia, number MDC 550 (holotype).

name: Huanghoite-(Ce)
description_short: Synchysite Group. The barium analogue of Synchysite-(Ce).
tlform: Platy masses up to 10x5x1 cm.
occurrence: In hydrothermal deposits, including calcite veins, genetically associated with alkalic grano-syenites and the enclosing hydrothermally altered dolomite.
aboutname: Named for the Huang Ho River (Yellow River), near the type locality. Originally named simply huanghoite.  The suffix/modifier was added in 1987 to conform to the Levinson rule for species with essential REE, indicating, in this case, predominant cerium.
other:
Alters readily on the surface to yellow and brown ochers, with considerable loss of barium.

Vigorously dissolved by HCl.
morphology: Platy to granular.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Greenish yellow shades
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 144184.
thermalbehaviour: DTA curve shows a small endothermal break at 400-470°C, a large one at 620-680°C, and a medium one at 760-800°C.

name: Hunchunite
tlform: Anhedral granular aggregates, 170-500 x 3-30 µm.
occurrence: Quaternary alluvial placers.
aboutname: For its occurrence along the Hunchun River, China.
type_specimen_store: National Geological Museum, Beijing, China.
commentcrystal: Fd3m - by analogy to synthetic Au2Pb
commentcolor: Readily oxidizes to a dull gray.

name: Hyalotekite
mindat_formula_note: also given as Ba<sub>4</sub>Ca<sub>2</sub>[Si<sub>8</sub>B<sub>2</sub>(SiB)O<sub>28</sub>]F (Hawthorne et al., 2018)
description_short: The Ba analogue of khvorovite. The Ca2SiB analogue of kapitsaite-(Y). The crystal structure is very closely related to that of itsiite - its B2[] (B2-vacancy-) analogue.

otheroccurrence: peralkaline pegmatites

uv:
blue, light brownish orange, or yellowish in SW UV
cathodoluminescence - bright yellow or blue

description_short:
An uncommon alteration product of glauberite.

Chemically related to eugsterite, antofagastaite, omongwaite, and partially to cesanite.

Decomposed by H2O to form gypsum.
Easily dissolved by dilute HCl.

name: Hydroxyapophyllite-(K)
description_short:
Fluorapophyllite-(K)-Hydroxyapophyllite-(K) Series. The Ca analogue of hydroxymcglassonite-(K).


Mineral name changed from apophyllite-(KOH) to hydroxyapophyllite-(K) (Hatert et al., 2013).

aboutname:
Apophyllite was named in 1806 by Rene Just Haüy from the Greek for "away from" (ἀπό, apo) and "leaf" (φύλλον, phyllos), in allusion to the way it exfoliates upon heating. Chemical variants were recognized by Pete J. Dunn, Roland C. Rouse, and Julie A. Norberg in 1978.
Mineral name changed from apophyllite-(KOH) to hydroxyapophyllite-(K) (Hatert et al., 2013).
type_specimen_store: The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1977,58; Geological Survey of Canada, Ottawa, 14099; Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Canada; Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 115268.

name: Ice
description_short:
Stable as a solid under 0°C (at standard atmospheric pressure). There are many different structural varieties of ice, although the standard form found on earth is Ih (hexagonal ice) as described here.

It is now confirmed that water ice is also extra...
colour: Colourless to white, pale blue to greenish blue in thick layers
aboutname: From Old English is, from Proto-Germanic *isa-.
other: Melts at 0 °C at atmospheric pressure.
morphology: Usually as snow crystals, in complex six-rayed stellate forms of great variety, flattened {0001}. Delicate skeletal forms or hopper-shaped prisms as hoar frost. Lathlike crystals, greatly elongated at times, by crystallization on the surface of water.

name: Ilsemannite
description_short: Note that there are numerous different and very complex heterovalent molybdenum oxide molecules forming amorphous blue substances. Most likely the "ilsemannites" at different localities, formed under different conditions, are not the same compound and ...

aboutname: After Johann Christoph Ilsemann (1727-1822), a former Mining Commissioner at Clausthal, Harz, who published an early study of molybdenite (1787).

name: Iowaite
description_short:
Hydrotalcite Group. Chemically similar to kuliginite, which however is anhydrous.

Bluish green, becoming pale green with a rusty red tint on exposure to air (alteration to pyroaurite).

occurrence: Altered serpentinite in precambrian basement
aboutname: For the state of the type locality.
other: Insoluble in water and readily soluble in mineral acids.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 121706.
thermalbehaviour: In DTA measurements, a large endothermic reaction occurs between 315°C and 350°C, representing a collapse of the iowaite structure. The material changes in color from light tan to dark brown, water is evolved, and periclase is formed.

name: Irtyshite
tlform: veins (0.02x0.2mm) and irregular grains (0.05mm)
occurrence: Granitic pegmatites
aboutname: Named for the Irtysh River, a major river close to the type locality.  The Irtysh leads into the Ob River.  The pair, taken together, form the seventh longest river in the world.

name: Jadeite
description_short:
Pyroxene Group - Clinopyroxene Subgroup.
Jadeite-Kosmochlor Series.

Rarely found as euhedral crystals, most commonly as the monomineralic metamorphic rock jadeitite which is often used as an ornamental gem and carving material as which it is known ...
colour: Apple-green, greenish white, purplish blue, blue-green, violet, white, black
aboutname: Named after <m>jade</m>, which is frequently composed of jadeite. <m>Jade</m> is named after the Spanish "piedra de ijada", "stone of the flank", as it was thought to cure kidney pains.
twinning: Single and lamellar twinning on {100} and {001}
commentcolor:
White when pure.
The green color of Guatemala jadeite jade, mainly composed of jadeite, is caused by the electronic transition between bands of Fe3+. Fe content is proportional to the change of color in a particular range. The gray characteristics of the gray-green jadeite jade are related to Fe2+ and clay minerals. The black jadeite jade shows a black color due to the internal jadeite and metal mineral inclusions but appear green under transmitted light. The color of jadeite jade, mainly composed of omphacite, is generally attributed to Cr3+ and Fe3+, among which the blue features of blue-green jadeite jade are attributed to the presence of Fe2+ and Mn2+.[[1]]
Mineral chemistry studies show that the color of jadeite jade is associated with the content of chromogenic elements. For instance, a large amount of Cr3+ causes the jadeite jade to be dark green, while minor Cr3+ cause jade to appear an emerald-green color. Cr3+ was derived from the metasomatic chromium spinel, chromite, and sodium chromite pyroxene in serpentinites. The Fe causes jadeite to be dark green or gray, and may be associated with omphacite that is rich in Ca, Fe, and Mg but does not contain Cr3+ . Nearly all iron is presented as ferric (trivalent) iron in white jadeite jade, while in black jadeite jade, half is ferrous (divalent) and half is ferric (trivalent). In the green jadeite jade, the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio ranges from 0.1 to 0.2.[[1]] The chromite composition in Myanmar jadeite jade is characterized by a high concentration of Cr2O3 (46.18–67.11 wt.%), along with a notable abundance of MnO (1.68–9.13 wt.%) compared with the chromite from the adjacent Myitkyina peridotite. The diffusion of chromium (Cr) and manganese (Mn) in jadeite jade is accomplished by accompanying the metamorphic pathway of Mn-rich chromite → kosmochlor → chromian jadeite → jadeite. In the subsequent phase of jadeite jade formation, the chromium-rich omphacite veins generated by the fluid enriched in Ca and Mg along the fissures of kosmochlor and chromian jadeite play a role in the physical diffusion of Cr and Mn. The emergence of the lavender hue in jadeite is contingent upon the presence of a relatively high concentration of Mn (approximately 100–1000 ppmw) and the simultaneous absence of Cr, which would otherwise serve as a more effective chromophore (no Cr or up to a dozen ppmw). The distinctive Mn-rich chromite represents the primary origin of the chromogenic element Cr (green) and, perhaps more notably, an overlooked provider of Mn (lavender) in Myanmar jadeite jade. [[2]] Utilizing a suite of analytical techniques including Raman spectroscopy and XRD, the samples were classified into two distinct phases: a jadeite-dominant “jadeite-phase” and an omphacite-rich “omphacite-phase”. The blue coloration is mainly attributed to crystal field transitions controlled primarily by Fe3+ (peak at 381 nm), with a secondary contribution from Fe2+→Ti4+ charge transfer, while the color intensity shows a positive correlation with Fe and Ti concentrations. The jadeite phase crystallized under high-pressure, low-temperature conditions, whereas the omphacite phase formed through metasomatic replacement by Mg-Ca-Fe-enriched fluids, involving coupled substitutions of Na+ by Ca2+ and Al3+ by Mg2+/Fe2+. Fluid inclusion analyses revealed the presence of CH4 and CO, confirming a reducing environment and supporting its classification as a P-type jadeitite formed from Na-Al-Si-rich fluids derived from Na-Al-Si-rich fluids in subduction zones. [[3]]

name: Jamesonite
mindat_formula_note: May contain minor Bi.
description_short:
Benavidesite-Jamesonite Series.

Easily confused with boulangerite with which it may be intergrown. As in boulangerite and, e.g., robinsonite and zinkenite, the structure contains interconnected SbS5 groups exhibiting the SnS archetype.
otheroccurrence: Late stage hydrothermal mineral formed at moderate to low temperature.
aboutname: Named in honor of Robert Jameson (11 July 1774, Leith, Scotland – 19 April 1854, Edinburgh, Scotland), naturalist and mineralogist.  He was Professor of Natural History at the University of Edinburgh for fifty years.
other: Raman bands connected with stretching and bending of the SbS<sub>3</sub> groups are between 350 and 180 cm<sup>-1</sup>
morphology: Acicular to fibrous [001] and striated parallel [001]. In felted masses of needles. Also massive, fibrous to columnar; radial or plumose at times. In subparallel aggregates of prismatic crystals, forming a columnar mass.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Distinct.

name: Jeffreyite
tlform: Micaceous
occurrence: Rodingitized granite dyke
aboutname: Named by Joel D. Grice and George W. Robinson in 1984 after the Jeffrey Mine, the type locality.
other: Not readily soluble in 20% HCl.
morphology:
Thin pseudotetragonal plates.  The observed forms on the plates include the pinacoid
{001} and a prism, [110].
type_specimen_store: Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Canada, 48740.
commentdense: methylene iodide - methyl alcohol solution at 21C
commentcolor: Originally found with a brownish cast due to a fungal coating.

name: Jinshajiangite
description_short:
The Fe-analogue of perraultite.
Closely related to bafertisite, cámaraite, and emmerichite.
occurrence: Albitite dike
aboutname: Named by Hong Wenxing and Fu  Pingqiu in 1982 for the Yangtze river (Chinese, Jinsha Jiang), which is south of the mineral's type locality.
twinning: Pseudo-monoclinic due to nanoscale polysynthetic twinning on the (001) composition plane.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = light golden yellow; Y = brownish yellow; Z = brownish red.
type_specimen_store: Institute of Geochemistry, Academia Sinica, Guiyang, Guizhou Province, the People's Republic of China.
commentdense: Very much higher than observed or calculated. ICDD 35-722
commentcrystal: Cell data from Jin et al. (2018).  SG C2/m (Sokolova et al., 2009), not P2/m, as originally reported (original cell parameters: 5.350, 6.909, 20.96 A, 99.83°). As pointed out by Sokolova et al. (2009), the structure determination of Rastsvetaeva et al. (2008) is erroneous in several points.

name: Johnsomervilleite
mindat_formula_note:
Originally given, i.a., as
{Ca}{Na<sub>6</sub>[]<sub>2</sub>}{Ca<sub>6</sub>Na<sub>2</sub>}{(Fe<sup>2+</sup>,Mg,Mn<sup>2+</sup>)<sub>43</sub>}(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>36</sub>; the above IMA formula is wrong
description_short: Fillowite Group. The Ca analogue of chladniite and fillowite. Also the Fe analogue of galileiite.
tlform: Gray to pink greasy grains up to 4 mm in size.
occurrence: Granite pegmatite pods in kyanite-sillimanite gneiss.
otheroccurrence: Granite pegmatite
colour: Dark brown to blackish gray, pitch-black
aboutname: Named in 1980 by A. Livingstone in memory of Mr John M. Somerville (1908-1978) who presented to the Royal Scottish Museum a specimen of garnet-quartz rock, which contained the new species.
other: Soluble in 20% HCl, H2SO4, and HNO3.
streak: Light brown; gray-brown with an olive tint

Anomalously biaxial: α = 1.655 β = ∼1.655 γ = n.d. 2V(meas.) = 10◦
n = 1.646(1) (metamict)
uv: Not fluorescent with LW or SW UV.
type_specimen_store: Scottish Mineral Collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh.

name: Jouravskite
description_short: Ettringite Group.

occurrence: Oxidized zone of a manganese deposit.
colour: Bright yellow, greenish yellow to greenish orange, pink
aboutname: Named in 1965 by Christophe Gaudefroy and François Permingeat in honor of Georges Jouravsky (1896, Warsaw, Poland – 1964), Chief Geologist, Geological Survey of Morocco, for his work on the mineral deposits of Morocco.
morphology: Prism <mi>{10_10}</mi> and dipyramid <mi>{10_12}</mi>.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Barely perceptible.
opticalcomments: The interference colors are very abnormal, alternating shades of green and russet being observed in favorable sections up to the 17th order, rather than the ordinary colors.
ir: the spectrum contains specific bands of Mn<sup>4+</sup>(OH)<sub>6</sub> octahedra, CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup> and SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>anions, and H<sub>2</sub>O molecules
type_specimen_store:
Natural History Museum, Paris, France, 175.152.
National School of Mines, Paris, France.

name: Kaersutite
mindat_formula_note:
The Kaersutite group minerals are <sup>W</sup>O<sup>2-</sup> dominant amphiboles defined with: 
<sup>A</sup>(Na+K+2Ca)> 0.5 apfu,
<sup>B</sup>: Ca dominant
<sup>C</sup>Ti > 0.5 apfu and 
<sup>W</sup>O > 1.0 apfu  

Kaersutite is defined with: 
A position: Na dominant
C<sup>2+</sup> position: Mg dominant
C<sup>3+</sup> position: Al dominant
description_short: The chemical formula of kaersutite has been changed in the 2012 amphibole nomenclature from {Na}{Ca^2}{Mg^4Ti}(Al^2Si^6O^22)(OH)O  to {Na}{Ca^2}{Mg^3AlTi}(Al^2Si^6O^22)O^2  thus adding WO > 1.0 apfu to the CTi > 0.5 apfu requirement to the definition o...

opticalpleochorismdesc: X = yellow, yellow-brown; Y = red, red-brown; Z = deep brown, dark red-brown

name: Kalistrontite

morphology: Platy crystals
type_specimen_store: Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, 1397/1; A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 69943.

name: Kaňkite

Related to and easily confused with hilarionite. Compare 'UM1979-03-AsO:Fe' and 'UM1979-04-AsO:Fe'.
Often associated with bukovskýite.

Crystal structure not yet solved, as the mineral decomposes in vacuum to Fe2(AsO4)(HAsO4)(OH)(H2O), that equals F...

Charles University, Prague, Czech Republic, 20135.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 144939.

name: Karpinskite

Possibly a Ni-rich antigorite or a Ni-rich interstratification of a talc-group mineral and a chlorite-group mineral.

Status needs to be confirmed.

name: Keckite

A member of the jahnsite group which contains trivalent iron not only at the C site but also at the B site.

Note: According to Hochleitner & Fehr (2010), keckite from Hagendorf forms golden-yellow to orange fibrous crusts which are intimately associ...

morphology: Tightly clustered bladed to stout crystals arranged in subparallel groups.

name: Kentrolite

Kentrolite-Melanotekite Series.

Compare also Unnamed (Ba-Pb-analogue of kentrolite).

A synthetic aluminium analogue is known.

morphology: Prismatic to equant. Isolated crystals or rosettes, sheaflike groups, massive.

X= bright yellowish pink

name: Khanneshite

occurrence: Disseminated in fine-grained carbonatite.
aboutname: After the type locality at Khanneshin, Afghanistan.

name: Kipushite
description_short:
The phosphate analogue of philipsburgite ("partial" analogy) and fully phosphate analogue of goldhillite. 
Chemically related to veszelyite and zincolibethenite.

The Zn site, of tetrahedral coordination, in the kipushite-philipsburgite solid soluti...
tlform: More or less elongated aggregates of prisms up to 3 mm or rarely as isolated prismatic crystals up to 0.3 mm.
aboutname: Named in 1985 by Paul Piret, Michel Deliens and Jacqueline Piret Meunier, after the type locality at the Kipushi Mine (Prince Léopold Mine), Kipushi, Lubumbashi (Elizabethville), Katanga (Shaba), Congo (Zaïre).
morphology: Elongated aggregates of prisms; prismatic crystals of which lateral faces are uneven and rounded. Prisms {111} are elongate along <mi>[10_1]</mi> and terminated principally by (100). Forms present: {102}, <mi>{01_2}</mi> and <mi>{11_1}</mi>.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = colorless; Y = blue; Z = bright blue.
type_specimen_store: A holotype specimen of kipushite is registered in the mineralogical collection of the Musee royal de I'Afrique centrale (No. 14.026).

name: Klyuchevskite
tlform: Crystals in orientated aggregates, acicular, elongate [010], up to 0.1 mm long and not thicker than 0.01 mm.
occurrence: Fumarole
aboutname: Named for the Klyuchevskaya group of volcanoes, of which the type locality Tolbachik volcano is one.
other:
Readily soluble in H2O and weak acid (1:20).
Hydrates in air in one week. Stable in air up to 625°C.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = olive-green, Y = green, Z = dark olive-green
type_specimen_store: Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, Russia, 979/1.

name: Kolbeckite
description_short:
Metavariscite Group. The P analogue of bonacinaite.

A very rare secondary mineral in phosphate deposits and some hydrothermal veins.
otheroccurrence: Phosphate deposits; some hydrothermal metallic veins.
colour: Colourless, light yellow; when impure: cyan-blue, blue-gray, apple-green
aboutname: Named in honor of Dr. Friedrich Ludwig Wilhelm Kolbeck  (12 January 1860, Dresden - 6 February 1943, Freiberg), German mineralogist, Mining Academy, Freiberg, Germany.
other: Decomposed by acids.
morphology: Crystals commonly short prismatic [001], with prominent {110}, {011}, and less prominent {010}, {101}, and {130}. Platy crystals in radiating aggregates less common.
twinning: On {100}, common. May exhibit diagonal sutures on {001}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Only in coloured material.
type_specimen_store: Mining Academy, Freiberg, Germany: #50268. U.S. National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA: #10632.

name: Koninckite
occurrence: Secondary mineral in phosphatic sedimentary rocks.
colour: Yellow; light yellow to colourless in transmitted light
aboutname: Named by Giuseppe Cesàro in 1883 in honor of Laurent-Guillaume de Koninck (3 May 1809, Leuven, Belgium – 16 July 1887, Liège, Belgium), Professor at the University of Liège, Belgium. He identified hundreds of new paleontological Paleozoic species. He received the Wollaston medal in 1875.
other: Readily soluble in hot HCl or HNO3.
morphology: Small spherical aggregates of radiating needles.
opticalcomments: Uniaxial (+), may be biaxial to nearly isotropic.
type_specimen_store: University of Liège, Liège, Belgium, 9251–9257.

name: Kostovite
tlform: Small grains and short veinlets in tennantite and chalcopyrite. Equant to slightly elongated grains, 20 to 50 µm in diameter. Outlines in polished sections are usually polygonal, seldom rounded.
occurrence: Replacement copper deposit
aboutname: Named by Georgy Terziev in 1966 in honor of Ivan Kostov Nikolov (Иван Костов Николов) (24 December 1913, Plovdiv, Bulgaria - 31 March 2004, Sofia, Bulgaria), geologist, mineralogist and crystallographer at Sofia University and earlier at London Imperial College. He was President of the International Mineralogical Association from 1982–1986.
other: Tests with HNO3 (1:1), HCl (1:1), KCN, KOH, HgCl2, and FeCl3 are negative.
morphology: 20-50 micron equant to slightly elongated grains.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
light creamy white (lighter) 
to light creamy brownish (darker)
opticalanisotropism: Distinct: pinkish grayish brown, yellowish gray, brownish gray and reddish hues.
type_specimen_store:
Geological Institute, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Bulgaria.
University of Sophia, Bulgaria.
Institute of Geology of Ore Deposits, Petrography, Mineralogy and Geochemistry (IGEM), Moscow, Russia.
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia.

name: Krausite
occurrence: Secondary mineral in sulfate bearing chert.
otheroccurrence: Oxidation material on pyrite bearing dumps.
colour: Pale lemon yellow, yellowish green, gray; colourless to pale yellow in transmitted light.
aboutname: Named by William F. Foshag in honor of Dr. Edward Henry Kraus [December 1, 1875 Syracuse, New York, USA - February 3, 1973 Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA], American mineralogist, University of Michigan.
other: Slowly decomposed by water leaving ferric oxide.
morphology: Commonly earthy to finely granular. Crystals may be short prismatic [001]; also equant to tabular {001}. Larger crystals tend to be rough and opaque, smaller ones brilliant and clear.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = Colourless
Y = Pale yellow
Z = Pale yellow
type_specimen_store: Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC

name: Krutovite
description_short: Probably a member of the Pyrite Group (Strunz and Nickel, 2001). Synthetic NiAs^2 has a pyrite-type structure (Munson, 1968).
tlform: grains intergrown with ore
aboutname: Named in honor of Georgy Alekseevich Krutov (Георгий Алексеевич Крутов) (24 April 1902, Lytinko, Solnechnogorsk, Moscow, Russian Empire - 11 December 1989, USSR), Professor, Department of Mineralogy, Moscow State University. He specialized in the field of geology, mineralogy, and geochemistry of nickel-cobalt. He was awarded the 1961 A.E. Fersman prize.
opticalcolour: bright white with rose tint, compared to nickel skutterudite
type_specimen_store:
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Science, Moscow, Russia.
Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, Russia.
National Museum, Prague, Czech Republic, 61625.

name: Kuramite
description_short:
Stannite group.

Compare also the varieties, stannoenargite and stannoluzonite, and other Cu-Sn sulphides: mohite, erazoite and 'UM1981-18-S:CuSn'.
tlform: Inclusions, 5-80 microns in diameter within goldfieldite.
occurrence: Gold-sulfide deposit.
aboutname: Named in 1979 by V.A. Kovalenker, T.L. Evstigneeva, N.V. Troneva, and L.N. Vyal´sov for the Kuramin (Qurama) Mountains where the type locality is found.
type_specimen_store:
1) A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia.
2) Institute of Ore Deposits (IGEM), Moscow, Russia.

name: Kuznetsovite
mindat_formula_note: formula may instead be [Hg<sub>3</sub>]<sup>4+</sup>[AsO<sub>4</sub>]Cl, where the three Hg atoms occur as a polyatomic cluster.
description_short: According to Borisov et al. (2003) it might be possible that kuzetsovite - as terlinguaite - contains the [Hg3]4+ polycation.
occurrence: Oxidation zone of cinnabar bearing mercury deposits.
aboutname: Named in honor of Valery Alekseevich Kuznetsov (Валерий Алексеевич Кузнецов) (12 April 1906, Nikolsk, Vologda province, Russian Empire - 4 August 1985, Novosibirsk, USSR), Russian geologist. He was an expert in magmatism and endogenous ore formation (mercury and non-ferrous metals) and discovered the Aktash and Peza mercury deposits (Gorny Altai).
other: The mineral is blackened by KOH, decolorized and decomposed by HCl, does not react with 1:1 HNO3.
opticalcomments: RI considerably higher than that of the "highest liquid of the standard set"
type_specimen_store: Central Siberian Geological Museum, Inst. of Geology, Novosibirsk, Russia.
commentdense: Some native mercury in measured SG

name: Laihunite
description_short:
Olivine Group.
Corresponds to a strongly oxidised, vacancy-bearing fayalite.
The "polytypes" 1M, 2M and 3M seem to be distinct intermediate phases (between laihunite and fayalite) with defined stoichiometries (Xu et al., 2014): 2M has a 1:1 ratio and...
occurrence: Precambrian metamorphic iron deposit.
cleavage: Perfect on {100} and {010}, two less perfect ~ perpendicular to {100} and intersecting at 60 degrees
aboutname: After the type locality, Laihe Fe deposit, near Laihe village, Qianshan District, Anshan Prefecture, Liaoning Province, China.
other: Moderately magnetic and electromagnetic
opticalpleochorismdesc: Gray to grayish black.
type_specimen_store: n.d.

name: Langite
description_short:
A secondary copper mineral formed from the oxidation of copper sulphides. 
Often forms pseudohexagonal twins. Some habits are easily confused with posnjakite and wroewolfeite. 

May be altered to brochantite.
aboutname: Named by Nevil Story-Maskelyne in 1864 in honor of Victor von Lang (2 March 1838, Vienna, Austrian Empire - 3 July 1921, Vienna, Austria), physicist and crystallographer, Professor of Physics, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria. At the time of the mineral's discovery von Lang was employed at the British Museum (1862-1864). He became a pioneer of crystal physics.
other: Insoluble in water. Readily soluble in acids or ammonia.
morphology: Crystals small; equant or elongated [100]; lath-like, scales; fibro-lamellar crusts; earthy.
twinning: Common on {110}. Repeated in part as aggregates flattened {001} rendering star-shaped twins.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = c = Light yellowish green
Y = b = Blue-green
Z = a = Sky-blue
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, Vienna, Austria, A.a.4353.
commentdense: Measured values on Cornwall material.

name: Larnite
description_short:
The high-temperature, monoclinic polymorph of Calcio-Olivine.

Larnite crystallizes at high temperatures. It occurs in limestones or chalk zones in contact with molten basaltic rocks. Larnite is stable in the range of 520° to 670° C; otherwise, it is...
occurrence: contact metamorphic terranes involving sedimentary carbonate rocks.
otheroccurrence: Metamorphosed sedimentary carbonate formations in contact with basaltic rocks.
colour: White, gray, colorless in thin section
aboutname: The material was first identified from Portland cement and named belite by Törneborn in 1897. The natural substance, a mineral, was named by Tilley in 1929 after the town of Larne, North Ireland, UK.  The town is near the type locality of Scawt Hill.

name: Laurite
description_short: Pyrite Group. Erlichmanite-Laurite Series. Compare 'UM1965-11-S:IrOsRu', 'UM1978-15-S:IrOsPtRhRu' and 'UM1978-18-S:IrOsRu'.
otheroccurrence: Ultramafic intrusives and derived placers.
aboutname: Named for Laura Louisa Henrietta Rupe Joy (1833-1929). The mineral was named by Wöhler in 1866 as a compliment to the wife of his personal friend, Charles Arad Joy, American chemist at Columbia University in New York City, USA.
morphology: octahedral, cubic, and pyritohedral crystals, rounded grains

name: Lazarenkoite
tlform: Fibrous incrustations.
occurrence: In oxidation zone of a cobalt-nickel ore deposit, where it is an oxidation product of skutterudite (smaltine) and löllingite.
aboutname: In honour of Academician Evgenii Konstantinovich Lazarenko (1912–1979), mineralogist, Lvov University, Lvov, Ukraine.
other: Insoluble in water, but easily dissolved in dilute, cold HCl.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = pale yellow; Y = pale brown; Z = rose-brown

name: Lehnerite
description_short: Meta-autunite Group.
cleavage: Perfect on {010}; good on {101}; less good on <mi>{_101}</mi>; poor on {100}.
aboutname:
Named by Prof. Dr. A. Mücke (1988) for a new mineral from the Hagendorf pegmatite, Germany. It was named in honour of Ferdinand Lehner (15 February 1868 – 4 December 1943), German mineral collector, of Pleystein, Bavaria, Germany. He was one of the first collectors of Hagendorf minerals. 

The name lehnerite had also been introduced by F. Müllbauer (1925) for another mineral, later discredited and shown to be identical with ludlamite.
other: Radioactive
morphology: As thin pseudotetragonal crystals
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = Y = light yellow; Z = yellow.

name: Leonite
description_short:
The magnesium analogue of Mereiterite.
May occur as a dehydration product of Picromerite.
occurrence: Rock salt deposit.
otheroccurrence: Oceanic potash deposits.
aboutname: Named in honor of Leo Balthasar Leberecht Strippelmann (26 July 1826, Kassel, Germany - 17 June 1892, Bad Oeynhausen, Germany), Director of the salt works at Westeregeln, Germany.
other: Soluble in H2O, taste slightly bitter. Turns white upon alteration/dehydration to picromerite if left exposed.
morphology: Crystals tabular {100} and elongated [001]. Usually anhedral.
twinning: On {100} - artificial crystals. Lamellar twinning observable under magnification.
type_specimen_store: No designated type specimen.
thermalbehaviour: Dehydration occurs at 410-420 K and leads to langeinite and arcanite.

name: Hydroxycalcioroméite
mindat_formula_note: Ca may be replaced by Na, Fe, Mg and H<sub>2</sub>O. Sb may be replaced by Si.
description_short: Previously known as lewisite, the crystal structure of this mineral was initially determined by Rouse et al.. (1998) and later by Zubkova et al.. (2000). The type sample for "lewisite" was described by Hussak & Prior (1895) and became the type specimen...
otheroccurrence: Sulfosalt veins
colour: Amber yellow, golden yellow, yellow brown
aboutname: Originally described as lewisite by Hussak & Prior (1895). Renamed as Ti-bearing roméite in 2007 in anticipation of systematic names replacing trivial names. Renamed according to the nomenclature of the pyrochlore supergroup as hydroxycalcioroméite.
morphology: Octahedral
ima_history:
Pre-IMA, grandfathered (as lewisite).
2007: Discredited as Ti-bearing roméite (Burke 2007).
2010: Redefined and renamed by IMA as hydroxycalcioroméite (IMA special procedure 2010)

name: Lillianite
mindat_formula_note: May be Ag-free, and may contain Se replacing S.
description_short: Gustavite-Lillianite Series.
cleavage: {100} very good, {010} less so, probably also {001}.
aboutname: Named by Keller in 1889 for the supposed occurrence in the Lillian Mine, Printerboy Hill, Leadville, Colorado, USA. Much doubt has been generated concerning lillianite from the original locality. Gustav Flink made a crystallographic study of "lillianite" in 1910, but Berry (1940) suggested that Flink's data could be identical to that of galenobismuthite, but with "c" doubled and concluded, based on XRD studies that "lillianite" was heterogeneous. Paul Ramdohr (1969) wrote - "Normally not stable at low temperature and actually broken down into a mixture of Pb- and Bi-sulfides, mostly galena and galenobismuthite [and acanthite], but sometimes intact." Ramdohr mentioned that similar heterogeneity was observed from other occurrences. An occurrence at Iilijärvi [Jilijärvi], Finland was believed by Ramdohr to have authentic lillianite, that is not transformed into a mixture over time. Syritso and Senerova (1964) studied the lillianite problem and provided data which "confirmed and enlarged" knowledge of the mineral from Finland. Otto and Strunz (1968) synthesized a homogeneous mineral with lillianite's formula and properties.
morphology: Rare, prismatic [001]. Usually massive granular; also radiating fibrous [001].
commentcrystal: Space group Bbmm (non-standard setting). Silver-free lillianite from Vulcano has: 13.567(1), 20.655(2), 4.1216(4) Å (Pinto et al., 2006).

name: Liottite
tlform: Flattened hexagonal prisms up to 1 cm in diameter.
occurrence: In cavities of ejected blocks in a pumice deposit.
aboutname: Named in 1977 by S. Merlino and P. Orlandi in honor of Luciano Liotti (1932 - 2006), a mineral collector who donated the material in which liottite was first found.
type_specimen_store:
University of Pisa, Pisa, Italy, 3209.
University of Modena, Modena, Italy.
commentdense: Measured in a mixture of bromoform and acetone.
commentcrystal: Cell parameters from Ballirano et al. (1996).

name: Lithosite
tlform: Irregular grains 1-3 mm in size.
occurrence: Occurs in veins of ultra-agpaitic pegmatite cutting nepheline syenites (rischorrites).
colour: Colourless; bright pink after X-ray irradiation for at least 8 months
aboutname: The name is from the Greek lithos meaning stone, because it is composed of the most abundant components in the Earth's crust.
other:
Easily decomposed by cold 10% HCl.

Under X-rays it acquires a bright rose color, which persists for at least 8 months; it is then pleochroic with X and Y colorless, Z bright rose.
opticalpleochorismdesc: After X-ray exposure: X and Y colorless, Z bright rose.
opticalcomments: Y near a, X near c.
ir: The infra-red spectrum indicates the presence of molecular water.
type_specimen_store:
Geology Museum, Kola Branch, Academy of Sciences, Apatity, Russia.
Mineralogical Museum, St. Petersburg University, St. Petersburg, Russia, 17073.
Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, Russia, 1633/1.
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 82751.
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1994,14.
