name: Loparite
tlform: As cubic or octahedral crystals, to 2 cm, which may be highly modified; overgrowing perovskite and massive
aboutname: From the Russian name for the Saami or Lapp people, Lopar', the indigenous people of the Kola peninsula. It was first reported from the <l id='2697'>Lovozero massif, Kola, Russia</l> by W. Ramsay in 1890 as " new mineral no.1".  The name was changed from loparite to loparite-(Ce) by the IMA in 1987, although Mitchell et al. (2000) argue that "given the disordered distribution of cations in the structure of this mineral, the use of Levinson modifiers to indicate the dominant REE species is clearly unwarranted."
opticalcomments:
dark brown in thin section, may be zoned;
anomalously anisotropic
opticalcolour: light gray or white with a creamy tinge
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 21043–21045.
ima_history: Renamed as loparite-(Ce) by IMA in 1987, special procedure. Name changed back to loparite by IMA in 2024 by procedure 2024-4.1

name: Lovdarite
tlform: Massive rims, with a thickness of 1-2 cm, on chkalovite grains and crystals.  Aggregates are porcelanous or have a fibrous-radial structure.  Also as druses of prismatic crystals 1-2 mm long.
occurrence: Alkaline pegmatite. A late stage hydrothermal mineral, originating after natrolite and replacing chkalovite.
cleavage: Distinct along (100), (010) and (001) and weak along (110).
opticalextinction: X = a; Y = b; Z = c.
aboutname: Named by Y.P. Men'shikov, A.P. Denisov, Y.I. Uspenskaya, and E.A. Lipatova in 1973. The name derives from the Russian 'dar Lovozera', meaning 'a gift from Lovozero', Lovozero being the type locality.
other:
Readily melting in the blowpipe to a colorless glass.
Insoluble in 4% HCl, 6% HNO3, and 5% H2SO4, at 20 C.
morphology: Prismatic crystals.
ir: The infrared spectrum indicates the presence of hydroxyl and H2O groups.
type_specimen_store:
National School of Mines, Paris, France.
Geology Museum, Kola Branch, Academy of Sciences, Apatity, Russia, 3208.
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia.
thermalbehaviour:
When heated, it loses water steadily to about 400°; about 10%. After heating to 300°, water is resorbed at room temperature in about 2 hours.
The DTA curve shows a double endothermic effect at about 250° and endothermic effects at 390° and 640°.
commentcrystal: Space group Pma2. Distinct domains and various degrees of structural disorder are present (Merlino 1990).

name: Ludwigite
description_short:
Ludwigite Group. Ludwigite-Vonsenite Series. The magnesium analogue of Vonsenite and Marinaite.

A high-temperature mineral occurring in contact metamorphic deposits.
otheroccurrence: In contact metamorphic deposits as high-temperature phases.
aboutname: Named in honor of Ernst Ludwig (19 January 1842, Freudenthal, Austrian Silesia - 14 October 1915 Vienna), Professor of Chemistry, University of Vienna. He worked in the areas of mineral chemistry, mineral water analysis, food chemistry and forensic chemistry. He first analyzed the material.
other:
Slowly soluble in acids.

Alters to Limonite.
morphology: Crystals prismatic [001], rare, with a rhombic cross-section and lacking terminal faces. As fibrous masses, radiating to dense felted aggregates; sheaf-like aggregates; rosettes of needle-like crystals. Granular.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = Dark green
Y = Dark green
Z = Dark reddish brown (may be opaque)
opticalanisotropism: yellowish brown to bluish violet gray.
opticalbireflectance: Pinkish gray to dark greenish gray
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, Vienna, Austria, A.a.6315.

name: Leucite
description_short: Leucite is common in some volcanic rocks in which it crystallises with a cubic crystal structure at high temperature (ca. 900°C). Upon cooling to 700-600°C, it transforms into a tetragonal modification which is stable at room temperature and forms char...
otheroccurrence: Potassium rich mafic and ultramafic lavas.
aboutname: From the Greek "leucos," for white, in allusion to its common colour.
morphology: Euhedral pseudocubic crystals showing {112}.  Other forms include {100}, {110}.
twinning: Common, repeated on {110} and {101}, from two complex displacive phase transformations during cooling.
type_specimen_store: Technische Universität, Bergakademie, Freiberg, Germany, numbers 100206, 100207, 100210, 100212, 100216.

name: Ferri-katophorite
mindat_formula_note:
The katophorite group minerals are sodium-calcium amphiboles defined with <sup>A</sup>(Na+K+2Ca)> 0.5 apfu and 0.5 apfu < <sup>C</sup>(Al+Fe<sup>3+</sup>+2Ti) < 1.5 apfu.

Ferri-katophorite is defined with 

A position: Na dominant
C<sup>2+</sup> position: Mg dominant
C<sup>3+</sup> position: Fe dominant
W position: (OH) dominant
description_short: The kataphorite group species with Mg and Fe3+>Al in the C position was named magnesio-ferrikatophorite in the 1978 and 1997 amphibole nomenclatures. The katophorite group minerals were redefined in the 2012 amphibole nomenclature, renaming the Mg, Fe3...
type_specimen_store: No designated type specimen.

name: Pyrosmalite-(Mn)
description_short:
Pyrosmalite-(Fe)-Pyrosmalite-(Mn) Series.
Chemically very similar to friedelite (monoclinic-pseudorhombohedral) and mcgillite.
tlform: Granular veinlets in franklinite ore. Individual grains to about 0.3 mm.
colour: Blackish green, pistachio-green, liver-brown, brown, gray
aboutname: Originally named manganpyrosmalite by By Clifford Frondel and Lawson H. Bauer for its manganese-dominant composition relative to the original pyrosmalite. Both pyrosmalites were later given suffixes, -(Mn) or -(Fe) by the IMA to indicated cation dominance in the chemical formula
morphology: Thick prismatic hexagonal crystals, to 4 cm, in subparallel groups.
opticalpleochorismdesc: O = greenish yellow; E = colorless.
type_specimen_store: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 104214, 104215; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, C6216.

name: Axinite-(Mn)
description_short: Axinite Group. Axinite-(Fe)-Axinite-(Mn) Series, and the Axinite-(Mn)-Tinzenite Series. The Mn2+ analogue of Axinite-(Fe) and Axinite-(Mg).
tlform: Yellow bladed crystals and yellow granular masses
occurrence: Zinc-Iron polymetalic metamorphosed deposit hosted by marble
aboutname: Iron-rich axinite was named in 1797 by Rene Just Haüy from the Greek αξίνα ("axina") for "axe", in allusion to the common habit of its crystals. Manganese-dominant axinite was reported by Frederick A. Genth in 1891, who noted that Franklin, New Jersey axinite had the highest known manganese contents. Robert Mauzelius also found manganese-dominant axinite in 1895. Manganaxinite was formally named by Waldemar T. Schaller in 1909 and manganaxinit was used by J. Fromme in 1909, both mentioning Franklin, New Jersey. Manganoaxinite was used by Schaller in 1911, but Schaller did not provide a species description as his research material was "destroyed by fire." Manganaxinite was used by Gregori Aminoff in 1919 when referring to specimens from Franklin, New Jersey, USA and a complete species description was finally made by Charles Palache in 1929 and was expanded by Palache (1935), both based on Franklin, New Jersey specimens. Renamed with suffix "-(Mn)" by IMA in 2007.
morphology: Bladed crystals, also compact granular
opticalpleochorismdesc: Yellow-colorless to amber-pale yellow.
uv: Magenta-red (SW UV) (Franklin, NJ massive material only).
ima_history: Renamed by the CNMNC IMA in 2007 from manganaxinite to Axinite-(Mn) (IMA 07-C).

name: Macquartite
tlform: Crystals can reach 1 mm long
aboutname: Named in 1980 by Sidney A. Williams and Marjorie Duggan in honor of Louis Charles Henri Macquart [5 December 1745 Reims, France - 12 July 1808 Paris, France], French medical doctor (l'école Centrale de Seine et Marne), chemist, and mineralogist. Macquart's books mostly contain medical information, but his Essais ou Recueil de mémoires sur plusieurs points de minéralogie with 580 pages + 7 plates in 1789 described the mines and minerals of Berosovsk and other topics. Macquart wrote a research article with Louis Vauquelin and they reported that the future "crocoite" contained lead peroxide, iron, and aluminum. Johan Bindheim re-analyzed the future "crocoite" and reported it contained molybdic acid, nickel, cobalt, iron, and copper. In 1798, Vauquelin re-analyzed the mineral, using the specimens supplied by Macquart and discovered they contained a new element, which Vauquelin named chromium. Macquartite was named in acknowledgement of Macquart's role in the chain leading to the discovery of chromium as a new element. Vaquelin's answer to the uncertainty of crocoite's true composition, unfortunately does not document Macquart's chemical participation in the discovery of chromium. Macquart was curator of the mineral collection at Fontainebleau, Seine-et-Marne.
other: Decomposed by concentrated HCl.
morphology: Euhedral crystals in quartz
type_specimen_store: The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1980,542; University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, R18726.

name: Manganotychite
description_short: Northupite Group. The manganese analogue of Tychite and Ferrotychite.
tlform: Irregular grains up to 1 cm across and in massive aggregates up to 5 cm.
occurrence: Core of hyperalkalic pegmatitic veins.
aboutname: Named in 1990 by Alexander Petrovich Khomyakov, Aleksander Yur'evich Bakhchisaraitsev, and A. V. Martynova from Greek τυχή, "tyche", luck or chance, because the first and only one of the last ten crystals of a stock of about 5000 crystals of northupite being examined by Penfield and Jamieson were tychite, plus the prefix "MANGANO-" in allusion to the dominance of manganese in the composition.
other: Weakly magnetic; slightly soluble in H2O, forming a brown coating.
type_specimen_store: Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, 2023/1; Geology Museum, Kola Branch, Academy of Sciences, Apatity; A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, p545/2.
commentcolor: On fresh surfaces

name: Magnussonite
mindat_formula_note: Initial (Moore & Araki, 1979) structural formula: Mn<sup>2+</sup><sub>18</sub>[As<sup>3+</sup><sub>6</sub>Mn<sup>+</sup>O<sub>18</sub>]<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub> but it is not necessarily confirmed (or disproved) by further studies
description_short:
Related to UM1984-09-AsO:ClHMn. Also said to be the OH analogue of brattforsite, although with a higher symmetry.

Fluorite structure derivative.

Magnussonite is / may be the only mineral with univalent manganese. Indeed, in its structure, octahed...
tlform: As finegrained encrustations in fissures in hausmannite impregnated dolomite or in finegrained hematite.
otheroccurrence: Irregular masses to several cm carbonate-hosted zinc oress.
colour: Emerald- or grass-green; bluish green; pale green, olive-green. greenish-tan
aboutname: Named in 1956 by Olof Erik Gabrielson in honor of Professor Nils Harald Magnusson [January 15, 1890 Filipstad, Sweden - September 28, 1976 Stockholm, Sweden], Director of the Geological Survey of Sweden and professor of geology at the Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm, Sweden for his contributions to the geology and mineralogy of Långban.

name: Maldonite
description_short:
Thermodynamically unstable below ~116°C, but is found in a metastable state in nature.
Maldonite is the only stable binary alloy phase in the system Au-Bi.
occurrence: Gold reef associated with Devonian granites
aboutname: Named for the type locality, Maldon (Australia).
morphology: octahedral crystals or massive
commentcolor: Tarnishes to black

name: Mansfieldite
description_short: Mansfieldite-Scorodite Series. The aluminium analogue of Scorodite.
cleavage: On {201}, imperfect; on {001} and {100} in traces.
colour: White, light gray; colourless in transmitted light.
aboutname: After George R. Mansfield (1875-1947), American geologist, U.S. Geological Survey.
morphology: Porous, cellular masses and crusts of spherulitic fibers.
commentdense: Measured value on Hobart Butte material.

name: Marokite
description_short: The Mn(III) analogue of ellinaite and harmunite.
tlform: Prismatic crystals to 5 cm.
occurrence: Manganese deposit
aboutname: For the first occurrence in Morocco, Maroc in French.
morphology: Prismatic, flattened on {010}, with {120}, {110}, {201}, and {011}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = c = safflower-red; Y and Z = opaque (very dark red in very thin sections)
opticalanisotropism: Strong: yellowish green to greenish yellow
type_specimen_store:
Geological Survey, Rabat, Morocco.
National School of Mines, Paris, France.
commentcrystal: Point Group: 2/m 2/m 2/m or mm2.; Space Group: Pmab or P21ab.

name: Mathewrogersite
description_short: Chemically related to bartelkeite.
tlform: Platy, six-sided crystals to 0.3 mm, forming subparallel intergrowths. Also as radiating aggregates, to 1 mm diameter, of scales and blades.
colour: Colorless, white, or pale greenish yellow
aboutname: Named by P. Keller and P. J. Dunn in 1986 in honor of Mathew Rogers, the first European prospector in Tsumeb, Namibia.
other: Soluble in HNO3.
morphology: Crystals are flattened along {0001} and are six-sided with possibly rhombohedral faces. The crystals form subparallel intergrowths. Also as radiating aggregates of scales and blades.
type_specimen_store: University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany, NM15; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA.
commentcrystal: <mi>Point Group: 3; _3; 32; 3m; or _3 2/m:; Space Group: R3; R_3; R32; R3m; or R_3 2/m</mi>

name: Mawsonite
tlform: Rounded to irregular inclusions in bornite (from which it was exsolved).
occurrence: Massive to disseminated copper ores
aboutname: For Sir Douglas Mawson (5 May 1882, Shipley, West Riding of Yorkshire, England - 14 October 1958, Brighton, South Australia, Australia), geologist, professor at the University of Adelaide, and Antarctic explorer. He was part of the first team to reach to south magnetic pole.
other:
Negative to the following etch reagents: 1:1 HNO3, 1:1 HCl, NaCN, KOH, HgCl2 and FeCla. 
NaCN produces a verv slight darkening of certain mawsonite grains.
morphology: Rounded to irregular inclusions in bornite.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
Orange
Brown with slight orange tint
opticalanisotropism: Very strong - Bright straw yellow to royal blue
type_specimen_store:
1) The Australian Museum, Sydney, Australia, D48487.
2) The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1965,347.
3) Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA.

name: Mcgovernite
description_short:
The mineral species with the largest number of atoms in the unit cell.

Closely related to carlfrancisite and turtmannite.
tlform: Uniformly granular mass of coarse grain, the individual grains showing an almost micaceous cleavage.
occurrence: Filling veinlets traversing lean franklinite-zincite ore rich in calcite.
aboutname: Named in 1927 by Charles Palache and Lawson Henry Bauer in honor of James J. McGovern [June 1861 Ireland - 1915 Franklin, New Jersey, USA], a mineral collector, and probably mineral dealer, who worked on the picking table for the New Jersey Zinc Company.
morphology: Aggregates of micaceous plates and radial aggregates of platy crystals.
type_specimen_store: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA, 113888.

name: Medenbachite
mindat_formula_note: Endmember formula; Cu may be replaced by minor Fe3+.
description_short: Copper analogue of neustädtelite and cobaltneustädtelite.
tlform: Very small, intergrown, tabular crystals up to 0.2 mm in length, often forming aggregates of parallel intergrowths, which crystallize within cavernous quartz.
occurrence: Weathering of small ore impregnations in a silicified barite vein.
aboutname: Named by W. Krause, H.-J. Bernhardt, W. Gebert, H. Graetsch, K. Belendorff, and K. Petitjean in 1996 in honor of Olaf Medenbach (1949 – ), mineralogist, Ruhr University, Bochum, Germany. He has authored/coauthored descriptions of about 50 new minerals.
morphology:
The crystals are tabular on {-101} and slightly elongated parallel to [111]. They exhibit two main zones: One is parallel to [111] and includes {-101}, {-110},
{0-11}, and the other is parallel to [010] and includes {-101}, {101}, and {001}.
type_specimen_store: Institut fur Mineralogie, Ruhr-Universitiit Bochum, Germany

name: Melkovite
description_short: Compare UM1990-22-MoO:CaHP.
tlform: Finely crystalline powdery films and veinlets consisting of platy crystals generally 0.001-0.002 mm in diameter.
occurrence: Oxidation zone of a molybdenite-fluorite deposit.
opticalextinction: Extinction wavy to nearly parallel ⊥ to the cleavage.
aboutname:
First described from a <l id='23268'>U-Mo deposit, Shunak Mts, Kazakhstan</l> by Yegorov et al. (1969). Named in honour of Professor Vyacheslav Gavrilovich Melkov (Вячеслав Гаврилович Мелков)(1911–1991), Russian mineralogist specializing in uranium minerals, of the All-Union Research Institute of Mineral Resources, Moscow, Russia.

The mineral <m>vyacheslavite</m> is also named in his honor.
other: Slowly soluble in concentrated HCl
opticalpleochorismdesc: Colourless to light green.
type_specimen_store:
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 72716.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 160237.

name: Mereheadite
mindat_formula_note: Formula originally assumed to be Pb<sub>2</sub>O(OH)Cl.
description_short: Related to symesite.
tlform: Polycrystalline aggregates, up to 10 x 30 mm, in which individual grains are anhedral and rarely exceed 2 mm.
occurrence: Lead bearing lenses and cavities in veins of manganese and iron oxide minerals that cut through a sequence of dolomitic limestone.
aboutname: Named after Merehead quarry, Somerset, the source of this and other unusual lead secondary minerals.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, London, England, specimen BM 1965,285 and polished mount E.1175.
commentcrystal: SG Cm; originally reported cell (Welch et al., 1998): C2/c, 5.680, 5.565, 13.143 A, 90.64°.

name: Meta-aluminite
tlform: Microcrystalline, minute laths, aggregated into nodular to irregular masses
aboutname: Named by C. Frondel in 1968 for its relationship to <m>aluminite</m> and being in a lower hydration state.
type_specimen_store: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA, 109543.

name: Metacalciouranoite
tlform: dense, fine-grained aggregate
aboutname: Named for being dehydrated (meta) calciouranoite.
commentcrystal: Crystal Data: n.d. Point Group: n.d; Space Group: n.d. Z == n.d

name: Metamunirite
description_short: May form by dehydration of munirite.
tlform: Clusters of radiating colourless needles up to 0.2 mm in length in cavities in sandstone.
occurrence: sandstone vanadium deposit
opticalextinction: X = c; Y = a; Z = b; positive elongation
aboutname: Named for its probable relationship to munirite.
other: Readily soluble in water
morphology: Needle-like crystals, which sometimes are broadened into narrow laths. Dominant crystal habit is {101}, with no clearly developed terminal faces.
opticalbirefringence: Note that the calculated and illustrated birefringence is a minimum, based on n<sub>γ</sub> = 1.85; because n<sub>γ</sub> is reportedly >> 1.85, the actual observed birefringence will be higher.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 168386.
commentdense: Measured is synthetic material

name: Metatyuyamunite
mindat_formula_note: Previously assumed to have 3-5 water molecules per formula unit.
description_short: Visually indistinguishable from tyuyamunite or similar uranyl vanadates. May spontaneously dehydrate in dry atmosphere from tyuyamunite.
tlform: Scales and laths, radial aggregates. Massive, compact to cryptocrystalline. Powdery.
occurrence: Sedimentary uranium deposit
aboutname: Named in 1953 by Alice Mary Dowse Weeks, Mary E. Thompson, and Raymond B. Thompson for prefix meta- indicating a dehydration relationship to tyuyamunite.
morphology: Usually earthy granular, also rhombic platy crystals.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = colorless
Y= very pale canary yellow
Z = pale canary yellow

name: Meymacite
description_short: An amorphous hydrated tungsten oxide.
aboutname: Named for the town of Meymac, France. The original substance named meymacite was later found to be ferritungstite. However the name was then reused for this new mineral found in both Zaïre and at Meymac. This redifinition was by R. Pierrot and R. van Tassel in 1965.
type_specimen_store: Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France (cotype).

name: Millerite
description_short:
Commonly found as radiating and jackstraw clusters of shiny metallic acicular crystals, pale brass-yellow with an iridescent tarnish.

Compare 'UM1989-25-S:FeNi' - a representative of the Fe1-xS-Ni1-xS (Mss) solid solution; and also crowningshieldite...
otheroccurrence: A low-temperature mineral which occurs in sulfidic limestones and dolostones, and as a late-forming mineral in nickel sulfide deposits.
colour: Pale brass-yellow, with an iridescent tarnish, and greenish-grey.
aboutname: Named by Wilhelm Haidinger in 1845 in honor of William Hallowes Miller [April 6, 1801, Velindre, Wales, UK - May 20, 1880, Cambridge, England, UK], professor at the University of Cambridge, who first studied the crystals.  He wrote 'A Treatise on Crystallography'.  Miller indices are also named after him.
morphology: Acicular crystals in radiating or jackstraw clusters; also massive.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
Weak in air stronger in oil
Pale yellow-brown to bright yellow

name: Minrecordite
description_short: Dolomite Group.
tlform: Small, strongly twisted rhombohedral crystals.
occurrence: Hydrothermal polymetallic deposit.
aboutname: Named for the Mineralogical Record, a magazine started in 1970 by John S. White. It is the authoritative English language magazine for mineral collectors, with articles detailing worldwide localities, fine minerals and collections, and the history of mineral collecting. The name was for the Mineralogical Record being "a worthy magazine in promoting both a better knowledge of Tsumeb minerals and a more beneficial interaction between professional and amateur mineralogists."
other: Very slowly soluble in cold dilute HCl. Easily soluble in 2N HCl at 80° C.
morphology: Mosaic rhombohedral crystals to 0.5mm. Saddle-shaped, strongly twisted.
type_specimen_store: Institute of Mineralogy, Bari University, Bari, Italy.

name: Molybdofornacite
description_short:
An unnamed phosphate analogue is known: UM1994-19-PO:CuHMoPb.

Related to the Brackebuschite Group.
tlform: Minute lath-like crystals on dioptase
occurrence: Oxidation zone
aboutname: Named for its relationship to fornacite, but with molybdenum dominant over chromium.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X and Y pale yellow, Z green yellow.
uv: Not known to fluoresce in UV
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Institute, Ruhr-University, Bochum, Germany.

name: Molybdite
description_short:
Anhydrous counterpart of tianhuixinite, raydemarkite (monohydrate) and sidwillite (dihydrate).

Compare also ferrimolybdite.
tlform: greenish-yellow to colorless flat needles or thin plates
occurrence: Quartz vein, near contact with fine-grained topaz-quartz greisen.
otheroccurrence: Molybdite is commonly found in fumerolitic conditions such as mine dump fires or volcanic fumeroles. Sometimes found as secondary alterations of molydenum-bearing ores. Occurrences of hydrothermal origin are scarce.
colour: colorless, light greenish yellow, light brown, also pale blue
aboutname: Possibly the uncertain molybdic ocher of William Phillips and other earlier authors. Named molybdine by Robert Greg and William Lettsom in 1854 and 1858 in reference to its containing molybdenum and oxygen. The name was changed to molybdite by August Breithaupt in 1858. In 1907, Waldemar Schaller analyzed a mineral from a new locality, but with similar physical properties as described for molybdite. Because no adequate chemical analyses of molybdite were known and, presumably, no specimens of the very rare species were available from the type locality, the early analysis was supposed to be defective, as iron was reportedly detected, but not quantified in the original analysis by Greg and Lettsom. Schaller named ferrimolybdite furthering the use of a chemical name. In 1963, František Čech and Pavel Povondra discovered a new occurrence of a molybdenum oxide and resurrected molybdite for molybdenum oxide, but did not examine material from previously reported localities.
morphology: Platy to very elongated crystals
commentluster: Crstals have a high luster, coatings may look waxy

name: Montanite
mindat_formula_note:
0 ≤ n ≤ 2/3.
Originally thought to be <f>Bi^2(TeO^6).2H^2O</f>.
description_short:
An alteration product of Tetradymite.

"Type localities are Highland, Montana, USA (sample BM 85116), and David Beck’s Mine, North Carolina, USA (sample BM 1985, Nev336)."

Crystal structure details:
* 50% of the Bi and 100% of the Te atoms have t...
tlform: Fibrous, earthy to compact, massive.
aboutname: From the locality where it was found in the state of Montana, USA.
morphology: Earthy to compact.
type_specimen_store: Two neotypes, both at the Natural History Museum, London, UK.
commentcrystal: supercell was only observed in the synthetic analogue
ima_history: Redefined (with different water content) in 2022 (IMA 22-A: "redefinition of montanite").

name: Montroyalite
description_short: Probably related to the dresserite group.
tlform: Translucent white millimeter-sized hemispheres.
occurrence: Silicocarbonate sill
aboutname: Named by A.C. Roberts, A.P. Sabina, M. Bonardi, J.L. Jambor, R.A. Ramik, B.D. Sturman, and M.J. Carr in 1986 for  Mont-Royal, which is one of the Monteregian  hills and a prominant landmark in Montreal. Mont-Royal is not the type locality for the species; the Francon quarry approximately 15 km to the NE has that designation.
other: Soluble in 1:1 HCl at room temperature.
uv: Fluoresces white under long and short wave UV.
type_specimen_store: Canadian Geological Survey, Ottawa, Canada, 64261–64265.

name: Morelandite
description_short: Apatite Group. The barium analogue of Mimetite.
tlform: Irregular segregations, to 2.5 cm, in calcite.
aboutname: Named by Pete J. Dunn and Roland C. Rouse in 1978 in honor of Grover C. Moreland (1912-1978), supervisor of the sample preparation laboratory at the Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., USA, 'in honor of his dedication to the support of mineralogical research'.
other: Completely soluble in cold dilute 1:1 nitric acid. Whitens to an opaque chalky appearance after prolonged immersion in cold dilute 1:1 HCl.
type_specimen_store:
National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C. 20560 under catalog number C4147. 
The Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M35176.
Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA, 126607.
Natural History Museum, London, England.
commentcrystal: Point Group: 6/m or 6.: Space Group: P63/m or P63.

name: Mounanaite
description_short: The Fe3+ analogue of krettnichite.
tlform: Red-brown crystals to a  0.3 mm in size.
occurrence: Upper part on an oxidation zone.
aboutname: Named for its Type Locality, the Mounana Mine in Gabon
type_specimen_store: Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France, number 50892 (cotype).
thermalbehaviour: The DTA curve of synthetic material shows endothermic breaks at 490°C (loss of water) and 635°C (fusion) and an exothermic peak at about 600°C.

name: Muirite
mindat_formula_note: The IMA formula for muirite with 10 Si differs from related species ferrimuirite (8 Si), and may be inconsistent with the 8-Si ring structure of the muirite group. The mindat formula for muirite is modeled after the formula for ferrimuirite.
tlform: Anhedral grains. Also subhedral to euhedral tetragonal crystals averaging 0.5 mm and up to 3 mm in size.
occurrence: Sanbornite-quartz-bearing metamorphic rock.
aboutname: Named by J.T. Alfors, M.C. Stinson, R.A. Matthews, and A. Pabst in 1965 in honor of John Muir (21 April 1838, Dunbar, Scotland - 24 December 1914, Los Angeles, California, US), also known as "John of the Mountains".  Muir was a geologist and explorer, naturalist, author, environmental philosopher, and glaciologist. He was an early advocate for the preservation of wilderness in the United States and founded the Sierra Club.
other: Decomposed by dilute hydrochloric and nitric acids. Loses its color and disintegrates to a white or colorless residue. Not affected by sulfuric acid, acetic acid, or concentrated sodium hydroxide.
morphology:
Subhedral to euhedral crystals not uncommon.

The common forms are {001} and {100}; other forms include {110} and a few (h01) faces.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
O = orange
E = colorless
type_specimen_store: California Divisions of Mines & Geology, USA.
thermalbehaviour:
Gives off water in a closed test tube and fuses at about 3.

Heated rapidly to 900 °C in an electric furnace, it turns brown. Further heating turns it pinkish and it partially melts at 1100 °C. At 1200 °C it completely melts to a pale lavender glass.

name: Murunskite
description_short: Bukovite group
tlform: very tiny grains, to 1 µm, and in aggregates
occurrence: rocks that have undergone intensive potassium metasomatism
aboutname: Named for the Murunskii alkalic massif, the type locality.
opticalanisotropism: Moderate, gray to brownish gray with a bluish tint.
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (81604)
commentcolor:
iridescent
a fresh surface oxidizes to a sooty black film

name: Nacareniobsite-(Ce)
mindat_formula_note: Formula modified to better show relation to the Y analogue; the idealised formula below is the structural formula of the most "fresh" refinement by Agakhanov et al. (2023).
description_short: Rinkite group. The Ce analogue of nacareniobsite-(Y) and nacareniobsite-(Nd). Unique combination of elements (as of Feb. 2023).
tlform: Ruler-shaped crystals up to 3.0 x 0.04 x 0.04 mm, and crystal aggregates.
occurrence: Alkaline igneous complex.
opticalextinction: X = b; Y ≃ c; γ ∧ a = 11° in the obtuse angle β.
aboutname: Acronym for NAtrium (sodium), CAlcium, Rare Earths and NIOBium.
morphology: Individual ruler-shaped crystals and crystal aggregates; elongate [001], tabular {100}, modified by {310} and {410}.
type_specimen_store: Geological Museum, University of Copenhagen, Denmark.

name: Nambulite
mindat_formula_note: Often contains minor Na replacing Li.
description_short:
Nambulite-Natronambulite Series.

The Li analogue of Natronambulite.
aboutname: Named in 1972 by M. Yoshii, Y. Aoki, and K. Maeda in honor of Matsuo Nambu (南部 松夫) (19 November 1917, Soma City, Fukushima Prefecture - 21 August 2009), economic geologist, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, who is known for his research in manganese minerals.
type_specimen_store: National Science Museum, Tokyo, Japan, M18829.
commentcrystal: Data from Nagashima et al. (2014) for a sample from the Fianel mine; for a sample from the Gozaisho mine, they give: 7.5372(1), 11.7267(1), 6.7078(1) Å, 93.057(1), 95.147(1), 106.240(1)°, V = 565.02(2) Å<sup>3</sup>. Original data: 7.62, 11.76, 6.73 Å, 92.77, 95.08, 106.87°.

name: Nastrophite
tlform: Crystals, mostly 0.2-0.5 but up to 2-3 mm and as deposits of irregular form up to 1 cm in diameter.
occurrence: Veinlets cutting nepheline syenites.
aboutname: For its essential chemical constituents sodium (latin: NAtrium), STROntium and PHosphate.
other: The mineral dissolves completely in cold 1% HCl. It is partly decomposed by hot water, giving a solution alkaline to phenolphthalein. It partially dehydrates under natural conditions.
ir: IR spectrum shows bands for the phosphate group and H2O.
type_specimen_store: Geology Museum, Kola Branch, Academy of Sciences, Apatity, 5529; Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, 1194/1–2; A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 81405; The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1994,16.
thermalbehaviour: The DTA curve shows a sharp endothermic break at about 150°C.

name: Natron
otheroccurrence: In solution in soda lakes.
cleavage: On {001} distinct; on {010} imperfect; on {110} in traces.
colour: Colourless to white, greyish, yellowish; colourless in transmitted light.
aboutname: In allusion to its sodium content (Latin = NATRium).
other:
Soluble in H2O. Gives an alkaline taste.
Dehydrates rapidly in air forming thermonatrite.
morphology: Occurs naturally only as crystalline, granular, and columnar crusts. Artificial crystals somewhat tabular {010} with varying development of the [100] and [001] zones.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.
thermalbehaviour: Melting Point: 34.5°.

name: Nchwaningite
tlform: Radiating balls, up to 5 mm in diameter, of acicular crystals. Crystals to 1.0 x 0.2 x 0. 1 mm.
occurrence: Fault zones in a manganese deposit. Formation temperature is estimated to be in a range of 270-420 C, with pressures between 0.2-1.0 kbar.
cleavage: Two perfect cleavages, parallel to (100) and (010).
aboutname: After the type locality, N'Chwaning II mine, South Africa.
morphology: Platy parallel to (010) and terminated by subordinate (110) faces. The point is formed by faces of the type (h0l), predominantly (201) and (301).
opticalcomments: Y = a, X = b, Z = c
uv: No fluorescence under LW or SW UV.
type_specimen_store:
Museum of the Geological Survey in Pretoria, South Africa, catalogue number MGS 28362.
Naturhistorisches Museum, Bernastrasse 15. CH-3005 Bern, Switzerland, number NMB-B 8735.
commentdense: Not measured due to scarcity of material.

name: Nepheline
description_short: A very important change concerning nepheline is found in the recent (42nd) IMA Newsletter: potassium is essential in nepheline and the formula is changed to that recognized by Mindat. See https://www.mindat.org/mesg-437726.html for details, and CNMNC N...
otheroccurrence: Characteristic of alkaline igneous rocks.
aboutname: From the Greek "nephele" for "cloud" since it turns cloudy when treated with strong acid.
morphology: Stout prisms, granular, compact, massive.
commentcolor: Coloured by inclusions as well.

name: Nickelbischofite
description_short:
Compare droninoite, muonionalustaite; akaganeite and paratacamite-(Ni).

Deliquescent and soluble in water.
aboutname: The name reflects its composition as the nickel-dominant analogue of <m>bischofite</m>.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = greenish yellow; Z = green
type_specimen_store: Canadian Geological Survey, Ottawa, Canada, 17980.

name: Ferronigerite-2N1S
tlform: Intergrowths and coatings on gahnite. Also as isolated brown hexagonal plates up to 5 X 2 mm.
occurrence: Quartz-sillimanite-rocks associated with tin-bearing pegmatites.
aboutname: Originally named nigerite, for the type locality in Nigeria. Renamed according to the new nigerite group nomenclature as Fe dominant mineral and the 2N1S polysome.
other: Weakly magnetic. Insoluble in acids.
type_specimen_store:
Muséum Nationale d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France, 153.44 and 178.163 (type).
Natural History Museum, London, United Kingdom, number BM 1947,392 (type).
thermalbehaviour: Very imperfectly attacked by fusion with sodium carbonate or caustic soda, but readily gives a clear fusion with borax and with sodium pyrosulphate.

name: Niter
description_short: Niter, potassium nitrate, is found as an efflorescence in hot, dry regions. Also known as saltpeter.
tlform: Frequently compact granular.
otheroccurrence: Surface efflorescences in arid regions; in caves or other dry, sheltered places. Also in soils rich in organic materials, especially after rain during hot weather.
cleavage: On {011} nearly perfect; on {010} fairly good; on {110} imperfect.
colour: Colorless or white, light yellow, very light gray
aboutname: Evolved from "neter" or "nether" (Hebraic), which derived from "natar," a substance that effervesces, which corresponds to the "nitron" of the Greeks and the "nitrum" of the Romans.
other: Readily soluble in water.
morphology: Massive, granular, earthy, mealy. Crusts, silky tufts, and delicate acicular crystallization.  Artificial crystals are prismatic [001].
twinning: Common on {110}, frequently as pseudo-hexagonal groupings.

name: Nordite-(La)
description_short: The zinc analogue of Ferronordite-(La). The lanthanum analogue of Nordite-(Ce).
aboutname: Originally named nordite for the northern latitudes, where the mineral was discovered. The suffix was added by Levinson in 1966 to denote the dominant rare earth element.

name: Nowackiite
description_short: Chemically related to tennantite. Zn analogue of aktashite and zhengminghuaite; ZnAs-analogue of gruzdevite.
aboutname: In honour of Professor Werner Nowacki (1909–1989), Swiss crystallographer, University of Bern, Switzerland, for his extensive research on sulphosalts from Lengenbach.

name: Obradovicite-KCu
description_short: Formerly called obradovicite; redefined in 2010 (IMA 10-E). Both obradovicite-NaCu and obradovicite-KCu was found on the type specimen of "obradovicite".
tlform: dense clusters of platy crystals to 0.1 mm
occurrence: on brecciated, slightly leached, vein quartz or on crusts of earthy tan jarosite
aboutname: Named obradovicite by Finney et al. (1986) in honor of Martin T. Obradovic, from whose mineral collection the type material came. He graduated from Colorado School of mines in 1953. In 1970 he headed the alumni association in Lima, Peru. The double suffix was added in 2010 by the International Mineralogical Association in a redefinition of this and related species. The double suffix corresponds to the dominant cations in two different types of non-framework cation sites; in this case potassium and copper.
other: It is insoluble in cold 1:1 HNO3 but dissolves rapidly upon heating, readily soluble in cold 1:1 HCl, rapidly turns dull brick orange in 40% KOH, and is unaffected by 20% NH4OH.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Weak yellow pleochroism, Z > X = Y
type_specimen_store: Colorado School of Mines Museum, and National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, DC, USA
ima_history: Renamed from obradovicite to obradovicite-KCu in IMA Proposal 10-E (CNMNC Newsletter 7)

name: Olekminskite
description_short:
Olekminskite-Paralstonite Series.

Compare 'UM1989-07-CO:CaSr'.
tlform: Needle-like crystals, 0.005-0.010 mm thick, occurring in spherulitic aggregates 0.10-0.15 mm in radius.
occurrence: In barytocalcite-quartz veins that cut intrusive breccias accompanying an alkaline massif.
otheroccurrence: Daughter products in fluid inclusions in carbonatites.
aboutname: Named for the city of Olekminsk, the administration center of the Murunskij alkaline complex.
type_specimen_store:
Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, Russia, number 2071/1.
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, number p461/1.
commentcrystal: Hexagonal symnrletry and space group P321 were assumed by analogy with paralstonite.

name: Omphacite
mindat_formula_note:
a+b+c+d = 1
e+f+g=h = 1
a = e+f
0.2 ≤ a ≤ 0.8
e > f
description_short: A clinopyroxene intermediate between jadeite and augite, with solid solution towards aegirine-augite. There is a solvus between omphacite (P2/n) and jadeite (C2/c) and also between omphacite and augite/diopside (C2/c), below about 500°C. Above this tem...
aboutname: From the Greek for unripe grape, in allusion to its green colour.
commentcrystal: Space group may be C2/c or P2/n.

name: Orlymanite
description_short: Gyrolite Group.
tlform: Dark brown, radiating, tightly packed rosettes that form spheres 2-3 mm in diameter, or more irregular aggregates resembling a botryoidal texture in cross section.
occurrence: Vein mineral in manganese ore.
aboutname: Named in honor of Orlando Hammond Lyman (19 November 1903, Hawaii, USA – 11 December 1986, Hilo, Hawaii, USA), the Lyman House Memorial Museum's founder. He built its mineral and gem collection of over 20 000 specimens. The new mineral was found as a specimen taken from his collection.
morphology: Fibrous crystals, botryoidal
opticalpleochorismdesc:
O = pale brown
E' = dark brown
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian), Washington D.C., USA, catalogue NMNH 16636.
commentcrystal: Point Group: <mi>_3 or 3:; Space Group: _P3 or P3</mi>

name: Osarsite
description_short: Arsenopyrite Group.
occurrence: Placer sand
aboutname: The name reflects its composition: osmium, arsenic and sulfur. The related minerals ruarsite, irarsite, and platarsite are similarly named.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 123218.
commentcrystal: Point Group: n.d.; Space Group: n.d.
commentcolor: In reflected light

name: Oulankaite
description_short:
Unique combination of elements. The Cu analogue of UM2004-32-S:AgCuFePdPtSnTe.

Also compare 'argentian oulankaite'.
tlform: platy subhedral to euhedral inclusions in chalcopyrite
occurrence: In pegmatoidal pyroxenite hosted in microgabbronorite.
aboutname: Named by Andrew Y. Barkov, Yurii P. Men'shikov, Victor D. Begizov, and Andrew I. Lednev in 1996 for the Oulanka River, that passes near the type locality.
morphology: platy grains to 0.2 mm, with characteristic fine twins. Occurs as inclusions in chalcopyrite.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Purplish pink, creamy pink or grayish cream tints.
type_specimen_store: Fersman Museum, Moscow, Russia
commentcrystal: Tetragonal (based on XRD pattern). Point Group: n.d.;  Space Group: n.d.

name: Padĕraite
mindat_formula_note: Cook & Ciobanu (2003) suggest the formula Cu<sub>7</sub>(Ag<sub>0.4</sub>Pb<sub>1.2</sub>)<sub>∑1.6</sub>Bi<sub>11.4</sub>S<sub>22</sub>
aboutname: Named by W.G. Mumme and L. Žák in 1985 in honor of Karel Padĕra (5 May, 1923 - 2010), Czech mineralogist, Charles University, Prague who first worked on the mineral.
morphology: Platy fragments, in granular to parallel fibrous aggregates, to several mm.
type_specimen_store: Charles University, Prague, Czech Republic, 11329; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 164244.
commentcolor: Steel-gray on fresh fractures, turning brown to black;

name: Palladseite
description_short: Chemically related to verbeekite and UM1995-39-Se:Pd.
tlform: Grains up to 0.5mm
occurrence: Placer deposit
aboutname: Named for its chemical composition (Pd and Se).
opticalcolour: white in air and in plane polarized light, and a very light grey in oil
type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1977,500 and 1934,72.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 142504.

name: Parabutlerite
colour: Pale orange to pale orange-brown; light yellow in transmitted light.
aboutname: Named in 1938 by Mark Chance Bandy for its resemblance to Butlerite.
other:
Insoluble in cold or hot water; soluble in dilute acids.

Observed as pseudomorphs after copiapite.
morphology: Crystals prismatic [001]. The prism zone is striated [001].
epitaxidescription: Intergrowths, with {011} of parabutlerite nearly parallel to {001} and {100} of butlerite.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
Alcaparrosa material:
X = b = Light yellow
Y = c = Greenish yellow
Z = a = Brownish yellow

Argentinian material:
X = b = Colourless
Y = c = Faint yellow
Z = a = Light yellow
commentcrystal: Space group Pnma(0β0)​s0s; the structure is commensurately modulated, with a = 20.0789 (8), b = 7.4024 (7), c = 7.2294 (15) Å and q = 0.4b* (Plášil et al., 2017).

name: Parakeldyshite
tlform: Grains to 5 mm and aggregates.
cleavage: Three cleavages result in a pseudo-rhombohedral shape: {001} perfect, {110} and <mi>{1_10}</mi> somewhat less perfect. The acute angles between these planes are all between 76° and 82°. Also a good cleavage parallel to {011}.
opticalextinction: Y ≈ c; X ≈ b; Z ≈ a.
aboutname: Named for its chemical relationship to <m>keldyshite</m>.
twinning: Polysynthetic on {100}, with several other sets intersecting.
uv: Fluoresces deep cream under SW UV and a very weak cream under LW UV.
type_specimen_store: Geology Museum, Kola Branch, Academy of Sciences, Apatity, 3270, 4457; Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, 1079/1{2, vis4361; Vernadsky Geological Museum, Moscow, 517151; A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 78461, 78462
specdispm: Alters readily to a snow-white coating.

name: Pararammelsbergite
description_short:
The low-temperature polymorph of NiAs2.

The crystal structure is transitional between the marcasite and pyrite structures (Fleet, 1972).

Compare, e.g., the (now approved / redefined) dienerite.

Peacock (1940) gives a summary of the early histo...
tlform: Massive, in part minutely crystallized.
aboutname: Named in 1940 by Martin Alfred Peacock and Alexander Stewart Dadson from the Greek παρά = beyond and rammelsbergite, because of its relationship to the root mineral.
other:
Etch reactions:
HNO3, effervesces and etches rapidly brown to black.
FeCl, etches quickly light to dark brown, bringing out the texture.
HgCl2, slowly gives a brown to iridescent stain which does not rub off.
HCl, KCN, KOH, negative.
In air saturated with water vapour etching is already perceptible after four hours; in twelve hours the surface is deeply etched; after a week white and green bloom are formed. Pararammelsbergite appears to decompose more rapidly than rammelsbergite in moist air.
opticalanisotropism: Strong, in russet-brown, brown, yellow, gray.
type_specimen_store: Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, numbers M11772a-c, M14242, and M12411 (cotype).

name: Paravauxite
description_short:
The triclinic dimorph of Metavauxite.

A rare mineral in hydrothermal tin veins and in complex granitic pegmatites.
occurrence: Hydrothermal tin veins
otheroccurrence: Hydrothermal tin veins and pegmatites
colour: Pale greenish white to colorless; colorless in transmitted light. also gray-white or Light brown.
aboutname: Named in 1922 by Samuel George Gordon from the Greek παρα for "near" and its chemical relationship to Vauxite, a lower hydrate.
morphology: Short prismatic [001], thick tabular {010}. Numerous forms ay be exhibited. Forms subparallel to radial aggregates.
type_specimen_store: U.S. National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA: #112735, #136012, #R5467.

name: Parwelite
tlform: Crystals rounded, stubby prismatic, to 1 cm.
occurrence: High temperature skarn.
aboutname: In honour of Dr. Alexander Parwel (June 15, 1906, Valga - 23 December 1978, Stockholm, Sweden), Swedish chemist, Swedish National History Museum, Stockholm, Sweden, who has performed many analyses of Långban minerals, including this one.
other: It is insoluble in cold 1:1 HCl solution
type_specimen_store: Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm, Sweden, NRMS 26758; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 120065.

name: Pectolite
description_short:
Wollastonite Group. 
Pectolite-Serandite Series. The calcium analogue of Sérandite.
Constitutes serandite-schizolite-pectolite series.
otheroccurrence: Primary mineral in nepheline syenites. Hydrothermal mineral in cavities in basalts and diabases. In serpentinites and peridotites.
colour: Colourless, white, pale pink, greenish, pale blue
aboutname: Named in 1828 by Franz von Kobell from the Greek πηκτός (English: pektos) for "held tightly together", in allusion to its resistance to pulverization.
other: May be triboluminescent.
morphology: Crystals tabular, acicular. Radiating fibrous, spheroidal, columnar, fine-grained, massive.
twinning: Common with twin axis [010], composition plane {100}
opticaldispersion: r > v weak to very strong
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.

name: Pentagonite
description_short:
Structurally related to plumbophyllite.

Ishida et al. (2009) suggest that cavansite is a low-temperature form and pentagonite a high-temperature form. Conditions of formation of both dimorphs are discussed in Ottens et al. (2025).

To distinguish ...
tlform: Radiating greenish-blue prismatic crystals.
occurrence: Cavities and veinlets in basalt and vugs in tuff.
otheroccurrence: Fracture filling in tuffs and basalts.
opticalextinction: X = b; Y = a; Z = c.
aboutname: For the pseudosymmetrical five-fold habit of the typical pentagonite twins. Note that "characteristic pentagonite fivelings are not formed from five, but from six individuals." (Ottens et al., 2025).
other: Soluble in acids with difficulty. In HNO3, the blue color bleaches out and turns olive brown. A fine white crystalline precipitate is slowly formed on a microscope slide when the minerals are heated in dilute H2SO4.
morphology: Prismatic, bladed.
twinning: Cyclical by reflection across {110}, producing twinning at an angle near 72.7° ((110) ∧ <mi>(_110)</mi>), and sometimes giving rise to fivelings. Note that "characteristic pentagonite fivelings are not formed from five, but from six individuals." (Ottens et al., 2025).
opticaldispersion: r > v strong. Dispersion opposite to that of cavansite.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X=Z= colourless
Y= blue
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 120584, 122769.

name: Perite
description_short:
Nadorite Group.

Perite from the Zakharovskoe deposit is bromian, with 0.62 wt.% Br.
tlform: Plates to 0.5 mm
occurrence: Skarn in a metamorphosed Fe–Mn deposit
aboutname: Named by Marianne Gillberg in 1960 in honor of Per Adolf Geijer (7 May 1886, Svea Artillery Government's Assembly, Sweden - 18 April 1976, Danderyd, Sweden), economic geologist with the Swedish Geological Survey (SGU) and professor at the Royal Institute of Technology.
other: Easily soluble in dilute acids.
type_specimen_store:
Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm, Sweden.
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1980,106.

name: Petarasite
description_short: Related to the Lovozerite Group.
tlform: Irregular grains up to 10 mm across.
occurrence: In a xenolith, composed mainly of coarse grained biotite and microcline, in nepheline syenite.
cleavage: Very good on {110}, plus 2 more directions distinct.
colour: Orange to brown, pink, yellow, white
aboutname: Named in 1980 by George Y. Chao, T. T. Chen, and J. Baker in honor of Dr. Peter Tarassoff [b. April 11, 1934 Canada] of Beaconsfield, Quebec, considered to be “the dean” of Mont Saint-Hilaire mineral collectors, for his long (55+ years) and sustained contributions to Mont Saint-Hilaire mineralogy.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = colorless; Y = Z = pale greenish yellow.
type_specimen_store:
Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, numbers 43721, 43630, 43631 (cotype).
Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, numbers M36456, M36457, M36458.
Geological Survey of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, number 61531 (cotype).
commentdense: Calculated value based on the empirical formula.

name: Phosphuranylite
description_short:
Small crystals may have thin rectangular bladed habit. See also the closely related yingjiangite and dewindtite. 

NOTE: Modern analytical techniques applied to specimens of "phosphuranylite" in the Joseph Cilen [1916-1997] collection, Hawthorne, NJ,...
tlform: Powdery incrustation on quartz, feldspar, and mica composed of minute rectangular scales.
occurrence: Granite pegmatite
otheroccurrence: Weathered zones of granitic pegmatites near altered uraninite. In paleochannels in Colorado Plateau type sandstone deposits.
aboutname: Named in 1879 by Frederick A. Genth in allusion to the chemical composition, being a PHOSPHate of URANYL uranium.
other: Readily soluble in acids.
morphology: Occurs as thin scales with an irregular to rectangular outline. The scales form scaly crusts, thin films and coatings. Also powdery.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = Clorless to pale yellow
Y = Z = Golden yellow
opticalcomments: The refractive index of reported phosphuranylite is unreasonably large, suggesting poor identification control.
uv: May fluoresce due to admixed autunite, etc.
type_specimen_store:
1) Pennsylvania State University, State College, Pennsylvania, USA.
2) Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, USA, 3249–3251

name: Phoenicochroite
aboutname: From the Greek φοίυικος for "deep red" and χρόα for "colour," in allusion to its colour.
other: Soluble in HCl with separation of lead chloride.
morphology:
Crystals tabular and imperfect, often reticularly intergrown. Massive; thin coatings.

Tabular on {100} or {201}, elongated along [010] or [001], showing {010}, {100}, {110}, {201}, {211}, {310}.
opticaldispersion: r > v, moderately strong to strong
commentcolor: Turns lemon-yellow on exposure.

name: Picromerite
description_short:
Picromerite Group.
Fresh picromerite is colorless. Specimens may dehydrate in collections within days to years (according to the conditions) to white, opaque leonite. 

Picromerite-type compounds are labeled Tutton salts in chemistry.
occurrence: Active volcanic fumaroles.
otheroccurrence: In kainite zones of some oceanic salt deposits.
colour: Colourless, white, reddish, yellowish, grayish; colourless in transmitted light.
aboutname: From the Greek for "bitter" and "part" in allusion to the presence of magnesium and was originally applied to material crystallized from an aqueous solution of mixed salts from Vesuvius fumaroles.
morphology: Short prismatic [001]. Crusts on other salts; also massive.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.
commentdense: Measured on artificial material.
commentcolor: Tints due to admixed materials

name: Pinnoite
tlform: Nodules with a faint fibrous internal structure.
occurrence: Upper Kainite layers of a salt deposit.
colour: Yellow to yellow-green; yellow in transmitted light
aboutname: Named in honor of Johann Friedrich Hermann Pinno (16 March 1831, Kleinkamsdorf, Prussia, German Empire - 6 September 1902, Berlin-Charlottenburg, German Empire), Chief Councillor of Mines, Halle, Germany.
other: Soluble in dilute acids. Dissolves in boiling water with the formation of an alkaline solution with a flocculent precipitate which re-dissolves upon cooling of the solution.
morphology: Crystals short prismatic [001], rare. Commonly crystalline, fine-granular to faintly fibrous. Nodules with radiated fibrous structure and a crystalline surface.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.

name: Plumbotsumite
description_short:
New formula according to Cooper (pers. comm.), in Marty et al. (2010).
Originally given formula was Pb5Si4O8(OH)10.

May be confused with leadhillite or susannite.
aboutname: Named for its composition, which includes lead (plumbo), and its type locality, Tsumeb, Namibia.
other: Dissolves with difficulty in hot HNO3.
morphology: irregular to skeletal pseudohexagonal crystals
type_specimen_store: Institute for Mineralogy and Crystal Chemistry, University of Stuttgart, Germany, NM10; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 148301.

name: Plumbogummite
description_short:
The lead analogue of crandallite and goyazite, and the phosphate analogue of philipsbornite.
Compare also the chemically similar hinsdalite with which it forms a complete solid-solution series.

A relatively common secondary lead aluminium phosphate...
occurrence: Found in a polymetallic Pb vein.
otheroccurrence: Oxidized zones of lead-bearing deposits.
colour: Light blue, gray-white, yellow-gray, yellow, yellow-brown, red-brown, greenish, bluish, dark blue-gray
aboutname: Named in 1819 by François Pierre Nicolas Gillet de Laumont from the Latin "plumbum" for lead, and "gummi" for gum, in allusion to its lead content and appearance at times as drops or coatings of gum.
other:
Soluble in hot acids.

May be pseudomorphic after Pyromorphite (common) or baryte.
morphology: Commonly occurs as botryoidal, reniform, stalactitic, or globular crusts or masses, frequently with a concentric structure; also occurs compact massive. Radial fibrous or spherulitic under magnification. May resemble drops or coatings of gum. Minute crystals with a hexagonal outline are rare.
uv:
May fluoresce in medium-wave UV light. 
Usually not fluorescent in short- and long-wave UV light, although a weak bluish fluorescence was observed for some samles in long-wave UV light.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, Paris, France.

name: Polydymite
description_short:
Linnaeite Group, and the Thiospinel Group. Linnaeite-Polydymite Series.

Compare siegenite, violarite.
colour: Violet gray, copper red, light gray, or steel gray
aboutname: From the Greek πολνς, many, and διδνμος, twin, because it was observed in twinned forms.

name: Poubaite
description_short: Aleksite Group.
tlform: Euhedral to subhedral lath-like crystals 30-40 microns, rarely up to 80 microns long, 8-10 microns thick.
cleavage: distinct parallel to elongation. Perfect on {0001}
aboutname: After Prof. Zdeněk Pouba (8 June 1922 - 27 Dec. 2011), Czech mineralogist, Chair of deposit and economy geology (from 1953 to 1982) in Charles University in Prague, Czech Republic.
opticalcolour: Light white with a creamy tint.
type_specimen_store: Charles University, Prague, Czech Republic, 21241; National School of Mines, Paris, France.

name: Priceite
description_short: Occurs as nodules or irregular masses; soft and chalky, to hard, compact and tough with porcellanous texture and sub-conchoidal fracture. Rarely also as small colourless crystals.
tlform: Compact and as roundish masses to several hundred pounds (100 kg ?)
occurrence: Hot spring (?)
otheroccurrence: Evaporite deposits.
aboutname: Named in honor of Thomas Price (1837 Brecon, Breconshire, Wales  - 13 October 1912), a metallurgist, chemist and assayer who first analyzed the mineral. He began his career as an assayer and professor in Swansea. In 1862 he moved to San Francisco and worked for the San Francisco Refinery, taught chemistry and toxicology at Toland Medical College, and later was an international consultant for mining companies.
other:
Insoluble in water. Readily soluble in acids.

Alters to colemanite and calcite.
morphology: Nodules and irregular masses. Compact and tough, chalky to hard.

name: Pseudorutile
description_short:
Closely related to kleberite. Chemically, but not structurally, the Fe analogue of machiite and schreyerite. The Fe analogue of (the Mn dominant) UM2004-26-O:FeMnTi.

See also Arizonite (of Palmer).
colour: Dark steel-gray on fresh fractures, light brown to black
aboutname: Named for the relation to rutile.
other: magnetic
morphology: thin, irregular plates having fibrous texture; fine-grained, massive.
opticalpleochorismdesc: very weak in reds
type_specimen_store: Museum Victoria, Melbourne, Australia, M42789.

name: Pumpellyite-(Mg)
description_short:
Pumpellyite Group. 
Julgoldite-(Fe2+)-Pumpellyite-(Mg) Series.
Pumpellyite-(Fe2+)-Pumpellyite-(Mg) Series.
aboutname: Named in 1925 by Charles Palache and Helen E. Vassar in honor of US geologist, Raphael Pumpelly [September 8, 1837 Owego, New York, USA – August 10, 1923 Newport, Rhode Island, USA]. The chemical suffix was added in 1973 by the IMA. Pumpelly was an active mining consultant and was professor of Mining Science at Harvard University. He was appointed director of the New England branch of the U. S. Geological Survey in 1884.
morphology: Bladed, typically elongated along [010]; in stellate clusters, fibrous, or dense mats.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = nearly colorless to pale greenish yellow; Y = blue-green; Z = almost colorless to brownish yellow.
type_specimen_store:
Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 90919.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 95279-95281.
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1926, 225-226.

name: Pyrope
description_short:
Garnet Group. 
Almandine-Pyrope Series, Knorringite-Pyrope Series, Pyrope-Grossular Series.

Occurs predominantly in ultrabasic igneous rocks.

Pure end-member pyrope is colorless! (but rare).

Optical anisotropy may be present, caused by strain...
colour: Blood red, orange red, purple red, pink, black red, colorless.
aboutname: From the Greek "pyropos", "fiery-eyed", in allusion to the red hue.
morphology: Subhedral to euhedral crystals, showing the dodecahedron or trapezohedral forms, to 20 cm; also granular, massive.
opticalcomments:
R.I. value given for pure synthetic material.
R.I. values for natural material typically fall between 1.720-1.770
commentcolor:
The “alexandrite effect” is when its colour changes from green in the presence of daylight to purplish red under incandescent light. The UV-Vis spectra show two zones of transmittance, in the red region at 650–700 nm and the blue-green region at 460–510 nm. The absorption bands of Cr3+ and V3+ at 574 nm in the UV-Vis spectra are the main cause of the change in colour. 

see: Qiu, Yan, and Ying Guo

name: Qilianshanite
tlform: Colorless aggregates to 4 mm in diameter, less commonly as tabular or prismatic crystals to 2 mm.
occurrence: Borate deposit.
aboutname: Named after its discovery locality in the Qilian Mountains (Qilian Shan in Chinese) in Qinghai Province.
other: Soluble in water
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Geology, Beijing, China.

name: Rabbittite
tlform: Bundles of pale-green extremely small acicular crystals. Some crystals are bent and twisted, in a manner similar to talc.
occurrence: Efflorescence on a pillar of high-grade ore.
cleavage: Parallel to the c-axis. Under the microscope the crystals show a cleavage across the fibers, which is probably parallel to {001}, and two easy and perfect prismatic cleavages.
aboutname: Named by Mary E. Thompson, Alice D. Weeks, and Alexander M. Sherwood in 1954 after John "Jack" Charles Rabbitt (3 November 1907, Butte, Montana, USA - 10 June 1957, Washington, D.C., USA), geochemist of the United States Geological Survey and chief of the Trace Elements Section from 1947 to 1953, in recognition of the leadership and inspiration he gave to the members of that laboratory.
other: Effervesces in dilute HCl and slowly soluble in cold water
type_specimen_store:
Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA, 105099.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 112741, 162619.
commentdense: Measured using mixture of bromoform and acetone
commentcrystal: Point Group: n.d.; Space Group: n.d.

name: Rammelsbergite
description_short:
The high-temperature polymorph of NiAs2; pararammelsbergite is the low-temperature polymorph (Fleet, 1972).

Compare, e.g., nickeline and the (now approved / redefined) dienerite.
tlform: Bright silvery metallic masses
otheroccurrence: In moderate temperature hydrothermal veins
colour: Tin white with faint pinkish hue
aboutname: Named in 1845 by James D. Dana in honor of Karl Friedrich August Rammelsberg (April 1, 1813 Berlin, Germany (Prussia) – December 28, 1899 Gross Lichterfelde, Germany), German chemist and mineralogist who taught at the University of Berlin and at the Royal Industrial Institute. He published many significant books on systematic mineralogy.
morphology: Usually massive. Prismatic crystals are rare.
opticalpleochorismdesc: In yellowish to pinkish hue and bluish white

name: Raspite
description_short:
The monoclinic dimorph of stolzite. Heating of raspite to 395(5)°C leads to a transformation into stolzite.

A rare secondary mineral occurring in the oxidized zones of tungsten-bearing hydrothermal base metal deposits.

An unusual Te-rich variety ...
otheroccurrence: Secondary oxidation zone of tungsten containing ores.
colour: Pale yellow, yellowish brown, gray, colorless
aboutname: Named after Mr. Charles Rasp (7 October 1846, Stuttgart, Kingdom of Württemberg (now Germany) - 22 May 1907, Adelaide, South Australia, Australia), German-Australian prospector, and discoverer of the Broken Hill deposit.
other: Decomposed by HCl with separation of yellow tungstic acid.
morphology: Crystals typically tabular, flattened on {100}, which is striated parallel [010], and somewhat elongated parallel [010]; also elongated [100] or thin tabular <mi>{_101}</mi>.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, Vienna, Austria: #G6263.
thermalbehaviour: Inverts to Stolzite above 410°C.
commentcrystal: Cell data from Fujita et al. (1977).

name: Reddingite
description_short:
Phosphoferrite Group, Phosphoferrite-Reddingite Series.

Note: Some "reddingites" may in fact be correianevesite.
tlform: Minute orthorhombic octahedral crystals. Also massive and granular.
occurrence: Granite pegmatite.
colour: Colourless, pale pink or yellow, reddish brown to dark brown (altered); colourless, faintly tinted pink in transmitted light
opticalextinction: Parallel. X = a; Y = b; Z = c.
aboutname: For the type locality at Branchville, in the town of Redding, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, USA.
other: Soluble in hydrochloric and nitric acids.
morphology: Crystals pseudo-octahedral with large {111}, or tabular {010}. The crystals are frequently in parallel grouping. Massive, granular; coarsely fibrous. Forms include {111}, {212}, {221}, {010}, {223}, {122}.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
Buckfield, Maine material:
X = colourless; Y = pinkish brown; Z = pale yellow.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.
thermalbehaviour:
Heating in the closed tube, it whitens at first, then turns yellow and finally brown, but does not become magnetic.

Before the blowpipe, colors the flame pale green and fuses easily (scale = 2) to a blackish-brown non-magnetic globule.
commentluster: Lustre extends to sub-resinous from vitreous.
commentdense: Calculated value is for Mn:Fe = 3:1.

name: Rémondite-(Ce)
tlform: Massive.
occurrence: Massive fillings in veinlets that cut nepheline syenite orthogneiss.
aboutname: To honour Dr. Guy Rémond (1935 – 2 December 2014), physicist, Bureau de Recherches Géologiques et Minières, Orléans, France, for his work on the physics of minerals. The suffix/modifier indicates the predominance of cerium over other rare-earth elements in the composition.
other: Soluble in HCl and HNO3 with effervescence.
type_specimen_store: Muséum Nationale d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France, number 51314 (holotype).

name: Rhabdophane-(Nd)
mindat_formula_note: Nd is almost always replaced by major to minor La and Ce.
description_short: Rhabdophane Group.
aboutname: Originally called simply rhabdophane, from the Greek, rhabdos, a rod, plus phainesthai, to appear, in allusion to the bands characteristically exhibited in its spectrum.  In 1966 the suffix/modifier was added to differentiate it from cerium dominant rhabdophane. The modifier "-(Nd)" indicates the predominance of Nd over other REE in this species.
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.

name: Ribbeite
mindat_formula_note: Mn may be replaced by minor Mg.
tlform: Fine-grained, anhedral granular aggregates of crystals approximately 0.5 mm in diameter with a typical granulitic texture.
occurrence: Ribbeite occurs as pinkish lenses up to 5 cm thick and 20 cm long within a 20-m-wide zone of tectonically intercalated manganese and iron ores. Locally within the stope environs, the complexly deformed manganese andiron ores assume the attitude of a vertically plunging cylindroidal fold in which ribbeite has a preferential association with carbonate-silicate facies within the manganese ores. The lenses are derived by tectonic transposition and boudinaging of the original sedimentary protore layering. The area containing ribbeite measured only ca. 40 cm across as exposed on the stope back. Ribbeite can be regarded as a scarce mineral. The transposed layering is transgressed by an abundance of veinlets of a proposed new manganese hydroxy-carbonate that clearly postdate the major tectonism but are themselves slightly deformed. Of interest also is the occurrence of manganosite as a constituent (to 5olo by volume) of some hausmannite-pyrochroite-barite-calcite layers within the Mn ores but not immediately associated with the ribbeite-alleghanyite layers. The manganosite is altering to pyrochroite and hausmannite and occurs as ragged emerald-green relicts up to 2 cm in diameter. The textural evidence strongly suggests that manganosite was a syngenetic precursor of the hausmannite ores.
aboutname: Named in 1987 by Donald R. Peacor, Pete J. Dunn, S. C. Su, and J. Innes in honor of Paul Hubert Ribbe [2 April 1935 Bristol, Connecticut, USA - 24 June 2017 Virginia, USA], professor of mineralogy at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Virginia, USA and investigator of crystal structures, particularly those of the feldspar group. The publication of the new species commented: "We have named this new species ribbeite in honor of Dr. Paul H. Ribbe in recognition of his many contributions to mineralogy, both to the science through his research, and to the society of mineralogists, in part through his editorship of the Reviews in Mineralogy series of the Mineralogical Society of America. It is particularly appropriate that ribbeite is closely related to the humite group, to which he has made major contributions."
morphology: Anhedral
opticalpleochorismdesc: X, Y colorless; Z light pink
opticalcomments: Z > X - Y; X = b, Y = a, Z = c
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 163208.
commentcrystal: Space group either Pbnm or Pbn21

name: Rinkite-(Ce)
description_short:
See also Mosandrite-(Ce).
The crystal structure  of  rinkite  was  established  by  Galli and Alberti (1971). Some authors (Fleischer 1958, 1987; Sokolova & Cámara, 2008, etc.) have argued that rinkite is identical with mosandrite. However, reinvestig...
aboutname:
Named as rinkite by Lorenzen (1884) for a mineral found in material collected by K.J.V. Steenstrup in the years 1874, 1876 and 1877 at <l id='1960'>Kangerdluarssuk area, Ilímaussaq  complex, Greenland</l>.  The exact locality is not known.  The name is in honor of Henrik Johannes Rink (26 August 1819 Copenhagen, Denmark - 15 December 1893 Christiania, Norway), at the time Director of the Royal Greenland Board of Trade. 
Name was changed by IMA in 2016 from rinkite to rinkite-(Ce) (IMA 16-A).  See Sokolova and Cámara 2017.
morphology: Crystals prismatic along [001] and flattened on {100} with {hk0} faces strongly striated.
type_specimen_store: In the Natural History Museum of Denmark, University of Copenhagen.
ima_history:
Redefined 2009, special procedure
2016: Name changed from rinkite to rinkite-(Ce) (IMA 16-A).

name: Rockbridgeite
mindat_formula_note: Previously given as <f>Fe#2+#Fe#3+#^4(PO^4)^3(OH)^5</f>.
description_short:
Rockbridgeite Group. Frondelite-Rockbridgeite Series. 
The Fe2+-analogue of frondelite and plimerite.

A secondary mineral resulting from the alteration of primary phosphates.

Visually similar to dufrénite and natrodufrénite.

Compare chemicall...
occurrence: granite pegmatite
otheroccurrence: Also rarely found in limonite iron ore deposits.
cleavage: On {100}, excellent; on {010}, good; on {001}, fair.
colour: Dark green, olive-green, brown, yellow-brown, greenish black, black
aboutname: Named in 1949 by Clifford Frondel for the type locality at the Midvale Mine, South Mountain, Midvale, Rockbridge County, Virginia, USA.
other: Soluble in HCl, but not in HNO3 or H2SO4.
morphology: Euhedral crystals rare. Typically fibrous, elongated along [001]; compact radiating in crusts, botryoidal and drusy masses.
opticaldispersion: r < v, or r>v very strong
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = Light brown to light yellow-brown
Y = Bluish green
Z = Dark bluish green
type_specimen_store: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA - #80600.
commentluster: The cruss-sections of botryoids is radially fibrous
commentcolor: Commonly exhibits colour banding. May be bronze-brown or reddish brown when oxidized.

other: Slightly soluble in concentrated acids.
morphology: The type crystals are tabular to lathlike with {010} by far the most prominent form.  Other forms observed include {001}, {100}, {140}, {110}, {210}, <mi>{1_10}</mi>, <mi>{2_10}</mi>, <mi>{0_32}</mi>, <mi>{0_21}</mi>, <mi>{0_31}</mi>, <mi>{_101}</mi>, <mi>{_1_22}</mi>.

name: Roweite
description_short:
Fedorovskite-Roweite Series. The manganese analogue of Fedorovskite.

Only one specimen known is known from the type locality (all additional specimens are "crumbs" from the original single specimen).
tlform: Narrow veinlet of almost pure roweite
occurrence: Hydrothermal veinlets transversing Precambrian metamorphosed Zn-Mn-Fe orebody (Franklin, NJ).
colour: Light brown; colourless in transmitted light
aboutname: Named in 1937 by Harry Berman and Forest A. Gonyer in honor of Mr. George Rowe [1868 Cornwall, England, United Kingdom - 1947 USA], Mine Captain and mineral collector, of Franklin, New Jersey, USA.
other:
Perfectly soluble in dilute HCl, solution giving boron reaction with turmeric paper.

Fuses at 1 (candle flame) to a  black glass.

Colors the flame faintly green. With boron flux a strong green (boron). 

In closed tube turns brown, gives off water and after long heating melts to a glass.
morphology: Crystals rough, lath-shaped, flattened {010} and elongated [001]. Terminations not measurable.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = very pale brown to colorless; Y = pale amber; Z = yellowish brown.
opticalcomments: Orientation: X = c; Y = b; Z = a

National School of Mines, Paris, France.
Harvard University, Cambridge,Massachusetts, USA, 96252.

name: Russellite
description_short:
An alteration product of primary bismuth minerals and wolframite.

The tungstate analogue of koechlinite and the Bi analogue of tungstibite.
tlform: Pale yellow, rounded fragments, fine-grained and compact.
aboutname: Named in 1938 by Max Hey and Frederick Allen Bannister in honor of Sir Arthur Edward Ian Montagu Russell [November 30, 1878 Folkestone, Kent, England, UK - February 23, 1964]. Sir Arthur Edward Ian Montagu Russell (1878-1964) 6th Baronet, of Swallowfield Park, Reading, Berkshire, was perhaps the greatest British mineral collector of the 20th century. Sir Arthur Russell’s Will, directed that his collection should be given to the British Museum (Natural History) – now the Natural History Museum. The Russell Society, an organisation for amateur and professional mineralogists, dedicated to British topographical mineralogy, was named in his honor. Arthurite was also a mineral named in his honor and a name shared with his friend Arthur Kingsbury.
other: Hodge (1970) noted that HCl caused a change in color to orange-yellow.
type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1934,615.
National School of Mines, Paris, France.

Saryarka is a UNESCO world heritage site, containing two nature reserves that are important stops for millions of migratory birds.

name: Scheelite
description_short:
Powellite-Scheelite Series.

A primary mineral commonly found as a component of contact-metamorphic tactite; in high-temperature hydrothermal veins and greisen; in granitic pegmatites and medium-temperature hydrothermal veins; in alluvial deposits.
otheroccurrence: Contact metamorphic tactites, high-temperature hydrothermal veins, greisens, and granitic pegmatites; alluvial deposits.
cleavage: Distinct on {101}, interrupted on {112}, indistinct on {001}.
colour: Tan, golden-yellow, colourless, white, greenish, dark brown, etc.; colourless in transmitted light
aboutname: Named in 1821 by Karl Caesar von Leonhard in honor of Carl Wilhelm Scheele [December 9, 1742, Stralsund, Pomerania, Sweden - May 21, 1786, Köping, Sweden], Swedish experimental chemist and commercial apothecary. His experimental work was monumental for the time period and he discovered chlorine and experimented with oxygen before Joseph Priestley recognized it as an element. He investigated many fundamentally important organic compounds. He proved the existence of tungstic oxide in the mineral now bearing his name in 1781.
other:
Decomposed by HCl or HNO3, leaving a yellow powder of hydrous tungstic oxide, which is soluble in ammonia.

Alters to Tungstite, Hydrotungstite, or Cuprotungstite.

Replaced by Wolframite as perfect pseudomorphs. Often replaces Wolframite.
Pseudomorphs of Quartz, Kaolinite, and Bismutite after Scheelite have been noted.
morphology: Crystals commonly pseudo-octahedral {011} or {112} predominant, with modifying forms include {001} {013}, {121} and/or several additional; tabular on {001} at times; {001} commonly rough; {112} frequently diagonally striated, usually parallel to <mi>[_311]</mi>, the intersection with {121}. Usually granular, massive; also columnar.
twinning: On {110} common, penetration and contact twins with a composition plane of (110)or (001).
epitaxidescription:
Scheelite on wolframite, with scheelite {001} [110] parallel to wolframite {010} [001].

Discrete crystals of fluorite on the (111) face of scheelite from the <l id=2235>Tae Hwa mine, Korea</l> (So et al. 1983).
uv: Inherently brightly fluorescent (SW UV & X-rays). Pure end-member material ubiquitously fluoresces bright blue-white (SW UV), but even a small amount of Mo substituting for W produces a creamy yellow fluorescence (SW UV), becoming more yellow with increasing % of Mo. A moderate Fe content can quench the fluorescence. It usually has no response to LW UV but some specimens will fluoresce pink to this band.
thermalbehaviour: Thermoluminescent.
commentcolor: May be compositionally colour zoned.

description_short:

otheroccurrence: granite pegmatites

morphology: Bladed crystals, also elongated to acicular.

opticalbireflectance: Very weak, grey-white to bluish grey-white
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 165479.

opticalextinction: Parallel. X = c; Y = a; Z = b.

commentcolor: Fresh senegalite is green becoming yellow on exposure to sunlight.
