name: Native Silver
description_short:
Copper Group. Gold-Silver Series and Palladium-Silver Series.

Native Silver is the preferred name here for the natural mineral, although the IMA officially uses simply the name 'silver' for the mineral.

Silver is used in jewelry, tableware, coins...
otheroccurrence:
1) Primary hydrothermal veins
2) Secondary enrichment
3) Alluvial nuggets
industrial: An electrical conductor, in photoactive chemicals in film and light darkening glass, jewelry, coinage.
colour: Silver-white, tarnishes dark gray to black
aboutname: An Old English word "seolfor" whose original meaning is now lost. The current spelling "silver" was known as early as 1478. Known in ancient Roman times as argentum. The chemical element abbreviation Ag comes from argentum.
morphology: Crystals are cubic, octahedral, dodecahedral to a cm. Often elongated to many cms in herringbone twins and wires (crystals elongated along the [111] axis).
twinning: Penetration twins on (111) with cubes from Kongsberg and tetrahexahedrons from Michigan (bearpaws). Arborescent growths twinned on (100) and on (111).
epitaxidescription:
Mixtures with Ag on Cu and more rarely Cu on Ag. The face centred lattice is continuous between the two minerals.
Wires with black Acanthite crystals and coating form by continuing the face centred cubic silver between the minerals.

name: Sinkankasite
tlform: Complete pseudomorphs after subhedral to euhedral triphylite and as cavity fillings formed from the partial or complete dissolution of triphylite; ranging in size from <1 to 10 cm3. Also found along fractures that cut quartz, microcline, albite, and muscovite.
occurrence: Late-stage hydrothermal alteration product of triphylite.
aboutname: Named in 1984 by Donald R. Peacor, Pete J. Dunn, Willard Lincoln Roberts, Thomas J. Campbell, and William B. Simmons in honor of Captain John Sinkankas [May 15, 1915 Paterson, New Jersey, USA - May 17, 2002 San Diego, California, USA] innovator in faceting gem stones, author of mineralogical and gemological books, rare geoscience book dealer, mineral artist, mineral collector, and associate with Scripps Institute of Oceanography.
other: Readily soluble in dilute 1:1 HCl.
morphology: Elongate on [001], tabular on {100} and composed of the forms {100}, {010}, and {001}.
opticalcomments: Optical measurements are complicated by intrinsic multiple twinning.
type_specimen_store: The Natural History Museum, London, England; National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 149597.

name: Smirnite
tlform: Tabular crystals up to 2 mm and aggregates, or crusts on quartz and tellurides.
occurrence: Occurs in fractures of vein quartz and chalcedony, containing the relics of tellurobismuthite, tetradymite, volynskite and galena.
otheroccurrence: Oxidation zone of tellurium bearing hydrothermal ore deposits.
cleavage:
Perfect on {010}
Distinct in other directions
aboutname: Named after Vladimir Ivanovich Smirnov (Владимир Иванович Смирнов) (18 (31) January 1910, Moscow, Russian Empire - 16 June 1988, Moscow, USSR), chief of economic minerals studies in the geology department, Moscow State University, a specialist in ore deposit geology.  He also served as Vice-President of the International Union of Geological Sciences (1968-1976).
morphology: Crystals tabular to 2mm, aggregates and incrustations.
opticalcomments: Z = a, Y = b, X = c
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, 82767.
thermalbehaviour: Melts at 900 C without decomposition.
commentcolor: Darkens on exposure to sunlight

name: Sodalite
mindat_formula_note: Some K substitutes for Na in the grey-white Afghan sodalites. Hackmanite was originally defined as containing S. The brilliant yellow fluorescence arises from a disulfide ion with a negative charge replacing the Cl.
description_short:
Sodalite Group. Also classed as a feldspathoid.

Ideally sodalite has Na^4Cl in the two cages in the unit cell. Unlike haüyne and nosean, sodalite is virtually CO2-free (Bellatreccia et al., 2009).

In some sodalites, the aluminosilicate cages appe...
occurrence: Nepheline Seyenite
aboutname: The name reflects its sodium content.
other: May give off odor of H<sub>2</sub>S on fracture.
morphology: Crystals rare, dodecahedron.
twinning: Common on {111} forming pseudohexagonal prisms. (This may not be twinning, but merely elongated growth in the (111) direction). Twinning can occur in these elongated crystals. These have re-entrants in the terminations and 6 terminal faces instead of 3 for an elongated dodecahedron.
uv:
Bright red-orange under SW UV light and blue, white, pink, red, yellow under LW UV light.
Cathodoluminescent (the effect is quenched by high concentrations of S, as shown by Zahoransky et al., 2016).
Yellowish phosphorescence may be photochromic in magentas.
commentcolor: Colourless, white, light yellow, green, light to very dark blue, gray, pink to violet

name: Sperrylite
description_short:
Pyrite Group.

S-rich variety was once described as a separate species - 'platarsite' (now discredited).
tlform: Brilliant grains, showing crystal faces, from 0.05 to 0.5 mm in diameter.
otheroccurrence: Ultramafic intrusions, platinum deposits.
aboutname: Named after Francis Louis Sperry (22 October 1861, Talmadge, Ohio, USA - 17 April 1906), chemist at Sudbury, Ontario, who discovered the mineral.
other: Only slightly attacked by aqua regia.
morphology: Cubes and cubo-octahedrons.
type_specimen_store: Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Canada; Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, USA, 1.2950, 1.5895.
thermalbehaviour: Decrepitates slightly when heated. In the closed tube it remains unchanged at the fusing point of glass. In the open tube it very readily gives a sublimate of arsenic trioxide and does not fuse if slowly roasted, but if rapidly heated it melts very easily after losing a part of the arsenic.

name: Spurrite
description_short: The Negra mine (B,Na)-enriched spurrite is isotypic with synthetic NaCa5(SiO4)2(BO3) compound.
tlform: Granular masses which resemble crystallized marble.
occurrence: High-temperature thermal metamorphism along the contact between carbonate rock and mafic magma.
aboutname: Named by Fred Eugene Wright in 1908 after Josiah Edward Spurr (1 October 1870, Gloucester, Massachusetts, USA - 12 January 1950, Orlando, Florida, USA), economic geologist who collected the first specimens. He led expeditions to mapping the interior of Alaska at the beginning of the gold rush. Later he became a renowned consulting economic geologist. In his later years he studied the craters of the moon. The volcano Mount Spurr, in Alaska, and Spurr Crater in the northwestern part of Palus Putredinis near Archimedes Crater, on the Moon, are also named for him.
other:
With a blowpipe srurrite shows a strong calcium flame reaction, loses its glassy luster, becomes white and porcelain-like but does not fuse even in thin splinters.

Effervesces readily with weak hydrochloric acid, dissolves completely and gelatinizes thoroughly.
Green cathodoluminescence.
twinning: Polysynthetic twins on {001} and {101}. Also composition planes {001} or <mi>{20_5}</mi>.
type_specimen_store:
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 86532.
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1923,1032.
commentdense: Measured with a pycnometer, both in xylene and in water

name: Stannite

Penetration twins on {102}. Twin axis {112}, Composition plane {112}.
Polysynthetic in polished section.

name: Stellerite
description_short:
Zeolite Group.
Easily confused with the chemically similar stilbite-Ca and other members of the stilbite subgroup.
Bladed crystals may be confused with colourless prehnite.

Stellerite is a zeolite mineral in the stilbite subgroup. It is the orthor...
otheroccurrence: Cavities and fracture surfaces in hydrothermally altered volcanic and metamorphic rocks.
colour: Colourless to white, pink, orange, yellow, salmon, green, brown
opticalextinction: X = a; Y = c; Z = b.
aboutname: Named after Georg Wilhelm Steller (10 March 1709, Bad Windsheim, Holy Roman Empire - 14 November 1746, Tyumen, Siberia Governorate, Russian Empire), German explorer and zoologist. He took part in the 2nd Kamchatka expedition ("the Great Northern Expedition") led by Danish explorer Vitus Bering.
morphology: Commonly in spheres of radiating crystals. Individual crystal are thin to thick tabular, brick-shaped or with roof-shaped crystal terminations.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, London, United Kingdom, number BM 1934,550 (holotype).

name: Stewartite
description_short: Golden yellow bladed crystals, usually with an acute termination. May occasionally show a similar less acute termination similar to laueite. Note: stewartite may have very similar appearance to laueite, but laueite is usually conspicuously striated, wh...
tlform: Fine fibers arranged normal to the cleavage cracks of the lithiophilite.
occurrence: In pegmatite, as an alteration product of lithiophilite which it replaces along cleavage cracks.
aboutname: Named in 1912 by Waldemar T. Schaller for its discovery locality, the Stewart Lithia pegmatite, Pala, California, USA, that was owned by John Stewart of Los Angeles, Caliornia, USA.
morphology: Crystals minute; tufts of fibers.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = Colourless
Y = Light yellow
Z = Yellow

name: Stilleite

name: Straczekite

name: Sturmanite
mindat_formula_note: Fe(III) may be replaced by Al and Mn(III).

Ettringite Group.

name: Sulvanite
description_short:
Member of Germanite Group?

According to Cressey et al. (1993), four metal valencies characterize sulvanite: Cu+, Cu2+, V2+ (!), and V5+. This could make sulvanite the first known mineral species with divalent vanadium (compare dellagiustaite).
tlform: Massive
colour: Grey in visible light, but cream-gold, bronze gold-yellow in polished section
aboutname: The name reflects its sulfur and vanadium contents.

name: Svanbergite
description_short:
The Sr analogue of woodhouseite and UM2011-07-POSO:AlBaH.
The P analogue of kemmlitzite.

A secondary mineral that is a product of sulphatic argillic wall-rock alteration in hydrothermal vein and disseminated ore deposits, replacing apatite, and occ...
tlform: Euhedral crystals.
occurrence: Quartzite
colour: Colourless, yellow, reddish brown to rose-pink; colourless in transmitted light
aboutname: Named after Lars Fredrik Svanberg (13 May 1805, Stockholm, Sweden – 16 July 1878, Uppsala, Sweden), chemist, mineralogist, and Professor of Mineralogy, University of Uppsala, Uppsala, Sweden.
other: Insoluble in acids.
morphology: Crystals commonly rhombohedral <mi>{10_11}</mi>. May be pseudocubic, with <mi>{10_12}</mi>, <mi>{02_21}</mi> and {0001}. Other forms include <mi>{10_10}</mi>, <mi>{01_15}</mi>, <mi>{01_12}</mi>, <mi>{10_17}</mi>, <mi>{10_14}</mi>. Massive, granular.
opticalcomments: Optical anomalies typical in minerals of the Beudantite Subgroup are reportedly absent in Svanbergite.
type_specimen_store: n.d.

name: Swinefordite
description_short: Smectite Group.
aboutname: Named in honor of Ada Swineford (12 July 1917, Chicago, Illinois, USA - 31 July 1993, Manhattan, Kansas), clay mineralogist and professor of geology at Western Washington State College, Bellingham, Washington, USA.

opticalpleochorismdesc: Y = almost colorless; Z = pale yellow-brown
type_specimen_store:
Department of Geology, East Carolina University, Greenville, North Carolina, USA.
Irenee Dupont Mineral Collection, University of Delaware, Newark, Delaware, USA.
National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., USA.
Musee

name: Szaibélyite
description_short: Sussexite-Szaibélyite Series. The magnesium analogue of Sussexite.
tlform: Nodular masses.
occurrence: Crystalline limestone
otheroccurrence:
Saline and borate deposits.
Magnesian skarns.
colour: White to light yellow; colourless in transmitted light

other:
Slowly soluble in acids.

An alteration product of Colemanite, Inyoite, and Hydroboracite (Inder deposits).

name: Taenite
description_short:
Nickel-iron of meteorites with 25-40% nickel; γ-(Ni,Fe). 
Also occurs terrestrially in serpentine bodies.

Compare also the other typical iron meteorite component kamacite, α-(Fe,Ni).

Also compare UM1995-05-E:FeMn.
aboutname: From the Greek ταινία [tainia] meaning "band".
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.

name: Tamarugite
otheroccurrence: Occurs under arid conditions by the oxidation of sulphides in aluminous and alkali-rich environments.

opticaldispersion: r > v to r < v strong

name: Tetrataenite
description_short:
Iron-Nickel Group.

Common in iron meteorites, but very rare in terrestrial rocks.

occurrence: Slow cooled meteorites, esp. mesosiderites and some chondrites which have cooled the slowest.

name: Thermonatrite
description_short:
This water-soluble mineral is found primarily in evaporite deposits and in arid climates where it may form as a surface deposit, or in volcanic fumaroles. 
May originate as an alteration product of natrite.

See also 'UM1959-02-CO:HNa'.
otheroccurrence: As efflorescences on soil in arid regions and in saline lakes.
colour: Colourless to grey or yellow, white
aboutname: From Greek θερμός, "thermos", heat, plus natron, alluding to its origin by thermal drying of that mineral.
other: Soluble in water.
morphology: Forms crusts and efflorescence. Crystals thin-lamellar {001}, also tabular {010}; elongated [100] (artificial material).
type_specimen_store: No designated type material.

name: Thorosteenstrupine
mindat_formula_note: Pekov et al. suggest Na<sub>0-5</sub>Ca<sub>1-3</sub>(Th,REE)<sub>6</sub>(Mn,Fe,Al,Ti)<sub>4-5</sub>(Si<sub>6</sub>O<sub>18</sub>)<sub>2</sub>[(Si,P)O<sub>4</sub>]<sub>6</sub>(OH,F,O)<sub>x</sub>•nH<sub>2</sub>O.

name: Native Tin
description_short:
For the commodity click here.

Occurs as greyish metallic grains and nuggets to 1 cm.

Some occurrences may be anthropogenic (product of the smelting of cassiterite ore).

name: Titanite
mindat_formula_note: Often contains minor Al, Fe<sup>3+</sup> and F.
description_short:
Titanite Group. The titanium analogue of Malayaite and Vanadomalayaite. It also seems to be the Ti analogue of UM1999-35-SiO:Ca.

Forms a series with Malayaite. 
Titanite close to end-member composition has space-group symmetry P21/a, whereas titani...
otheroccurrence: Common accessory mineral in intermediate and felsic plutonic rocks, pegmatites, alpine veins. Also in some gneisses, schists, and skarns.
colour: Brown, green, yellow, orange, rose-red, black, beige, grey, colourless, grey-blue, bluish
aboutname: First recognized as "nouveau substance minérale" in 1787 by Marc August Pictet, but only described and named in 1795 by Martin Klaproth for its titanium content. A common synonym, sphene (from the Greek sphenos (σφηνώ), meaning wedge, for its common wedge-shaped crystals), was introduced in 1801 by Rene Just Haüy.
morphology:
Common forms are {111}, {110}, {102}, {100}, {001} and {112}. Crystals equant to wedge-shaped, or flattened with large {001} or {102}, or prismatic by extension along [001], to 65 x 17 x 17 cm, compact, massive.
NOTE: The morphological data is based on a choice of unit-cell parameters that differs from the one that is given in Mindat. This 'old' unit cell has a = 6.56, b = 8.72, c = 7.44 Å and β = 119.54° (see the introduction in http://rruff.info/rruff_1.0/uploads/AM61_238.pdf). The 3D drawings of titanite are also based on this old cell.
twinning: On {100}, contact and penetration, less commonly lamellar on {221}.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X= nearly colorless
Y= yellow to green
Z= red to yellow orange
commentcrystal: May be metamict. Titanite close to end-member composition has space-group symmetry P21/a, whereas titanite with significant additional constituents has A2/a symmetry. Smaller unit cells indicate an Al- and F-rich composition.

name: Todorokite
mindat_formula_note: Also given as (Ca,K,Na,Mg,Ba,Mn)(Mn,Mg,Al)<sub>6</sub>O<sub>12</sub>.3H<sub>2</sub>O.
description_short:
A relatively common Mn oxide that occurs in a variety of aggregate forms. Usually fibrous, either compact or isolated. Micaceous aggregates may be confused with ranciéite, fibrous forms with pyrolusite. Compare woodruffite.

As with birnessite, it ma...
tlform: Very fine fibrous flakes, < 0.05 mm in length. The flakes are arranged in lamellar layers, in which the lamellae are vertical to the surface of the layer.
otheroccurrence: Common in ocean floor manganese nodules; found in manganese oxide deposits; late stage coating in granite pegmatite
colour: Purplish gray, brown to black; brown in transmitted light
aboutname: Named in 1934 by Toyofumi Yoshimura after its discovery locality, the Todoroki Mine, Hokkaido, Japan.
morphology: Spongy banded and/or reniform aggregates composed of minute lathlike to fibrous crystals. Crystals flattened {010} and elongated [001] with terminal edges inclined about 60° and 70° to [001].
twinning: Contact twins with c ^ ć about 60°.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Pleochroic in brown.
commentcrystal: β may be variable; formerly given as orthorhombic or tetragonal

name: Törnebohmite-(La)
description_short: The La analogue of törnebohmite-(Ce).
tlform: Rare crystals in fissures; more commonly as grains, to 3 mm, or veins in cerite; in concentrically zoned aggregates around cerite and bastnaesite.
aboutname: Named törnebohmite after Alfred Elis Törnebohm (1838-1911), geologist, and a pioneer in the study of the Archean rocks of central Sweden. Later renamed with the suffix indicating the dominant rare earth element.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = strong bluish green; Y = yellow-green; Z = pinkish.

name: Trembathite

description_short:
Boracite Group. The magnesium analogue of congolite, always (at standard temperature and pressure) containing some iron, from Mg^0^.68Fe^0^.32 to Mg^0^.5Fe^0^.5. 

Compare with boracite.

occurrence: Evaporite deposit.

type_specimen_store: Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M44741.

name: Triphylite
description_short:
Triphylite Group.  Triphylite-Lithiophilite Series.

The most abundant primary phosphate mineral in phosphate and other complex pegmatites, in which it occurs as coarsely crystalline masses, rarely in crystals.
Fresh material is greenish gray to blu...
occurrence: Granite pegmatite.
otheroccurrence: Complex zoned granitic pegmatites.
cleavage: On {001} nearly perfect; on {010} good; on {011} poor.
colour: Brown-green, light green-gray, may appear blue-gray; colourless to pale yellow in transmitted light.
opticalextinction: Parallel, may rarely be optically (+), oxidation greatly increases RI, e.g. α 1.790 β 1.805 γ 1.820 biref 0.030 2V = 85°; Mg reduces RI (Am Min 28:90 (1943)).
aboutname: Named in 1834 by Johann Nepomuk von Fuchs from the Greek τοίς, "tria", for threefold, plus φυλή "phylon", family, because it was thought to contain three cations (Fe, Li, Mn).
other: Soluble in acids.
morphology: Crystals rare; commonly coarse with uneven surfaces; stout prismatic [100]. Massive, rarely granular. May exist in pods over 1 meter across. Commonly replaced by siderite with accompanying secondary phosphate species.
epitaxidescription: As coarsely laminated intergrowths with Graftonite, both phases mutually oriented with Graftonite {010} [100] parallel to Triphylite {102} [010].
commentdense: Value for Fe end-member. Range 3.53-3.59
commentcolor: Blue shades may be due to vivianite inclusions.

name: Trolleite
description_short: Usually massive translucent light green to bluish green masses with a greasy luster. May be very blue because of mixtures with scorzalite.

name: Tsumebite
description_short:
The phosphate analogue of arsentsumebite.

A secondary mineral in polymetallic ore deposits.

Note: Chemically verified Tsumeb tsumebite is rare, and most unanalysed specimens so labelled are most likely arsentsumebite.

occurrence: Oxidation zone.
colour: Emerald-green sometimes bluish green; green in transmitted light.

name: Tunellite
tlform: White compact fine-grained nodules. Also as individual long prismatic crystals up to 1.5 cm in length and equant crystals up to 1 cm in diameter.
occurrence: A secondary mineral in a borate deposit.
otheroccurrence: Secondary mineral in borate deposits
aboutname: Named by R.C. Erd, V. Morgan, and J.R. Clark in 1961 in honor of George Gerard Tunell, Jr. (4 April 1900, Chicago, Illinois, USA - 4 July 1996, Montecito, California, USA), professor of geochemistry, University of California. President of the Mineralogical Society of America (1950) and Roebling Medal recipient in 1973. He made major advances in X-ray crystallography, physical chemistry, and thermodynamic analysis of minerals, especially metallic ores. The name is pronounced tŭn nĕl' īt.
other:
Soluble in cold dilute acid or strong alkaline solutions. Unaffected by glycerol or methanol. In H2SO4, a coating of SrSO4 inhibits further dissolution.

Heated in a closed tube, tunellite exfoliates perpendicular to the cleavage, turns silvery white (resembling muscovite), then turns chalky white. The water driven off has a pH of 4.
morphology: Crystals to 10 cm elongated on [001]. Flattened tabular with dominant {100}. Compact fine grained nodules.  Forms include {100}, {001}, {110}, {011}, and {111}.

name: Tyrrellite
mindat_formula_note: Also given as <f>Cu(Co#3+#,Ni#3+#)^2Se^4</f>.
description_short:
Se analogue of carrollite and Co analogue of nickeltyrrellite. Unique combination of elements (2024).
Compare bornhardtite.

Occurs as small grains that look like clausthalite without the cleavage.
tlform: Grains, rounded or subhedral cubes.
occurrence: Selenide deposit composed primarily of umangite.
aboutname:
Informally named by S.C. Robinson in honor of Joseph Burr Tyrrell (1 November 1858, Weston, Ontario, Canada - 26 August 1957, Toronto, Ontario, Canada), geologist, Geological Survey of Canada. Tyrrell was an early explorer and surveyor of northern Canada, especially the area between Lake Athabasca and Hudson Bay.

Robinson & Brooker (1952) gave a partial description of an unnamed selenide from Ato Bay (TL2), which according to Harris (1970) was later informally named tyrrellite by Robinson. The name appeared in Hey (1963) and Sendeeva (1964) without explanation. It was formally confirmed as a new species by Harris (1970), who completed the full description of the mineral on material from the Eagle claims (TL1) (Horváth 2003).
morphology: granular

description_short:

name: Uytenbogaardtite
description_short:
May form as exsolutions in (originally Au-bearing) acanthite. Structurally different from (stoichiometrically similar) petzite and fischesserite, although forming a series with the latter. Often found in 0.1mm grains, in clusters. 

Analogous to Cu-b...
tlform: Gray-white metallic to tannish gray-white metallic grains. Frequently changes color, especially in polished sections. Iridescence noted varying from metallic tan, to brassy and "metallic pink". The mineral rarely is larger than 100 microns and crystals ar
aboutname: Named in 1978 by M. D. Barton, C. Kieft, E. A. J. Burke, and I. D. Oen in honor of Willem Uytenbogaardt (July 18, 1918 Amsterdam, The Netherlands - May 25, 2012 Aalsmeer, The Netherlands), professor of geology, Technical University of Delft (The Netherlands).
morphology: Not observed in crystals to date. Grains of uytenbogaardtite are rarely larger than 100 microns and magnification is necessary to observe the mineral.

1) Institute of Earth Sciences, Free University of Amsterdam.
2) University of Amsterdam, Amsterdam, The Netherlands
3) National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian), Washington, D.C., USA, 105328, B239.

commentcolor: Uytenbogaardtite is commonly gray-white metallic, but it tarnishes very easily in bright light. Polished sections, in particular, may show rapid color changes within minutes. Various references report differing iridescence. Tan is commonly observed, but shades of pink to brassy are also observed.

name: Vanmeersscheite

name: Vasilite

type_specimen_store: National Museum of Earth and Man, Sofia, Bulgaria (sample No. l0 213).

name: Verplanckite
cleavage: Good on<mi> {11_20}</mi>; on {0001}, poor or a fracture.

aboutname: Named in honour of William Everett Ver Planck Jr. (1 September 1916, Pennsylvania, USA - 14 June 1963, San Francisco, California, USA), geologist, California Division of Mines and Geology, USA.
other: Completely but slowly soluble in dilute HCl. The mineral is quickly bleached, and then slowly dissolved. The mineral reacts essentially the same in other dilute acids; but the bleached fragments do not dissolve completely. No apparent change in concentrated sodium hydroxide.
opticalpleochorismdesc: O = yellow-orange; E = colorless
type_specimen_store: California Division of Mines & Geology, San Francisco, California, USA
thermalbehaviour:
Fuses at about 3 1/2 and gives off water in a closed tube test.

Rapidly heated to 900 °C, in an electric furnace, verplanckite retains its shape but turns black. At 1100 °C it turns purple, and at 1200 °C it melts completely to a reddish brown glass.

name: Villyaellenite
description_short:
Compare giftgrubeite, the ordered (Ca:Mn = 3:2) intermediate member between villyaellenite and sainfeldite.

See also the closely related miguelromeroite. Note: The miguelromeroite samples from the Veta Negra mine, Chile, were originally labeled "vil...

morphology: Rosettes of prismatic crystals, elongated || [001], tabular || {100}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X=very pale orange pink, Y=exceedingly pale pink, Z=pale orange pink; Z>>X>Y.

prismatic, to 5 mm
granular, and in fine-grained aggregates.

name: Voltaite
description_short:
Voltaite Group. The Fe2+ analogue of magnesiovoltaite, and K-Fe2+ analogue of ammoniomagnesiovoltaite.

Belongs to a group of ferrous-ferric sulfate minerals, together with bílinite, copiapite, römerite (purely Fe minerals), metavoltine, and pertliki...

Chi from the language of the early inhabitants of the discovery area (Franklin, NJ), the Lenni Lenape Indians, "wawayanda" meaning many or several windings, in allusion to the grossly curved and winding habit of the mineral's crystals.

name: Wickmanite
description_short: Schoenfliesite Group. The Ge analogue (unnamed) is described by Geier & Ottemann (1970) (see 'UM1970-16-OH:GeMn').
tlform: Yellow perfect unmodified octahedra to 2 mm on edge.
occurrence: Late-stage low temperature mineral in skarn.
aboutname:
Named after Frans Erik Wickman (21 March 1915, Stockholm, Sweden - 2 January 2003), Swedish mineralogist. He made many contributions regarding the mineralogy of Långban, the type locality of Wickmanite.

Wickman graduated with a licentiate degree in 1943, was a physicist at Bolidens Gruv AB from 1944 to 1946 and an assistant teacher of mineralogy at Stockholm University from 1946 to 1947. He was professor of mineralogy at the Swedish Museum of Natural History in Stockholm from 1947 to 1967, of geochemistry at Pennsylvania State University from 1967 to 1974 and of mineralogy and petrology at Stockholm University from 1974 to 1980. Wickman was a member of the Swedish Natural Science Research Council from 1955 to 1962. He was awarded an honorary doctorate in Stockholm in 1952 and was awarded the Sixten Heyman Prize in 1983.

Wickman's research was focused on the structure determination of minerals, and it was he who introduced isotope geology to Sweden. He also devoted himself to meteorite research and was the researcher who first realized that many rounded structures in the Swedish bedrock were formed by meteorite impacts. Wickman was elected a member of the Swedish Academy of Sciences in 1955 and served as its president from 1976 to 1979. He was elected to the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters in 1963, to the Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters in 1971 and to the Physiographic Society in Lund in 1973. Wickman was chairman of the Geological Society in Stockholm in 1975.
other: Soluble, with difficulty, in cold 1:1 hydrochloric acid solution, coloring the solution pale green.
morphology: Octahedrons.
type_specimen_store:
Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm, Sweden, 532405.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 120068, 162615.

name: Wöhlerite

He was the first to isolate the chemical elements beryllium and yttrium in pure metallic form.
other: Cathodoluminescence is blue-green.
morphology: Prismatic crystals to 3 cm, granular. Thick tabular on {100}. Brøgger (1890) list these forms as the more frequent ones <mi>{100}, {110}, {210}, {120}, {130}, {001}, {_101}, {101}, {_111} and {011}. Other forms observed are {010}, {720}, {012}, {021}, {111}, {121}, {311}, {_201}, {_212}, {_121}, {_211}, {_221} and {_161}.</mi>
twinning: Twin plane {010} common; may be complex, lamellar.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X=Y= nearly colorless to pale yellow
Z= wine-yellow

name: Wurtzite
description_short:
Usually found as black to dark reddish-brown massive resinous to sub-metallic material, also as botryoidal banded crusts, and more rarely as hemimorphic pyramidal, or tabular, crystals.
Several polytypes are known; the hexagonal 2H polytype is the mos...
otheroccurrence: Found in hydrothermal veins rich in Zn and as concretions in sedimentary rocks.
cleavage: Very good and easy on <mi>{11_20)</mi>, more difficult on {0001}.
lustre: resinous, bright submetallic on xl faces
aboutname: Named in 1861 by Charles Friedel in honour of Charles Adolphe Wurtz (26 November 1817, Wolfisheim, near Strasbourg, France - 10 May 1884, Paris, France), French chemist who promoted ideas of atomic structure and organic chemistry. Wurtz was a laboratory assistant for Jean Baptiste Dumas at the École de Médecine and succeeded Dumas and was later appointed Professor of organic and mineral chemistry and eventually promoted to dean of the college. Wurtz was appointed chair of organic chemistry at the Sorbonne.  Wurtz was one of the most influential chemists in the world, he received many honours in his lifetime, and his name is one of 72 scientists, mathematicians, and engineers whose name is on the Eiffel Tower. Biography by Rocke (2001).
morphology:
Cell dimensions are given for the -2H polytype, which is reported as being the most common.

Crystals are hemimorphic pyramidal. No forms reported.
Short prismatic to tabular. Concentric banded crusts, fibrous, columnar.

name: Xifengite
description_short:
The Fe analogue of mavlyanovite. One of many natural Fe-Si phases; beside the approved species (listed below) you may want to compare Unnamed (Fe silicide I), Unnamed (Fe silicide II) and UM2000-60-Si:Fe.

The Fe(Si)-analogue of wenjiite.

name: Yoderite

He conducted pioneering work on minerals under high pressure and temperature. He was noted for his study of silicates and igneous rocks.
morphology: Anhedral grains, bladed or lathlike crystals to 12mm

Green - Green, pale yellow, yellow
Color - alpha, beta, gamma

name: Yukonite

Easily confused with Arseniosiderite and identifiable only with XRD methods, although yukonite is frequently amorphous to X-rays.
Paktunc et al. (2015) consider yukonite a "nanocrystalline precursor and Ca-deficient variety of arseniosiderite". King e...
tlform: Black bright pitchy lumps with deep yellow to brown internal reflections. The lumps of yukonite decrepitated from the heat of handling or when submersed in water due to escape and expansion of enclosed carbon dioxide.

Natural History Museum, London, United Kingdom, number BM 1947,344 (holotype, India).
Institute for Mineralogy and Crystallography, Berlin Technical University, Berlin, Germany, number 81/40 (holotype, Namibia).
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, number 149681 (type, Namibia).
commentdense: all data for "brabantite"; measured after heating to 900<sup>o</sup>C
commentcolor: Brown-gray in thin section ("brabantite" material).
ima_history: Redefined IMA 05-F: The name cheralite is applied to the members dominated by CaTh(PO4)2 in the system 2(REEPO4) - CaTh(PO4)2 - 2(ThSiO4); the name brabantite is discredited. See Linthout (2007).

name: Clinoptilolite-K
mindat_formula_note: Generally not pure but containing additional Na and/or Ca. Formula previously given as (K,Na,Ca)2-3Al3(Al,Si)2Si13O36.12H2O.
description_short: The potassium analogue of Clinoptilolite-Ca and Clinoptilolite-Na. Clinoptilolite-K-Heulandite-K Series.
aboutname: From the Greek klino - "oblique"  ptylon - "feather" and lithos - "stone." Named as the monoclinic dimorph of "ptilolite" (mordenite).
opticaldispersion: r > v to r < v strong
commentcrystal: Space Group: C2/m C2, or Cm

name: Damiaoite
tlform: Intimately associated with yixunite. Immiscible gloubles 1-2 mm in diameter.
occurrence: Cobalt- and copper-bearing platinum ore vein of a contact metasomatic deposit (a contact zone of pyroxenite with plagioclasite).
aboutname: For its locality, the Damiao deposit, Damiao, Luanping Co., Chengde Prefecture, Hebei Province, China.
other: Insoluble in HCl, HNO3, HF and H3PO4.
opticalcolour: Bright white with a yellowish tint
type_specimen_store: National Museum for Geology, Beijing, China, M10120.

name: Effenbergerite
description_short: The Ba analogue of wesselsite with which it forms a solid-solution series.
tlform: Subhedral plates with maximum dimensions 8 x 8 x 0.1 mm.
occurrence: Hydrothermal, with a maximum temperature of 450°C.
cleavage: Perfect parallel to {001}. Also a very poor cleavage parallel {1l0} that is usually not readily recognized.
aboutname: Named after Prof. Dr. Herta S. Effenberger (born 16 December 1954), mineralogist and crystallographer of the University of Vienna.
other: Insolubile in all common acids, except hydrofluoric acid.
morphology: The form {001} is always present, at least as a cleavage plane. Sometimes the forms {100}, {1l0}, and {102} are developed.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Dark blue in O and pale blue to nearly colorless in E.
type_specimen_store:
Institut fur Mineralogie und Kristallographie, University of Vienna, Austria, cat. no. 8H/OI-060#1.
Smithsonian Institution, Washington D.C., USA, no. NMNH 170945.
commentluster: Vitreous on cleavage planes, resinous on crystal faces and subvitreous on fracture surfaces.
commentcolor: Similar to linarite in color.

name: Clino-ferro-ferri-holmquistite
mindat_formula_note:
The clino-holmquistite group minerals are monoclinic lithium amphiboles defined with: 
<sup>A</sup>(Na+K+2Ca)< 0.5 apfu,
<sup>C</sup>Li < 0.5 apfu

Clino-ferro-ferri-holmquistite is defined with 
C<sup>2+</sup> position: Fe dominant
C<sup>3+</sup> position: Fe dominant
W position: (OH) dominant
tlform: Intergranular aggregates of subhedral to euhedral habit (size not stated, but extremely small).
occurrence: The episyenites from the Sierra de Guadarrama (Spanish Central System) were formed by the hydrothermal alteration (dequartzification and alkalinization) of granitoids.
aboutname: The nomenclature history for this species is complicated: It was originally described by Caballero et al. (1998) as "ferri-clinoholmquistite", which was later renamed "clino-ferri-holmquistite", renamed again as "sodic-ferri-clinoferroholmquistite", and yet again as "Clino-ferro-ferri-holmquistite", its current valid species name. (The "clino-ferri-holmquistite" name has been re-used for the species originally published as "ferri-ottoliniite" (IMA2001-067).)
type_specimen_store: Museo di Mineralogia, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Università degli Studi di Pavia, Italy, 2001-03 (type).
commentdense: Could not be measured

name: Ferrotitanowodginite
aboutname: The name reflects its composition and relationship to wodginite.

name: Frankhawthorneite
aboutname: Named in honour of Frank Christopher Hawthorne (b. 1946), Professor of Mineralogy, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Manitoba, for his significant contributions to the science of structural and experimental mineralogy and crystallography, especially the crystal chemistry of the amphibole group and oxysalt minerals. Hawthorne has been the author or coauthor of more papers in mineralogy and crystallography than any other scientist and received numerous international honours.
type_specimen_store: Canadian Geological Survey, Ottawa, Canada, 67263.

name: Gmelinite-K
tlform: Granular and radial aggregates of columnar to acicular crystals up to 0.1 x 3 mm (Russia).
occurrence: Found in cavities within brecciated pegmatite (Russia).
aboutname: Named after the German mineralogist and chemist, Christian Gottlob Gmelin (1792-1860) of Tübingen, Germany.  The suffix indicates the dominant extra-framework cation.  In 1997, the name gmelinite (without suffix) was promoted from species to series and gmelinite-K was defined as one of several species.

name: Haigerachite
description_short: Associated with Gengenbachite.
tlform: White spherules, to 0.2 mm across, consisting of scaly crystals to 0.05 mm; rarely as well-developed, thin tabular, pseudohexagonal crystals.
occurrence: Secondary phosphate formed on dump material.
aboutname: Named for the village and valley near the locality.
other: Soluble in dilute HCl or HNO3.
morphology: Thin tabular, pseudohexagonal crystals flattened (001), showing {100} and {110}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X perpendicular to (001)
type_specimen_store:
1) Institute of Mineralogy and Crystal Chemistry, University of Stuttgart, Germany.
2) Staatlichen Museum für Naturkunde, Stuttgart, Germany.

name: Hydrowoodwardite
description_short:
Slowly and reversibly dehydrates to woodwardite.
The range of composition currently ascribed to hydrowoodwardite may represent more than one species (Mills et al., 2012).

Compare also glaucocerinite.
tlform: Blue stalactitic aggregates and botryoidal porous crusts.
occurrence: Secondary mineral in copper deposits.
aboutname: Named as the higher hydrated analogue of <m>woodwardite</m>. Woodwardite itself was named after Samuel Pickworth Woodward (17 September 1821 – 11 July 1865), English naturalist and geologist. In 1845, S. P. Woodward became the professor of geology and natural history in the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester. In 1848, he was appointed assistant in the department of geology and mineralogy in the British Museum. He proposed the term Bernician Series for the lower portion of the Carboniferous System, below the Millstone Grit.
other: Dehydrates to woodwardite in a dry atmosphere, but can be re-hydrated by immersion in water.
type_specimen_store: Technische Universität, Bergakademie, Freiberg, Germany, number 76639 (holotype).

name: Zálesíite
description_short:
Mixite Group. 
The arsenate analogue of Calciopetersite and the Ca-analogue of plumboagardite.

Ca-dominant member, with Ca > sum of REE. 
Visually indistinguishable from other greenish members of the mixite group. Often only unambiguously identifi...
tlform:
transparent hexagonal crystals, up to 100 µm long and 10 µm wide
powdery coatings, cross-fiber veinlets, and tufts of acicular crystals
colour: Pale green, grass-green, pale bluish green
aboutname: Named after the type locality, Zálesí uranium deposit, Zálesí, Javorník, Jeseník District, Olomouc Region, Czech Republic.
other: slowly soluble in dilute HCl.
opticalpleochorismdesc: O = pale yellow-green, E = pale green
type_specimen_store:
Natural History Museum, National Museum Prague
Museum of the Bohemian Paradise, in Turnov, Czech Republic

name: Lemmleinite-K
occurrence: ultra-agpaitic pegmatites in apatite-nepheline in an alkaline massif.
aboutname: Originally named lemmleinite (without suffix) in honor of Georgy Glebovich Lemmlein (Георгий Глебович Леммлейн) (1901-1962), Russian mineralogist and crystallographer.  The suffix was added in 2002 to fit the recommended nomenclature for labuntsovite-group minerals.
morphology: pseudo-orthorhombic, spindle-like crystals
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia.
commentcrystal: : Monoclinic. Point Group: 2/m.; Space Group: C2/m.

name: Kapitsaite-(Y)
mindat_formula_note: more correctly given as Ba<sub>4</sub>(YCa)[Si<sub>8</sub>B<sub>2</sub>B<sub>2</sub>O<sub>28</sub>]F (Hawthorne et al, 2018)
description_short: The YCaB2 analogue of hyalotekite. The crystal structure is very closely related to that of itsiite.
tlform: sheaf-like agregate (1 х 3 сm) of pale-pink grains
aboutname: Named in honor of Pyotr Leonidovich Kapitsa (Пётр Леони́дович Капи́ца) (8 July [O.S. 26 June] 1894[2], Kronstadt, Russian Empire – 8 April 1984, Moscow, Soviet Union), physicist. He was given many awards including the 1978 Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on low temperature physics.
type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia

name: Cerchiaraite-(Mn)
description_short: The Mn analogue of cerchiaraite-(Al) and cerchiaraite-(Fe). Related to bobmeyerite and ashburtonite.
tlform: grains and radial aggregates
aboutname: Named cerchiaraite by Basso et al. in 2000, for the type locality of Cerchiara mine, Italy. It was renamed with a suffix by Kampf et al. in 2013 following the discovery of the Fe and Al analogues. The suffix is for the dominant trivalent M cation.
type_specimen_store: Dipartimento per Studio del Territorio e delle sue Risorse, Università di Genova, Italy.

name: Niobokupletskite
description_short: Astrophyllite Group.
tlform: Anhedral to subhedral, platy to tabular, light beige to yellow epitaxic overgrowths on primary, dark brown kupletskite.
occurrence: Nepheline syenite pegmatites. Late stage mineral.
opticalextinction: Z = c; X and Y in the (001) plane.
aboutname: Named for its Nb content and its relation to <M>kupletskite</M>.
morphology:
Three types described from type description:
Type-I = anhedral to subhedral, platy to tabular, light beige to yellow epitaxic overgrowths on primary, dark brown kupletskite.
Type-II = as a dense, fibrous, light yellow-brown overgrowth on coarse-grained primary kupletskite.
Type-III = as an overgrowth on primary kupletskite as very fine-grained bronze to silvery brown acicular crystals in sheaf-like aggregates, originally described as “witch’s broom astrophyllite”.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X ≈ Y = light orange-yellow; Z = red-brown.
type_specimen_store: Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, number CMNMC 82924 (holotype).
commentdense: Experimentally sinks in methylene iodide that has a density of 3.325 g/cm3.

name: Isovite
tlform: Isometric to angular grains to 0.2mm
occurrence: Associated with gold, various platinum-group minerals, cinnabar, Cr spinel, and unnamed Cr-Fe minerals, including carbides.
aboutname: Named for the Isovsky district, that includes the locality.
type_specimen_store: A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia

name: Juonniite
description_short: Unique combination of elements.
tlform: Spherulites, to 0.8 mm across, consisting of subparallel, commonly curved, plates up to 12 mm across and 2 mm thick.
occurrence: Incrustations in cavities and along contacts with ore minerals in metasomatically reworked calcite-phlogopite-clinohumite-magnetite ores in a calcite-dolomite carbonatitic stockwork zone.
aboutname: The name alludes to the type locality, near the Yona or Juonni River (from the Russian or Finnish, respectively). Pronounced YO'NAITE.
other: Slowly soluble in 10% HCl
morphology: Platy crystals, subparallel, curved, to 12 µm, in spherulites
type_specimen_store: St. Petersburg Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, Russia.
commentdense: Calculated density 2.39–2.47.
commentcrystal: Space Group: by analogy to overite

name: Korobitsynite
description_short: Compare tsepinite-Na and Unnamed (Ca-Na-ordered analogue of Korobitsynite).
tlform: Prismatic crystals uр to 2 сm.
occurrence: In miarolitic cavities in pegmatite.
aboutname: Named after Mikhail Fedorovich Korobitsyn (Михаил Федорович Коробицин) (1928-1996), amateur mineralogist and collector who made significant contributions to mineralogical investigations of the Lovozero alkaline complex.
morphology: Needle-like crystals.  Forms include {110}, {001}, {010}, {100}, and {021}.
ir: The infrared spectrum has absorption bands at 3500, 3390, 3250, 1633, 1118, 959, 919, 750, 667, and 454 cm–1 .
type_specimen_store: A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia, number 89457 (type).

name: Lukechangite-(Ce)
tlform: Tabular, short prismatic, and barrel-shaped crystals up to 1 mm.
occurrence: In a pegmatite dike in a nepheline syenite intrusion.
aboutname: Named in honor of Luke L. Y. Chang (18 September 1934 - 3 August 2009, Silver Spring, Maryland, USA) Professor, University of Maryland, for his contributions to the study of carbonate group minerals.  The suffix follows the nomenclature (Levinson rule) for rare earth elements.
other: Soluble in 1:1 HCl with effervescence.
morphology:
Type material: tabular or short prismatic to barrel shaped crystals.
Forms: <mi>{0001}, {11_20}, and {ll_2l}</mi>.
type_specimen_store: Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, catalogue no. CMNMI 81535 (cotype).
commentdense: Measured greater than 3.3

name: Mitryaevaite
description_short: Chemically related to sanjuanite and arangasite.
tlform: White powder-like masses of crystals 0.01 to 0.04 mm in length.
occurrence: Secondary mineral in fractures and veinlets.
aboutname: For Dr. Nonna Mikhailovna Mitryaeva (b. 1920), in recognition of her contributions to the mineralogy of Kazakhstan.
other: Slowly dissolves in cold acids.
ir: IR absorption bands for (SO4)2- (615 and 650 cm-1), (PO4)3- (500 and 560 cm-1. Broad bands for H2O (3400 and 1630 cm-1) and bands for (OH)- (3575 and 1660 cm-1).
type_specimen_store: Geological Museum, Satpaev Institute of Geological Sciences, Alma-Ata, Kazakhstan, GM IGS 24/1270.
thermalbehaviour:
When heated in a closed tube, it gives off copious amounts of H2O with an acidic pH.

Most water released between 60 and 350 C. A weak endothermic peak at 100 C and a strong peak and 165 C. Up to 250 C a loss of H2O of 24.8 wt.%.

name: Nierite
description_short:
A very rare natural nitride, originally formed in star dust and now found in meteorites.

Synthetic silicon nitride is a very important high-performance ceramic.
aboutname: Named in 1995 by Martin R. Lee, Sara S. Russell, John W. Arden, and C.T. Pillinger in honor of Alfred Otto Carl Nier (May 28, 1911 – May 16, 1994), physicist and Professor of Chemistry at the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA. He was responsible for the now accepted measurement of the atmospheric N-isotope composition. Also was instrumental in the development of mass spectrometry (especially stable isotope mass spectroscopy).
type_specimen_store: The Natural History Museum, London, England.

name: Parascorodite
description_short: The trigonal dimorph of Scorodite. Compare 'UM1979-03-AsO:Fe' and 'UM1979-04-AsO:Fe'.
tlform: Earthy white to white-yellow aggregates.
occurrence: From heavily weathered dumps of polymetallic ore rich in arsenic but thought to have formed in the deposit pre-mining due to natural weathering in the supergene zone.
aboutname: From the Greek "para," for "near," and Scorodite, with which it has a dimorphic relationship.
other:
Dissolves slowly in 10% HCl, but no reaction with water

Under hydrothermal conditions (distilled water, sealed quartz glass container, temperature of 155 °C) lasting for a period of two months, parascorodite re-crystallizes to scorodite.
morphology: Tabular to prismatic hexagonal, tiny (to 1 μm) crystals; may be fan-shaped, in crudely hemispherical aggregates.
type_specimen_store: National Museum, Prague, Czech Republic, number P1p 25/98.

name: Phosinaite-(Ce)
tlform: Accumulations of irregular form (Lovozero). Columnar crystals up to 5 x 1 mm (Khibina).
occurrence: Alkalic pegmatites (Khibina), ussingite veinlets cutting alkalic rock (Lovozero)
aboutname: For its major constituents -  a phosphate silicate of sodium (from Latin "natrium")
other: Dissolves slowly in concentrated acids.
type_specimen_store:
1) A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Science, Moscow, Russia.
2) I.M.G.R.E., Moscow, Russia.
thermalbehaviour: Fuses at 860 deg.

name: Potassic-richterite
mindat_formula_note:
The richterite group minerals are defined as sodium-calcium amphiboles with 0.5 apfu < A(Na+K+ 2Ca) where Na or K is dominant, and with C(Al+Fe<sup>3+</sup>+2Ti) < 0.5 apfu. The W position may contain (OH),F or Cl. 

Potassic-richterite is defined with 
A position: K dominant
C position: Mg dominant
W position: (OH) dominant.
tlform: Subhedral to anhedral short-prismatic crystals and commonly elongated along [001] with average crystal size of 1–2 mm, exceptionally up to 4 mm long
uv: No fluorescence effects have been observed under ultraviolet light
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Department of Geosciences, Swedish Museum of Natural History, Box 50007, SE-10405 Stockholm, Sweden, collection number NRM19311387
commentdense: could not be measured directly due to the foreign mineral inclusions in the crystals
commentcolor: In thin sections transparent and pale yellow
ima_history:
2012: "Named amphibole" (in accordance with the IMA-approved nomenclature, but not formally approved as a species)
IMA 2018: Approved (IMA No. 2017-102)

name: Quadratite
description_short: The Cd analogue of manganoquadratite.
tlform: Occurs as characteristic quadratic crystals, some of which are octagonal in shape, rarely to 1 mm.
aboutname: The name is derived from the conspicuous quadratic shape of the mineral.
morphology: Crystals tabular, showing a large {001}, with {103}, {104}, {111}, and {116}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Could not be determined because type polished sections were parallel to (001).
opticalcomments: Optical data are available only for grains mounted parallel to (001)
opticalcolour: Grayish white with a bluish tint
opticalinternal: Dark red along cleavage cracks (in oil)
opticalbireflectance: Could not be determined because type polished sections were parallel to (001).
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum in Basel, and in the Mineralogical Institute, University of Basel, Switzerland.
commentbreak: Ductile to flexible in thin laminae

name: Scandiobabingtonite
tlform: Submillimeter-sized, short, prismatic crystals.
colour: Colourless, pale grey-green, ligth green, dark green
aboutname: The name reflects its composition, as the scandium analogue of Babingtonite. It was first found in the 1990s by the Italian collector G. Nova and later described by Orlandi et al. (1998).
morphology: Short, prismatic crystals, slightly elongated on [001]. Forms observed: {010}, {001}, {110}, {1-10}, and {101}.
epitaxidescription: Platy crystals forming a thin rim around green-black prismatic crystals of babingtonite (Seula Mine).
opticalpleochorismdesc: With colors from pink (gamma') to green (alpha').
type_specimen_store: Museo di Storia Naturale e del Territorio, University of Pisa. A small crystal is also stored in the Royal Ontario Museum, University of Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
commentdense: The calculated density is given for the Sc endmember

name: Sidpietersite
description_short:
One of a relatively small group of thiosulphate minerals.

The thiosulphate analogue of kennygayite.
tlform: Iill-formed, almost warty, nodular masses and crystal groups, as earthy masses and, rarely, as free-standing to radiating bladed-crystal aggregates. Masses, groups and aggregates never exceed 3 mm.  Individual subhedral to almost euhedral crystals are bladed, with a length-to-width ratio of approximately 4:1 and not exceeding 0.2 to 0.3 mm in maximum length.
occurrence: Oxidation zone, secondary after galena. The last mineral to form, on the galena-sphalerite matrix and on the zincite-coated crystals of smithsonite.
aboutname: Named after Sidney Pieters (1920-2003), of Windhoek, Namibia for his outstanding contributions to Namibian mineralogy.
other: In dilute HCl, there is only an initial effervescence, after which the material turns to a chalky white color over a few minutes.
morphology: Crystals are bladed, elongate <mi>[01_1]</mi>, with a length-to-width ratio of approximately 4:1. Forms are {001} major, and possible very thin {100} and <f>{01_1}</f> minor.
opticalcomments: Specular reflectance about 12-14%.  Refractive index about 2.
opticalinternal: Reflectance is almost entirely overpowered by brilliant white internal reflections. The thickest crystals gave yellow-brown internal reflections.
type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1998,36.
Canadian Geological Survey, Ottawa, Canada, 68076.

name: Stilbite-Na
mindat_formula_note: Usually not pure, but containing also minor K and Ca. Formula also given as <f>(Na,Ca,K)^6-7[Al^8Si^28O^72].nH^2O</f>.
description_short:
Zeolite Group.

Note: due to the high Na content, the monoclinic C2/m symmetry of stilbite is retained, in contrast to the chemically similar, but Na-free stellerite which is orthorhombic.
colour: White, colourless, red, light yellow, light to dark brown, cream
aboutname: Named in 1797 by Jean Claude de la Métherie from Greek στιλβη "stilbein", to glitter or shine, or "stilbe", a mirror, alluding to its pearly or vitreous luster. Originally, but inconsistently called zeolite in 1756 by Axel Cronstedt. Named crystalii ad centrum tendentes in 1758 by Cronstedt. In 1772, Johan Gottschalk Wallerius called this mineral zeolite selenitica lamellaris. Also in 1797, de la Métherie called this mineral zeolite nacrée. Werner (1780) called this mineral strehliger zeolith. Rene Just Haüy (1801) used the term stilbite anamorphique for a mineral now recognized as heulandite. Desmine was introduced in 1818 by Johann Friedrich August Breithaupt. Sphaerostilbite was used in 1832 by François Sulpice Beudant. Additional varietal names and synonyms have been proposed: blättricher zeolit, hypostilbite, puflerite, radiated zeolite, and syhedrite. Chemical suffixes were added by the IMA.

name: Terranovaite
description_short:
Zeolite Group.

According to Galli et.al., "Terranovaite .... was found in only one of the Ferrar dolerite samples collected. The specimen is from the SW crest, just under the summit of Mt. Adamson (Lat. 73° 56'S, Long. 162° 56'E)."

Terranovaite, ...
tlform: Globular masses that flake off in transparent lamellae.
occurrence: Cavities in dolerite.
opticalextinction: X = c; Y = a; Z = b.
aboutname: Named for the Italian Antarctic Station at Terranova Bay, Antarctica.
type_specimen_store: Museo di Storia Naturale e del Territorio, University of Pisa, Italy (catalog no. 15520).
commenthard: Could not be measured due to the small crystal size.
commentcrystal: Cmcm space group, even though the real symmetry is probably C2cm

name: Vanadomalayaite
description_short:
Titanite Group. 

The vanadium (V4+) analogue of titanite and malayaite.
tlform: Subhedral, prismatic, deep red, isolated grains up to 0.4 mm.
occurrence: Occurs sparingly in a small vein of calcite, quartz, and haradaite that cuts ophiolitic metacherts.
aboutname: Named for its vanadium content and chemical relationship to malayaite.
morphology: Prismatic
opticalpleochorismdesc: X ≈ Y = brownish red-orange, Z = deep greenish blue.
type_specimen_store: Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Sezione di Mineralogia, Universita di Genova, Italy.

name: Wilhelmkleinite
description_short: Lazulite Group.
tlform: blackish green, spearhead-shaped crystals up to 5 mm long.
aboutname: For Wilhelm Klein (29 November 1889, Distelshausen, Germany - 30 November 1939, Windhoek, (now) Namibia), Mine Manager of the Otavi Mining and Railroad Company mines in Namibia (1916 to 1939), who made the first systematic collection of minerals from the Tsumcorp Mine, Tsumeb.
morphology: Spearhead-shaped crystals showing the forms <mi>{430}, {100}, {31_1}, and {3_1_1}</mi>.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Strong; olive-green to emerald-green to reddish brown.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Museum of the University of Hamburg, Germany.

name: Zdenĕkite
description_short: Lavendulan Group. The lead analogue of Lavendulan.
aboutname: Named by P.-J. Chiappero and H. Sarp in 1995 in honour of Dr. Zdenĕk Johan (18 November 1935, Lomnice nad Popelkou, Czech Republic - 13 February 2016, Orléans, France), mineralogist and Director of Scientific Affairs of the Bureau de Recherches Géologiques et Minières, France. Vice president of the International Mineralogical Association, 1996-1998. The mineral is based on his given name rather than his family name because the mineral <m>johannite</m> was already named.
morphology: Thin pseudotetragonal plates.
twinning: Several twin laws appear to exist.

name: Calciosamarskite
description_short:
Samarskite Group.

The empirical formula based on Hanson et al. (1999) is (Ca0.31Y0.17Fe2+0.26U0.19Na0.08REE0.23)1.24(Nb0.79Ta0.07Ti0.04)0.90O4; all elements are required for charge balance, and iron is assumed to be ferrous, also to maintain charge ...
tlform: As anhedral masses.
occurrence: An accessory mineral in RE-rich granite pegmatites
aboutname: Honors Colonel Vasilii Evgrafovich von Samarskii-Bykhovets (1803-1870), Chief of Staff of the Russian Corps of Mining Engineers. The prefix, calcio, indicates Ca is dominant in the A-site.
morphology: Massive or in rough, square prisms (Parry Sound material)

name: Silicocarnotite
mindat_formula_note: May also be written Ca<sub>5</sub>SiP<sub>2</sub>O<sub>12</sub> or Ca<sub>5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>SiO<sub>4</sub>.
description_short:
Isotypic with ternesite. A member of the ternesite-silicocarnotite solid solution. Chemically similar to nagelschmidtite and 'ciplyite'.

Known for a long time as an artificial, calcium silico-phosphate in slag.

Natural material was found within t...
tlform: Common grains with ternesite
occurrence: Pyrometamorphic gehlenite-bearing rocks
aboutname:
Synthetic material was discovered in slag by Adolphe Carnot and A. Richard in 1883.  The material was named by Kroll in 1911 after Carnot. The name silicocarnotite has been used for the synthetic phase Ca5[(SiO4)(PO4)](PO)4 since then.  The natural mineral was described by Galuskin et al. in 2016 and they kept the same name.

Marie Adolphe Carnot (27 January 1839, Paris, France – 20 June 1920) was a French chemist, mining engineer and politician.  He was a chemistry professor at École des Mines in Paris and later Chief Engineer of Mines and Inspector General of Mines, becoming Dean of the École Nationale des Mines in 1901-1907, when he retired. The unrelated mineral <m>carnotite</m> is also named after him.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Museum of Natural History in Bern with catalogue number NMBE-42716

name: Fencooperite
tlform: A dominant phase within black aggregates 2 mm across in barium-silicate-rich lenses.  Individual grains are anhedral to somewhat rounded to occasionally platy, and do not exceed 100 µm in size.
colour: Jet black to a dirty grey-brown (on very thin edges)
aboutname: Named for California mineral collector Joseph Fenimore Cooper, Jr. (April 30, 1937, Santa Cruz, California - June 6, 2017, Santa Cruz, California). He was an avid collector of western U.S. minerals, especially in California and Nevada, and contributed to more than twenty publications.
morphology: No crystal forms observed.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Very strongly pleochroic. nω = deep bluish-black nε = light greenish-gray
type_specimen_store: National Mineral Collection at the Geological Survey of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
commentdense: Dcalc 4.212 (empirical formula) and 4.338 (ideal formula).  Density could not be measured due to small grain size and lack of pure material.

name: Theoparacelsite
description_short: Related to lapeyreite.
tlform:
Aggregates in cuprite cavities 1 mm in diameter. The aggregates consist of
crystals (up to 0.2x0.1x0.05 mm), rectangular elongate crystals (up to 90x10x5 µm), perfect rectangular crystals (10x7 x µm), equidimensional crystals (~20 µm), pseudomorphs after thin acicular crystals of olivenite. Also as powder.
occurrence: Oxidation zone.
opticalextinction: X = a; Y = c; Z = b.
aboutname: For Swiss scientist Paracelsus, whose full name was Philippus Theophrastus Aureolus Bombastus von Hohenheim (1493–1541), an eminent physician, chemist, toxicologist and alchemist who also worked in metallurgy and in mineralogy.
other: Soluble in HCl.
morphology:
Anhedral grains 0.2 × 0.1 × 0.05 mm, as smaller equidimension
crystals, and as rectangular crystals elongate [010], flattened
{001}, showing {001}, {010}, {100}, {110}, and {101}; also
powdery, and as pseudomorphs after olivenite.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
α = light olive green, β = olive green, γ = dark
green.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum of Geneva, Switzerland.

name: Kleberite
mindat_formula_note:
Structural formula:  [Ti<sub>3</sub><sup>4+</sup>[]][Ti<sub>3</sub>
<sup>4+</sup>Fe<sup>3+</sup>]O<sub>11</sub>(OH)<sub>5</sub>
description_short:
Chemically similar to 'Hydroxylian Pseudorutile'.

Product of the alteration of ilmenite.

The structure is described as a unit-cell scale intergrowth of two elements: (1) goethite-type M(2)O(OH), with M(2) = Ti, and (2) rutile-type M(1)O2. The int...
tlform: Rounded grains, anhedral to euhedral, 0.04-0.3 mm.
occurrence: Tertiary sands of Königshain.
aboutname: Named for Wilhelm "Will" Kleber (15 December 1906 - 27 August 1970), a German mineralogist, crystallographer and petrologist, Humboldt University, Berlin, Germany. The mineral name was originally published without IMA approval, but the species was finally officially approved in 2012.
opticaldispersion: Locally biaxial (-) with 2V ~0; average n value given
type_specimen_store: Type specimens from Murray Basin and Kalimantan: Museum Victoria, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, nos. M52010 and M52011, respectively. Type specimen from Königshain: Museum für Naturkunde, Berlin, Germany, no. 1980-0283.
commentdense: Measured density lower than the calculated one due to intragrain porosity.
commentcrystal: Pseudohexagonal subcell (due to multiple twinning) with a = 2.845, c = 4.575 A (similar to pseudorutile which has a subcell with a = 2.866, c = 4.602 A) (Grey et al., 2013).
commentcolor: Becomes orange when the Fe content decrease; yellow through red-brown to deep red in transmitted light.

name: Baumstarkite
mindat_formula_note: Minor As-for-Sb substitution possible. Formerly given as AgSbS<sub>2</sub>.
description_short: The triclinic polymorph of Miargyrite and Cuboargyrite.
tlform: Individual crystals not exceeding 3 mm, crystal aggregates up to 40x10mm coating miargyrite. Anhedral grains in miargyrite common (up to several mm).
occurrence: In high-grade silver ores of hypogene origin.
aboutname: For German mineralogist and mineral dealer, Manfred Baumstark (b. 1954), who discovered the mineral.
morphology: {001}, <mi>{10_1}</mi>, {201}, {010} and <mi>{01_1}</mi> most frequent, {100} subordinate.

name: Orthominasragrite
tlform: Rounded aggregates (up to ~200 µm across) of irregular grains that are pale blue to bright blue.
occurrence: In a silicified tree, approximately 46 cm x 30 cm.
aboutname: Named for being the orthorhombic polymorph of minasragrite.
type_specimen_store:
Holotype specimen: Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa,
Ontario, catalogue number CMNMC 83269.
X-ray powder mount: Reference collection, X-ray-diffraction laboratory, Geological Survey of Canada.

name: Symesite
description_short:
Related to mereheadite.

Krivovichev et al. (2009) mention a possible carbonate analogue of symesite.
occurrence: Oxidised zone of Mn-Pb-Cu deposit.
aboutname: Named for Robert Frederick Symes (10 February 1939, Harrow, London, UK - 23 May 2016, Exeter, England, UK) of the Department of Mineralogy, The Natural History Museum, London, England.
morphology: Aggregates of blocky crystals.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, London (Specimen # BM1998,37).
commentluster: "adamantine" added, since Welch et al. (2000) indicate R.I. > 2
commentcrystal: Welch et al. (2000) use non-standard setting:  space group B-1, with a  = 19.727(2), b = 8.796(1), c = 13.631(2) Å, alpha = 82.21(1), beta = 78.08(1), gamma = 100.04(1)°, V = 2242.4(5) Å3,  Z = 4. P > B transformation matrix is [0-1-1|100|01-1]

name: Matsubaraite
tlform: Euhedral, prismatic crystal, to ~0.3 mm long occurring interstitially within jadeite grains.  Often hollow.
occurrence: Jadeitite boulder from the bed of the Kotaki River.
aboutname: after Satoshi Matsubara, specialist for strontium minerals in the National Science Museum, Tokyo, Japan
morphology: Euhedral to subhedral prismatic crystals to 0.3mm long. Commonly hollow and in fan-shaped aggregates.
opticalcomments: Refractive indices are higher than those of titanite.
type_specimen_store: National Science Museum, Tokyo, Japan, and Foss Magna Museum, Itoigawa, Niigata, Japan.

name: Magnioursilite
description_short:
Magnioursilite was originally described in 1957 as “ursilite” (now discredited) from the Oktyabr’skoye deposit, Kyzyltyube-Saj, Samgar Steppe, Tajikistan. 

Forms a solid solution with calcioursilite.
tlform: Lemon-yellow earthy or nodular incrustations, rarely radiating spherulites.
occurrence: Occurs along joints in granite porphyry.
aboutname: Named for its chemical composition as a magnesium uranyl silicate.
other: Easily soluble in acids (especially when warm), turning the solution green and yielding silica gel.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = pale green; Z = green.
uv: Fluorescent in greenish yellow under ultraviolet light.
type_specimen_store: No defined type material.

name: Labuntsovite-Fe
tlform: anhedral grains to 2 mm; in aggregates to 0.5 cm
aboutname: Named for the iron content and its relationship to <M>Labuntsovite-Mn</M>
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = Z = pale yellow, Y = orange.
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia (91285).

name: Zincohögbomite-2N6S
description_short: Högbomite Group.
tlform: Small hexagonal plates, in parallel intergrowths or occur in aggregates up to 2 mm in size
occurrence: Metamorphic reaction product in a high grade metamorphic assemblage (marble).
aboutname: Named as the zinc dominant mineral and 2N6S member of polysomatic series of the <m>Högbomite Group</m> (originally described as zincohögbomite-16H). The root name is for Arvid Gustaf Högbom (11 January 1857, Vännäs, Västerbotten, Sweden - 19 January 1940, Uppsala, Sweden), Professor of Mineralogy and Geology at Uppsala University.
opticalpleochorismdesc: O = brown-yellow; E = pale greenish-yellow.
opticalcomments: nω(red) = 1.850 and nω(yellow) = 1.845, nε = not determined.
type_specimen_store: No designated type specimen.
ima_history: IMA Case 01–A - Renamed from zincohögbomite-16H (Grice and Ferraris 2003)

name: Cattiite
tlform: Small massive aggregates and very small crystals.
occurrence: In a vein of dolomite carbonatite in forsterite-magnetite ore.
aboutname: Named in honor of Michele Catti (1945 - ), Italian Professor of Physical Chemistry, University of Milano Bicocca.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Museum, Department of Mineralogy, Saint Petersburg State University, Saint Petersburg, Russia.

name: Proto-anthophyllite
mindat_formula_note: The anthophyllite group are orthorhombic amphiboles in the magnesium-iron-manganese amphibole subgroup. The minerals in this root name group may have either Pnma or Pnmn (proto- prefixed name) space group symmetry. The anthophyllite group's composition is defined with A(Na+K+2Ca)<0.5 apfu and C(Al+Fe3++2Ti)<1 apfu. Proto-anthophyllite is defined with Pnmm symmetry and Mg as the dominant element both in the B and C positions.
tlform: acicular prisms to 10 mm
occurrence: contact-metamorphosed serpentinite
otheroccurrence: metamorphosed serpentinites
aboutname: Named for being a protoamphibole polymorph of Anthophyllite.
morphology: prismatic crystals, elongated parallel to [001]
type_specimen_store: Natural Science Museum, Tokyo

name: Goldquarryite
description_short:
One of the very rare secondary cadmium minerals.
Occurs as isolated sprays of radiating crystals.
tlform: Isolated clusters of radiating crystals and as compact parallel aggregates of crystals. Cluster are typically 0.5 mm in diameter and max 3 mm.  Maximum crystal size is 1.5 mm x 0.1 mm.
occurrence: Supergene mineral in a breccia.
aboutname: For the type locality, at the Gold Quarry Mine, Maggie Creek District, Eureka Co., Nevada, USA.
morphology: Type material: Acicular to elongated flattened blades with dominant {010} and {001}, minor {100}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Deep blue parallel to elongation, very pale blue normal to elongation.
ir: IR absorption shows absorption bands for H2O. A strong intensity band at 3293 cm-1 with a shoulder at 3123 cm-1 due to O-H stretching. A medium intensity band at 1665 cm-1 due to H-O-H bending. Also a very strong band at 1042 cm-1 and a medium strong band at 1143 cm-1 due to fundamental stretching for phosphate.
type_specimen_store: Geologic Survey of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, number 68084 (holotype).

name: Tuite
description_short:
High-pressure polymorph of merrillite.

One of the most simple natural calcium phosphates (compare grahampearsonite).
tlform: Microscopic tabular grains (< 0.02 mm).
occurrence: High pressure phase in a meteorite.
aboutname: Named in honor of Guangzhi Tu (涂光炽) (14 February 1920, Beijing, China - 31 July 2007, Beijing, China), "the founding director of the institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (in Guiyang) and first President of the Chinese Society of Mineralogy, Petrology and Geochemistry, in honour of his great contribution to geochemistry research and his pioneering work in studying Chinese meteorites."
type_specimen_store: Geological Museum of the Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Wushan, Guangzhou, China.

name: Vasilyevite
tlform: microscopic, rounded hollow aggregates (< 0.5 mm across), probably pseudomorphs after mercury
colour: Silverish grey to dark reddish black
aboutname: Named after Vladimir Ivanovich Vasilyev (Владимир Иванович Васильев) (b. 1929) of the Geological Institute at Novosibirsk (Russia) who discovered nine mercury minerals.
type_specimen_store: Holotype material is housed in the Systematic Reference Series of the National Mineral Collection at the Geological Survey of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, cat. num. NMC68094. Polished sections preserved at The Natural History Museum, London, U.K., cat. num. BM2003,5.

name: Catalanoite
tlform: Crystals 0.05 to 0.5 mm in size.
occurrence: Salt lake in arid, high-altitude environment.
opticalextinction: X = a, Y = b, Z = c.
aboutname: Named for Argentine geologist and economist Luciano Catalano (Buenos Aires, 1890 - 1970).
morphology: Bipyramidal and tabular.
type_specimen_store: n.d.

name: Zincospiroffite
description_short: The zinc analogue of Spiroffite. Compare the chemically related dagenaisite.
tlform: As micrometric films coating <M>calaverite</M> or in irregular aggregates replacing <M>calaverite</M>.
occurrence: Secondary co-oxidation product in gold-bearing ore veins.
aboutname: Named as the zinc analogue of <M>Spiroffite</M>.
morphology: micrometric aggregates to 0.35 mm
type_specimen_store: Geological Museum of China, Beijing, People’s Republic of China; M10442.

name: Manganilvaite
description_short: Mn(II)-dominant analogue of Ilvaite.
tlform: Rarely well-shaped dipyramidal crystals, with a prismatic habit along c.
occurrence: In marble-hosted distal skarn-type orebodies.
aboutname: The name is given for its composition, being the manganese analogue of ilvaite.
other: Becomes gelatinized with HCl.
morphology: Predominant forms: r{011}, m{110}, s{210} and o{111}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Bluish gray to grayish brown
opticalcolour: Grayish blue to pale reddish brown
opticalanisotropism: Strong, grayish blue to pale reddish brown
type_specimen_store: Geological Institute, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, Bugaria, M1.2003.5-6.

name: Rouxelite
description_short: Shares structural elements with marrucciite and pellouxite, among other minerals.
tlform: Black acicular crystals, elongated and striated parallel to [010].
occurrence: Late extensional calcite veins embedded in dolomitic limestones.
aboutname: The name honors Jean Rouxel (24 February 1935, Malestroit, France – 19 March 1998, Nantes, France), solid state chemist, Professor and founder of the Institut des Matériaux, University of Nantes, France.
type_specimen_store: Museo di Storia Naturale e del Territorio, Università di Pisa.
commentdense: Calculated based on empirical formula

name: Aluminomagnesiohulsite
description_short: Aluminium dominant analogue of Magnesiohulsite.
tlform: minute stubby prisms to 0.1 mm, included in fibrous ludwigite
occurrence: in a spinel bearing kotoite marble
aboutname: In allusion to the dominance of aluminum in the composition and its chemical relationship to Magnesiohulsite.
opticalpleochorismdesc: brown to blue-green, in polarized light
opticalcomments: Color: Blue-green to brown in thin section
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Collection, Institute for Geology, Mineralogy and Geophysics, Ruhr Universität Bochum, Germany (25164).

name: Bario-olgite
description_short: Originally considered to be Ba(Na,Sr,REE)2Na[PO4]2, the barium-dominant analogue of olgite, but then proposed for discreditation after the crystal structure of olgite was revised and found to be also Ba-dominant [Sokolowa, E. et al. (2005)]. However, s...
tlform: Grains up to 1.5 x 1 cm and, more rarely, pyramidal-prismatic crystals.
occurrence: Hyeragpaitic pegmatite.
aboutname: For the chemical composition and its relationship to olgite
uv: Bright pink-orange in (short wave) and weak pink-red (long wave).
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Science, Moscow, Russia; 2908/1.

name: Herbertsmithite
description_short:
Atacamite Group.
A polymorph of (metastable) kapellasite.
Closely related to paratacamite and easily confused with twinned clinoatacamite.
On heating paratacamite reversibly transforms into herbertsmithite between 353K and 393K (Welch et al., 2014)....
tlform: Rhombohedrons to 1.5 mm across.
otheroccurrence: Copper mineralizations in syenitic porphyries and granites, hosted by triassic dolomites (Anarak, Iran)
aboutname: Named in honor of George Frederick Herbert Smith (26 May 1872, Edgbaston, England, UK - 20 April 1953), crystallographer and curator, British Museum of Natural History, London (England), who discovered the similar mineral paratacamite. The mineral <m>smithite</m> is also named after him.
morphology: Platy, pseudohexagonal crystals to 0.5 mm (Iran); rhombohedrons and pseudo-octahedra to 1.5 mm (Chile).
opticalpleochorismdesc: O > E; green to greenish blue
opticalcomments:
Indices gradually increase with increasing Cu/Zn.
Anomalous birefringence in greenish-blue to dark blue.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, London, United Kingdom, number BM 2003.33.

name: Skaergaardite
description_short: Compare UM2004-06-E:AgCuHgPdTe.
tlform: Skaergaardite occurs as droplets, equant grains with rounded outlines, subhedral to euhedral crystals and as irregular grains that vary in size from 2 to 75 mm, averaging 22 mm.
occurrence: In a tholeyitic gabbro.
aboutname: Named after the Skaergaard intrusion, Kangerlussuaq area, East Greenland.
opticalcomments: Second column of reflectivity data is in oil.
opticalcolour: Bright creamy white to bright white.
type_specimen_store:
Geology Museum, Copenhagen, Denmark (90-24 1057 45-1, 45-2, 125-2, 125-3; GM 2004.66).
Natural History Museum, London, England (BM 2003,47).
Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario (90-24 1057 75-1; CMNMC 84396).

name: Enalite
description_short: Many references (and even the original description) call enalite a uranium-rich variety of thorite, but this is not possible, considering that phosphate dominates over silicate. It could be considered either a Th-Si-rich xenotime, or an independent mem...
tlform: Waterworn tetragonal crystals.
occurrence: Alluvium derived from granite pegmatites.
aboutname: Named for the discovery locality at Fukuoka, Fukuoka-cho, Ena-gun, Gifu Prefecture, Chubu Region, Honshu Island, Japan.

name: Gatelite-(Ce)
description_short:
Gatelite-(Ce) can be regarded as a ET polisome within a polysomatic series having epidote and törnebohmite as end-members.

Chemically related to dissakisite-(Ce), dollaseite-(Ce), manaevite-(Ce), västmanlandite-(Ce), and somewhat to khristovite-(Ce).
tlform: Striated crystals, finely intergrown with minute lamellae of törnebohmite-(Ce).
occurrence: Talc deposit.
aboutname: For Pierre Gatel, founder president of the Association Française de Microminéralogie (AFM).
other: Insoluble in HCl.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, Paris, France (MNHM 201.228).

name: Dissakisite-(La)
description_short:
A member of the Allanite Subgroup of the Epidote Group.

Dissakisite-(La) is the Mg-analogue of allanite-(La), and it also forms a continuous series with dissakisite-(Ce). Like the latter mineral, it can be found in Fe-poor environments.
tlform: Up to 2.5cm-sized black to very dark brown anhedral nodules, thick blades and smaller grains.
occurrence: In Alpine-type peridotite, under eclogite-facies conditions.
aboutname: For its close relationship with dissakisite-(Ce).
type_specimen_store:
(-) Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France (203.133)
(-) Museo di Mineralogia e Petrologia dell'Università di Padova, Padova, Italy

name: Piergorite-(Ce)
description_short: Chemically similar to ferri-hellandite-(Ce).
occurrence: extremely thin, platy micro crystals and aggregates perched within small seams in a volcanic ejecta.
aboutname: After Giancarlo Pierini (b. 1929 Monsummano Terme, Tuscany, Italy) and Pietro Francesco Gorni (b. 1939, Varese, Lombardy, Italy), two well-known and keen Italian mineral collectors, members of AMI (Italian Micromineralogical Association). The name is a portmanteau after their surnames, PIERini and GORini.
twinning: polysynthetic twinning on {100}; frequently, they show L-shaped form by further twinning on the <mi>{30_1}</mi>
type_specimen_store: Museo di Mineralogia, Dipartimento di Scienzedella Terra, Universita degli Studi di Pavia, Italy with catalog number 2005-001 OL.

name: Potassic-fluoro-hastingsite
description_short: The name fluoro-potassichastingsite has also been used for this mineral. The 2012 amphibole nomenclature follow the principle that the various prefixes to the root name are listed in order it occurs in the formula. The approved name for this mineral is...
tlform: Greenish black intergrown grains and laths.
occurrence: A magnetite-rich iron ore deposit hosted by Proterozoic metamorphic rocks.
aboutname: Named in 2009 by Marian V. Lupulescu, John Rakovan, M. Darby Dyer, George W. Robinson, and John M. Hughes for its chemical relationship to hastingsite.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X Bluish green Y Green to Brownish green Z = Blue to Light Blue
type_specimen_store: New York State Museum, New York, USA, 21205 (type).

name: Stavelotite-(La)
description_short: Unique combination of elements.
tlform: Roundish to rectangular, generally equidimensional masses of 10–160 µm in diameter.
occurrence: Late quartz vein cross-cutting manganiferous phyllites of Ordovician age.
colour: Black, reddish brown in transmitted light
aboutname: For the type locality
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Collection, Institut für Geologie, Mineralogie und Geophysik, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, Germany (#25169).

name: Françoisite-(Ce)
aboutname: Named for the relation to Françoisite-(Nd).
type_specimen_store: Geological Museum of Lausanne

name: Aspidolite
description_short: The Na analogue of phlogopite.
tlform: Interleaved with phlogopite.
