occurrence: Contact aureole.
otheroccurrence: were also found in igneous rocks. They occur as inclusions in chromites of mafic layered intrusions and ophiolite complexes
aboutname: Named in 1869 by Franz von Kobell from the Greek ασπίδα ("aspida"), "a shield", and λίθος ("lithos"), "stone", alluding to the appearance of its crystals (Zillertal). First formal description was by Banno et al. in (2005).
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = colourless with yellowish tint and
Y = Z = pale yellowish brown
type_specimen_store:
The type specimens of aspidolite have been deposited at the Geological Museum, Geological Survey of Japan, AIST, Tsukuba, under the registered number GSJ M35151-4 and
National Science Museum, Tokyo, under thecatalogue no. NSM-28719.
commentcrystal: . Aspidolite-1M is monoclinic, space group C2/m and Z = 2; aspidolite-1A is triclinic, space group C1Å and Z = 2

name: Rogermitchellite
description_short: Related to benitoite.
tlform: Free-standing crystals in vugs. Isolated, single crystals are prismatic slightly flattened perpendicular to the elongation, with a maximum dimension of 0.1 x 3 x 0.25 mm.
occurrence: A late-stage igneous breccia in nepheline syenite.
aboutname: Named after Dr. Roger Howard Mitchell (b. 1941), Professor Emeritus in the Departement of Geology at Lakehead University, Thunder Bay, Ontario, Canada in recognition of his outstanding contributions to the mineralogy and petrology of alkaline rocks.
morphology:
Type material:
Prismatic along [001], and slightly flattened perpendicular to this direction. Prominent forms include the prism {100} and pinacoid {001}, with a minor, very shallow ditrigonal scalenohedron {10l}.
type_specimen_store: Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, CMNMC 860087.
commentdense: Calculated value based on the empirical formula.

name: Milotaite
tlform: Subhedral grains not exceeding 25 µm in size, embedded in eucairite and tiemannite and randomly intergrown with bornite and digenite.
occurrence: A low-temperature mineral in fractures in selenium-rich uraninite in calcite veins.
aboutname: Named after Milota Makovicky, University of Copenhagen, Denmark, for her outstanding investigations of sulfide and sulfarsenide systems with platinum-group elements.
type_specimen_store: Department of Geography, Geology and Mineralogy, Division of Mineralogy and Material Sciences (Mineralogical Museum), Salzburg, Austria (14935).

name: Poppiite
description_short: Pumpellyite Group.
tlform: minute prismatic crystals up to 0.6 mm
occurrence: Manganese deposit
aboutname: Named in honor of Luciano Poppi, Professor of Mineralogy, Modena and Reggio Emilia University, and "all his generous and fruitful efforts devoted to mineral science".
morphology: Minute (0.1 to 0.6 mm) prismatic crystals.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
α = light yellowish brown
ß = deep greenish brown
γ = brown to reddish brown
type_specimen_store: Museo Mineralogico e Geologico Estene, GEMMA 1786 at the Modena and Reggio Emilia University, Italy.

name: Moëloite
description_short: A sulphosalt with a trisulphide anion.
tlform: Very thin needles and soft plumose aggregates of flexible thin fibres.
occurrence: Marble quarry
aboutname: Named in honor of Dr. Yves Moëlo, Institut des Matériaux, CNRS - Université de Nantes, France, a specialist of lead sulfosalt mineralogy. He first prepared and studied this compound.
type_specimen_store: Museo di Storia Naturale e del Territorio, Università di Pisa (Via Roma 103, I-56011 Calci (PI), Italy).
commentcolor: Brownish-red very thin fibers

name: Chukanovite
description_short:
The Fe analogue of malachite. 

Product of terrestrial alteration of meteorite iron. Also observed as an anthropogenic corrosion product in the hot-water exchanger of an industrial plant in Beringen, Switzerland (Erdös & Altorfer, 1976). A synthetic ...
tlform: acicular to fibrous crystals, up to 0.5 mm long and max. 2-3 μm thick, in spherulites up to 1 mm in diameter, also in botryoidal spherulitic clusters and parallel-columnar or radial-columnar aggregates forming crusts up to 1 mm thick
occurrence: Terrestrialized (weathered) iron meteorite.
colour: Pale green or colourless (unaltered) to brownish green (at the surface) and brown
aboutname: Honours Nikita Vladimirovich Chukanov (Никита Владимирович Чуканов) (b. 1953), Russian physicist and mineralogist, a specialist in infrared spectroscopy. He is author/coauthor on the description of over 200 minerals.
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia.
commentcolor: turns brown by oxidation within a few months

name: Arrojadite-(KNa)
description_short: Arrojadite Group
tlform: Clear, yellow, mm-sized euhedral crystals. Stout, more-or-less platy prisms.
occurrence: In open fractures in siderite-rich Lower Cretaceous sandstones. From low-salinity fluids, under very low-grade metamorphic conditions, at minimum temperatures of 180-200 C.
aboutname: For Miguel Arrojado Lisbôa, Brazilian geologist and Redefinition after the new arrojadite nomenclature (CNMMN 05-D, October 2005).
opticalpleochorismdesc: Very weak. Y = colorless; X = Z = pale yellow.
type_specimen_store: Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France, 41081.

name: Arrojadite-(PbFe)
description_short: Unique combination of elements (as of 2023).
tlform: Clear, up to millimeter-sized anhedral, corroded, isolated crystals in a groundmass of triphylite with some chloritized biotite and albite.
occurrence: Granite pegmatite.
aboutname: For Miguel Arrojado Lisbôa, Brazilian geologist and Redefinition after the new arrojadite nomenclature (CNMMN 05-D, October 2005).
type_specimen_store: Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines, Paris, France, 32088.

name: Chopinite
description_short: Mg-dominant analogue of sarcopside.
tlform: anhedral and range from 0.1 × 0.3 mm to 0.2 × 0.6 mm in size
occurrence: Metamorphic fluorapatite segregation in granulite-facies.
aboutname: Named in honor of Christian Chopin (1955), French mineralogist and petrologist, Directeur de recherche au CNRS, for his major contributions to the mineralogy of phosphates.
type_specimen_store:
Holotype material (sample no. 121401E and thin section 121401E4) is deposited in the Musee de Mineralogie, Ecole
des Mines de Paris as catalogue number M 73096.

name: Chesnokovite
description_short: Alters to Thermonatrite and Opal when left exposed to normal atmospheric humidity.
tlform: Colorless to pale brownish aggregates of small, coarsely lamellar crystals.  Crystals ranges from a few micrometers to 0.05 × 1 × 2 cm, and aggregates reach up to 4 × 6 × 10 cm.
occurrence: Ussingite vein.
aboutname: In honor of Russian mineralogist Boris Valentinovich Chesnokov (Борис Валентинович Чесноков) (11 June 1928 - 25 October 2005). He was a specialist in the mineralogy of the Southern Urals and founder of a Russian school of mineralogy technogenesis. He also described about 10 new minerals.
other: Highly unstable at normal atmospheric humidity and CO2 concentration; decomposes to thermonatrite and opal.
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, catalog no. 3419/1.
commentdense: Calculated value of 1.60 (empirical formula) or 1.64 (ideal formula).
commentcolor: Aggregates are white to pale brown or yellowish. Colorless in thin section.

name: Walkerite
tlform: Fibrous crystals found as residue from dissolving halite drill cores.
occurrence: Halite member of an evaorite sequence of rocks, near a potash deposit.
aboutname: The name honors Thomas Leonard Walker (31 December 1867, Brampton, Ontario, Canada - 6 August 1942, Toronto, Ontario, Canada), Professor and Head of Mineralogy and Petrography, University of Toronto (1901-1937), for his contributions to mineralogy in general and to the studies of the New Brunswick borate deposits in particular. Before his academic career at University of Toronto, Walker was Assistant Director of the Geological Survey of India (1897-1901) and lecturer of the University of Calcutta. He was also the Director of the Department of Mineralogy, Royal Ontario Museum (1913-1942), and the founder in 1921, of Contributions to Canadian Mineralogy, University of Toronto Studies, the predecessor of The Canadian Mineralogist.
morphology: Fibrous to bladed crystals to 2mm and bundles to 7 mm. Elongate on [001] with pinacoids {100} and {010} and pedion {001}.
uv: No fluorescence with either short-wave or long-wave ultraviolet light.
type_specimen_store:
Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, CMNMC 83379 and CMNMC
83380.

name: Uedaite-(Ce)
description_short:
A member of the Allanite Group of the  Epidote Supergroup. Mn2+ analogue of Allanite-(Ce).

The composition fits to the unnamed phase 'UM1957-02-SiO:AlFeHMnREE'.
tlform:
Short-prismatic crystals elongated along  the
b-axis and less than 1 mm in length.
aboutname: Named in honor of Tateo Ueda (上田健夫) (1912-2000), Japanese crystallographer and professor at Kyoto University, who determined the structure of allanite.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Brown to yellow. Y = b.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Nature and Science, Japan catalog number NSM-M28864
commentdense: density unable to be measured because of intergrowth with other minerals

name: Pradetite
description_short:
Lindackerite Group. 
Co-analogue of Lindackerite and Veselovskýite.
tlform: Fibrous aggregates consisting of individual very elongated (parallel to [001]) crystals (0.3 mm x 0.05 mm x 0.15 mm) and massive equidimensional grains (~ 0.2 mm).
occurrence: Secondary alteration mineral.
aboutname: Named for the city of Le Pradet, France, which is near the type locality of the Cap Garonne mine.
other: Soluble in HCl.
morphology:
Fibers, very elongated parallel to [001]. Crystal forms are {001} and
{100}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Z = green, X and Y = colorless.
type_specimen_store: Departement de Mineralogie du Museum d'Histoire Naturelle de Geneve, Switzerland, no. 477.081 (holotype).
commentdense: Calculated value uses powder data and empirical formula based on 25 O+OH apfu (Burke et al 2007).

name: Ferro-ferri-pedrizite
mindat_formula_note:
The pedrizite group minerals are lithium amphiboles defined with: 
<sup>A</sup>(Na+K+2Ca) > 0.5 apfu and
<sup>C</sup>Li > 0.5 apfu

Ferro-ferri-pedrizite is defined with 
A position: Na dominant
C<sup>2+</sup> position: Fe dominant
C<sup>3+</sup> position: Fe dominant
W position: (OH) dominant
tlform: Intergranular aggregates of subhedral to euhedral habit (size not stated, but extremely small).
occurrence: Episyenite formation (desilication and albitization) of a cordierite-bearing porphyritic granite, by the action of aqueous non-magmatic fluids of low salinity, at temperatures close to 520°C.
aboutname: Described as sodic-ferro-ferripedrizite by Oberti et al. (2003), renamed to ferro-ferri-pedrizite in the 2012 amphibole nomenclature.
opticalcomments: Gladstone–Dale calculations indicate that the mean index of refraction is 1.708.
type_specimen_store: Museo di Mineralogia, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Università degli Studi di Pavia, under the codes 2001–02 (sodic-ferri-ferropedrizite).

name: Knasibfite
aboutname: Named for its chemical composition (K, Na, Si, B, F).
type_specimen_store: Reference Collection of Dipartimento di Chimica Strutturale e Stereochimica Inorganica of Università degli Studi di Milano. no. 2006–03.
commenthard: Hardness could not be determined because of the small size of the crystals

name: Hydroxylpyromorphite
description_short:
Apatite Supergroup.
First reported as an unnamed mineral, then approved in 2017.

The hydroxyl analogue of pyromorphite and fluorpyromorphite.
The phosphate analogue of Unnamed (OH-analogue of Mimetite).
Known as a synthetic compound.
tlform: Occurs as aggregates of randomly oriented hexagonal prisms, primarily between about 20–35 μm in length and 6–10 μm in diameter.
occurrence: In a formation comprised primarily of metagraywacke and conglomeratic, ferruginous quartzite.
aboutname: For being the OH analogue of pyromorphite.
morphology: Elongated prismatic, showing the {100} prism terminated by the {101} pyramid.
opticalcomments:
The predicted average index of refraction based upon the
Gladstone-Dale relationship is 2.04
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles,CA90007, USA, catalogue number 66627.

name: Ramanite-(Rb)
tlform: Melt inclusions in graphic quartz
occurrence: Pegmatite
aboutname: Named in honor of Sir Chandrasekhara Venkata Raman (7 November 1888, Thiruvanaikoil, Tiruchirappalli, Madras Presidency, British India - 21 November 1970, Bangalore, Karnataka, India), physicist. He was awarded the 1930 Nobel Prize for Physics for discovering what is now called Raman scattering. Raman spectroscopy is based on this effect and is now an important tool for mineral identification, and was critical for the discovery of this mineral.
other: Highly water soluble
type_specimen_store: Museum of the Mining Academy Freiberg (Germany), catalog no. 81616.
commentdense: Based on synthetic material

name: Barahonaite-(Fe)
description_short:
Smolianinovite group?

The Fe analogue of barahonaite-(Al).
tlform: Isolated, rosette-like beads, up to about 200 µm in diameter. Sparse coatings on fracture surfaces and coalescences of glittering beads. The beads consist of razor-thin, tabular, composite crystals whose maximum length is about 20 µm.
occurrence: An oxidation mineral occurring as coatings and within closely spaced fractures in weathered siliceous and micaceous host-rocks.
opticalextinction: X is perpendicular to the crystal plates, and Y and Z are within the plates.
aboutname: Named for Antonio Barahona (1937- ), Spanish mineral collector and micromounter, who first noticed that this material might be a new mineral.
other: Readily soluble without effervescence in 10% HCl at room temperature.
opticalcomments: The β value above is not given, but rather the relation β ≈ γ.
type_specimen_store: Canadian Museum of Nature at Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, number CMNMC 85716.
commenthard: Not determinable, crusts are easily scratched with a fingernail, likely due to disaggregation rather than true hardness.

name: Thermessaite
description_short:
The K-analogue of thermessaite-(NH4).

This mineral contains linear infinite chains of repeating (AlF3) units, classifying it as a so-called ino-fluoro-aluminate.
tlform: sharp translucent crystals up to 0.25 mm
occurrence: An altered pyroclastic breccia in active medium- to high-temperature fumaroles at the rim of La Fossa crater.
aboutname: Named after Thermessa, an ancient Greek name of the island of Vulcano meaning "the warm island".
morphology: Prismatic with {110} and the pinacoid {100} as the dominant forms, terminated by minor {111}.
uv: none observed under both short- and long-wave
type_specimen_store: Referece Collection of Dipartimento di Chimica Strutturale e Stereochimica Inorganica of Universita degli Studi di Milano, Milan, Italy
commentdense: from flotation at 25°C in bromoform-chloroform

name: Ivanyukite-Cu
description_short:
Unique combination of elements: the first Cu-Ti silicate mineral. Compare the other group members (not analogous): ivanyukite-Na and ivanyukite-K.

The structure of all ivanyukites is described as a 3D framework of the pharmacosiderite type; it is ba...
tlform: Cubic crystals, up to 1.5 mm in diameter.
occurrence: Natrolitized microcline-aegirine-sodalite lens within orthoclase-bearing urtite; formed from ivanyukite-Na-T by its partial hydration and cation exchange.
aboutname: Named in honor of Gregory Yur’evich Ivanyuk, Russian mineralogist and petrologist, head of the Laboratory of Self-Organized Mineral Systems in the Geological Institute of the Kola Science Centre of the Russian Academy of Sciences
ir: 14 absorption bands from Si-O, Ti-O, molecular water and OH groups vibrations
type_specimen_store: Geological and Mineralogical Museum of the Geological Institute of the Kola Science Centre of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Apatity, Russia, 6354.

name: Potassic-ferro-pargasite
mindat_formula_note:
Potassic-ferro-pargasite is defined as a pargasite group member with the following dominant elements: 
A position: K
C position: Fe as the dominant divalent cation and Al as the dominant trivalent cation.
W position: OH as the dominant anion
tlform: Subhedral to anhedral crystals to 0.7mm.
occurrence: Calcareous hornfels.
aboutname: For the mineral pargasite and its potassium and ferrous iron content.
opticalpleochorismdesc: pale green to bluish green
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Nature and Science, Tokyo NMN M29296.

name: Qusongite
description_short: Natural tungsten carbide. The W analogue of zoyashlyukovaite.
tlform: Irregular, granular, or platy grains, generally 4–8 μm in diameter, but ranging up 0.2 × 0.3 × 0.25 mm.
occurrence: Chromite deposit, hosted in mafic-ultramafic rocks.
otheroccurrence: In kimberlite; in a PGE-bearing Cu-Ni sulphide deposit hosted by mafic-ultramafic rocks.
aboutname: Named for type locality location in Qusong Co.
morphology: Irregular, granular, or platy grains
type_specimen_store: Geological Museum of China, Beijing (2007-034).

name: Jahnsite-(NaMnMg)
description_short: Jahnsite Subgroup.
tlform: Zoned yellow crystals with orange-red bands near their terminations. prisms, elongate on [100].
occurrence: Pegmatite
aboutname: The root name is in honor of Richard Henry Jahns (March 10, 1915 Los Angeles, California, USA - December 31, 1983 Palo Alto, California, USA), mineralogist and pegmatite expert, Stanford University, Palo Alto, California, USA. The suffix indicates metal site occupancies.
other: At room temperature, the mineral is slowly soluble in dilute HCl.
morphology: Elongate on [100], exhibiting the forms {100}, {001}, and {011}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = colorless, Y and Z = orange-yellow
opticalcomments:
Y ≈ Z = X
Optical orientation: Z = b; XΛc = 51° in obtuse b
type_specimen_store: The holotype specimen from the Sapucaia mine is housed in the collections of the Mineral Sciences Department, Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, California 90007, USA, catalogue number 66701. The cotype specimen from the White Rock No. 2 quarry is deposited in the collections of the South Australian Museum, North Terrace, Adelaide, South Australia, Australia, registration number G34298.
ima_history:
Pre-2018: Unnamed, but probably valid.
2018: Approved by IMA as a new species (IMA 2018-017).

name: Eirikite
description_short:
Leifite Group.
The K analogue of leifite and telyushenkoite.

Not to be confused with the discredited "erikite".
tlform: finely or coarsely fibrous, monomineralic aggregates up to several centimetres across
occurrence: A nepheline-syenite pegmatite
aboutname: Named after Eirik Raude (950-1003), discoverer of Greenland and father of Leiv (Leif) Eiriksson, after whom <m>leifite</m> is named.
other: insoluble in warm 6 M HCl, melts relatively easily using a gas torch, leaving a white, vesicular globule
type_specimen_store: Department of Geology, Natural History Museum, University of Oslo (catalogue no. 41773).

name: Punkaruaivite
description_short:
Related to lintisite, eliseevite; and kukisvumite and manganokukisvumite.

AM-4 family of natural titanosilicates.
tlform:
well-shaped prismatic crystals flattened on (100) and elongate along [001] arranged in
sheaf-like and radiating aggregates.
occurrence:
ussingite - aegirine - microcline vein in nepheline syenite.
Rare late-stage hydrothermal minerals formed as a result of the alteration of earlier titanosilicates
aboutname: Named for Mt. Punkaruaiv, the type locality in the Lovozero massif, Kola Peninsula, Russia.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Y light brownish yellow, X brownish yellow
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Museum of the St. Petersburg State University (Russia) and the Geological and the Mineralogical Museum of the Geological Institute of the Kola Science Centre of the Russian Academy of Sciences (Apatity, Russia, No. 6441).

name: Pyracmonite
description_short:
Closely related to aluminopyracmonite (chemically, the Al analogue). Also chemically related to sabieite and ferroefremovite. The ammonium analogue of 'Unnamed (Na-Fe Sulphate)' (both trigonal but not isostructural).

Well-known also as a synthetic c...
tlform: aggregates of colorless to white elongate hexagonal prismatic crystals up to 0.2 mm in length
occurrence: medium-temperature (~250°C) intracrater fumarole developed on a pyroclastic breccia
aboutname: The name is after the Greek words πνρ = “fire” and ακμων = “anvil”; it recalls the mythical Hephaistos’s workshop, which allegedly was located on the Island of Vulcano
other: The mineral is not hygroscopic and is stable in air
type_specimen_store: Reference Collection of the Dipartimento di Chimica Strutturale e Stereochimica Inorganica, Università degli Studi di Milano, specimen number 2008–04.

name: Adranosite-(Fe)
mindat_formula_note: Alternative crystal-chemical formula, emphasising the presence of -Na-Cl-Na-Cl- chains in the structure:(NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>Fe<sup>3+</sup> <sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>.NaCl; some NH4 may be replaced by K.
description_short:
The Fe3+ analogue of Adranosite-(Al). Chemically related to acmonidesite and therasiasite.

Originally described as an anthropogenic phase that has formed on a burning coal dump ["Unnamed (NH4-Fe-Na-Cl Sulphate)"]. Subsequently found in a natural fum...
tlform: acicular crystals up to 1 mm in length, in aggregates; probable forms (the most common):{100}, {110}, and {111}
occurrence: pyroclasic breccia among fumaroles
otheroccurrence: a burning coal dump
aboutname: For the relation to <M>Adranosite-(Al)</M>.
morphology: Acicular.
type_specimen_store:
Dipartimento di Chimica Strutturale e Stereochimica Inorganica, Università degli Studi di Milano, sample number 2010-02)
C.L. Garavelli Museum, Dipartimento Geomineralogico, Università di Bari.
commentcrystal: Cell of anthropogenic material: a = 18.259(3), c = 11.557(2) A (Kolitsch and Brandstätter, 2007).

name: Zigrasite
description_short:
The Mg analogue of Malhmoodite. 

See also UM2009-11-PO:CaHZr (Ca analogue of zigrasite) and another co-described species, 'Unnamed (Zirconium Monohydroxyorthophosphate Tetrahydrate)'.
tlform: Subhedral blocky grains sometimes exceeding 1 mm in max. dimension.
occurrence: A complex rare-element granitic pegmatite.
cleavage: Imperfect in two directions, parallel to (010) and (001)
colour: Pale-yellow or light tan, also orange to off-white
aboutname: James Zigras (12 June 1981), a prominent young mineral collector, in 2005 observed some small orange "balls" on a specimen of green <m>elbaite</m> and thought them very unusual. He sent them to Dr. William "Skip" Simmons at the University of New Orleans who determined it was an new mineral species. Dr. Frank Hawthorne of the University of Manitoba determined the crystal structure in 2008.  The species was eventually named after James Zigras. The pictures of the MinDat gallery are of the type specimen and represent most of the known zigrasite. One other specimen is currently known. [Rock Currier 2009]
other: Light blue to pale yellow cathodoluminescence.
type_specimen_store: Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, catalogue number M53323.

name: Groatite
description_short: Alluaudite Group.
tlform: Slightly divergent sprays of acicular crystals on whitlockite; stellate sprays embedded in whitlockite and an unidentified Na–Al phosphate; tabular mass of densely intergrown acicular crystals.
occurrence: In a vug in a single 5–10 cm mass of phosphate–carbonate mineralization in a spodumene-rich boulder.
cleavage: Crystals are too small in cross-section to observe cleavage.
opticalextinction: X ∧ a = 35.4 (in β obtuse); Y ∧ c = 10.1° (in β acute); Z = b.
aboutname: Named in honor of Lee A. Groat, Professor of Mineralogy at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver.
type_specimen_store: Department of Natural History, Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada (catalogue number M40501).
commentcolor: Pale orange, where massive

name: Balliranoite
tlform: Crystals up to 1x1x2 mm in cavities and as anhedral grains up to 1 cm in the groundmass.
occurrence: A product of metasomatic interaction between alkaline magma and limestone.
aboutname: Named in honor of Professor Paolo Ballirano (b. 1964), Professor of Crystallography, Department of Earth Sciences, University of Rome "La Sapienza", for his contributions to the crystal chemistry of cancrinite group minerals.
morphology: The prismatic faces, probably <mi>{10_10}</mi>, have striations parallel to [0001].
type_specimen_store: A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (catalog no. 3756/1).

name: Ferri-fluoro-katophorite
mindat_formula_note:
The katophorite group minerals are sodium-calcium amphiboles defined with <sup>A</sup>(Na+K+2Ca)> 0.5 apfu and 0.5 apfu < <sup>C</sup>(Al+Fe<sup>3+</sup>+2Ti) < 1.5 apfu.

Fluoro-katophorite is defined with 

A position: Na dominant
C<sup>2+</sup> position: Mg dominant
C<sup>3+</sup> position: Fe dominant
W position: F dominant
tlform: greenish grey prismatic to lamellar crystals
aboutname: Named according to the IMA-approved amphibole naming scheme (Hawthorne et al. 2012)
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = very light grey, Y = medium grey, Z = light grey
opticalcomments: X˄a = 45.4deg (in β obtuse), Y||b, Z˄c = 30.7deg (in β acute)
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Department of Natural History, Royal Ontario Museum, Canada (catalogue number M57071)

name: Domerockite
tlform: Aggregates of equant to short prismatic and tabular crystals up to 0.3 mm long and 0.2 mm across.
occurrence: A supergene mineral, forming with others in thin seams in a schist matrix.
aboutname: Named after the type locality.
morphology: Equant to short prismatic and tabular crystals. Crystal forms are major {100}, {010} and {001}, and minor <mi>{01_1}</mi>, <mi>{01_2}</mi>, and {212}.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
Very weak. X = pale greenish yellow, Y = greenish blue, Z
= greenish blue.
type_specimen_store: Department of Mineralogy, South Australian Museum, Adelaide, South Australia, G32329.
commentdense: Calculation based on the structure refinement

name: Chihuahuaite
description_short:
Magnetoplumbite Group.

Originally named hibonite-(Fe), for its similarity and relationship to hibonite and its iron content. Renamed as part of a new nomenclature of the magnetoplumbite group (Holtstam and Hålenius, 2020).
Does not belong to a subg...
tlform: scattered micrometer-sized single crystals within an aggregate of hercynite
occurrence: A highly altered Ca-,Al-rich refractory inclusion from the Allende meteorite.
aboutname: Originally named hibonite-(Fe). Assigned a new root name, ‘chihuahuaite’, after the state (estado) of Mexico where Allende, the holotype host meteorite fell in 1969 (Holtstam & Hålenius, 2020).
type_specimen_store: (Caltech Allende12A section D) has been deposited in the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., and is cataloged under USNM 7554.

name: Ferro-ferri-obertiite
mindat_formula_note: Ferro-ferri-obertiite is a obertiite root name amphibole in the <sup>W</sup>O<sup>2-</sup> dominant amphibole group with Fe<sup>2+</sup> as the dominant element in the C<sup>2+</sup> position and Fe<sup>3+</sup> as the dominant element in the C<sup>3+</sup> position.
tlform: Occurs as euhedral to subhedral prismatic to acicular crystals up to 1.25 mm across in a matrix of aegirine and feldspar.
occurrence: Occurs in an alkali diatreme that penetrates a lithic-wacke sandstone sequence of the Franciscan assemblage.
cleavage: Perfect {110} cleavage of monoclinic amphiboles, intersecting at ~56°.
opticalextinction: X ∧ a = 77.3° (in β acute); Y = b; Z ∧ c = 91.2° (in β obtuse).
aboutname: This mineral (IMA 2009-034) was originally named ferro-obertiite (Hawthorne et al. 2010). It was redefined in the 2012 amphibole nomenclature, and is now named ferro-ferri-obertiite.  The root name is for Roberta Oberti, professor at the University of Pavia, Italy, and an expert on the crystal chemistry of amphiboles.
morphology: Grains are euhedral to subhedral, prismatic to acicular on [001] and are bounded by {110} cleavage faces.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = dark brown; Y = brown; Z = dark grey.
type_specimen_store: Department of Natural History, Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, specimen number M54035.

name: Telluroperite
tlform: thin somewhat rounded square plates and flakes up to 0.25 mm on edge and 0.02 mm thick
occurrence: Oxidation zone, formed from the partial oxidation of primary sulfides (e.g., galena) and tellurides (e.g., hessite) during or following brecciation of the quartz veins.
aboutname:
Named as the tellurium analog of perite.

Per Adolf Geijer (7 May 1886, Svea Artillery Government's Assembly, Sweden - 18 April 1976, Danderyd, Sweden) was an economic geologist with the Swedish Geological Survey (SGU), and professor at the Royal Institute of Technology.
other: In dilute HCl acid, telluroperite immediately decomposes, turning white and opaque, and then dissolves slowly.
opticalpleochorismdesc: moderate bluish-green pleochrosim with absorption: X < Y = Z
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, catalog numbers 62513 and 62514.

name: Guidottiite
description_short: Serpentine Group. The Mn-analogue of Cronstedtite. Compare 'UM1969-14-SiO:FeHMn'.
tlform: Columnar, with grains, ranging in size up to ~3 mm; poorly adhered to each other.
occurrence: Stratiform manganese deposit.
aboutname: Named in honour of Charles V. Guidotti (19 September 1935, Somerville, Massachusetts, USA - 19 May 2005, Boston, Massachusetts, USA), professor at the University of California, Davis (1962–1969), the University of Wisconsin–Madison (1969–1981), and the University of Maine (1981–2005), for his many contributions to phyllosilicate mineralogy. He also made important contributions to the petrologic studies of metamorphic rocks in the northern Appalachian Mountains of Maine.
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian Institution), Washington, D.C., USA, NMNH 174879.
commentluster: Vitreous in bulk, silky under magnification
commentdense: Measured on bulk sample with impurities. Calculated value is based on sets of microprobe analyses.

name: Paratimroseite
description_short: Up to date (2018) there are approx. 10 paratimroseite specimens known and verified.
tlform: Blades, which are intergrown in irregular clusters; also botryoids.
occurrence: On fracture surfaces and in small vugs in quartz veins.
aboutname: Name in allusion to its resemblance to Timroseite.
other: In dilute HCl paratimroseite immediately decomposes, turning opaque white, and then the residue slowly dissolves.
morphology: Blades are elongated on [100], flattened on {001}, and exhibit the forms {001}, {010}, {120}, and {100}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = light green, Y = Z = green.
opticalcomments: Average refractive index (n = 2.059) was calculated from the Gladstone-Dale relationship. 2V = large.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County (62263, 62534).

name: Megawite
description_short:
Perovskite Group. The Sn analogue of perovskite and lakargiite.
Chemically related to burtite.
tlform: Either pseudo-cubic or pseudo-cuboctahedral crystals <15 µm in size, usually as inclusions in spurrite (Xenolith No. 1). Also as rims on µm-sized lakargiite crystals in larnite-cuspidine zones in skarns which contain abundant hydrogarnet and hydrosilicates.
occurrence:
It was found in the spurrite zone of skarned xenolith no. 1
(20-25 m in size) in ignimbrite.
colour: Pale yellowish brown, pale yellow to colourless
opticalextinction: X = b; Y = a; Z = c.
aboutname: It is named in honour of the British crystallographer Helen Dick Megaw (1 June 1907, Dublin, Ireland - 26 February 2002, Ballycastle, Northern Ireland) who made significant contributions to our understanding of the structure and properties of natural and synthetic perovskites. In 1989, Megaw became the first woman to receive the Roebling Medal of the Mineralogical Society of America.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Museum of Wrocław University, Poland under accession number MMUWrII16 717 and the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia under accession number 4021/1.

name: Tancaite-(Ce)
tlform: Small truncated octahedra up to 0.2 mm in size.
occurrence: Oxidation zone of a sulfide ore vein, in a quartz vein cutting granite.
aboutname: Named after Giuseppe Tanca (b. 1943), mineral collector.  He discovered the mineral and provided it for study.
morphology: Octahedra truncated by cubes.
twinning: Twinning at a small scale is probable.  Not observed macroscopically.
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, University of Pisa, Italy, catalogue no. 18911.

name: Greenwoodite
tlform:
Small, disseminated semi-prismatic to tabular 
grains
occurrence: Metamorphic mineral formed under greenschist-facies conditions
aboutname: Named in honor of Hugh J. Greenwood, Canadian mineralogist, former Professor of Mineralogy, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada.
morphology: A semi-prismatic to tabular habit.
opticalcomments: Straight extinction relative to its cleavage direction.
opticalcolour: Gray color with a weak brownish tint
type_specimen_store: American Museum of Natural History, New York, NY, catalog no. 109839

name: Tashelgite
description_short: Type locality is a calc-skarnoid occurrence near the mouth of the Tashelga River, Kuznetsky Alatau, Gorny Shoria (53°22′60.3N, 88°17′07.1E).
tlform: Long prismatic to acicular, slightly flattened crystals and their parallel intergrowths up to 0.2 x 0.3 x 2 mm in size.
occurrence: In calc-skarnoid zones.
aboutname: Named for the type locality.
other: Tashelgite does not dissolve in hydrochloric and sulphuric acids.
morphology: Prismatic crystals elongated on [100] with main forms {001} and {010}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = blue-green, Y = light yellowish green, Z = almost colourless
type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, no. 3983/1
commentcolor: Fibrous segregations are occasionally white

name: Rickturnerite
aboutname:
Named in honor of Richard William "Rick" Turner (1958 - 14 October 2020), British mineral collector, mining engineer and technology consultant.  He was an expert on the Mendip Hills and discovered the mineral in 2005. He also served as President of the Russell Society.

https://www.mindat.org/mesg-539620.html
type_specimen_store:
Type material is deposited in the collections of
the Natural History Museum, London, UK,
registration number BM 2008,100

name: Oxystannomicrolite
description_short: Chemically similar to thoreaulite.
tlform: Narrow rims around ferrowodginite , and in small grains replacing ferrowodginite almost completely.
occurrence: Granite pegmatite.
aboutname: Originally named sukulaite in 1967 for the Sukula Pegmatites, Finland, the type locality.  It was renamed to stannomicrolite during a classification and nomenclature update of the pyrochlore group in 1977 (Hogarth 1977).  It was renamed again, to oxystannomicrolite, according to new recommended pyrochlore supergroup nomenclature (Atencio et al. 2010), indicating dominant elements and its relation to other microlite group minerals.
morphology: As rims, to 20 μm, surrounding ferrowodginite crystals
opticalcolour: light gray with a reddish or lilac tint
type_specimen_store: Not described.

name: Oxy-schorl
description_short:
"Schorl" with O>OH,F on the W site; not uncommon, but can be reliably identified only from detailed and quantitative chemical analyses.

Originally used as a working name and published without approval, then finally approved in 2011.


Compare als...
tlform: Fan-shaped aggregates of greenish black acicular crystals ranging up to 2 cm in size, forming aggregates up to 3.5 cm (Zlatá Idka)
occurrence:
Metasomatically altered metarhyolite pyroclastics (Zlatá Idka):
Foliated muscovite-tourmaline orthogneiss (Přibyslavice)
aboutname: For being an "oxidised" "schorl".
morphology: Acicular crystals forming fan-shaped aggregates; subhedral, columnar Crystals arranged in thin layers or irregular clusters.
opticalpleochorismdesc: In plane-polarized light: O = green to bluish-green, E = pale yellowish to nearly colorless (Zlatá Idka) and O = dark grayish-green, E = pale brown (Přibyslavice)
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Department of Mineralogy and Petrography, Moravian Museum, Brno, Czech Republic, specimen numbers B10521 and B10522, the East-Slovak Museum, Natural History Division, Košice, Slovakia, specimen number G
commentdense: 3.17 g/cm3 (Zlatá Idka) and 3.19 g/cm3 (Přibyslavice)
commentcrystal: Data given for Zlatá Idka sample. For Přibyslavice: a = 15.985(1) Å, c = 7.154(1) Å, V = 1583.1(2) Å3 .

name: Pseudolyonsite
description_short: Known as a synthetic compound. Possibly also polymorphous with borisenkoite.
tlform: Needles that are 5–20 µm across and up to 0.5 mm in the length, which sometimes produce parallel intergrowths, sprays or openwork clusters up to 2 mm.
occurrence: Fumarole. Likely deposited at a temperature ranging from 200 to 300 °C.
colour: Dark red with a brownish tint to black
aboutname: For the relation to lyonsite to which it is visually similar.
opticalcolour: Grey with a weak bluish tint.
type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (# 3879/1).

name: Rongibbsite
description_short: A zeolitic aluminosilicate. The first natural aluminosilicate with Pb as the only extraframework cation.
tlform: Elongated  blades
occurrence: Quartz vein in a Proterozoic gneiss
aboutname: Named after its finder, Ronald Bradford Gibbs, a mineral collector and a mining engineer in Tucson, Arizona.
other: Insoluble in water, acetone, or hydrochloric acid
morphology: Bladed (elongated along the c axis, up to 0.70 × 0.20 × 0.05 mm), often in tufts. Dominant forms are {100}, {010}, {001}, and {101̄}.
type_specimen_store: Part of the co-type sample has been deposited at the University of Arizona Mineral Museum (catalog no. 19292) and the RRUFF Project (deposition no. R100031).

name: Vladimirivanovite
description_short: First recognized as “triclinic lazurite” (compare UM1976-26-SiOSO:AlCaClHNa) and later as “orthorhombic lazurite”; but later as an orthorhombic polytype of lazurite with a modulated structure, i.e. Lazurite-O. The modulations arise from a rotation of t...
tlform: Rims on lazurite, 0.01-3 mm thick, and elongated grains from 0.2-4 mm in size, and occasionally up to 15 x 20 mm. Rarely as veinlets up to 5 mm.
occurrence: Calciphyres and marble.
otheroccurrence: Gem lazurite deposits
colour: Dark blue to ink-blue, light blue or greenish-blue to white
aboutname: Named in honor of Vladimir Georgievich Ivanov (Владимир Георгиевич Иванов) (1947-2002), Russian mineralogist and geochemist. He studied the lazurite deposits of the Pamirs and Pribaikalye and made significant contributions to the knowledge of the complex processes of lapis formation.
other: Dissolves in HCl and HNO3 with the release of H2S.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Pleochroism: Light to dark blue; absorption: Z = Y > X
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Museum of Saint Petersburg State University, Saint Petersburg (Russia), catalogue no. 1/19366.
commentcolor: Similar colours to hauyne.

name: Kazanskyite
tlform: Flexible and commonly bent flakes 2-15 µm thick and up to 330 µm across.
occurrence: Apatite mine in alkaline massif. Hydrothermal action on pegmatite.
aboutname: In honour of Professor Vadim Ivanovich Kazansky (Вадим Иванович Казанский) (27 May 1926, Tashkent, USSR (Uzbekistan) - 4 January 2013), a prominent Russian ore geologist and an expert in Precambrian metallogeny. He was a chief researcher at the Institute of Ore Deposits, Petrography, Mineralogy, and Geochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences (IGEM RAS), working on rocks of the Kola Peninsula for forty years.
other: Under an electron beam, kazanskyite is extremely unstable, first losing H2O, and then Na and K.
type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, catalogue number 4103/1.
commentdense: Density could not be measured due to the very small thickness of the flakes

name: Chukhrovite-(Ca)
mindat_formula_note: Also given as <f>Ca^4^.^5Al^2(SO^4)F^13.12H^2O</f>.
description_short: Very closely related to meniaylovite.
tlform: Colourless to whitish, transparent to translucent, sharp octahedral crystals up to 100–150 µm diameter.
occurrence: Found as low temperature hydrothermal crystallizations covering the surfaces of brittle fractures crosscutting a marcasite and REE-bearing fluorite vein.
aboutname: Named in 2011 by P. Vignola, F. Hatert, Olaf Medenbach, D. Bersani, V. Diella, P. Gentile, and A. Risplendente in honor of Fedor Vasil'evich Chukhrov and for its being the Ca analogue of chukrovite-(Ce).
morphology: Sharp octahedra up to 150 µm in diameter.
twinning: Twinning along the [001] axis, with a rotation of 90 deg (iron cross law), is widespread, while spinel law twins are rare.
uv: Non-fluorescent either under short-wave (254 nm) or long-wave (366 nm) ultraviolet light
type_specimen_store:
Museum of Natural History of Milano, Italy, catalogue number M37901.
Laboratory of Mineralogy of the University of Liege, Belgium, catalogue number 20383.

name: Lileyite
description_short: Visually indistinguishable from schüllerite.
tlform: Platy crystals up to 0.1 x 0.3 x 0.5 mm in size and their clusters up to 1 mm across.
occurrence: In miarolitic cavities of alkaline basalt.
aboutname: Named for the type locality, the Löhley (Liley).
morphology: The main crystal form is {100}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = colourless, Y = light brown, Z = greyish brown
type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (registration number 4106/1).

name: Ianbruceite
tlform: Thin flakes and tapered platy crystals up to 80  μm long
occurrence: ‘Zinc Pocket’ on the 44 level of Tsumeb mine
colour: Sky blue to very pale blue, white, colourless
opticalextinction: X ∧ a = 12.0º (in β obtuse); Y = b; Z ∧ c = 4.7º (in β obtuse).
aboutname: Named for Ian Bruce (born 1 April 1969 at Okehampton, Devon, England), a prime mover in the recent reopening the Tsumeb mine for mineral collecting, who has made significant contributions to the mineral collections of many of the world's major museums through his professional activities.
type_specimen_store: Department of Natural History, Royal Ontario Museum (catalogue number M53150) and holotype crystals are deposited in the collection of the Mineralogical Museum of the University of Hamburg, Grindelallee 48, D-20146 Hamburg, Germany (catalogue number TS 11

name: Karenwebberite
description_short: The Fe2+-equivalent of natrophilite; Na-equivalent of triphylite.
tlform: Late-magmatic-stage exsolution lamellae up to 100 μm thick in graftonite.
occurrence: Pegmatite dyke
cleavage: In thin section it displays a perfect cleavage along {001}.
aboutname: In honor of Karen Louise Webber, Assistant Professor Research at the Mineralogy, Petrology and Pegmatology Research Group, Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences, University of New Orleans, Louisiana, U.S.A. Her research "has focused on the cooling and crystallization dynamics of granitic pegmatites."
morphology: Forms thin exsolution lamellae (< 0.1 x 7 mm) in graftonite.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Moderate with X = dark gray, Y = brown, and Z = yellow
uv: Non-fluorescent either under short-wave or long-wave ultraviolet light
type_specimen_store: Laboratory of Mineralogy, University of Liege, Belgium, cat. no. 20385
commentcolor: Lamellae are translucent (pale green) to opaque (dark green).

name: Hilarionite
description_short: Related to and easily confused with the ferric iron arsenate hydrate kaňkite.
tlform: Spherulites (up to 1 mm in size) and bunches of prismatic to acicular «individuals» (up to 0.5 mm long) that are in fact near-parallel or divergent aggregates of very thin, curved fibers up to 0.3 mm long and usually lesser than 2 µm thick.
occurrence: In the oxidation zone of a sulfide-rich ore-body.
colour: Light green (with typically olive or greyish tint) to light yellowish-green, grey-green
aboutname: For the type locality, the Hilarion mine, Lavrion, Attica, Greece.
morphology: Spherulites; near-parallel or divergent aggregates of very thin, curved fibers.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, catalogue number 92988.
commentcrystal: Space group C2, Cm or C2/m.

name: Menzerite-(Y)
tlform: Inclusions within almandine euhedral crystals.
occurrence: Accessory mineral of felsic granulites.
colour: Brown in thin sections, megascopically black
aboutname: Named in honour of Georg Menzer (4 May 1897, Riga, German Empire - 13 October 1989, Gauting, Germany), crystallographer who was the first to solve the crystal structure of garnet in 1925.  The suffix/modifier follows the Levinson rule for species with essential REE indicating, in this case, a predominance of yttrium.
type_specimen_store:
Canadian Museum of Nature (Ottawa) - specimen CMNMC 86088
National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution (Washington, DC) - specimen NMNH 174896

name: Debattistiite
tlform: Very rare tabular euhedral crystals up to 150 µm across in cavities in dolomitic marble.
aboutname: Named by A. Guastoni, L. Bindi, and F. Nestola in 2012 in honor of Luca De Battisti (7 March 1958 - 29 May 2015), a systematic mineralogist and expert on the minerals of Lengenbach quarry.
morphology: Tabular well-formed crystals.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Dark gray to greenish gray
type_specimen_store: Museum of Mineralogy of the Department of Geosciences at the University of Padova, Italy, catalogue number MMP M10680.

name: Fuettererite
description_short:
Elemental combination is rather unique, only slightly resembling that in quetzalcoatlite.

The structure is based on double spangolite-type sheets; the sheets are composed of two types of octahedra: CuO5Cl (typically with Jahn-Teller distortions) and...
occurrence: In vugs in quartz; originated by partial oxidation of primary sulfide and telluride minerals during/following brecciation of the quartz veins
otheroccurrence: Bird Nest drift specimen
aboutname: Named in honor of Otto Fuetterer (born ca. 1880, Germany; died ca. 1970, USA) who is largely responsible for the development of the mining claims on Otto Mountain, the type locality.  The mountain is also named after Mr Fuetterer.
morphology: Tabular to short prismatic, exhibit the forms {100}, {101}, and {001} and reach a maximum dimension of 50 μm.
type_specimen_store: Mineral Sciences Department, Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, California 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 63588 and 63589

name: Browneite
description_short: Low-temperature (<200 °C) dimorph, metastable relative to alabandite.
tlform: One single crystal (∼16 µm in size).
occurrence: Enstatite-rich achondrite.
aboutname: Named in honour of Professor Patrick R. L. Browne (b. 1941, Suva, Fiji) of the Institute of Earth, Science & Engineering, The University of Auckland, New Zealand, for his contributions to low-temperature mineralogy and petrology.
other: Non fluorescent under electron beam
type_specimen_store: Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, registration number USNM 7607.
commentdense: Calculated from empirical formula

name: Jakobssonite
description_short: It is known as a synthetic phase (Hemon & Courbion, 1991). Jakobsson et al. (2008) referred to it as "mineral HA". In the IMA list of unnamed minerals it is listed in the invalid minerals under the code UM2008-//-?[5].
tlform: Acicular crystals up to 50 µm long.  Also as a white overgrowth on a yellowish base of massive ralstonite, anhydrite and jarosite which together form a 2-3 cm thick crust on altered scoria.
occurrence: Fumarole at ~230ºC.
aboutname: The name honours Sveinn Peter Jakobsson (20 July 1939, Reykjavík, Iceland - 12 July 2016, Iceland), volcanologist at the Icelandic Institute of Natural History, who was the first person to recognize it.
morphology: Acicular crystals which are probably elongated along [100]; fragile crusts.
uv: Does not fluoresce in LW UV
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Icelandic Institute of Natural History, Reykjavık, Iceland, sample number NI 12256 (Eldfell). A cotype sample has the number NI 15511(Hekla).

name: Miyahisaite
description_short: A mineral of the hedyphane group in the apatite supergroup.
tlform: As a pseudomorphic aggregate (up to about 100 μm in size)along with fluorapatite in the quartz matrix in a namansilite-rich layer of the chert.
occurrence: Low grade metamorphism of manganese deposits formed in chert.
aboutname: Named in honor of Michitoshi Miyahisa (宮久三千年) (1928 Oita pref., Japan - 6 February 1983), mineralogist and professor at Ehime University, Japan, for his work on deposits on Kyushu.
morphology: As pseudomorphic aggregates
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Nature and Science,Tokyo, Japan, specimen number NSM M-41299

name: Lavinskyite
description_short: Two polytypes are known, lavinskyite-2O (formerly "lavinskyite") and lavinskyite-1M; the latter was originally approved as "liguriaite", but subsequently recognised as a monoclinic MDO polytype of "lavinskyite" (IMA proposal 16-E; Kolitsch et al., 2018...
tlform: Light blue plates, associated with <m>wesselsite</m> and <m>scottyite</m>.  Broken pieces are bladed, elongated along [001], up to 0.5 × 0.3 × 0.1 mm.
occurrence: Hydrothermal.
opticalextinction: X = a, Y = b, Z = c
aboutname: Named by H. Yang, R.T. Downs, S.H. Evans, and W.W. Pinch in 2014 in honor of Robert Matthew Lavinsky (13 December 1972, Columbus, Ohio, USA - ), mineral collector and dealer.
other: Insoluble in water, acetone, or hydrochloric acid.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = dark blue, Y = light blue, and Z = light blue
type_specimen_store: Mineral Museum of the University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona, USA, catalogue number 19335.

name: Iseite
description_short: Black, sub-metallic, small grains (<20 microns) in 1 mm granular aggregates. The manganese analogue of kamiokite and majindeite.
tlform: Zoned aggregates (up to ~1 mm) of  minute anhedral crystals of a several micrometers to 20 μm.
occurrence: Manganese deposit.
aboutname: Named by Nishio-Hamane Daisuke, Tomita Norimitsu, Minakawa Tetsuo, and Inaba Sachio  in 2012 for Ise City, Honshu Island, Kinki region, Mie Prefecture, Japan where the type locality is located.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Pale grey to yellowish grey
opticalanisotropism: Medium to strong, gray to pale gray
type_specimen_store: National Museum of Nature and Science, Tsukuba, Japan, specimen number NSMM-43652
commentcolor: Light yellow gray in transmitted light

name: Trébeurdenite
description_short: The mineral formerly described as fougèrite has been found to be an intimate intergrowth of two phases with distinct Fe2+:Fe3+ ratios. The phase with Fe2+:Fe3+ = 2:1 retains the name fougèrite; that with Fe2+:Fe3+ = 1:2 is defined as the new species tr...
aboutname: Named for the township of Trebeurden, near the maritime marsh where the mineral was first found.
type_specimen_store: The holotype specimen M52133 is accessioned in the collections of Museum Victoria.

name: Darrellhenryite
description_short: Compare also Elbaite.
tlform: subhedral, short, columnar crystals and parallel aggregates, up to 3 cm long and up to 2 cm thick
occurrence: Complex Li-bearing pegmatite, petalite-subtype
otheroccurrence: Li-rich pegmatites
aboutname: In honour of Darrell J. Henry (born 1951), Professor of Geology at the Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, U.S.A., an expert on the mineralogy, petrology, crystal chemistry, and nomenclature of tourmaline group minerals.
opticalpleochorismdesc: colorless (||c) to pale pink (^c)
type_specimen_store: In the collections of the Department of Mineralogy and Petrography of the Moravian Museum, Brno, Czech Republic, catalogue number B1066.

name: Ferro-ferri-hornblende
mindat_formula_note: Defined as a an amphibole in the magnesiohornblende group of the Calcium subgroup with Fe<sup>2+</sup>Mg and Fe<sup>3+</sup>Al in the C position and with (OH) as the dominant anion in the W position
description_short: The mineral was originally described by  Luigi Colomba in 1914 as "speziaite", a name never approved by IMA, and discredited by Leake (1978) as a variety of hornblende. As the type material exhibit intergrowths of ferro-ferri-hornblende and hastingsite...
tlform: Aggregates of crystals embedded in a matrix of fibrous to acicular tremolite with minor quartz and calcite. A significant inter-crystalline variation in the hastingsite component is observed, with some crystals falling in the compositional field of hastingsite and even of magnesio-hastingsite.
opticalextinction: X ∧ a = 26.2° (β obtuse); Y = b ; Z ∧ c = 11.5° (β acute).
aboutname: Named in 1789 by Abraham Gottlieb Werner from an old German term for dark minerals with no ore value and from "blende", meaning to deceive. The prefix ferro-ferri is in alignment with the guidelines in the latest amphibole nomenclature (Hawthorne et al. 2012)
morphology: As acicular or lamellar crystals.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = medium gold/brown; Y = dark brown/black; Z = dark grey.
type_specimen_store:
Museo di Mineralogia, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra e dell’Ambiente, Università di Pavia, catalogue number 2015-01 (type).
Museo Regionale di Scienze Naturali di Torino (type).

name: Fluor-uvite
description_short:
The F-analogue of (the much rarer) uvite.

See uvite series for more information on the nomenclature revisions of uvite.

NOTE: Most of the numerous "uvites/fluor-uvites" from Brumado, Bahia, Brazil, require individual confirmation.
otheroccurrence: Calcium-rich rocks subjected to contact metamorphism and addition of boron.
colour: Black, greenish-black, brownish-black, brown, green, colourless
aboutname: Named in 1929 by Wilhelm Kunitz for the type locality, Uva Province, Sri Lanka. Chemical pre-fix added by IMA in 2008.
morphology: Prismatic to equant crystals, tabular, pyramidal, radiating groups.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
O= pale yellow
E= colorless
uv: May show a weak mustard-yellow under SW
type_specimen_store: Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

name: Nickelpicromerite
description_short: Nickelpicromerite is the product of alteration of primary sulfide minerals and the reaction of the acid Ni-sulfate solutions with biotite (Belogub et al., 2015).
tlform: equant to short prismatic or tabular crystals up to 0.07 mm in size and anhedral grains up to 0.5 mm across, their clusters or crusts up to 1 mm.
occurrence:
In the fractures of slightly weathered actinolite-talc schist.
As the product of alteration of primary sulfide minerals and the reaction of the acid Ni-sulfate solutions with biotite.
aboutname: From the mineral picromerite and its nickel content
morphology: Equant to short prismatic or tabular crystals up to 0.07 mm; anhedral grains up to 0.5 mm across.
type_specimen_store: Natural Scientific Museum of the Ilmen State Reserve, Miass, Russia, specimen number 17301, and the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4281/1

name: Leydetite
description_short:
New structure type. Chemically related to deliensite.
Chemically very similar to rietveldite (a lower hydrate).

Isostructural with magnesioleydetite.

The structure is based on protasite anion topology; there is a sheet of UO7 bipyramids, that sh...
tlform: Tabular crystals up to 2 mm.
occurrence: Supergene alteration of a uranium deposit in sandstones, pelites and conglomerates.
aboutname: Honours Jean-Claude Leydet (born 18 April 1961 - died 21 November 2018), an amateur mineralogist from Brest (France), a great connoisseur of uranium minerals.
opticalcomments: Further optical properties could not be measured.
type_specimen_store: Musée Cantonal de Géologie, Lausanne, Switzerland, registration number MGL 92661.

name: Alburnite
description_short: Closely related to the argyrodite-canfieldite series (which contains no Te).
tlform: Rounded to sub-rounded grains, veinlets or irregular inclusions hosted mainly by tetrahedrite, hessite, and rhodochrosite.
occurrence: Intermediate sulfidation gold-silver vein
aboutname: Derived from the Latin name of the deposit. The Roşia Montana Au-Ag deposit was known during the Roman period (106-273 AD) as Alburnus Maior.
other: The mineral decomposes in intense light.
type_specimen_store:
Mineralogical Museum, Department of Geology, Faculty of Biology and Geology, Babes-Bolyai University, Cluj-Napoca, Romania (71a/1 and 71a/2).
Zentrale Elektronen-Mikrosonde, Institute of Geology, Mineralogy and Geophysics, Ruhr University, Bochum, Germany (1064b).

name: Hydroxyplumbopyrochlore
mindat_formula_note: Also (previously) given as (Pb,Ca)<sub>2-x</sub>(Nb,Ti,Ta)<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub>(OH) (x = ~0.5)
description_short:
The OH- and Pb-dominant member of the group.

First find was made in 1992 on Khaldzan Buragtag massif, Altai Mts, Hovd Aimag (Khovd Aimag), Mongolia.
Approved in 2020, with the type locality being the Jabal Sayid peralkaline granitic complex, Saudi ...
tlform: pseudomorphoses after unknown tabular PbNb-mineral-II in complex pseudomorphoses after tetragonal PbNb-silicate-I; from the abstract: euhedral octahedra, slightly rhombic dodecahedra and cubes, or their combination, with crystal sizes in the 0.01-0.06 mm
occurrence: pegmatite of alkaline granites
other: Raman spectroscopy: OH bands present, water bands missing
type_specimen_store: mineralogical collections of the Geological Museum of China, no. 16 Yangrou Hutong, Xisi, Beijing 100031, People's Republic of China, catalogue number M13239

name: Arsenquatrandorite
description_short:
A lillianite homologue.

Compare quatrandorite.

Chemically similar to, i.a., montpelvouxite, barikaite, jasrouxite, parasterryite, and polloneite.
aboutname: Named for being an As-bearing derivative of quatrandorite.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Department of Materials Engineering and Physics, University of Salzburg, Salzburg, Austria, specimen number 15011

name: Balićžunićite
description_short: Known as a synthetic phase (balićžunićite corresponds to the low-temperature stable form of Bi2O(SO4)2, known as alpha form). Chemically the most simple Bi sulfate mineral known; similar to leguernite and Unnamed (Bi Oxysulphate). The only other known ...
tlform: elongated (along [100]) prisms, ca. ~50 x max. 200 μm
occurrence: high-temperature (600<sup>o</sup>C) fumarole (sublimate)
aboutname: Honours Tonci Balić-Žunić (born 1952), Professor of Mineralogy at the Natural History Museum of the University of Copenhagen.  He made important contributions in crystal-structure determination from single-crystal and powder techniques and the theoretical crystal-chemistry of minerals. He discovered/codiscovered several volcanic sublimates including kudriavite, mutnovskyite, eldfellite, heklaite, jakobssonite, leonardsenite and oskarssonite.
morphology: Prismatic and elongated crystals (∼50 μm across and up to 200 μm long).
opticalcomments: optical parameters not measured; n value is calculated
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the C.L. Garavelli Museum, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra e Geoambientali, Università degli studi di bari Aldo Moro, Italy, sample number 17/nm
commentdense: not measured

name: Engelhauptite
description_short: Structurally related to volborthite, and can be considered as its analogue resulting from the replacement of H2O molecules by the equal amounts of K+ and Cl− ions (Pekov et al 2015).
tlform: Spherulites (up to 0.2 mm in diameter) and bunches consisting of rough spindle-shaped crystals. The crystals are up to 0.12 mm long and up to 0.04 mm thick.
occurrence: In cavities in nepheline basalts.
colour: Yellow-brown to brown, typically with an olive green hue
aboutname: Named after the German amateur mineralogist and mineral collector Bernd Engelhaupt (born 1946), who found the mineral.
morphology: Spherulites (up to 0.2 mm in diameter) and bunches consisting of rough spindle-shaped crystals elongated parallel to [0001].
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4309/1
commenthard: Could not be measured because of the very small size of individual grains and the porosity of the aggregates.
commentdense: Could not be measured because of the very small size of individual grains and the porosity of the aggregates.

name: Minjiangite
description_short: Chemically related to loomisite, that may be treated as its monohydrate counterpart. Both are beryllophosphates. Topologically similar to the structure of dmisteinbergite. The natural analogue of synthetic BaBe2(PO4)2. Not a true analogue but chemical ...
tlform: Found in fractures of montebrasite
occurrence: Granite pegmatite
aboutname: Named by C. Rao, F. Hatert, R.C. Wang, X.P. Gu, F. Dal Bo, and C.W. Dong in 2015 for the Minjiang River, located near the Nanping pegmatite type locality.
morphology: Subhedral to euhedral white crystals from 5 to 200 μm long.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the collections of the Geological Museum of China, Xisi, Beijing, People’s Republic of China, catalogue number M11842

name: Yurmarinite
description_short: Isotypic with several synthetic compounds.
tlform: Well-shaped, equant crystals,  up to 0.3 mm in size, their clusters up to 0.5 mm and thin, interrupted crystal crusts up to 3 mm × 3 mm on volcanic scoria.
occurrence: Sublimates
colour: Pale green or pale yellowish green to colourless
aboutname: Named in honor of Yuri Borisovich Marin (Юрий Борисович Марин) (b. 2 August 1939, Leningrad, USSR), Russian mineralogist, petrologist and specialist in studies of ore deposits. He was awarded the 2016 A. E. Fersman Prize and is a past president of the Russian Mineralogical Society.
morphology: Well-shaped, equant crystals showing {101}, {011}, {100}, {110} and {001}.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4389/1

name: Falottaite
description_short: Dehydrates slowly (over several months) under ambient conditions to form the dihydrate lindbergite (Gröbner & Nikoleizig, 2009; Graeser & Gabriel, 2016). The originally colourless and transparent crystals turn white and opaque during the dehydration pr...
tlform: Well formed colorless ship-like crystals up to 1 × 0.5 mm, on quartz crystals.
occurrence: Alpine metamorphism of manganese ores. Then, presumably reaction of humus and oxalic acids (from plants) with those manganese minerals.
aboutname: Named for the type locality, Falotta mine, Switzerland.
morphology: Elongated along c and flattened on b with main forms {010}, {100}, and {101} modified by minor {210} and {10.1.10}.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Natural History Museum Basel, Basel, Switzerland, specimen number S69
specdispm: Without protection, crystals become milky white and opaque in a few months, dehydrating into lindbergite.

name: Arsiccioite
description_short:
Unique elements combination. 

Structure details: (1) framework of (Hg,Ag)-centered tetrahedra (1 M1 + 2 M2); (2) channels || [001] wiht TlS6 and (As,Sb)S3 disymmetric polyhedra.

Derived from routhierite according to the substitution M1Cu+ + M2Hg2...
tlform: As anhedral grains scattered in microcrystalline baryte
occurrence: Baryte-pyrite-iron oxide ore deposit
aboutname: The name is for the type locality, Monte Arsiccio mine, Apuan Alps, Tuscany, Italy
morphology: Anhedral grains
opticalinternal: weak and deep red in colour
opticalanisotropism: weak grey to bluish rotation tints
type_specimen_store:
1) Museo di Storia Naturale, Universita` di Pisa, Via Roma 79, Calci (Pisa), Italy, catalogue number 19659.
2) Museo di Storia Naturale, Universita` degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy, catalogue (# 3132/I).

name: Nickeltsumcorite
mindat_formula_note: May be Fe<sup>3+</sup>-free but contain minor Co instead.
description_short: The Ni analogue of tsumcorite and cobalttsumcorite. Also the Pb analogue of nickellotharmeyerite. Forms a series with the latter.
tlform: (1) coarse radial spherulites or dense concentric nodules, up to 0.15 mm in diameter, forming open-work aggregates and interrupted crusts, up to 3 × 5 mm (and up to 0.2 mm thick); (2) bunches or hemispherical clusters of crude individuals and separate, im
occurrence: oxidation zone of a hydrothermal orebody
colour: Yellow, brownish-yellow, light brown or brown
aboutname: Named as the Ni analogue of tsumcorite and cobalttsumcorite.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4391/1.

name: Zvyaginite
tlform: Rectangular or irregular shaped lamellae up to 0.1 × 1 × 2 cm in size.
occurrence: Hydrothermally altered peralkaline pegmatite.
cleavage: Perfect {001}. Also two directions of distinct cleavage, which are nearly perpendicular to each other and to {001}.
colour: Colourless, pearly-white, yellowish-brownish, pale pink or lilac-pink
opticalextinction: Y and Z lie in the ab plane.
aboutname: Named in honor of Boris Borisovich Zvyagin (Борис Борисович Звя́гин) (14 April 1921, Nevel, Vitebsk, Russia - 18 September 2002, Moscow, Russia), crystallographer, crystal chemist and physicist at IGEM. He was a specialist in the field of electron diffraction methods.
morphology: Rectangular or irregularly shaped lamellae flattened on [001].
type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum of Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow.
commentluster: Nacreous on crystal faces and greasy on broken surface

name: Calcinaksite
tlform: Clusters of colourless to light-grey subhedral prismatic crystals
occurrence: A xenolith of metamorphosed carbonate-rich rock in an alkaline magma
cleavage: perfect on {001} and less perfect on {010}
aboutname: Calcinaksite is named for the chemical composition and by analogy to the related minerals manaksite and fenaksite.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4419/1

name: Itsiite
mindat_formula_note: may also be given as Ba<sub>2</sub>Ca(BSi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>2</sub>
description_short: Structurally related to hyalotekite and kapitsaite-(Y). The B2[] (or B2-vacancy-) analogue of hyalotekite.
tlform: As intergrowths of tetragonal plates up to 1 mm across. Crystals of Itsiite are commonly heavily included with cerchiaraite-(Fe)
occurrence: Ba-rich skarn deposit associated with a quartz monzonite. Itsiite found in low temperature, late-stage veins
colour: Colorless and light blue to medium greenish-blue
aboutname: Itsiite is named for the Itsi Mountain Range, a spectacular, glaciated, multi-peaked massif within the Selwyn Mountains proper. “Itsi” means “wind” in the language of the Kaska, a First Nations people of the area.
other: Slowly decompose in concentrated HCl (about 1 h) and are unreactive in concentrated H2SO4 (days).
morphology: Tetragonal plates flattened on {001} and exhibit the forms {001}, {101}, and {112}; ; the forms {101} and {112} are generally striated.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, Los Angeles, California, USA, catalogue number 64072
commentdense: Could not be measured because the crystals are generally heavily included with cerchiaraite-(Fe)

name: Oxo-magnesio-hastingsite
mindat_formula_note:
Oxo-magnesio-hastingsite is defined as an amphibole with 
<sup>w</sup>O > 1 apfu
<sup>z</sup>Ti<0.5 apfu , (i.e x<0.5) and 
A position: Na dominant
C<sup>2+</sup> position: Mg dominant
C<sup>3+</sup> position: Fe dominant

The Mindat formula acknowledges  the important role of the M<sup>2+</sup>(OH)<sub>2</sub> ->TiO<sub>2</sub> substitution that is necessary to form w(O)-dominant amphiboles. The Mindat formula is close to the empirical formula of the type specimen.
tlform: Occurs as megacrysts up to 12 cm in size. All samples are single crystals, rounded, do not show any crystal faces, and they are characterized by a smooth (‘‘melted’’) surface.
occurrence: The mineral occurs as megacrysts up to 12 cm in size in crystal-rich tuff.
aboutname:
Name derived from hastingsite based on guidelines from Hawthorne et al. (2012): Nomenclature of the amphibole supergroup.
Originally IMA proposed name: Ferrikaersutite (proposal 2011-035CNMNC Newsletter No. 10, 2011), but changed to oxo-magnesiohastingsite, to be consistent with the new amphibole nomenclature (CNMNC Newsletter No. 16, 2013).
morphology: Single crystals, rounded, and not showing any crystal faces.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Z: dark brown, Y: brown, X: light brown
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Museum, Department of Mineralogy, St Petersburg State University, St Petersburg, Russia, catalogue number 1/19465.
ima_history: Redefined IMA 2012 amphibole nomenclature report( Hawthorne et al., 2012)

name: Torrecillasite
description_short: The Cl analogue of synthetic NaAs4O6Br. Structurally related to gajardoite (but different crystal system). Compare lucabindiite and russoite.
tlform: As a secondary alteration phase forming , thin prisms up to 0.4 mm long in jack-straw aggregates, as very thin fibres in puff balls and as massive intergrowths of needles.
aboutname: Named after the Torrecillas mine, Chile, the type locality.
other: Very slowly soluble in H2O, slowly soluble in dilute HCl and rapidly soluble in concentrated HCl.
morphology: Thin prisms elongated on [100] with diamond-shaped cross-section and irregular terminations.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 64079, 64080, 64081 and 64082

name: Maruyamaite
description_short:
The first IMA-approved K member of the tourmaline group, found in high-pressure rocks. Related to oxy-dravite, of which it is the K analogue.

See also UM2000-64-SiO:BFeHKMg (another K-dominant group member).

Supposed to originate near the peak pr...
tlform: Anhedral to euhedral grains up to 2 mm across, embedded in a matrix of anhedral quartz and K-feldspar. May contain inclusions of microdiamonds.
occurrence: Ultrahigh-pressure quartzofeldspathic gneisses
aboutname: Named in honor of Shigenori Maruyama (24 December 1949, Tokushima, Japan), professor at the Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan. He "led the project that unraveled the mechanism of continental subduction and exhumation (from a depth greater than 120 km) of the Kokchetav massif of northern Kazakhstan, and discovered the diamond-bearing UHP rocks that contain the new K-dominant tourmaline."
morphology: Anhedral to euhedral grains up to 2 mm across
opticalpleochorismdesc: O = darkish brown, E = pale brown
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the National Museum of Nature and Science, Tsukuba, Japan, registered number NSMMF15696

name: Geschieberite
description_short: Known synthetic analogue.  A secondary alteration phase after uraninite.
tlform: Crystalline aggregates of bright green colour.
aboutname: The mineral is named for one of the most important ore veins in Jáchymov – the Geschieber vein.
other: Slightly soluble in cold H2O.
morphology: Aggregates composed of multiply intergrown prismatic crystals elongated on [001].  Forms observed are {010} and {001}.
uv: Strong yellowish-green fluorescence under both shortwave and longwave UV.
type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4537/1.

name: Pharmazincite
description_short: Known synthetic analogue.
tlform: Prismatic to acicular crystals up to 1 mm long and up to 0.03 mm
occurrence: Fumarole, temperature at the time of collecting 360–380°C
aboutname: Named for the Greek φάρμăκου "pharmakou" for "poison or drug" in allusion to the arsenic content, and also for containing zinc.
morphology: Prismatic to acicular crystals up to 1 mm long and up to 0.03 mm thick typically combined in near-parallel, radial or chaotic intergrowths, open-work aggregates or crusts up to 2 mm across.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4539/1

name: Znamenskyite
description_short: Known synthetic analogue.
tlform: Druse-like  aggregates of elongated slender plates to 0.4 mm long and 0.05 mm across, usually striated along elongation and easily split to needles.  Box-shaped skeletal crystals are also  ommon.
occurrence: High temperature fumarole  600–700 degrees C
aboutname: Named in honor of Vladimir Sergeevich Znamensky (Владимир Сергеевич Знаменский) (1939–2002), Russian geologist at IGEM who studied the geology and mineral deposits of the Kurile Islands. He was among first to conduct mineralogical research at the Kurdiavy volcano.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Science, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4558/1

name: Kenotobermorite
description_short:
Tobermorite has been redefined by IMA in 2014 as two minerals: tobermorite and kenotobermorite. which form a continuous solid solution series.

Two natural polytypes are known: Kenotobermorite-4O and Kenotobermorite-2M.
aboutname: Its relation to tobermorite. The prefix keno indicates the Ca-free nature of the structural cavities of this member of the tobermorite group.
type_specimen_store: In the mineralogical collection of the Museo di Storia Naturale, Universita` di Pisa, catalogue number 19691.

name: Bulgakite
description_short: Bulgakite is a Ca-analogue of nalivkinite.
occurrence: Fenitized amphibole–quartz–feldspar rock from a glacial morraine
cleavage: Perfect parallel to {001} and moderate parallel to {010}
aboutname: Named after Lev Vasil'evich Bulgak (Лев Васильевич Булгак) (b. 1955), Russian mineralogist, gemologist, and discoverer of several new minerals. He worked at the A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum (1975-2003).
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = intensive reddish brown, Y = light brown, Z = greenish
light brown
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4572/1

name: Shuvalovite
description_short:
New structure type.

Chemically and anion-stoichiometrically similar to but structurally different from krasheninnikovite. May also be compared to cesanite (similar chemistry and anion stoichiometry) and other apatite group species (stoichiometry).
...
tlform: Crusts and open-work groups (up to 1 x 1 cm) on basalt scoria.
occurrence: Found within sublimates.
aboutname: In honour of the Russian nobleman and statesman Ivan Ivanovich Shuvalov (1727–1797), who was an enthusiastic patron of the sciences, arts and literature, and one of the founders of the Moscow University in 1755.
morphology: Coarse lamellae or tablets, [100] flattening, rectangular, octagonal or irregular up to 0.05 x 0.7 x 0.9 mm; in aggregates.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4549/1.

name: Tululite
description_short: Tululite belongs to a group of compounds with the general formula Ca14MT15O35+x (0 ≤ x ≤ 1), and is a new structure type.
tlform: In thin clusters as irregular grains with indented outlines (20–100 μm in size), having typical open-work textures
occurrence: In medium-temperature (800–850 °C) combustion metamorphic (CM) spurrite-fluorellestadite marbles
aboutname: The name was chosen after the geographical name Tulul Al Hammam (Arabic for Pigeon Hills) located in the northern Siwaqa area, where the mineral was found.
other: Dissolves in 1.5 % HCl
morphology: Irregular grains
type_specimen_store: Type materialis deposited in the collections of the Central Siberian Geological Museum of the V.S. Sobolev Institute of Geology and Mineralogy, 3 Ac. Koptyuga Avenue, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia, catalogue number VII-91/1

name: Vanderheydenite
description_short: New structure type.
tlform: Aggregates of colourless crystals up to 0.5 mm across in voids of a sphalerite–galena matrix
occurrence: Sulfide in gneiss
aboutname: Named in honor of Arnold van der Heyden (b. 1959, Melbourne, Australia) who worked as a mine geologist at Broken Hill for the former Minerals Mining and Metallurgy Ltd from December 1985 until June 1991, "in recognition of his contribution to the understanding of the secondary mineralogy of the Broken Hill ore body by the systematic collecting of specimens from the oxidized zone."
morphology: Pseudohexagonal blades up to 0.4 mm in length, flattened on {100} and exhibiting the forms {100}, {010}, and {021}.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the South Australian Museum, Adelaide, South Australia, Australia, registration number G32512
commentdense: Calculated density is 3.12 g/cm-3 from the empirical formula and 3.06 g/cm-3 from the ideal formula.

name: Addibischoffite
description_short:
The Al analogue of beckettite and warkite.

Chemically similar to brownmillerite, dmitryivanovite, grossite, hibonite, and krotite.

A new refractory phase formed in the solar nebula, most likely as a result of crystallization from an 16O-rich Ca, ...
tlform: Found in the core of a Ca-Al-rich inclusion (CAI) in the Acfer 214 CH3 carbonaceous chondrite
occurrence: CH3 carbonaceous chondrite
aboutname: Name in honor of Addi Bischoff (b. 4 April 1955, Werdohl, Germany), cosmochemist at University of Münster, Germany, for his many contributions to research on mineralogy of carbonaceous chondrites, including CAIs in CH chondrites.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the G.J. Wasserburg Meteorite Collection (section Acfer 214-1580) of the Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California 91125, USA

name: Gatewayite
description_short: Related to vanarsite and packratite. The other polyoxometalate from the same site is, e.g., kegginite.
tlform: Blades up to 0.5 mm long in divergent inter-growths.  Also as crude prisms, up to 1 mm long, with rounded faces and as composite crystals consisting of subparallel inter-growths of narrow prisms up to 2 mm long.
occurrence: On montroseite- and corvusite-bearing sandstone. Oxidation of montroseite-corvusite assemblage in a moist environment.
