aboutname: Named for the Gateway mining district that includes the type locality.  Gateway is also the nearest town to the Packrat mine.
other: Insoluble in room-temperature H2O; easily soluble in room-temperature dilute HCl.
morphology: Blades, more or less flattened on {101} and elongated on [010].
opticalpleochorismdesc: X pale olive green, Y medium greenish blue, Z dark greenish blue; X < < Y < Z
opticalcomments: Y = b, X^a ≈ 30° in obtuse β
type_specimen_store: Co-type material is deposited in the collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, Los Angeles, California, USA, catalogue numbers 64513, 64514, 65555 and 65559

name: Cryptochalcite
description_short:
New structure type. The K (or K2-) analogue of cesiodymite.

Visually indistinguishable from cesiodymite.
tlform: Coarse tabular or prismatic crystals or grains up to 0.3 mm
occurrence: Fumarole
aboutname: Named from Greek κρυπτóς, concealed, and χαλκóς, copper.  The name was selected because the species was found in association with other visually similar green copper oxysulfates, hence the name cryptochalcite means “concealed among other copper minerals.”
morphology: Coarse tabular or prismatic crystals; grains up to 0.3 mm.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4675/1

name: Alexkhomyakovite
tlform: Equant grains up to 0.2 mm, veinlets up to 3 cm long and up to 1 mm thick and fine-grained aggregates replacing delhayelite
occurrence: peralkaline pegmatite
aboutname: Named in honour of Alexander Petrovich Khomyakov (Александр Петрович Хомяков) (2 April 1933, Moscow, Russia – 12 October 2012, Moscow, Russia), mineralogist and Director of the Institute of Mineralogy, Geochemistry and Crystal Chemistry of Rare Elements.  He described more than 100 new minerals.  The minerals <m>khomyakovite</m> and <m>manganokhomyakovite</m> are also named for him.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4696/1

name: Andychristyite
description_short:
New structure type. Chemically related to housleyite, khinite, paratimrosite, and timroseite. Structurally related to bairdite, eckhardite, paratimroseite, and timroseite.

Crystal structure details: stair-step-like hcp layers built of TeO6 and CuO6 ...
tlform: bluish-green tablets flattened on {001}, up to about 50 μm across
occurrence: a secondary oxidation zone mineral and is presumed to have formed by oxidation of earlier formed tellurides, chalcopyrite, and galena
aboutname: The mineral is named for Andrew (Andy) Gregor Christy (b. 1963) a Welsh–Australian mineralogist, petrologist, geochemist, and solid-state chemist, for his contributions to mineralogy, in particular, for the description of the new minerals (kapundaite, mössbauerite, mojaveite, bluebellite and favreauite), his work on minerals of the sapphirine supergroup, pyrochlore supergroup and hydrotalcite supergroup, and more recently for helping advance the knowledge of the crystal chemistry of tellurium.
other: decompose rapidly in dilute HCl at room temperature.
morphology: tabular crystals to ca. 50 μm, forming sub-parallel aggregates
opticalpleochorismdesc: very pale blue green to medium blue green
opticalcomments: 2V large,  Gladstone–Dale relationship predicts an average index of refraction of 2.011.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Mineral Sciences Department, Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, California 90007, USA, catalogue number 65577

name: Żabińskiite
description_short:
The second Ta-bearing silicate mineral after holtite. Isostructural with triclinic modification of titanite, see triclinic titanite . Identical to titanite and other titanite group species in terms of bond topology. 

Titanites associated with żabińs...
tlform: Compositionally inhomogeneous aggregates (with titanite and K-mica), ca. 120 × 70 μm in size
occurrence: Variscan granitic pegmatite; formed together with (Al,Ta,Nb)-bearing titanites, from Ca-contaminated fluxed melts or early hydrothermal fluids, during increasing a(Ti) & a(Nb) but decreasing a(Ta), almost paralelly to polycrase-(Y) and euxenite-(Y)
aboutname: Named in honor of Witold Stanisław Żabiński (17 July 1929, Kraków, Poland – 15 January 2007), one of the most eminent Polish mineralogists, one of the founders of the Mineralogical Society of Poland and its President in 1980–1994.  He was also a professor, head of the Department of Mineralogy and Geochemistry, and Director of the Institute of Geology and Mineral Materials WGP AGH.  He authored over 200 papers and textbooks.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Mineralogical Museum of the University of Wrocław (Faculty of Earth Science and Environmental Management, Institute of Geological Sciences, Mineralogical Museum, 50-205 Wrocław, Cybulskiego 30, Poland),
commentdense: Strong dependence on composition

name: Hexacelsian
description_short:
High-temperature polymorph.
Known as a synthetic compound (disordered β-BaAl^2Si^2O^8).
tlform: In oval polymineralic inclusions in paralava, as elongate crystals <10 μm thick
occurrence: In veins of paralava cutting gehlenite-flamite hornfels located in the Gurim Anticline in the Negev Desert, Israel.
aboutname: The name given to the mineral matches the historical name used for the synthetic material. It is the hexagonal polymorph of celsian.  The root name honors Anders Celsius (27 November 1701 Uppsala, Sweden - 25 April 1744 Uppsala, Sweden], astronomer, physicist, and naturalist. He had the Astronomical Observatory built and he experimented with standardizing temperature measurements. The Celsius temperature scale is also named in his honor.
ir: Raman spectrum of hexacelsian is similar to the one of the synthetic disordered β-BaAl2Si2O8.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Mineralogical Museum, University of Wrocław, Cybulskiego 30, 50-205 Wrocław, Poland, catalogue number MMUWr II-20465

name: Maneckiite
description_short: The M(3)Mn analogue of wicksite. The element combination (in terms of element dominance) is only shared with 'Mg-Fillowite'.
tlform: Subhedral or anhedral crystals, ca. 150 × 150 μm
occurrence: Outer zone of phosphate nodules in a pegmatite; results from Na- and Ca-metasomatism from a high-temperature fluid with parallel presence of Al ions coming from an aluminosilicate  melt occurring in the vicinity
aboutname: After prof. Andrzej Manecki (born 1933 in Cracow, Poland), which work is connected with the AGH University of Science and Technology, a member (Polish representative) of the Cosmomineralogy Commision of the IMA (1974–1988), also the Polish representative in the IMA Comission on New Minerals and Mineral Names in 1988.
other: Gladstone-Dale index: 0.027 ("excellent")
opticalpleochorismdesc: dark green (α), dark blue/green (β), light brown/tan (γ)
type_specimen_store: Cotype material is deposited in the collections of the Mineralogical Museum, University of Wrocław, Cybulskiego 30, 50-205 Wrocław, Poland, catalogue number MMWr IV7674 and MMWr IV7676.

name: Marklite
description_short:
New structure type.

Visually similar to devilline and serpierite.

Chemically similar to georgeite; also to claraite (Zn-bearing) and 'cuproartinite' (Mg-bearing); and to azurite and malachite (basic but without water molecules).
aboutname: Named after Prof. Dr. Gregor Markl,born February 22nd, 1971 in Frankfurt a.M., Germany,mineralogist at the University of Tübingen, Germany, who found the type specimen of marklite, for his numerous studies and books on crustal petrology, geochemistry and specifically on the hydrothermal ore deposits of the Black Forest area (genesis, oxidative alteration, mineralogy and geochemistry).
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of (1) the Eberhard Karls Universität, Tübingen, Germany (catalogue number 3586 T), and (2) the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, Los Angeles, USA (catalogue number 65630)

name: Castellaroite
description_short:
Probably a polymorph of sterlinghillite. Structurally related to metaswitzerite.
A higher hydrate (octahydrate) is manganohörnesite.
tlform: thin blades, flattened on [001], striated and elongated parallel to [100] and exhibiting the forms {110}, {012} and {001}.
occurrence: Secondary arsenate mineral
aboutname: Named in honour of the mineral collector Fabrizio Castellaro who has discovered castellaroite, but also balestraite, <m>cerchiaraite-(Fe)</m> and <m>lavinskyite-1M.</m>
other: easily soluble in dilute HCl at room temperature
morphology: Thin blades, flattened on [001], striated and elongated parallel to [100] and exhibiting the forms {110}, {012} and {001}.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, cataloguenumbers 65603 (holotype - MN) and 65604 (cotype - MN), and the Museo Regionale

name: Péligotite
description_short:
Related to ottohahnite. 

Also chemically similar to fermiite and oppenheimerite; further, lesser similarity with sulfate-hydrosulfates belakovskiite and meisserite, and basic sulfates plášilite and natrozippeite.

Found together with klaprothite a...
tlform: Equant rhombs up to ∼0.5 mm, but usually much smaller. Crystal faces often  concave with rounded edges. Crystals typically occur in subparallel aggregates and drusy intergrowths.
aboutname: To honour Eugène-Melchior Péligot (24 March 1811 in Paris – 15 April 1890 in Paris), French chemist credited for isolation of the first sample of metallic uranium.
other: Easily soluble in RT water; Raman spectrum is given as is similar to that of klaprothite and ottohahnite.
twinning: No twinning observed in type material.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = colourless, Y = light yellowish green, Z = light yellowish green.
uv: Bright bluish-green under both longwave and shortwave ultraviolet light.
type_specimen_store: Cotype material is deposited in the collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 65610, 65614, 65615 and 65616, and the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences.
commentdense: Calculated value is based on empirical formula

name: Ottohahnite
description_short:
Related to klaprothite and péligotite. 

Also chemically related to fermiite and oppenheimerite. 

Further relation to sulfate-hydrosulfates belakovskiite and meisserite, and to basic salts plášilite and natrozippeite.

Found together with péligo...
tlform: Equant crystals up to ∼0.1 mm in maximum dimension
aboutname: To honour Otto Hahn (8 March 1879 – 28 July 1968), German chemist known as the "father of nuclear chemistry", conducting research on radioactivity and radiochemistry, Nobel Prize winner in the field of Chemistry in 1944 as the discoverer of nuclear fission.
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X=light yellowish green, Y=colourless, Z=yellowish
green; Y<X<Z
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, USA (catalogue numbers 65610, 65611, 65614 and 65617), and the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russsian Academy of Sciences,Russia,registration number 4782/1

name: Verbierite
mindat_formula_note: Ideal formula (by analogy to byrudite): Cr<sub>2</sub><sup>3+</sup>Ti(BeO<sub>4</sub>)O<sub>2</sub>.
description_short: The Cr analogue of byrudite. Unique combination of elements. Second Be-Cr mineral after mariinskite.
aboutname: Named for the community of Verbier, Switzerland, near the type locality.
type_specimen_store: Collections of the Musée Cantonal de Géologie, Lausanne, Switzerland (registration nos. MGL 93100 and MGL 93101)

name: Zincoberaunite
mindat_formula_note: More detailed version: ZnFe<sup>3+</sup><sub>2</sub>Fe<sup>3+</sup><sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(OH)<sub>5</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O
description_short: The Zn analogue of ferroberaunite. Chemistry similar to phosphophyllite, plimerite, steinmetzite, zinclipscombite and wilhelmgümbelite.

otheroccurrence: Granite pegmatite
morphology:
Radial or randomly oriented aggregates of flexible fibers up to 1.5 mm long and up to 3 μm thick.

Elongated along [010] and somewhat flattened on {100}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = Y (pale beige) < Z (light orange-brown)
type_specimen_store: Collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (registration number 4828/1)
commentdense: Could not be measured; calculated given for holotype, cotype gave 2.94
commentcrystal: Cell parameters given for the holotype at room temperature

name: Cardite
mindat_formula_note: The original material is slightly Cd-bearing.
description_short:
New structure type (the structure is determined). The first zinc arsenate-hydroxyarsenate mineral. Chemically similar to koritnigite (another Zn hydroxyarsenate).

Crystal structure is based on sheets edge-sharing octahedra; details:
- there is one ...
tlform: Radiating sprays comprising acicular crystals, up to 0.09 mm in length .
occurrence: Oxidation zone. In a matrix of highly weathered, coarse-grained sulfides.
colour: White to pinkish white and pale tan
aboutname: Named in honor of George William Card (7 January 1865, Pill, Somerset, England – 2 June 1943, Collaroy, New South Wales, Australia), petrologist and mineralogist with the Geological Survey of New South Wales and Curator at the Mining Museum, Sydney from 1893 to 1927. He published a series of mineralogical notes in which a number of Broken Hill minerals were described.
opticalcomments: One refractive index, 1.678(4), was found using immersion liquids.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the South Australian Museum, Adelaide, Australia (registration number G34301)

name: Cabvinite
description_short: New structure type. The first purely thorium-halogenide, thorium-fluoride, and actinide halogenide mineral to date.
tlform: White square prismatic crystals, up to 100 μm in length and 40 μm in thickness
occurrence: Mo-Bi ore deposit
aboutname: The name honours two Italian mineral collectors, Fernando Caboni (b. 1941) and Antonello Vinci (b. 1944), for their contribution to the knowledge of the Su Seinargiu mineralogy. Cabvinite is a portmanteau after their surnames, CABoni and VINci.
morphology: Square prismatic crystals, up to 100 μm in length and 40 μm in thickness.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Museo di Storia Naturale, Università di Pisa, Via Roma 79, Calci (Pisa), Italy, catalogue number 19711

name: Arsenatrotitanite
description_short: Tilasite-durangite group. The chemistry is not unique - see braithwaiteite.
tlform: Prismatic, tabular, lamellar or acicular crystals up to 0.3×0.8×2 mm. They are separated or combined in open-work aggregates up to 2 mm across or interrupted crusts up to 2x5 mm2 in area and up to 0.3  mm thick.
occurrence: Fumarole
colour: brownish red, pale pinkish-reddish, almost colourless
aboutname: For being the Na and As analogue of titanite
morphology: Prismatic, tabular or lamellar, wedge-shaped
opticalpleochorismdesc: Z (bright pink to, in thicker grains, carmin red) > Y(very pale pinkish to almost colourless) ≥ X(colourless)
type_specimen_store: Collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (registration number 4852/1)

name: Argentoliveingite
description_short:
A silver-bearing sulphosalt belonging to the sartorite group (Sartorite homologous series).
Closely related to liveingite and "rathite-IV".

The mineral is noticeable for its very large unit-cell parameter c.
aboutname:
Named for the presence of silver and its relationship to <m>liveingite</m>.

Liveingite itself was named by Richard Harrison Solly and H. Jackson in 1901 in honor of George Downing Liveing (14 August 1827, Nayland, Suffolk, UK - 26 December 1924), Professor of Chemistry, University of Cambridge, England.
opticalpleochorismdesc: pleochroism is not discernible
opticalinternal: Red internal reflections are seen on thin edges or at grain boundaries
opticalanisotropism: Moderate in dark grey – neutral rotation tints
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of (1) the Naturhistorisches Museum Wien, Austria (catalogue number N 9868), and (2) the Natural History Museum Basel, Switzerland (specimen number S83)
commentcrystal: The c axis is double the b axis of liveingite and represents the longest unit-cell parameter for a known natural sulphosalt

name: Calamaite
description_short: New structure type. Third Ti-dominant sulfate mineral after alcaparrosaite and innelite; second purely sulfate Ti-rich mineral.
tlform: Acicular to hair-like crystals to 2 mm, in bunches or radial spherulitic clusters to 4 mm across.  As prismatic crystals and cross-like twins.
occurrence: oxidation zone of a pyrite orebody at a sulfate mine
aboutname: Named after the Calama commune and the Calama city, Chile.
morphology: Acicular to 0.01 × 2 mm; rarely prismatic to 1 × 1 × 3 mm
type_specimen_store: The Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4883/1

name: Kuliginite
description_short:
A iron-magnesium hydroxychloride mineral. Fe2+ analog of tondiite. 
New structure type. Kuliginite has a spinel-like crystal structure which is also typical for several copper minerals of the atacamite group.

Chemically resembles iowaite, which how...
tlform: Green prismatic-bipyramidal crystals (0.2–0.5 mm) and fills cavities and veins in several units of kimberlites
occurrence: Kimberlites
colour: Dark green, green, greenish-yellow with impurities
aboutname: Named in honor of Sergey Semyonovich Kuligin (Сергей Семёнович Кулигин) (07.09.1961 - 12.05.2014), Russian geologist and researcher with the Sobolev Institute of Geology and Mineralogy (IGM, Novosibirsk, Russia), who studied and searched for kimberlites, xenoliths, and alluvial diamond deposits all over Yakutia and Canada.
other:
Slowly dissolves in H2O at room temperature.
Oxidizes very quickly upon interaction with atmospheric water even at ambient humidity.
morphology: Prismatic-bipyramidal crystals.
type_specimen_store: Collections of the Central Siberian Geological Museum, V.S. Sobolev Institute of Geology and Mineralogy, 3 Ac. Koptyuga Avenue, Novosibirsk, 630090 Russia (catalogue number VI-53/1)

name: Roymillerite
description_short:
Chemically quite similar to britvinite; structurally related to britvinite and molybdophyllite. The combination of anion types in roymillerite is unique.

Crystal structure details:
- pyrophyllite-type TOT-modules of the Mg9(OH)8[(Si,Al)10O28] compo...
tlform: Platy single-crystal grains, up to 1.5 x 0.3 mm in size
aboutname: Named for dr Roy McG. Miller for his contributions to the knowledge of the Namibia's geology
morphology: Platy single-crystal grains
ir: Confirms the presence of the britvinite-type tetrahedral sheets, and the complex anions given in the formula
type_specimen_store: Cotype: mineralogical collections of the Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm, Sweden (catalogue # 20080176)

name: Davidsmithite
description_short:
Ca-analogue of nepheline, to which it is related by the heterovalent substitution of 2K+ by [Ca2+☐]. Davidsmithite completes the compositional space of the nepheline-structure group by providing a new root-composition, (Ca☐)2Na6Al8Si8O32. 

Refered t...
occurrence: In strongly retrograded layers in formerly jadeite-rich zones in a kyanite eclogite pod.
aboutname: Named in honor of David Christopher Smith (b. 1946), mineralogist, petrologist, and Emeritus Professor at the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle (MNHN), Paris, France. He co-authored descriptions of the minerals nyböite, lisetite, taramite and ferro-taramite. As a petrologist, he pioneered the recognition of the new sub-discipline of UHPM (Ultra High Pressure Metamorphism). He also created the COSEM collection (Collection David Smith des Eclogites du Monde) at the MNHN.
type_specimen_store: Collections of the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France (thin section MNHN215-001)

name: Kampelite
description_short: A Ba-Mg-Sc phosphate, an unique combination of elements (2025).
tlform: Found in a void within the calcite-magnetite phoscorite (enriched in hydroxylapatite and Sc-rich baddeleyite) inside the axial zone of the Kovdor phoscorite-carbonatite pipe. It  appears as radiated aggregates (up to 1.5 mm in diameter) of platy crystals
occurrence: The Kovdor phoscorite-carbonatite complex.
aboutname: Named in honour of Russian mining engineer Felix Borisovich Kampel’ (b. 1935) for his contribution to the development of technologies of mining and processing of complex magnetite-apatite-baddeleyite ores of the Kovdor deposit.
other: Dissolves easily in 10% cold HCl.
morphology: Radiated aggregates (up to 1.5 mm in diameter) of platy crystals.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Mineralogical museum, St. Petersburg State University, Russia, catalogue No. 1/19660.

name: Shinkolobweite
description_short:
New structure type. Another mineral with confirmed U5+ after richetite, wyartite, and nollmotzite.

Crystal structure details:

* uranyl oxide-hydroxide sheets with β-U3O8 topology;
* they are commensurately modulated with (3 + 1)  ordering due to...

aboutname: For the type locality

name: Pansnerite
description_short: Forms a solid-solution series with the isotypic mineral ozerovaite, ideally KNa2Al3(AsO4)4. Chemically similar to achyrophanite and also somewhat to edtollite.

aboutname: Named in honour of Lavrentiy Ivanovich Pansner (also Johann Heinrich Lorenz Pansner, Панснер Лаврентий Иванович) (3 May 1777 Arnstadt, Thuringia (now Germany) – 22 March 1851, Arnstadt, Thuringia), mineralogist and geographer who spent his working years in Russia.  He was the first Director of the St. Petersburg (Imperial) Mineralogical Society and was head of the Department of Mineralogy, St. Petersburg University.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, catalogue numbers 4964/1

name: Protoenstatite

name: Schmidite
description_short: Related to schoonerite and wilhelmgümbelite.
tlform: Radiating sprays of orange-brown to copper-red laths.
occurrence: Zoned granitic phosphate pegmatite. On/near altered phosphophyllite in a corroded triphylite nodule.
aboutname: Named in honor of Hans Schmid (1925, Wackersdorf, Bavaria - 2013, Greece), mining engineer and geologist. He discovered a very large lithium phosphate occurrence in the Hagendorf Süd pegmatite that was mined from 1950-1955, producing ~1600 tons of lithium ore.  In 1955 he published a seminal paper on the textures and structures of pegmatites of the Oberpfälzer.
morphology: Laths, elongated on [100] and flattened on {010}
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = light brown, Y = medium brown, Z = dark red brown
Absorption X < Y < Z
opticalcomments: Orientation X = b, Y = c, Z = a
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Museums Victoria, Melbourne, Australia, registration number M53810 and M53811

name: Triazolite
description_short:
Chemically and structurally related to chanabayaite, for which it is a precursor phase. The second natural (mineral) triazolate to be discovered.

It is a metalorganic ammine complex in which 1,2,4-triazolate anion and ammonia molecule are ligands co...
tlform: Deep blue prismatic crystals up to 0.1 mm × 0.15 mm × 0.75 mm and their radial aggregates up to 1.5 mm across.
occurrence: In the contact zone between altered guano and the host rock, a gabbro consisting of amphibole, plagioclase minor clinochlore and accessory chalcopyrite.
cleavage: Perfect on (001) and imperfect on (100) and (010).
aboutname: Named for the presence of 1,2,4-triazolate anions.
other: Triazolite dissolves in dilute HCl and HNO3 without gas evolution. It is insoluble in water, but crystals of triazolite become dull after exposure to warm water. Heating in a closed tube gives a white sublimate of NH4Cl. Melting is accompanied by the release of water and an additional portion of sublimate. Stronger heating results in reduction to metallic Cu.
morphology: Prismatic crystals (up to 0.1 mm × 0.15 mm × 0.75 mm); Radial aggregates. Forms include pinacoids {001}, {010} and {100} and prisms {hk0} or {0kl}.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Distinct, Y = violet, X = Z = greenish-blue.
ir: IR spectrum shows the presence of 1,2,4-triazolate anion and ammonia and water molecules.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 5037/1.
commentbreak: The fracture across the perfect cleavage plane is uneven.

name: Martinandresite
mindat_formula_note: Chemical-analytical data of type material is close to that of the end-member composition.
description_short: Chemically related to harmotome.
tlform: Tan-coloured blocky crystals up to 8 mm, aggregates up to 6 cm across, and cruciform twins up to 3.5 mm.
cleavage: Presumably on (010) and in a direction across (010).
aboutname: Named in honor of Martin Andres (b. 1965), from Glis, Switzerland. He discovered the famous armenite locality of Wasenalp; the type locality of this mineral.
morphology: Blocky. Major form is {010}; the subordinate forms are {100} and {001}.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Geological Museum of Lausanne, Switzerland, catalogue number is MGL 093284
commentdense: Measured by floatation in heavy liquids
commentcolor: light green due to microscopic chlorite inclusions

name: Zoharite
description_short:
The Fe analogue of owensite. Also Ba analogue of gmalimite.


The primary structural units of these minerals are M8S14 clusters, composed of MS4 tetrahedra surrounding a central MS6 octahedron. The M site is occupied by transition metals such as Fe,...

occurrence: gehlenite–wollastonite paralava with pyrrhotite nodules located in the Hatrurim pyrometamorphic complex, Negev Desert, Israel
aboutname: Mt. Zohar, which overtops the Hatrurim Basin
opticalcolour: gray color with an olive tinge
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Leninskiy pr., 18/k2, 115162 Moscow, Russia, catalogue number 4959/1

name: Magnesioleydetite
description_short:
The Mg analogue of leydetite. Compare magnesiozippeite.

Known as a synthetic compound.
tlform: Irregular aggregates (to ~0.5 mm) of blades (to ~0.2 mm).
occurrence: Efflorescent mineral, formed in the humid underground workings of an abandoned mine in a sandstone-hosted uranium deposit.
aboutname: Named for being the Mg analogue of leydetite, with Mg replacing Fe2+.  The root name is for Jean-Claude Leydet (18 April 1961 - 21 November 2018), an amateur mineralogist from Brest (France) and collector of uranium minerals.
other: Easily soluble in room-temperature H2O and dehydrates readily even at moderate relative humidity.
morphology: Blades are flattened on {001}.
twinning: Commonly twinned by 180° rotation on <f>[1_10]</f> as indicated by single-crystal XRD. The composition plane appears to be <mi>{11_1}</mi>.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 66647, 66648, 66649 and 66650 (cotypes).
commentdense: Density could not be measured.

name: Dekatriasartorite
description_short: Sartorite homologous series.
aboutname:
Named for it relationship to <m>sartorite</m> and for dekatria- (Greek for thirteen) for the thirteen-fold superstructure of a 4.2 Å subcell.

Sartorite itself was named after Wolfgang Sartorius von Waltershausen (17 December 1809, Göttingen, Germany - 16 March 1876, Göttingen, Germany), Professor of Mineralogy, University of Göttingen, Germany. He was the first to describe the mineral.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the reference collections of the Naturhistorisches Museum Wien, Burgring 7, A-1010 Wien, Austria, catalogue number N 9863

name: Pampaloite
description_short: New structure type. Compare aurostibite and UM1996-36-Sb:Au.
tlform: anhedral grains (up to about 20 μm) intergrown with gold, frohbergite and altaite.
aboutname: Named for the Pampalo gold mine, Finland, the type locality.
other: All studied pampaloite grains exhibit Raman vibrational modes in the range 60–180 cm−1. Average peak positions are 71, 108, 125, 147 and 159 cm−1.
opticalpleochorismdesc: slightly pinkish-brown to slightly bluish white
opticalanisotropism: strong blue to light brown rotation tints
type_specimen_store: Department of Earth Sciences of the Natural History Museum, London, UK, catalogue No BM 2017, 16.

name: Ferrierite-NH4
description_short: Zeolite supergroup. First (or second - after ammonioleucite) natural ammonium-dominant zeolite.
tlform: Radiating aggregates up to 2 mm across consisting of thin flattened prismatic crystals.
occurrence: Coal deposit.
aboutname: Ammonium dominant member of ferrierite group.
morphology: Very thin flattened prismatic crystals elongated along (001).
uv: Intense bluish white fluorescence under both short- (254 nm) and long-wave (366 nm) UV.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 5120/1.

name: Nöggerathite-(Ce)
description_short:
Nöggerathite-(Ce) is an analogue of zirconolite-3O, ideally CaZrTi2O7, with Nb dominant over Ti in one of two octahedrally coordinated sites and REE dominant over Ca in the eight-fold coordinated site.
Closely related to Stefanweissite and laachite.
tlform: Nöggerathite-(Ce) forms isolated, prismatic crystals in cavities in a sanidinite ejectum
occurrence: Sanidinite volcanic ejectum
aboutname: The root name is given in memory of Johann Jacob Nöggerath (Bonn 10 October 1788 – Bonn 13 September 1877), a prominent German mineralogist and geologist. Since 1818 J. J. Nöggerath was professor of mineralogy and geology at the University of Bonn. Among his publications, there is a geological description of the Laach Lake paleovolcanic region.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 5123/1
commentdense: Calculated using the empirical formula

name: Belomarinaite
description_short:
Structurally and chemically related to aphthitalite.

Belomarinaite KNaSO4 (space group P3m1, a = 5.6072(3), c = 7.1781(4) Å and Z = 2) has been studied by high-temperature single crystal X-ray diffraction. The K and Na atoms are disordered, and M1(1...
tlform: Arborescent aggregates of tabular crystals. The average size of the aggregates is 0.5–0.7 mm.
occurrence: Fumarole
aboutname: Named in honour of Marina Gennadievna Belousova (Марина Геннадьевна Белоусова) (b. 1960), Russian volcanologist, for her significant contributions to the monitoring of the Tolbachik Fissure eruption.
type_specimen_store: Collections of the Mineralogical Museum, Saint-Petersburg State University, University Emb. 7/9, St. Petersburg 199034 Russia, catalogue number 1/19678

name: Majzlanite
description_short: New structure type. Unique combination of elements.

occurrence: High-temperature (300°C) fumarole.
aboutname: Named in honor of Prof. Dr. Juraj Majzlan, Institute of Geosciences, Friedrich-Schiller University, a specialist in the field of thermodynamics of secondary (mainly sulfate) minerals and supergene ore weathering.
other: Soluble in warm water
type_specimen_store: Collections of the Mineralogical Museum, Department of Mineralogy, St Petersburg State University, St Petersburg, Russia, specimen number 1/19690

name: Eddavidite
description_short:
Unique combination of elements. The Br analogue of murdochite with which it forms a solid solution.
Only way to distinguish eddavidite and murdochite is by chemical analysis.
The type locality of eddavidite is the 5th level of the Southwest mine in t...
tlform: eddavidite is only known as domains within mixed eddavidite–murdochite crystals.
occurrence: oxidized zones in copper/lead mines.
aboutname: honors Dr. Edward Emil “Ed” David (January 25, 1925 Wilmington, North Carolina – February 13, 2017, Bedminster, New Jersey). Dr. David sought to make science more relevant and accessible to the public; he received much recognition in the scientific, technical, and professional communities. Dr. David worked at Bell Labs from 1950 to 1970, eventually rising to Executive Director of Communications Systems Research. U.S. President Nixon tapped Dr. David to serve as National Science Advisor from 1970 to 1973. He also sat on NASA’s Advisory Council and served as the U.S. Representative to the NATO Science Committee. In 1973, Dr. David went to work in the private sector, later becoming President of Exxon Research Corporation in 1977, from which he retired in 1986.
morphology: Forms {100} and {111}; the habit grades from simple cubic through cuboctahedral to unmodified octahedral.

name: Proxidecagonite
description_short: New structure type.
tlform: 20 µm anhedral grain.
occurrence: Meteoritic fragments of the Khatyrka meteorite.
aboutname: The name is derived from “periodic approximant of decagonite”; from the truncated Latin word proxǐmus followed by the name of the quasicrystalline mineral decagonite.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Museo di Storia Naturale – Sezione di Mineralogia e Litologia, Università di Firenze, Via La Pira 4, I-50121 Firenze, Italy, catalogue number 3291/I.

name: Fanfaniite
description_short: Mn analogue of kingsmountite and montgomeryite; Al analogue of zodacite.
tlform: Radial aggregates up to 0.5 mm in diameter of colourless, transparent, thin blades, associated with whiteite-(CaMnMn). At Hagendorf-Süd, the mineral occurs as isolated very thin laths on the surface of fibrous spheroids of kayrobertsonite.

type_specimen_store:
1) Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 66771 (Foote mine holotype) and 66772 (Foote mine cotype)
2) Museum Victoria, Australia

name: Udinaite
description_short: Known synthetic analogue. First anhydrous sodium magnesium vanadate mineral. Chemically comparable to otherwise hydrated and more complex (decavanadate anion) minerals huemulite and lasalite. The V analogue of arsenudinaite.
tlform:
equant tetragonal prismatic–dipyramidal crystals up to 0.15 mm, aggregates up to 1 cm and interrupted crusts
up to 2 × 2 cm2

type_specimen_store: collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninskiy Prospekt 18-2, Moscow 119071, Russia, registration number 5237/1

name: Prachařite

cleavage: good cleavage parallel to {0001} and a distinct cleavage parallel to <mi>{10_10}</mi>.

type_specimen_store: Cotype material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum, Vienna, Austria, catalogue no. O 357, the National Museum, Prague, Czech Republic, catalogue no. P1P 15/2018, and the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County

name: Armellinoite-(Ce)
description_short: Tiny pale yellow to brown-yellow, pseudo-octahedral crystals embedded in associated quartz +/- hematite +/- muscovite +/- cryptomelane matrix.
tlform: pseudo-octahedral crystal embedded in matrix; easily confused with titanite.
occurrence: Fe–Mn ore in metaquartzites
colour: pale yellow to brown–yellow; also honey-yellow, canary-yellow, yellow-greenish, yellow-brown
aboutname:
The name honours Gianluca Armellino (born 1962) of Millesimo (Liguria, Italy). Mr. Armellino is an avid and sophisticated researcher and systematic collector specializing in the minerals of Liguria and other specific localities, with specimens only personally collected. 
He is the discoverer of this new species and the co-discoverer of poppiite, cortesognoite, molinelloite and piccoliite. Mr. Armellino is also the one who first found more than 80 mineral species new for Italian regions. Some of them [arsenogoyazite, bariopharmacoalumite, barnesite, brandtite, calderónite, čechite, duttonite, franciscanite, gageite, hummerite, natrodufrénite, norrishite, pyrochroite, roscoelite, schröckingerite, talmessite, and wakefieldite-(Y)] represented the first discovery for Italy or Europe.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Museo delle Collezioni di Mineralogia, Gemmologia, Petrologia e Giacimentologia, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra “A. Desio”, Università di Milano, catalogue number MCMGPG-H2018-003

name: Laverovite

occurrence: In a nepheline syenite pegmatite
aboutname: Named by E. Sokolova, M.C. Day, F.C. Hawthorne e.a. in honor of Nikolai Pavlovich Laverov [12 January 1930 - 27 November 2016], Soviet and Russian geologist, geochemist, academic, vice-President of the USSR Academy of Sciences (1988-1991) and RAS (1991-2013).
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = yellowish brown, Y = brownish yellow, Z = pale yellow
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, accession number M57542.

name: Magnesiobermanite
description_short:
The Mg analogue of bermanite.
Magnesiobermanite is structurally related to ercitite, mengeite and coralloite.

Magnesiobermanite was recently (2018) found on a specimen collected from the White Rock No.2 quarry in the 1960s.
tlform: as twinned, bladed to tabular crystals, up to 0.3 mm long, forming aggregates up to 1.2 mm across. Magnesiobermanite occurs in cavities in a matrix comprising quartz and hydrothermally altered dark brown to black dufrénite-group minerals (dufrénite–natrodufrénite–gayite–bimbowrieite) that have nearly completely replaced earlier triplite.
occurrence: granitic pegmatite
cleavage:
Good on {100} (mentioned in abstract)
Perfect on {001} (mentioned in article)
aboutname: The magnesium analogue of <m>bermanite</m>, in which Mg replaces Mn<sup>2+</sup> in the bermanite structure, hence the name.
morphology: The observed crystal forms are {010}, {100}, {001}, {101} and {111}
opticalpleochorismdesc:
X = pale orange red, Y = pale yellow, Z = dark
orange red; Z > X>Y.
uv: does not fluoresce under ultraviolet light
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the South Australian Museum, North Terrace, Adelaide, South Australia, Australia, registration number G34762
commentdense: measured with a sodium polytungstate and water mixture

name: Davidbrownite-(NH4)
description_short: New structure type. Unique combination of elements (compare rowleyite, though). Chemically somewhat similar to thebaite-(NH4), relianceite-(NH4) and dendoraite-(K): other oxalate-phosphate minerals. The first vanadium-bearing oxalate mineral (compare r...
tlform: Needles or narrow blades up to about 0.2 mm in length
occurrence: Bat-guano-related, post-mining assemblage
aboutname: Named in honor of I. David Brown (b. 11 April 1932, Edgeware, Middlesex, UK) British-Canadian crystallographer and professor at McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada. Dr. Brown is well known for developing Bond-Valence Theory used by mineralogical crystallographers worldwide.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = pale blue, Y = nearly colorless, Z = lightblue; Y<X<Z
type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 66951, 66955 and 66959 (cotypes)

name: Isselite
mindat_formula_note: Contains probably essential minor Ni, Co and Zn.
description_short:
The Cu analogue of guarinoite in terms of chemistry and chemically related to montetrisaite and redgillite.

"The actual role of Ni in stabilising this phase deserves further study" (Biagioni  et al., 2020).
tlform: Sprays of blue acicular crystals, up to 0.1 mm long.
aboutname: Dedicated to Arturo Issel (11 April 1842, Genoa, Italy – 27 November 1922, Genoa, Italy) for his pioneering work on the geology, palaeontology and mineralogy of Italy, with a special reference to Liguria (Issel, 1892). He was professor of Geology and Mineralogy at the University of Genoa beginning in 1866 and Director of the Institute of Geology and the Geological Museum until 1917.
morphology: Acicular crystals, striated parallel to [100] and tabular on {001}. Observed forms are {001}, {010}, {103} and <mi>{10_3}</mi>.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X = light blue, Y = blue, Z = blue
opticalcomments:
Optical orientation: X = b, Y = c and Z = a.
Absorption: X << Z < Y.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Museo di Storia Naturale, Università di Pisa, Via Roma 79, Calci (Pisa, Italy), catalogue number 19904 (holotype), the Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, dell’Ambiente e della Vita (DISTAV), Università di Genova, Corso Europa 26, Genova, Italy, catalogue number MO484 (holotype); the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue number 67195 (cotype).
commentdense: Calculated value based on empirical formula.

name: Aluminosugilite
tlform: Aggregates of small prismatic and/or granular crystals up to 1 mm in length
occurrence: Manganiferous metacherts
aboutname: Named for being the aluminum analogue of sugilite.  There is a technical discussion in Nagashima et al. (2020) on why the modifier was made a prefix rather than a suffix.
other: Insoluble in HCl, HNO3 and H2SO4
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the National Museum of Nature and Science, Tsukuba, Japan, specimen numbers NSMMF- 16503
commentcrystal: Cell parameters for single crystal X-ray.  Powder gave slightly smaller dimensions.

name: Caseyite
mindat_formula_note: previously given as [(V<sup>5+</sup>O<sub>2</sub>)Al<sub>7.5</sub>(OH)<sub>15</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>13</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[H<sub>2</sub>V<sup>4+</sup>V<sup>5+</sup><sub>9</sub>O<sub>28</sub>][V<sup>5+</sup><sub>10</sub>O<sub>28</sub>]<sub>2</sub>·90H<sub>2</sub>O
description_short: New structure type. It is related to structures based on flat-Al13 polyoxometalate cation.
tlform: Tapering needles or blades
aboutname: Named in honor of William H. Casey (b. 1955, San Francisco, California, USA), chemistry professor in the University of California Davis College of Letters and Science, for his work on vanadium compounds and polyoxometalates. He has made major contributions in the fields of aqueous geochemistry and inorganic solution chemistry, and has received multiple awards and medals.
type_specimen_store: In the collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, Los Angeles, USA, catalogue numbers 73526 (Packrat – holotype), 73527 and 73528 (Packrat –cotypes),73529 (West Sunday – cotype), 73530 and 73531 (Burro – cotypes)

name: Ferroefremovite
description_short: Fe analogue of efremovite. Chemically related to sabieite and pyracmonite.
tlform: Cubic crystals up to 0.1 mm across.
occurrence: Fumarole
aboutname: Named for being the Fe analogue of efremovite.
type_specimen_store: collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninskiy Prospekt 18-2, Moscow 119071, Russia, registration number 5368/1

name: Monchetundraite
description_short:
Known synthetic analogue. 
Chemically related to proxitwelvefoldite.
tlform: Euhedral grains (up to about 20 μm) intergrown with kotulskite and pentlandite.
occurrence: In metasomatically altered sulfide-bearing orthopyroxenite, formed in post-magmatic conditions, at temperatures of below 500 °C. Occurs in polymineralic PGM intergrowths and more often as two or three phase grains in secondary silicates.
aboutname: The mineral is named for the locality, the Monchetundra intrusion, Kola Peninsula, Russia and for Mt. Monchetundra.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Rotation tints of pale blue, orange and olive green
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Department of Earth Sciences, Natural History Museum, London SW7 5BD, UK, catalogue number BM2019,2

name: Liudongshengite
description_short:
Unique combination of elements (first natural Zn-Cr carbonate). 
The Cr analogue of zaccagnaite.

The ZnCr analogue of fougèrite. Third Zn-Cr mineral after zincochromite and hemihedrite.
tlform: Micaceous aggregates or hexagonal platy crystals (up to 0.10 × 0.10 × 0.01 mm).
aboutname: Named in honour of Liu Dongsheng (刘东生) (22 November 1917, Liaoning Province, China – 6 March 2008), also known as Tung-sheng Liu.  He was a Chinese geologist and paleontologist at the Institute of Geology and Geophysics, Chinese Academy of Sciences.  He was known as the "Father of Loess", loess being one of his specialties.
type_specimen_store: In the collections of the University of Arizona Mineral Museum, 601 E University Blvd, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA, catalogue # 22043 (holotype), and the RRUFF Project, deposition # R180016 (cotype)

name: Kodamaite
description_short: Similar to ellingsenite.
tlform: Develops in spherulitic aggregates up to ∼2 mm across, comprising thin, platy to bladed crystals, with individual crystals averaging <0.05 × 0.5 mm.
colour: tan to creamy-yellow to white in color, less often being colorless, light or dark green, or white.
opticalcomments: An average nD = 1.507 (for λ = 590 nm) was calculated using data from the refined crystal structure.
uv: pronounced bluish-white fluorescence under both long- and medium-wave ultraviolet radiation, much less so under short-wave radiation
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Canadian Museum of Nature, P.O. Box 3443, Station D, Ottawa, Ontario K1P 6P4, Canada, catalogue number CMNMC 87262.

name: Argentotetrahedrite-(Zn)
tlform: At Kremnica, as anhedral grains up to 0.1 mm in size in association with ‘argentotennantite-(Fe)’. At Lengenbach, as domains of tristetrahedrals crystal of tetrahedrite-(Zn), up to 1 mm in size. At Zvěstov, as irregular aggregates, up to 0.2 mm in size, partly rimmed by kenoargentotetrahedrite-(Fe).
aboutname: For the relationship to other members of the tetrahedrite group.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Department of Mineralogy and Petrology, National Museum in Prague, Cirkusová 1740, 19300 Praha 9, Czech Republic, catalogue number P1P 51/2020 (Kremnica), and the Museo di Storia Naturale, Università di Pisa, Via Roma 79, Calci (PI), catalogue numbers 19922 (Kremnica) and 19923 (Lengenbach).
commentcrystal: a = 10.5505(10) Å (Kremnica); a = 10.5155(13) Å (Lengenbach); and a = 10.5663(12) Å (Zvěstov).

name: Drechslerite
description_short:
Related to lorándite (TlAsS2, monoclinic) and weissbergite (TlSbS2, triclinic). 

Sb and As are ordered in the crystal structure.

Also compare jankovićite, gillulyite, pierrotite; and gungerite.
aboutname:
Named after Dr. Eva Drechsler (1947, Vienna, Austria - ), freelance journalist, publicist, and editor; member of the Basel section of the Swiss Association of Prospectors, Mineral, and Fossil Collectors (Schweizerischen Verein der Strahler, Mineralien- und Fossiliensammler - SVSMF); vice-president of the international collectors' club Friends of Lengenbach (Verein Freunde Lengenbach - VFL); co-founding president and secretary/board member of the Lengenbach Research Association (Forschungsgemeinschaft Lengenbach - FGL).

Source: https://www.zobodat.at/pdf/OOE-GEO_35_0003-0005.pdf
type_specimen_store: mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum Vienna, Burgring 7, 1010 Wien, Austria, specimen number O1181 (holotype), and the Natural History Museum Basel, Augustinergasse 2, 4051 Basel, Switzerland, specimen number S209 (cotype)

name: Suenoite
type_specimen_store: mineralogical collections of the Museo di Storia Naturale, Università di Pisa, Via Roma 79, Calci (Pisa), Italy, catalogue number 19891

name: Grammatikopoulosite
description_short:
Structurally related to florenskyite. Unique combination of elements.

Grammatikopoulosite was discovered in a heavy mineral concentrate.
tlform: Forms small crystals (from 5 μm up to about 80 μm) and occurs as isolated grains.
occurrence: Ophiolite complex.
aboutname: For Tassos Grammatikopoulos (b. 1966), a geoscientist at the SGS Canada Inc., for his contribution to the investigation of economic mineralogy and mineral deposits of Greece.
opticalpleochorismdesc: Measurable but not discernible pleochroism.
opticalanisotropism: Slight anisotropy with indeterminate rotation tints.
type_specimen_store: Holotype material is deposited in the Mineralogical Collection of the Museo di Storia Naturale, Università di Pisa, Via Roma 79, Calci (Pisa, Italy), under catalogue number 19,911.

name: Kesebolite-(Ce)
description_short: New structure type. Unique combination of elements.
tlform: Short-prismatic crystals along c, with lengthwise striation; euhedral crystals up to 3 mm
aboutname: The name is for the discovery locality, the Kesebol mine, in the Åmål municipality, Västra Götaland, Sweden
opticalpleochorismdesc: brownish-yellow shades
opticalcomments: Refractive indices were not determined directly; the calculated value is 1.740 from Gladstone–Dale constants
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Department of Geosciences, Swedish Museum of Natural History, Box 50007, 10405 Stockholm, Sweden, collection number GEO-NRM #20100343

name: Chukochenite
mindat_formula_note: Formula also given as (Li0.5Al0.5)Al2O4, so show spinel-type structure.
description_short:
The first lithium aluminate mineral. Compare, e.g., diaoyudaoite.

New structure type.

A cubic polymorph is known as a synthetic compound and has applications in several fields.
tlform: euhedral crystals to 200 microns
occurrence: hydrothermal veins in skarn
aboutname: Named in honor of Chu Kochen (also written Chu Coching, 竺可桢) (7 March 1890, Shangyu, Shaoxing, Zhejiang, China – 7 February 1974, Beijing, China), meteorologist and geologist. He was president of Zhejiang University (1936-1949) and one of the founders of earth sciences in China. In 1949 he became vice president of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.
type_specimen_store: mineralogical collections of the Geological Museum of China, no. 15 Yangrou Hutong, Xisi, Beijing 100031, People's Republic of China, catalogue number M13818

name: Johanngeorgenstadtite
description_short:
One of the most simple nickel arsenate minerals (compare xanthiosite, aerugite, petewilliamsite, honzaite; and annabergite).

Most likely belongs to the alluaudite group within the supergroup.
tlform: Sugary aggregates of pink-orange irregular, rounded grains or short prisms that are about 70 µm in diameter
occurrence: Apparently secondary in origin and most likely formed from the breakdown of primary nickeline under dry (low relative humidity, RH) and oxidizing (high oxygen fugacity) conditions.
cleavage: Probably {010}, {110} and <mi>{1_10}</mi> by analogy with other alluaudite-group minerals
aboutname: Named for the town of Johanngeorgenstadt, Germany, the type locality.
other: In dilute HCl at room temperature it rpidly loses colour (indicating decomposition) and slowly dissolves
morphology: No discernible forms.
opticalpleochorismdesc: X violet, Y light olive, Z yellow; X>Y>Z
opticalcomments: Optical orientation could not be determined
type_specimen_store: mineralogical collections of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, New York City, NY 10024, USA, catalogue number 17956
commenthard: Based on the difficulty in breaking small grains

name: Tomamaeite
description_short:
The Pt analogue of auricupride.

Concerning the material from Urals: the genesis is post-magmatic, related to transformation of primary PGE minerals, probably during serpentinization of ultramafics.
tlform: As inclusions in a platinum-group mineral (PGM) grain. Anhedral particle with a size of less than 20 µm.
occurrence: Placers derived from peridotites.
aboutname: Named for the type locality, Tomamae town, Hokkaido, Japan. The meaning of Tomamae is ‘the place where there are many of Toma’s flowers (Corydalis ambigua)’ in the language of the Ainu, the indigenous people of Hokkaido.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the National Museum of Nature and Science, Tsukuba, Japan, specimen number NSM-47328.
commentdense: Could not be measured.

name: Plumboperloffite
description_short: The Pb analogue of perloffite and strontioperloffite; the Mn2+-analogue of plumbojohntomaite; and the Mn2+Fe3+-analogue of nigelcookite. Unique combination of elements. The first member of the group with Pb dominant at the X site.
tlform: The mineral forms intergrowths of subparallel, thin tabular to bladed crystals. Individual crystals are up to 40 µm in length.
occurrence: pegmatites belong to the beryl-columbite phosphate-rare element type in the classification of Černý
aboutname: The name is for the relationship to perloffite with Pb dominating the X site.
opticaldispersion: Dispersion is apparently strong, based on extinction colours and the orientation is Y = b.
opticalpleochorismdesc: The pleochroism in shades of yellow brown is X < Z < Y.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the South Australian Museum, North Terrace, Adelaide, South Australia 5000, Australia, registration number G34868
commenthard: based on the hardness of other bjarebyite-group minerals.

name: Shakhdaraite-(Y)
description_short:
Isostructural with samarskite-(Y), its Fe(III) analogue.

Structurally related to brookite. Unique combination of elements (at the upload).

Associates with an unnamed Sc-Nb oxide, among others.

Structure details:
* [6]M(1) = Nb
* [6]M(2) = Sc...
tlform: (1) grains, 10-150 μm in size; (2) a single, well-shaped crystal, 200 μm in length.
occurrence: Miarolitic granitic pegmatite.
aboutname: Named after the Shakhdara river valley, Tajikistan where the type locality occurs.
type_specimen_store: collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninskiy Prospekt 18-2, Moscow 119071, Russia, registration number 5569/1.

name: Panskyite
description_short: The Pb analogue of thalhammerite. Unique combination elements (at the approval time). Isostructural with thalhammerite.
tlform: Forms tiny anhedral grains (0.5-10 μm in size) in the interstices of rock-forming silicates, often forming tiny inclusions in base-metal sulfides and complex intergrowths with other platinum group minerals.
occurrence: Platinum group element mineralization
aboutname: Named for the Pansky massif of the Fedorova–Pana layered intrusion in the Kola Peninsula, Russia, the type-locality.
opticalanisotropism: Distinct, brown to grey rotation tints
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Department of Earth Sciences, Natural History Museum, London SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, catalogue number BM2020,2.
commentdense: Calculated from empirical formula

name: Argentopearceite
description_short:
As the studied mineral from the Mikulov and Moldava deposits has As>Sb and the
structural position "Cu" of the B module layer dominated by Ag, it has been named argentopearceite to indicate the Ag-dominant analog of pearceite. Moreover, as it exhibits...
tlform: occurs as tabular (pseudo)hexagonal crystals up to 0.8 mm (Mikulov) and 3 mm (Moldava), their groups and aggregates up to 1 cm
occurrence: The ore district is represented by the quartz dominated As-Ag-Pb veins, located in gneisses of the crystalline mantle of Fláje granite massif.
aboutname: Ag-dominant analog of pearceite.
twinning: a four-fold twin due to metric merohedry twinning
opticalanisotropism: moderate with weak greenish and green-blue tints
type_specimen_store:
Type material is deposited in the collections of the Department of Mineralogy and Petrology, National Museum in Prague, Cirkusová 1740, 19300 Prague 9, Czech Republic, catalogue number P1P 35/2020 
The studied material (cotypes) from the Moldava deposit is deposited in the same collection under the catalog numbers P1N
64.380, P1N 66.881 and P1N 90.431.
commentcolor: tarnished to brown tints

name: Torryweiserite
description_short:
The Rh-dominant analogue of kuvaevite (IMA no. 2020-043). The Ni-dominant analogue of ferrotorryweiserite.

Co-described with oberthürite.

Together with the latter suggested to be formed at ca. 500 °C, under moderate fS2 conditions, via "ordering ...
aboutname: Named in honor of Dr. Thorolf (‘Torry') W. Weiser, a well-known researcher on platinum-group minerals, notably those found in deposits related to the Great Dyke, Zimbabwe and the Bushveld complex, South Africa.
opticalcolour: slightly bluish (compared to oberthürite), gray (compared to chalcopyrite, zvyagintsevite, and keithconnite), pale creamy brown (compared to bornite and coldwellite)
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Canadian Museum of Nature, 1740 Pink Road, Gatineau, Quebec, Canada, catalogue numbers 87179 and 87181

name: Kenoargentotennantite-(Fe)
description_short:
As analogue of Kenoargentotetrahedrite-(Fe).
Closely related to Argentotennantite-(Fe).
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Museo di Storia Naturale, Università di Pisa, Via Roma 79, Calci (PI), catalogue number 19920

name: Hydroxymcglassonite-(K)
description_short: The first Sr-dominant group member. Sr analogue of hydroxyapophyllite-(K).
tlform: Granular, with grain size <0.05 mm.
aboutname: Named in honor of Mr. James Archer "Jim" McGlasson (b. 18 April 1948, Houston, Texas, USA), exploration geologist and mineral collector. He served as the president of the Tucson Gem and Mineral Society, and on the board of directors of the Friends of Mineralogy.  The prefix and suffix follow the naming convention for other apophyllite-group species.
other:
Insoluble in water and HCl.
Raman data similar to that of hydroxylapophyllite-(K) (especially in the O-H stretching region).
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the University of Arizona Mineral Museum, 1601 E University Blvd, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA, catalogue number 22691 (holotype), and the RRUFF Project, deposition number R200004 (cotype).

name: Haitaite-(La)
description_short: Probably the U analogue of davidite-(La) and La analogue of cleusonite, mapiquiroite and mianningite. Unique combination of (species-defining) elements.
tlform: Black opaque centimeter-sized aggregates.
occurrence: In the external contact zone between Neoproterozoic (∼800 Ma) alkali feldspar granite and Mesoproterozoic (∼1700 Ma) mica schist.
aboutname: Named after the Haita Village in the Miyi County of Sichuan Province, China, where the mineral was discovered. The suffix/modifier follows the Levinson rule for species with essential REE indicating, in this case, predominant lanthanum.
opticalcomments: Reflectivity between 22.5% and 16.42% in the 400–700 nm band.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Geological Museum of China, No. 16 Yangrou Hutong, Xisi, Beijing 100031, People's Republic of China, catalogue number M13859.

name: Shagamite
description_short: The Fe3+-analogue of kahlenbergite. Chemically similar to jeppeite. Also compare priderite and 'K-ferrite'.
type_specimen_store: Collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninskiy Prospekt 18-2, Moscow 119071, Russia, registration number 5634/1

name: Dendoraite-(NH4)
description_short: New structure type. Unique combination of elements (at the upload time). Chemically somewhat similar to thebaite-(NH4) (that lacks sodium as a major cation and is also less hydrated). Also compare davidbrownite-(NH4) and relianceite-(K): another two ox...
tlform: Blades, up to ca. 0.1 mm in length.
occurrence: Post-mining assemblage related to bat guano.
aboutname: Named for the Dendora Valley and the Dendora Ranch, which are immediately west of the Rowley mine, Arizona - the type locality.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue number 75275.

name: Lisanite
description_short:
The Ni analogue of anastasenkoite. Chemically close to shasuite. Also chemically somewhat similar to samraite, yakubovichite and cassidyite. 

A representative of the rare group of pyrophosphate minerals; compare, e.g., canaphite, wooldridgeite; 'pyr...
aboutname: after the Lisan Peninsula that is in the vicinity of the type locality (?)
type_specimen_store: collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninskiy Prospekt 18-2, Moscow 119071, Russia, registration number 5629/1

name: Nabateaite
description_short: Known synthetic analogue. One of the most simple iron phosphate minerals (compare, e.g., rodolicoite, heterosite and graftonite). Chemically somewhat similar to other Fe-rich pyrophosphates (diphosphates): anastasenkoite and a chemical counterpart, tho...
type_specimen_store: collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninskiy Prospekt 18-2, Moscow 119071, Russia, registration number 5684/1

name: Kiryuite
description_short:
The Mn analogue of viitaniemiite. Chemically somewhat similar to (more complex) griphite.

Co-described with gunmaite.
tlform: Kiryuite mainly occurs as a white powder in the cracks of triplite crystals and along the triplite-quartz boundary. Kiryuite occasionally forms porous plate-like aggregates up to 5 mm in size, while the grain size is several micrometers.
aboutname: For the type locality
type_specimen_store: mineralogical collections of the National Museum of Nature and Science, Amakubo 4-1-1, Tsukuba, Japan, specimen no. NSM-M48724

name: Radvaniceite
description_short:
The most simple natural Ge sulfide. Known synthetic analogue. Compare, e.g., 'Unnamed (Ge-As Sulphide)' and argyrodite.

Natural analogue of synthetic, monoclinic, low-temperature β-GeS2. It represents GeS4 tetrahedra, that share corners to form 4-te...
tlform: Occurs as aggregates resembling cotton tufts up to 5 mm in size; they are composed of acicular crystals (somewhat resembling bent wires) up to fibres about 1–5 μm thick and up to 3 mm in length; also irregular grains, 10–50 μm, in aggregates.
occurrence: A burning coal mine dump.
aboutname: Named after the type locality.
opticalpleochorismdesc: From colourless to pale greenish yellow.
type_specimen_store: Type material deposition: mineralogical collections of the Department of Mineralogy and Petrology, National Museum in Prague, Cirkusová 1740, Praha 9, Czech Republic, catalogue no. P1P 9/2021.

name: Pseudopomite
description_short:
Closely related to pomite. The two are the first mineral species with carbonate-bearing heteropolyvanadate anions. Not a unique chemical combination (compare hanjiangite).


As pomite, the structure is based on [V4+xV5+15-xO37(CO3)](1+x)– heteropoly...
tlform: striated prisms and blades, up to ca. 1 mm in size
type_specimen_store: mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue no. 76155

name: Redmondite
description_short:
New structure type. Chemically somewhat comparable to beaverite-(Zn) and raygrantite. 

Somewhat chemically similar to but structurally distinct from hydroredmondite. These two are the first zinc thiosulfate minerals to date. 

Also compare sulfato...
tlform: transparent equant rhombs to about 1 mm
occurrence: oxidation of lead mine
aboutname: The name redmondite is based on the mine name.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 76160, 76161 and 76162.

name: Bixbyite-(Fe)
description_short:
The Fe analogue of bixbyite-(Mn); newly defined in December 2021 (IMA 21-H). Belongs to the Bixbyite Series.

As opposite to most other minerals/crystals, bixbyite(s) show diffuse scattering of a lower symmetry than the parent (general) symmetry (of ...
ima_history: Newly defined in December 2021 (IMA 21-H) - Miyawaki et al. 2022.

name: Sulfatoredmondite
description_short: Structurally related to redmondite and hydroredmondite.
tlform: wedge-shaped crystals to about 2 mm
occurrence: lead mine
aboutname: The name sulfatoredmondite is based on the chemical and structural similarity to <m>redmondite</m>, [Pb<sub>8</sub>O<sub>2</sub>Zn(OH)<sub>6</sub>](S<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>, which is instead a thiosulfate mineral.

description_short: The As analogue of veszelyite. Chemically related to, i.a., goldhillite, sabelliite, theisite, veselovskýite, and somewhat to zincolivenite.
tlform: radiating aggregates or as individual lamellar crystals
occurrence: supergene mineral from a sediment-hosted Zn–Pb–Cu deposit

name: Bounahasite
description_short:
New structure type.

First mixed-valency purely Cu chloride mineral (however, compare, e.g., allochalcoselite). Also compare nantokite - another natural Cu(I) chloride.

Chemically somewhat resembles minerals of the atacamite group.
tlform: Tiny pseudo-hexagonal plates combined in loose clusters.
occurrence: Oxidation zone.
aboutname: Named after the Bou Nahas Mine, Morocco, the type locality.
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Canadian Museum of Nature, PO Box 3443, Station “D”, Ottawa, Ontario K1P 6P4, Canada, catalogue number CMNMC 89874.

name: Scandio-winchite
description_short:
The first Sc-dominant member of the group. Unique combination of elements (at the upload time). The M2Sc analogue of winchite.

Most likely of a metasomatic genesis, related to metamorphic evolution of the country rocks & alteration of blackwall chlo...
tlform: (1) isolated subhedral crystal (~20 x 8 microns); (2) three polycrystalline aggregates (max. 50 microns across) comprising needle-like crystals with dominant {110} face
occurrence: a pegmatite, also known as "leucocratic zone", cutting serpentinites in a zone also rich in rodingites
aboutname: scandium analogue of winchite (named amphibole)
opticalcomments: optical parameters could not be determined

name: Ixiolite-(Mn2+)
description_short: The Ta analogue of nioboixiolite-(Mn2+).
commentcrystal: Nickel et al. (1963) give space group Pcan (non-standard setting) and unit-cell parameters a = 5.731, b = 4.742, c = 5.152 Å. Grice et al. (1976) give space group Pbcn (non-standard setting) and the unit-cell parameters a = 4.785, b = 5.758, c = 5.160 Å (used above). Heating usually produces an ordered wodginite-type structure.
ima_history: The old “ixiolite” has been redefined and results now in two distinct mineral species: ixiolite-(Mn2+), with end-member formula (TaMn)O2, and ixiolite-(Fe2+), with end-member formula (TaFe)O2. The type locality for both is Skogsböle, Kimito Island, Finland.

name: Heimite
description_short:
New structure type. Chemically comparable to, i.a., bayldonite and duftite.

The beta angle is almost ideally 90o making the mineral very close to be orthorhombic.
tlform: sprays of lath-like, prismatic crystals that reach up to 450 µm in length and 40 µm in width
occurrence: occurs as a secondary mineral on a remobilized sandstone uranium deposit.
aboutname: Named after Albert Heim (April 12, 1849, Zürich, Switzerland – August 31, 1937, Zürich, Switzerland), Swiss geologist and professor at ETH Zurich. His recognition in 1901 of his initial misinterpretation of the Glarus Alps tectonics, together with his fame, led to the general acceptance of the major Glarus thrust fault and a step forward in the history of orogeny. The type locality of heimite is, together with the Glarus thrust fault, part of the Tectonic Arena Sardona, a UNESCO world heritage site.
other: readily dissolves in hydrochloric acid.
opticalpleochorismdesc: faint green parallel to [100] to bright green parallel to [010].
type_specimen_store: Mineralogical Museum, Leibniz-Institut zur Analyse des Biodiversitätswandels, Grindelallee 48, 20146 Hamburg, Germany, registration number Ro3701
commentcolor: Some, but not all, crystals turn blue under the electron beam of the SEM. On certain specimens, crystals showing both changed and unchanged colours occur closely together. A few specimens were found on the mine dump showing blue-coloured crystals when unearthed.

name: Pohlite
description_short: New structure type.
tlform: Striated blades, up to about 4 mm in length.
occurrence: Polymetallic, quartz-barite vein hosted by porphyritic andesites.
aboutname: Pohlite is named for American economic geologist, Demetrius Pohl (b. 1944). Dr. Pohl received his Ph.D. in geochemistry in 1984 from Stanford University. In the mid-1980s, he was Assistant Curator of economic geology at the American Museum of Natural History.
other: Becomes cloudy and very slowly dissolves in room-temperature, dilute HCl.
morphology: Striated blades.
type_specimen_store: Cotype material is deposited in the collections of the American Museum of Natural History, 200 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024, USA, catalogue number 115471, and the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 76251 and 76252.
commentdense: calculated density is 5.838 g·cm-3 for the empirical formula and 5.975 g·cm-3 for the ideal formula.

name: Pendevilleite-(Y)
description_short: New structure type. Unique combination of elements (status: October 2022).
tlform: occurs as extremely thin blades (up to about 0.08–0.10 mm in length and only about 1 μm thick), often forming lichen-like aggregates and crusts
occurrence: hydration–oxidation weathering of uraninite in the presence of solutions with dissolved CO2 that can originate from various sources
colour: whitish or greyish-white, locally pale-bluish white
aboutname: It is named after Jean-Marie Pendeville (1936–2002), a school teacher and an avid mineral lover and collector. He started with mineral collecting in 1967 and expanded it during his 28-year stay in Katanga (Democratic Republic of Congo, DRC). Pendeville had a curiosity for science and a profound gift for writing.
opticalcomments: No optical properties were determined due to the minimal size of the crystals and complicated intergrowths. A mean index of refraction, calculated based on Gladston-Dale equations, is nGD = 1.47.
uv: Pendevilleite-(Y) is non-fluorescent in both SW and LW ultraviolet light.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Musée National d’Histoire Naturelle, Rue Münster 25, Luxembourg 2160, Luxembourg, catalogue number VP230

name: Nioboixiolite-(Mn2+)
description_short:
The Nb-dominant analogue of ixiolite-(Mn2+).

Identification and Analysis
Visual identification or chemical analysis alone are insufficient for identification. Must be differentiated from columbite-(Mn) by structural studies (e.g., X-ray diffraction).

Dr. Libby developed the method of radiocarbon dating (published in 1952) for which he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for 1960.
other: soluble in H2O

name: Lazerckerite
description_short:
Chemically similar to clino-oscarkempffite, izoklakeite, and staročeskéite. Co-described with also chemically (and stoichiometrically) similar holubite.

The structure of lazerckerite contains two Pb sites (Pb1 and Pb2) in bicapped trigonal prismatic...
tlform: replacement rims of earlier Ag–Pb–Bi–Sb minerals and grain aggregates, growing together in aggregates up to 0.6×0.3 mm.
occurrence: origin of the mineral is related to the later Bi mineralization, and we assume the mineral is a replacement product of earlier, Bi-richer lillianite homologues and galena that crystallized from originally low-temperature (ca. 100–250 °C) hydrothermal fluids in the tectonically opened fractures in yet earlier hydrothermal Fe–Cu–Zn–Sn–As base sulfide ore vein fillings
aboutname: The mineral is named after Lazarus Ercker (1528  Annaberg-Buchholz, Germany – 1594 Prague, Czechia), the supreme Royal Bergmeister of the Kingdom of Bohemia (Minister of Mining) and the Master of Prague Mint, a renowned metallurgist, chemist, and mining specialist and the author of the Books on Assaying (original title Beschreibung Allerfürnemisten Mineralischen Ertzt und Berckwercksarten). This work – published in 1574 – was reissued 15 times, translated into four languages, and until the end of the 18th century was used as a principal textbook by all mining universities and Bergakademie in Europe.
opticalpleochorismdesc: grey tints
opticalanisotropism: weak to moderate, with grey to bluish-grey rotation tints.
type_specimen_store: collections of the Department of Mineralogy and Petrology, National Museum, Cirkusová 1740, 19300 Prague 9, Czech Republic, catalogue number P1P 11/2022

name: Macraeite
description_short: The MnMnFe3+(H2O)-analogue of sperlingite. Possibly the Mn analogue of paulkerrite (?). Chemically similar to 'matveevite'.
tlform: equant euhedral crystals with relatively uniform sizes from sub-100 to ∼ 150 µm. Individual crystals have a pseudo-rhombic dodecahedral shape although the crystals are more commonly aggregated and form complex intergrowths with dimensions of up to 0.5 mm.
occurrence: pegmatite formation, is an important locality for secondary phosphate minerals.
aboutname: Colin MacRae (born 1961) for his important contributions to the characterisation of new mineral species using electron microprobe techniques. Since 2010, he has conducted electron microprobe analyses on 40 minerals, all of which were approved as new mineral species. As head of the Microbeam Laboratory at CSIRO Mineral Resources, Clayton, Victoria, Australia, he has been responsible for the development of new techniques that are of benefit to the analysis of highly hydrated, beam-sensitive secondary minerals.
type_specimen_store: collections of (1) the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue number 76293 (holotype), and (2) the Mineralogical State Collection (SNSB), Theresienstrasse 41, 80333 München, Germany, registration number MSM 38050 (cotype)

name: Kvačekite
description_short: The Se analogue of ullmannite. Unique combination of elements (at the upload time).

occurrence: This uranium ore district is an example of shear zone-hosted, late Variscan and post-Variscan hydrothermal mineralisation.
aboutname: Named after Milan Kvaček (13. 2. 1930 - 21. 5. 1993), a Czech mineralogist and the author of the first comprehensive descriptions of selenides from western Moravia. Milan Kvaček is the author of over sixty publications in the fields of mineralogy, chemistry and geochemistry. He also co-operated closely with Zdeněk Johan from BRGM (Orléans) on the description of six new selenides from the Bohemian Massif - bukovite, fischesserite, hakite, permingeatite, petrovicite and sabatierite.
opticalcolour: white with a faint yellowish shade

In accord with Bayliss and Levinson, the mineral is named rundqvistite-(Ce) as Ce is the dominant rare earth element.

name: Cabrerite
description_short:
Cation-ordered intermediate phase between annabergite and hörnesite, with Ni dominant at M1, Mg dominant at M2, and T = As.
Unique combination of elements (at the upload time).

The structure consists of NiO2(H2O)4 octahedra and Mg2O6(H2O)4 edge-sha...
tlform: divergent groups of green blades up to 1 mm long. Blades are elongated and striated parallel to [001],
occurrence: Oxygenated Ni Co arsenides
cleavage: three cleavages: perfect on {010}, fair on {100} and poor on <mi>{_102}</mi>.
aboutname: Dana (1868) used the name "cabrerite" for a Ni-Co-Mg-arsenate mineral from Sierra Cabrera, Almería, Andalusia, Spain, which was described by Ferber (1863) as Wasserhaltige Nickeloxyd Magnesia. Giuseppetti and Tadini (1982) published a crystal structure refinement for a crystal from Lavrion, Greece that they refer to as cabrerite and for which they report the empirical formula (Ni2.2Mg0.7Fe0.1)(AsO4)2·8H2O. Their structure study shows Mg to be almost entirely ordered into the M2 site (M1: Ni0.976Mg0.024; M2: Ni0.696Mg0.304); however, Ni was still dominant in both sites.
other: The mineral dissolves slowly in dilute HCl at room temperature.
type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue number 65733
